column2: A $440,000 spa getaway. A high-priced golf junket in Las Vegas. A hunting trip in England.

New York City schools offered more classes in visual art, music, theater and dance last year than the year before, and more students took advantage of those classes, according to a Department of Education report released on Wednesday.

From our friends at the Bits blog:Tesla Motors said Wednesday that it will lay off employees and delay production of its next battery-powered car. The once-hot electric car start-up also said it was removing Ze'ev Drori as chief executive and appointing co-founder Elon Musk, now the company's chairman, to the post.
New London’s lakes still whisper to tourists, second-home owners and retirees; but about 30 percent of the town’s residents are second-homers.
The Associated Press reports:

Tesla Motors said Wednesday that it will lay off employees and delay production of its next battery-powered car. The once-hot electric car start-up also said it was removing Ze'ev Drori as chief executive and appointing Elon Musk, now the company's chairman, to the post.
IDC, a market research firm, said today that global shipments of personal computers rose 15.8 percent in the third quarter.

In some corners of the city, they have become the equivalent of the guests that wouldn't leave: Salespeople who plant themselves on your sofa until you agree to switch to an alternative energy provider. These aggressive salespeople have given energy service companies, or ESCOs, a bad name, and led thousands of consumers to complain to the Public Service Commission and other state and city agencies.

The federal government's plan to inject $250 billion directly into the nation's banking sector has been met with some mixed reviews since it was formally announced on Monday. Several banking industry analysts have used the phrase "step in the right direction," when referring to the government's plan to rescue the financial system. Nevertheless, most have concluded that it is no panacea for the battered banking sector.

Today is the 50th anniversary of Edward R. Murrow's seminal address about radio and television. In what is now known as the "wires and lights in a box" speech, Mr. Murrow implored the attendees at the Radio and Television News Directors Association convention to make the most of the two electronic media, rather than allowing them to insulate Americans "from the realities of the world in which we live."
It's the bitterest of pills, but I must at long last swallow it.

Alexei Cherepanov was buried today in the Old North Cemetery in Omsk. This emerging star of the local Avangard club and the Rangers' top draft choice in 2007 was not a native of Omsk. He was from a town just outside Barnaul in Southwestern Siberia, more than 400 miles away. But Cherepanov's parents wanted him interred in Omsk.
Bill Niman responds to the first batch of readers' questions about raising animals.

Barack Obama has made a campaign point out of recalling his efforts to increase regulation in the mortgage industry. At the Wall Street Journal, the former Reagan administration offical Peter Wallison thinks the candidate needs a history refresher:

What is the mission of the National Hockey League? Is it to take our money? Well, yes, but there has to be more than that. Is it to take our money in exchange for entertainment involving skaters and goaltenders who are allowed to play their game at its highest level of creativity?
The Key West Literary Seminar blog has a nice memorial up to the influential former Esquire fiction editor Rust Hills. You can find it here.

Bloggers have noticed that the first wine served at the White House state dinner for the Italian Prime Minister Monday night was a Ponzi (from the Willamette Valley, Oregon). What an "apt commentary on the financial crisis," a blogger said. (More on Ponzi schemes here.) The menu follows:
You can get a 0.05 percent interest rate today on four-week Treasury bills. That is roughly half the yield available yesterday, and a sign of another flight to safety above all else.
The sauce for this pantry pasta is a vegetarian take on arrabbiata and amatriciana sauces.

Updated, 7:30 p.m. | An heir to the French fashion house Hermès appeared in federal court on Wednesday afternoon on charges he assaulted the captain of a jetliner en route from Paris to New York, grabbing the pilot's crotch and trying to punch him.

This week's guest blogger is Bonnie Fuller, the C.E.O. of Bonnie Fuller Media. Most recently, Fuller served as vice president and chief editorial director of American Media (Star, Shape, Men's Fitness, Natural Health and Fit Pregnancy) and was previously editor in chief of US Weekly, Glamour, Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire, YM and Flare magazines. E-mail her at info@bonniefuller.com or follow her on Twitter here.
(Image courtesy of Acolyte films)
And while I was writing the little note below, the bottom dropped out ...
Really, I don't want to talk about me when the world is melting down, but I have had a number of requests for an informal explanation of what I got you-know-what for. So here's an attempt.

A new Department of Education policy that gives military recruiters centralized access to high school student data is drawing fire from the New York Civil Liberties Union, as well as some parents and students.

Confronting the world financial crisis, leaders from the Group of 8 pledged this afternoon to hold a summit meeting in the "near future" and once again vowed to act as a united front. It's a theme the group of wealthy nations has been sounding time and time again as the countries stare into a tempest of erratic markets and plunging investor and consumer confidence.
Chrysler calls its new electric vehicle team ENVI, but I'm beginning to think the name doesn't stand for "environment." Maybe it really is about, well, envy.

Jarett Dillard is a senior receiver at Rice. He holds almost every Rice career receiving record and leads all active N.C.A.A. receivers in receptions, receiving yardage and touchdown receptions. He also graduated with a degree in political science. Jarett will be checking in with The Quad from time to time to give readers an inside look at his season. Here he writes about how he spent last weekend and why he was happy to be able to eat his mother's cooking.

New York City operates more than 30 job training and related employment programs, at an annual cost of more than $925 million in government funds, but poor coordination of the program "has compromised its efficiency, accountability and effectiveness," the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said in a report on Wednesday.
In his post on Monday honoring Paul Krugman, this year's winner of the Nobel in economic science, Edward Glaeser wrote:
It's sunny and 67 degrees in Central Park this afternoon, but out West, they're already skiing and snowboarding.
Updated at 4:10 p.m.
If you haven't gotten your fill of presidential debates after watching the McCain-Obama match-up this evening, mark your calendar for Sunday night.

Earlier this year Cindy McCain found herself in a scandalette after the oatmeal-butterscotch cookie recipe she submitted to Family Circle's quadrennial Cookie Bake-Off was revealed to be startlingly close to an oatmeal-butterscotch cookie recipe on Hershey's website.

Never mind stocks, although a 500-point decline in the Dow (as of right now) is hard to ignore. Even aside from that, things are not looking good. Signs of an unfreezing in the credit markets are hard to find -- maybe we shouldn't have expected a quick result, but you do have to say that even the reformed Paulson plan has yet to produce any visible improvement in confidence. I'm most struck by the .04% yield on one-month T-bills -- that's depression-level flight to safety.

Calestous Juma, director of the Science, Technology, and Globalization Project at Harvard Kennedy School's Belfer Center, flagged an article about a Princeton Review study ranking the "greenest'' colleges and universities.
Melena Ryzik reports:
Omar now a hurricane, while TD16 is scraping the coast...
Crime dramas propelled CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday, although Fox led the night in the 18-to-49 demographic thanks to "House" and "Fringe."

Both The Times and The Wall Street Journal ran pieces today describing Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr.'s meeting with the heads of nine major American banks, in which he persuaded them to allow the government to purchase ownership stakes in the financial institutions. Perhaps Ed Yardeni, president of Yardeni Research, described it most entertainingly, in his daily client note:
Like it or not, a neighbor's misfortune may cross your threshold.
It's a site consisting only of dogs photographed upside-down:

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. - As Senator Barack Obama prepared for his final debate with Senator John McCain, he did so sitting down. An adviser, playing the role of Mr. McCain, was directly at his side, pressing and prodding and poking for 90-minute practice sessions.

There seems to be some pressure these days on City Councilman David Yassky to move from the undecided column to coming out as a full-fledged opponent to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to extend term limits.

The stars are lining up nicely for New York litigation later this month by Huntsman and Hexion Specialty Chemicals against Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank, the two banks that agreed to finance Huntsman's troubled acquisition by Hexion and now likely have a big case of lenders' remorse.
Here I am broiling baby back ribs on this morning's "Today" show. --MB
The Conversation

Game 2 of the world championship match between Viswanathan Anand of India, the title holder, and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the former champion, ended in a draw, although it was not nearly as dry or dull as Game 1. The match is being played in Bonn, Germany, under the auspices of the World Chess Federation. Information about the players, along with photographs, is on the match Web site.

Back in 1999, in response to the Asian crisis and Japan's lost decade, I published The Return of Depression Economics, which argued that our faith in the ability of policymakers to easily fend off severe slumps was misplaced -- the real possibility of liquidity traps and dangerous balance-sheet effects of financial shocks could render conventional policy ineffective.
Fresh from its acquisition of Lehman Brothers' capital-markets business in the United States, Barclays has named the industry group heads at its rapidly expanding investment-banking arm.
More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, Oct. 15:

I live in a private house in the Bronx that has a shared driveway. What are my options if I want to make improvements or repairs to the driveway or the shared front gate to the driveway. The pavement is cracked and the gate doesn't close. My neighbor has been reluctant to pay for repairs, and I don't know what my rights are.

My roommates and I have been looking at apartments, and the best option right now is in a lovely brownstone in Brooklyn. But the owner of the building is acting as his own broker and charging a 12 percent fee of the yearly rent. Is this legal?

If there is one issue that members of our online roundtable of voters want the candidates to address in their third and final presidential debate tonight, it's the economy. And they're asking for specifics.

Politics | Amid auguries of doom for John McCain, a boomlet of ideas on how he might pull things out of the fire: a Salon writer says don't rule out the volatile voter, or an October surprise. And what about a full McCain repudiation of Bush? Or, a Slate critic asks, what if the economy boomerangs back? Or if Obama's surge proves to be just another bubble? [Salon, Slate]

Aravind Adiga's darkly comic first novel, "The White Tiger," won the Man Booker prize Tuesday. A parable of the new India, it takes the form of a series of unanswered letters from an entrepreneur, Balram Halwai, who calls himself the "White Tiger," to the Chinese premier, who is planning a visit to the subcontinent. Halwai is a likable villain who escapes rural India's "Darkness" to take a job as a chauffeur for a wealthy family - giving Adiga an opportunity to satirize upper-class Indian - but murders one of his masters.

Following is the first set of answers from the co-editors of "Gastropolis: Food and New York City," (Columbia University Press, November 2008), Annie Hauck-Lawson and Jonathan Deutsch, who answered selected readers' questions on the history and culture of food in New York City. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.
Some commentators have suggested that today's crisis represents a unique opportunity to motivate Americans to save more.
It's not a great time to be in the bottled-water business.
After all the checks come in, Senator John McCain and Gov. Sarah Palin will wind up collecting about $10.6 million from Tuesday night's fund-raiser in New York, finance officials said.

You want to talk about being committed to football? Look no further than Mesa State offensive linemen Trevor Wikre, who opted to have his pinkie finger cut off rather than miss his senior season for the Division II team.

Afghanistan | The Central Asia expert Ahmed Rashid argues that because the Taliban have expanded into a regional force, Afghanistan's neighbors should be enlisted in resolving its worsening conflict. That means Iran, along with India and the countries of Central Asia. And the German military must intensify operations in northern Afghanistan. [Atlantic Community video]
Harley-Davidson has signed supermodel Marisa Miller to be the face (and body) of its new V-Rod Muscle motorcycle.
Cable news can be unintentionally humorous, as Comedy Central's "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" has proved time and time again.

New York draws about one-fifth of its revenue from Wall Street, and with the economy in crisis, the city is bracing for tough times ahead. On Sept. 23, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that his administration is considering imposing a 7 percent tax increase on homeowners in January. The next day, his staff members released a letter the city's budget director sent to every city agency, ordering them to cut 2.5 percent of their budgets, which will amount to the third round of cuts called for this fiscal year alone.
The Neue Galerie’s “Alfred Kubin: Drawings, 1897-1909” is replete with the terrors of the freshly analyzed psyche.

TOLEDO, Ohio - The upbeat music played in the background and colorful graphics danced on the screen as the TV anchorman posed a question in the opening tease of the evening news: "He's still in town and everyone wants to know, where will Barack Obama pop up next?"
Stocks were sharply down on Wednesday midday, after a United States government report offered a bleak picture of consumer retail spending. Some analysts said the data was a clear sign of a recession.

For a change, some good economic tidings: There's a $50-billion treasure in the ocean available for the taking if governments change their policies -- and save taxpayers at least $10 billion per year in the process.
They've been announced ...
1. Lions quarterback Dan Orlovsky, above, running a bootleg directly out of his team's end zone for a safety. (Hard to blame that on Matt Millen.)
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
Reporter Kate Galbraith talks with the executive director of the Sierra Club.
Is Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club, forging a new path of environmental pragmatism?

Chicken breasts and dense, white-fleshed fish like halibut and monkfish come with a built-in difficulty: they must be cooked through to be tender, but such thorough cooking tends to make them dry. Among the techniques that solve this problem is one that is not used as often as it might be: poaching in olive oil.
(Jeff Brown)
Meredith Whitney is the kind of analyst who isn't afraid to shake things up. And Jamie Dimon can be pretty plain-spoken himself.

This chart comes from Calculated Risk, still my favorite housing-and-credit-bust site. It shows nominal and real retail sales, and shows that consumer spending is now plunging at serious-recession rates.
BAGHDAD -- Iraqi Christians are fleeing the northern city of Mosul after a new round of killings, the latest to hit the dwindling community since the American-led invasion of 2003.
Christians are facing an increasing number of threats, kidnappings and killings in northern Iraq and looking to Baghdad for a solution.

FRANKFURT - A crowd of international publishers went mostly quiet here in a ballroom at the Frankfurter Hof, a luxury hotel that serves as the putative headquarters for the Frankfurt Book Fair, when five flat panel screen televisions tuned in to the announcement of the Man Booker Prize for fiction late Tuesday night.

Media | A reviewer says feminists are divided over pornography, into those who think it's oppressive, and a "pro-sex" group seeking a "more female-friendly sexual environment in the culture." The reviewer seems to fall into the latter camp as she critiques a book that finds "porn so thoroughly absorbed into the culture that we hardly notice it anymore." [Smart Set]
David Gates is the author of two novels, "Jernigan" and "Preston Falls," and a book of stories, "The Wonders of the Invisible World."
Edward Wyatt reports:

-- "Bloomberg L.P., the financial news company, announced Tuesday that it had hired Andrew R. Lack, the longtime media executive who was once the president of NBC News, to a new position as chief executive of its multimedia group," Bill Carter reports in today's New York Times.

A study released this week, called "Go Out and Play: Sport and American Families" finds, not surprisingly, that kids who are physically active are healthier and happier. Their family lives are more satisfying and less stressful too, according to the survey of 2000 students (third grade through 12th) and 850 of their parents by the Women's Sport Foundation.
The television shows "Valentine" and "Easy Money," which made their debuts on CW on Oct. 5, have been put on hiatus for six weeks, today's New York Times notes.
"Querelle," Brad Davis, 1982. (Courtesy of Everett Collection)

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority recently cut the number of hours fans are allowed to tailgate before football games at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., where both the Jets and Giants play.
The Associated Press reports:
Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Got your costume picked out for Halloween? Because I got mine. I'm going to wear my pants with the pockets out and just go as the bank.

George W. Bush has only a few months left in the White House, and he seems destined to leave office with some of the lowest approval ratings in the history of the presidency. But he is not pulling back on most of the controversial policies that have marked his presidency -- like presidential signing statements.
Our friends at Green Inc. have put together a look at some energy and environment stories from around the globe in pictures. Check it out.

Aired Tuesday night on CBS: This economy is crazy. Are you with me on that one? This is what I saw today. I saw a Lehman Brothers executive walking around town wearing a sign that read, "Will work for a seven-figure bonus."

As countries cast about for alternatives to Middle Eastern oil supplies, the debate over nonconventional sources of oil -- principally that which is milked, in a variety of ways, from sand and rock -- has become increasingly pitched.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Levi Johnston, the boyfriend of Sarah Palin's pregnant daughter, is back in the news. He gave an interview in which he says that at first, he was nervous attending the Republican convention with the Palins, but then he was like, "Whatever." Yeah, he also admitted that he writes Sarah Palin's speeches.

Media | To get quickly read in on Christopher Buckley's resignation from National Review over his Obama endorsement, read his Daily Beast explanation: "I retain the fondest feelings for the magazine that my father founded"; National Review's response; Buckley telling The Caucus he's "been effectively fatwahed by the conservative movement"; and Howard Kurtz noting: "Buckley can't be completely disappeared; the Washington author owns one-seventh of National Review and serves on the magazine's board."
Sebnem Arsu contributed reporting from Istanbul.

Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: There's a new bank bailout today. The government is taking a $250 billion ownership stake in a bunch of failing banks, which is great news because at long last, banking will be as efficient as going to the DMV.

Coming back from 3-1 in a league championship series is not impossible. But only 10 teams of the 70 who have been on the brink of elimination have pulled it off. And despite being pummeled by the Rays 13-4 on Tuesday night, the Red Sox may know best how to turn things around.
What do you do with the player considered to be the top selection next June in the National Hockey League draft?

The Working Families Party, the union-backed group that has been one of the leaders against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to rescind term limits by legislation so that he can run for a third term, announced on Wednesday that it had sent out 100,000 harshly worded fliers to constituents of seven City Council members who have not yet decided how they'll vote on the issue.
Alexei Cherepanov's body lay in repose Wednesday morning at the Omsk Arena, with long lines of citizens filing by to pay their respects.

Well, if the relationship between Jesse Jackson and Barack Obama wasn't strained enough already, Jackson's reported comments at the World Policy Conference at Evian, France, last week, should stretch it to the breaking point.
A reader named Len wrote to me with a thoughtful comment about this paragraph from this morning's column, which tries to explain middle-class pay stagnation:

A few years ago, I was startled to learn that a rather prominent film critic I know had never heard of Robert Warshow. But maybe I shouldn't have been surprised. Although David Denby has called Warshow "one of the best of all American film critics," and a few of his essays, particularly the one on the western, have been widely anthologized, somehow he has never become culturally central. He is more of a cult figure than a must-read critic like Pauline Kael (even if Kael may not have been possible without Warshow).
Bob McTeer is a former president of the Dallas Fed.

Wells Fargo, whose planned purchase of Wachovia will create the largest U.S. retail branch banking network, said on Wednesday third-quarter profit fell 25 percent, hurt by higher credit losses and investment write-downs.
"We hope it will work."
Tim Ogden, the editor in chief of Philanthropy Action, a journal for high net worth donors, flagged an article in The Chronicle of Philanthropy about changes at Change.org.
Tim Ogden, the editor in chief of Philanthropy Action, a journal for high net worth donors, flagged this item:
From our colleagues in the Dining & Wine section:

In the next week, the two biggest sellers of online ads, Google and Yahoo, will disclose their third-quarter financial results. They are expected to report widely different results which mirror the increasingly diverging fortunes of two forms of online advertising: search ads and display ads like banners and video clips.

Call it denial, or wishful thinking, or self-preservation. But Representative Anthony D. Weiner is convinced that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and members of the City Council will not succeed in rewriting New York City's term limits law so that they can seek a third term in office.

Just hours away from the third and final presidential debate and less than three weeks from Election Day, a New York Times/CBS News polls finds that the increasingly negative tone of the campaign waged by Senator John McCain appears to be resonating with voters -- but not in the way the Republican nominee hoped.
Tonight's debate provides Senator John McCain with his last, best hope of reversing the tide that appears to be running against him.
More of your "late night" jokes (use the comment link below):
There are all sorts of connections between the Nixon administration and the Bush administration. But here's one I didn't know about: Hank Paulson was John Ehrlichman's assistant in 1972 and 1973.
Success has many parents, and with Senator Barack Obama gaining a lead in many polls, the Change to Win union federation is claiming that its ads, fliers and volunteers have helped him.

Venture capitalists' confidence has sunk to a new low, according to a report released Wednesday by Mark V. Cannice, founder and director of the University of San Francisco Entrepreneurship Program, who surveys Silicon Valley venture capitalists every quarter.

The chief executives of the nine largest banks in the United States trooped into a gilded conference room at the Treasury Department at 3 p.m. Monday. To their astonishment, The New York Times's Mark Landler and Eric Dash report, they were each handed a one-page document that said they agreed to sell shares to the government, then Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said they must sign it before they left.

The Treasury Department will make substantial profits on its investments in banks under the bailout program announced Tuesday - if the banks return to health within a few years. If not, the government could end up breaking even, or perhaps even lose money., The New York Times's Floyd Norris writes.
A battle for control of Epicor Software seems to be heating up.

Under the bailout plan for the nation's banks unveiled on Tuesday, no heads will roll, as they did in the United Kingdom. No banking executives are likely to go hungry, either. But their parting may not be quite as sweet, The New York Times's Reed Abelson reports.

He who pays the piper supposedly calls the tune. And Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, is rightly insisting on some restrictions on bank bosses' pay while their firms are benefiting from government cash, Breakingviews says.

Finance | A columnist looks into the future of state-controlled banking and sees not "masters of the universe" but bland civil servants. The swaggering, high-risk days of Croesus-like bonuses are over. "When you are working for a publicly owned utility, with no risk of bankruptcy, you can't expect to make anything more than a normal middle-class salary." [Bloomberg]
Linens 'n Things, the private-equity-backed home goods retailer, will begin liquidating its remaining stores as early as Thursday, after failing to find a buyer to keep the company running.

With his brooding aspect and sagging poll numbers, Prime Minister Gordon Brown had seemed to personify the bleak mood of a world traumatized by collapsing house prices, lost jobs and banks that would not lend.

Synacor, which designs Internet portals and offers aggregation services, put the kibosh on its planned initial public offering Tuesday, as the I.P.O. market remains comatose. The company cited unfavorable market conditions.

Sterlite Industries won't complete its $2.6 billion purchase of Asarco, a bankrupt copper producer, without a price reduction of "hundreds of millions of dollars," lawyers told Bloomberg News. The development puts Asarco's exit from bankruptcy in doubt.

Innovalight, a developer of solar cells, has raised $5 million in a new round of funding led Silicon Valley Bank and Leader Ventures. The new financing brings the start-up's total funding to $47 million since its inception in 2002.

Discover Financial Services has agreed to settle an antitrust lawsuit it filed in 2004 against card networks Visa and MasterCard. Discover had been seeking about $6 billion in damages, as it contended the card networks had harmed its business by preventing their member banks from issuing credit cards for Discover's network.

Carlyle Group, the big private equity firm, and Jeffrey Lane, the former chief executive of Neuberger Berman, filed an objection to Lehman Brothers' sale of Neuberger, its asset management business, according to documents filed with the bankruptcy court.

JPMorgan Chase said Wednesday that its third-quarter profit fell 84 percent, suffering a steep decline amid continued trouble with mortgages and other loans -- but still avoiding the loss that many research analysts had expected.
The Carlyle Group's co-founder, David Rubenstein, said on Wednesday that private equity had a great opportunity to invest in banks and other financial companies hit hard by the global credit crunch.

Colin Callender, who as president of HBO Films oversaw projects that won more than 80 Emmys and two dozen Golden Globe awards, announced Tuesday that he will leave HBO by the end of the year to start his own entertainment production company, The New York Times's Edward Wyatt reported.

Standard & Poor's has warned that corporate speculative-grade defaults in the United States could rise to more than 23 percent by 2010, which would be the highest level since 1981. Last week, its composite of speculative grade, or high-yield, debt spreads hit a five-year high.
Iceland drew on Nordic help to obtain foreign currency on Tuesday and held talks with Russia about a possible loan to stave off a crisis that has left its economy near collapse.

When Werner Berkling heard the news on Sept. 15 that Lehman Brothers had filed for bankruptcy protection, he started to worry. He searched for papers describing two securities that he had bought in February, worth a total of 35,000 euros, or $48,000.
An unprecedented cash crunch is choking the ability of banks to lend and creating an opportunity for hedge funds to launch, or ramp up corporate lending facilities, Reuters reports.

With Senator John McCain unveiling a $52.5 billion package of proposals on Tuesday, both presidential candidates have now outlined their plans for addressing the economic crisis, leaving voters with a clear choice when it comes to one of the biggest challenges the next president will face, The New York Times's Jackie Calmes writes.

InBev's $52 billion deal to buy St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch hit a snag this week, when the Belgian brewer announced that it was forced to postpone a $9.8 billion rights offering intended to help fund the purchase.
The euphoria that swept Wall Street on Monday gave way to a sober reality on Tuesday: a recession, perhaps the deepest one in decades, may be unavoidable, The New York Times's Vikas Bajaj writes.

Jury selection began on Tuesday in a closely watched tax shelter case once billed as the largest ever, but government prosecutors face a difficult road after a string of defeats in a proceeding that has been scaled back, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

If there is a bright spot amid the chaos in the financial markets, it is that it helps to settle a debate among economists about the outlook for the European economy, The New York Times's David Jolly writes.
Hong Kong's financial regulators announced on Tuesday that they would provide government backing for all of the territory's $773 billion in bank deposits through 2010.

Asian stock markets fell modestly on Wednesday as analysts and investors digested the details of the massive bailout plans in the United States, and as the poor state of the global economy returned to center stage, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.
Wells Fargo, which has agreed to buy Wachovia, asked a federal court to void Citigroup's earlier agreement to buy parts of the big North Carolina lender.

The Blackstone Group, the U.S. private equity giant, said on Wednesday that it still aims to complete a pair of property deals in Shanghai, although a company official said valuations in China need to come down and regulations should be friendlier to foreign investors.

It took only six weeks of negotiations for General Growth Properties, the nation's second-largest shopping mall owner and operator, to agree to buy the Rouse Company in 2004 for $12.6 billion, a breathtaking price at the time.

Technology | Two takes on micro-messaging: a linguist says text messaging on your mobile is like writing a sonnet -- a challenge to creativity. But an editor finds Twittering kind of dopey: "Tweeting journalists experience the same mind-meld that makes their non-tweeting colleagues so uninteresting and predictable." [New Yorker, Weekly Standard]

Shari Redstone and her father, Sumner M. Redstone, appear to be battling in public again - this time over the reason for a large sell-off of shares by the family company, National Amusements, The New York Times's Geraldine Fabrikant reported.

Health | University of Iowa neurologists are looking for the key to smoking cessation in smokers who have suffered brain damage, often because of a stroke. Those with damage to the insula, a part of the brain involved in emotion, "quit easily and immediately." [Not Exactly Rocket Science]
Energy & Environment News From Around the WebClick an image to jump to the story.
Sport | As we prepare to watch the best baseball has to offer, consider some of its
A neo-hardcore band from Toronto with an unprintable name finished an almost 12-hour set inside Rogan on Wednesday, a pricey boutique on the Lower East Side.

Technology | The widely predicted "paperless office" was long discredited because it never arrived. But now at last it's here, thanks to a new generation "who have grown up with e-mail, word processing and the Internet." And therein lies a lesson in how change gradually takes hold. Online ads and electric cars, at first disappointing, are two other cases in point. [Economist]

The financial problems in the United States are taking a toll on Costa Rica. Several well-publicized projects have been put on hold, including Cacique, an ambitious $800 million development on the northern Pacific Coast spearheaded by AOL founder Steve Case.

Ivory Tower | A writer for a term paper mill says there are three types of customers: "dumb clients" who "should not be in college"; one-timers, like the "chemistry major trapped in a poetry class" as a required course; and perhaps the most tragic: educated professionals who lack English-language skills. He says slapping papers together from databases is "extremely easy, once you get the hang of it. It's like an old dance routine buried in one's muscle memory." [Smart Set]
The sounds at Fenway Park on Tuesday night never really suggested there was a team on the verge of the World Series in its midst.
Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s gamble that forcing the country into its third election in four years would give him firm control over Parliament failed.
The last of the three presidential debates will be held at Hofstra University on Wednesday.
In the hours and days since the stock market crashed, then fluttered back to life, television has spun an uplifting riches to rags narrative out of a shattered and murky economic picture.

Federal prosecutors in San Francisco are asking a judge to send the track coach Trevor Graham to prison for 10 months while his lawyers are calling for probation. A jury convicted Graham of lying to authorities about his connection to an admitted steroids dealer during the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative investigation.

Nastia Liukin, the Olympic all-around gold medalist, was honored as the Women’s Sports Foundation’s Individual Sportswoman of the Year. Jessica Mendoza, a softball player, was honored as Team Sportswoman of the Year at the foundation’s 29th Annual Salute to Women in Sports.

Major League Soccer will announce the bidders for two, and perhaps four, expansion teams after Wednesday’s 5 p.m. deadline. On Tuesday, a surprise bidder emerged — the Spanish club F.C. "The Chicago team, according to the critics and the results, showed superiority in every department of the game in the series as a whole, although this superiority was not so apparent on the day that Detroit batted a victory off [Chicago pitcher Jack] Pfeister's curves. Athletes are earning degrees at record rates, according to an N.C.A.A. report, and at higher percentages than the overall student body. The N.C.A.A. figures showed that 79 percent of student-athletes who entered college in the fall of 2001 graduated and that 78 percent of those who entered between 1998 and 2001 earned degrees within six years. Both are one-point increases over last year’s report and the highest ever. Still, student-athletes who played men’s basketball, football and baseball continued to lag behind those in other sports. ¶Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel committed to Terrelle Pryor as his quarterback, but not all his players agreed. Tight end Jake Ballard said it could help the Buckeyes’ struggling offense to turn to the former starter Todd Boeckman and have him share the job with Pryor, a freshman. An article and a picture caption on Sept. 23 about Sweden’s response to its 1992 financial crisis misstated the government position at the time for Bo Lundgren, who described Sweden’s strategy and commented on the United States’ proposals for resolving its own crisis. An article in some editions on Thursday about Sikhulu Shange, a longtime Harlem businessman who has been selling CDs on the street since being evicted from his shop, the Record Shack, misstated the name of the court that ordered his eviction. It is State Supreme Court in Manhattan; there is no Manhattan Superior Court.

Because of an editing error, the Memo from Thailand article on Monday, about political tensions at the core of recent protests, misidentified the main opposition party in Parliament. It is the Democrat Party — not the People’s Alliance for Democracy, a coalition of anti-government protesters.

Because of a transcription error, an article on Sunday about corruption involving contracts for Army missile defense programs misstated a word in a quotation from Lt. Gen. Jay Garner, who briefly headed the missile command. In an interview, describing how Army officials would seek Congressional approval for money that was not contained in the military’s budget request, General Garner used the acronym POM, referring to the Program Objective Memorandum, an internal budget document. He said, “If the money does not end up in the POM and you need it, the only other place you can get it is the Congress.” He did not say, “if the money does not end up in the palm.”.

A picture caption on Sunday with an article about funds that focus on alternative energy misstated the combined assets of two exchange-traded funds that specialize in wind power. As the article correctly noted, First Trust ISE Global Wind Energy Index fund and the PowerShares Global Wind Energy Portfolio had combined assets of $83 million, not billion.

ROUSSAN--Matei, M.D. , 86. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Matei Roussan M.D., an esteemed colleague for close to 50 years and former chairman and attending physician in the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine. Dr. Roussan, an internationally renowned expert on spinal cord injury and bladder problems, will be remembered as a teacher, mentor and friend to hundreds of medical students and residents during his many years at Montefiore. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife Michelle and his entire family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D. President David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

The San Diego Chargers will head east this week to face Buffalo, then keep right on going, flying to London on Sunday night to begin preparing for their game Oct. 26 against the New Orleans Saints at Wembley Stadium. In a league in which something as benign as a Monday night game can involve weeks of planning and hand-wringing, a two-game trip could be a major disruption. But the Chargers are the third team to make one this season, and they will not be the last.

LITTLEFIELD--William Rose . Bill died peacefully September 29. He was 82 and lived a full rich life. He was devoted to Karen Marshall, his partner of 33 years. He was incredibly proud of his children, Josh and wife Kate, their children Molly, Jordan and Hank; his daughter Amy and husband Mike Norton, and their children Zack and Emma. His brothers Donald and wife Lydia and Brad; and sister Isobel and husband Don Shapleigh; and many nieces and nephews survive him. Bill loved, loved words and traveling the world. He was always ready for a new adventure. He shared his curiosity and enthusiasms with as many people as possible. He wrote children's books and had a long career writing and directing industrial films and print work. For the past 12 years he was a dedicated volunteer literacy tutor for the New York Public Library at the Saint Agnes Center for Reading and Writing. As Francis Bacon wrote, ''Reading maketh a full man, conference a ready man, and writing an exact man.... Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.'' Bill spent his life happily chewing and digesting and helping others to do the same. He will be missed by so many. He leaves an emptiness that will be hard to fill. Bill's family and friends will gather to celebrate his life Saturday November 8 from 36pm. Call 212-663-8327 for details. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library, Harlem Center for Reading and Writing c/o The Friends Office, 476 5th Ave. Room 6, New York, NY 10018.

RODGERS--Christopher Raymond Perry (Knobby), of Gulf Stream, FL, died on October 7th at his summer home in Brooklin, ME; he was 87. Son of C. Raymond P. and Alice A. (Meyer) Rodgers, he was born November 29, 1920. He graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI and from Princeton University with the class of 1942. He served in the United States Navy during WWII overseeing radar operations on the aircraft carrier ''San Jacinto'' in the South Pacific, after which he returned to Princeton, NJ where he made his home for many years. His entire career was spent at CitiBank from which he retired as a Vice President after 35 years of service. A skilled athlete, he was a goalie on the 1948 US Olympic Hockey team and played for many years with the St. Nick's Hockey Club. Dedicated to the game of golf, he was a founding member of the Bedens Brook Club in Skillman, NJ, a former member of Pine Valley Golf Club, served as President of the Gulf Stream Golf Club in Florida and was a member of the United States Seniors' Golf Association. He was a generous supporter of many charities, especially those associated with veterans, and served on the vestries of Trinity Church in Princeton and Trinity Church in New York. Predeceased by his sisters Alicia and Virginia, three wives, the former Charlotte Hundley, Mary Pardee, and Katharine Parson and one stepson Ario, he is survived by 10 children, Perry Rodgers of Hopewell, NJ, Emily Rodgers of Bucksport, ME, Mary Elizabeth Alexander of NYC, James Rodgers of Phoenix, MD, Sam Rodgers of Leverett, MA, Sally Smith of Exeter, NH, Alice Celestino of Sarasota, FL, Virginia Hoyt of Lake Placid, NY, John Rodgers of Sweden, Julie Alpert of Naples, FL, two stepchildren, Arrel Lindermann of Boston and Ann Parson of South Dartmouth, MA, 30 grandchildren and four great - grandchildren. Burial will be private; a memorial service is planned for January in Gulf Stream, FL. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Francis By the Sea Episcopal Church, PO BOX 76, Blue Hill, ME 04614 or St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 188 S. Swinton Ave., Delray Beach, FL 33444.

STEINBERG--Mrs. Evelyn Sachs , a mezzo-soprano soloist with the Metropolitan Opera, and wife of the late Dr. Morris F. Steinberg, died on Monday at New YorkPresbyterian Hospital. The cause was complications following a stroke said her niece, Barbara Tapolow Fei. Mrs. Steinberg, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Sachs, studied at Cornell University and was graduated from the Julliard School of Music. Her professional debut was with the Chicago Opera Company. Her Metropolitan Opera debut was in Charpentier's Louise in the 1947-48 season, for which Virgil Thompson wrote ''charmingly sung by a newcomer to the house, Evelyn Sachs.'' From there she went on to engagements with the ranking opera houses throughout the world, including the New York City Opera. During her lengthy career she sang in many operas and delivered a critically acclaimed performance in Rigoletto with famed Swedish tenor Jussi Bjoerling. American music critic and historian of the Metropolitan Opera, Irving Kolodin, called Ms. Sachs ''A Voice of Substance and Quality'' in the New York Sun. She is survived by many loving friends and family members. Funeral services will be on Friday, October 17, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Rogosin Institute or The Julliard School, Inc.

Forget the comfort food we're all supposed to crave in times of woe, writes Pete Wells. Instead, head to No. 7 in Fort Greene for ''big-city, night-on-the-town chef food'' -- like rare tuna with Asian pears and jalapeño oil; hanger steak with kimchi pirogis; and miso-stewed banana pudding -- at comfortable prices. The space ''feels lived in,'' and the menu ''brings sophistication and comfort together in one spoon,'' he writes. ''The economy may be regressing, but that doesn't mean our diets have to.'' ''Kitchen Counterpoint For the New Austerity,'' by Pete Wells

STRAUSS--Michael . One of the most durable and fascinating careers in journalism came to a close Saturday, October 11, 2008, with the death of Michael Strauss, the Palm Beach Daily News' sports editor since 1983, who came to Palm Beach after spending half a century at the New York Times. He was 96. In his extensive and remarkable 75plus years as a sports journalist, Mr. Strauss covered everything from archery to yachting and he prided himself on never having missed a deadline. His dry wit, wry smile and extensive knowledge of history and geography were inescapable for anyone who'd ever gotten to know him. In Palm Beach, Mr. Strauss was a regular presence at events at the Palm Beach Recreation Center, the Phipps Ocean Park Tennis Center, the Breakers and Mar-a-Lago. He was wellknown to the athletic directors of Palm Beach Day Academy, St. Ann's and Rosarian Academy as well as officials at Trump International, the Kennel Club and the Croquet Center in West Palm Beach. He first was published in the New York Times about 70 years ago, and his last published article was published in the Daily News last month. About two weeks ago, Mr. Strauss suffered a fall in his South Palm Beach condominium and was hospitalized at JFK Medical Center in Atlantis. Earlier this week, he was transferred to Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton. At the Times, he served as winter sports editor and a sports writer and traveled with his hometown Yankees and Mets for 14 seasons. He had a seemingly inexhaustible reserve of personal anecdotes about everyone from Babe Ruth to Pete Rose, Sonny Liston to Joe Namath, Calvin Coolidge to Richard Nixon. As the Times ski editor from 1963 to 1982, Mr. Strauss wrote more than 1,000 articles on the sport. He was inducted in 2001 into the U.S. National Ski Hall of Fame, in Michigan, because of his prolific coverage. Mr. Strauss did not limit himself to journalism; he managed his high school baseball team, and later managed women's professional basketball and baseball teams in the 1940s and 1950s. He also owned a public relations firm, and earned a law degree from St. John's. Mr. Strauss was born July 13, 1912 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. When he was 10, he caught a glimpse of his first professional baseball game at Ebbets Field, home of the Brooklyn Dodgers. As the 13year-old manager of his high school baseball team, Mr. Strauss called in the details of his team's games to the New York Times' sports desk. Soon his editor, Joe Gephardt, invited Mr. Strauss to write the stories himself. The following summer, he covered New York City boxing club matches for $3 a night. At 18, Mr. Strauss officially joined the staff of the New York Times, covering semipro baseball on Sundays. He was a college freshman, earning 40 cents an inch, or $8 a column. From there his 50year career at the Times blossomed. He covered hundreds of college and professional football games, from Dartmouth, Harvard and Notre Dame to the New York Giants and New Jersey Jets. He covered thoroughbred and harness horse racing. As the ski editor for the Times from 1963 to 1982, he covered Winter Olympics in Squaw Valley, Grenoble, Innsbruck, Lake Placid and Alberta. He covered dragon boat racing in China, Gaelic football in Ireland, and harness horse racing in Macau. He may have been the first sportswriter to take notice of a 12-year-old basketball player named Lew Alcindor later known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar when he attended an athletic awards ceremony at a New York City Boys Club in 1958. When he wasn't covering sports in exotic locales, Mr. Strauss frequently wrote stories and took photographs for the Times' Travel section. He also contributed articles to Readers Digest, Esquire, Playboy, Travel and Leisure and other magazines, as well as annual entries in Encyclopedia Brittanica and Collier's Encyclopedia Yearbook. And for about a decade Mr. Strauss also had his own radio broadcast, on WQXR in New York, which covered the subject of skiing. Mr. Strauss had such an appetite for winter sports that he once covered three stories in three states, Maine, New Hampshire and New York, in one day. His second career began in Palm Beach after a brief, untenable retirement from the Times in 1982. Mr. Strauss had settled in South Palm Beach with his wife, Cecilia. The couple, who married in 1938, also shared a home in Danby, VT, where they spent summers. Mr. Strauss credited Cecilia, who died in 2002 at 86, with landing him his job at the Daily News. Cecilia called then-publisher Agnes Ash, who hired Mr. Strauss on the spot. In Palm Beach, Mr. Strauss covered sporting events at a dozen venues and schools, from the Rec Center to Mar-a-Lago. ''I worked with him for 25 years.'' said Rick Dytrych, head pro at the Par 3 golf course. Tim O'Connor was stadium manager for the now defunct polo stadium at Palm Beach Polo & Country Club during the early days of polo in Wellington in the mid-1980s.That's when O'Connor, now spokesman for the Palm Beach County Health District, met Mr. Strauss who was covering the sport for the Daily News. Rose Carnicelli, supervisor at the town tennis courts, said Mr. Strauss was the second person she met when she came to work at the town's Palm Beach Par 3 10 years ago. Carnicelli said that she became close to Mr. Strauss after his wife died and she would cook him breakfast and help him around the house. Russ Bitzer, the former head of the Palm Beach Recreation Department who retired in 2005, once said of Mr. Strauss, ''He wrote hundreds of articles for us about the kids and the programs. I would credit him in large part with many of our successes over the years.'' Mr. Strauss also found time to write light verse, and in 1994 published ''Rhymes of My Times''. Mr. Strauss was a member of the Newspaper Guild; the Baseball Writers Association; the U.S. Ski Writers Association, for which he founded the Eastern chapter; the U.S. Harness Writers Association; and the New York and U.S. Turf Writers Associations. He is survived by daughters Ellen of Alexandria, VA, and the Village of Golf, and Sharon Parker of Boca Raton; four grandchildren; Dr. Alexa Boer Kimball of Boston, Andrew Boer of Greenwich, CT, Amy Sumida of Syracuse, NY and John Parker of Kansas City. and eight great-grandchildren. He also is survived by three brothers, Dr. Seymour Strauss of Oceanside, NY, and Boca Raton, Jack Strauss of Berea, KY, and Col. Raymond Strauss of Chapel Hill, NC. Mr. Strauss will be buried in Danby, VT, next to his wife of 65 years. A memorial service will be held in December in Palm Beach. Memorial donations may be made to Life Lover Foundation at lifeloverfoundation.org.

The cries went out: Meat! Meat! After all, we were drinking peppery, spicy, brambly zinfandels that often strode past 16 percent alcohol. I was a holdout. Our luncheon buffet included a dish of soba, Japanese buckwheat noodles. It seemed to me that the earthy noodles just might be an excellent foil for the wines. Pasta is a good idea with high-alcohol wine. But not cold soba, and certainly not with the usual dashi, soy sauce and mirin dressing.

When the studio clock at WBLS-FM (107.5) is reflecting the face of Champaine around 3:30, it is a.m., not p.m. She says she wanted to work at that station since she was in fifth grade, and in 1983 the station manager, Frankie Crocker, granted her wish. Champaine, a native of Staten Island, has been at WBLS ever since, most of the time carrying her listeners through the night. A conversation with Champaine: nytimes.com/nyregion.

Satisfied that they know what caused the Hubble Space Telescope to shut down two weeks ago, NASA engineers will begin to reboot it on Wednesday morning, the agency said. The telescope should be back to performing normal science by Friday morning, said Art Whipple, manager of the Hubble Space Telescope Systems Management Office at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. The orbiting eye has been out of commission since late September, when a router that formats data and helps relay it to the ground failed, causing the telescope to go automatically into a ''safe mode.'' The device has a backup channel. But to restore it, the engineers have to activate the backup channels in other components of the observatory, none of which have been turned on since the telescope was launched in 1990. So engineers wanted to wait until they were sure it would be safe. DENNIS OVERBYE

CLARK--Lt. Col. Scott S. , a 33 year career Air Force intelligence officer who was considered a military expert on the political-economic affairs of the Middle East, died in Denver on October 9, 2008. He was 87. The University of Denver granted Lt. Col. Scott a BA degree in economics in 1949. He later completed advanced studies in Middle Eastern affairs and Arabic at the University of Michigan and Georgetown University. During WWII, Lt. Col. Scott received the Distinguished Flying Cross medal while serving as an air crew member with 15 missions over Germany and France. He was awarded other medals of note during his career, including six Air Medals, the Air Force Commendation medal, and the Republic of Vietnam Gallantry Cross. Lt. Col. Scott was a skilled ROTC instructor, adroit diplomat, and an outstanding worldwide intelligence analyst. He developed these qualities as a Flight Commander with the 6911th Radio Group, Wheelus AFB, Libya; an assistant Professor of Aerospace Studies at the University of Iowa; Military Attache attached to the American embassy in Jidda, Saudi Arabia; Staff Officer SAC Headquarters, Offutt AFB, Omaha; Deputy Director of Intelligence 7th Air Force, Saigon; and Chief of the Air Force Intelligence Training Center, Lowry AFB, Denver. Lt. Col. Scott is survived by his wife, Elberta L. Scott, and three children: Lt. Col (Ret) Steven R. Scott, Jacqueline B. Scott, and John M. Scott.

In Good Company In 2006 and 2007, Peyton Manning of the Indianapolis Colts and Tom Brady of the Patriots received most of the attention as Super Bowl-winning quarterbacks. But in that time, Drew Brees of the Saints threw for the most yards of any N.F.L. quarterback by more than 400. His total of 8,841 was the third highest two-year total in league history. Dan Fouts of the Chargers threw for 9,517 yards in 1980-81, and Warren Moon of the Houston Oilers threw for 9,379 in 1990-91.

A bill signed by President Bush gives the Army the authority to award back pay with interest to soldiers wrongly convicted in one of the largest court-martials of World War II. At an Army post in Seattle in 1944, 28 black soldiers were convicted of rioting in connection with the death of an Italian prisoner of war. Last fall, an Army board overturned the conviction, citing violations of due process. Only one of the soldiers is known to survive. A handful of the soldiers' families have requested the formal review necessary for the Army to award the back pay to the descendants. It was unclear how the Army would calculate interest, but the payments potentially could be tens of thousands of dollars. WILLIAM YARDLEY

Close, Yet so Far Away How close were the Chicago Bears from being 6-0 instead of 3-3? How about four minutes? How about 8 points? In their three losses this season, the Bears have been leading late in the fourth quarter. In Week 2 against Carolina, Chicago led until the Panthers scored a touchdown with 3 minutes 52 seconds left to win, 20-17. Against Tampa Bay the next week, the Buccaneers tied the score with seven seconds left and won in overtime, 27-24. Then on Sunday in Atlanta, Chicago took the lead with 11 seconds left and lost on a final-second field goal, 22-20. As a result, Chicago finds itself in a three-way tie for first place in the N.F.C. North, heading into a home game with one of the teams it is tied with -- Minnesota. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

BERGEN--Peter J. , a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died on October 13th after a courageous battle with cancer. A proud patriot and a bon vivant extraordinaire, Peter had a talent for living life to the fullest. No one enjoyed a fine cigar, a good Scotch, a round of golf or watching a Mets game more than he. Peter was at his best firing bon mots around the table, belting out bar songs or hymns, or telling tall tales. He was a trustee of the Boys' Club of New York, a Senior Warden at the Church of the Epiphany and a member of the Holland Society and the Brook, Southampton and Piping Rock Clubs. Born in Brooklyn, he attended Poly Prep, New Hampton School and UVA before enlisting in the U.S. Navy. He is survived by his loving wife Susan, children Schuyler, Susan and Peter Jr. and grandchildren Angelica, Adriene, Graham, Claire and Sarah. Visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday, October 16 from 24 and 6-8pm. Funeral service on Friday, October 17 at 10am at Church of the Epiphany, York Ave. at 74th St.

ZELDIN--Richard Packer , 90, of Tinton Falls died Sunday October 12, 2008 at home, just six weeks after his wife of 57 years, Virginia. Mr. Zeldin had a distinguished career in scientific and technical book publishing, starting as a travelling salesman for McGraw Hill Book Company where he eventually became general manager. After that, he served as president of the R.R. Bowker Company, publisher of John Wiley and Sons, Inc., and vice president of Moseley Associates, all of New York City. Mr. Zeldin graduated from West Chester University in 1942 then served as a lieutenant in the United States Navy, captaining an LCT an Omaha Beach on DDay. He was an avid tennis player well into his 80s when he was ranked in the top 10 of the USTA over 80 section rankings. He was predeceased by his wife Virginia Graves Zeldin on September 1. Surviving are his daughter Elizabeth Ann and her partner, Polly Grant, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, a son Shepherd Zeldin and his wife, Linda Camino, of Madison, Wisconsin and his sister Alice Marcus and her husband John. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church 380 Sycamore Avenue, Shrewsbury, N.J. 07702 (732)741-2220 on Friday October 17 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Richard Zeldin's memory to the NYU School of Medicine, Development Office, 1 Park Avenue, 10th Floor, NY, NY 10016. TUCCI--Berta . Beloved Berta Tucci, 78, passed away on Saturday, October 11, 2008 at Greenwich Hospital. Born in Larino, Italy she emigrated to the United States with her parents Carmela and Alfredo Terreri and proudly became a US citizen. She graduated Hunter College with a B.A. in English. She was a beautiful, generous, and supportive person. Well loved by the community for her tireless dedication to the NY Lighthouse Association for the Blind, the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra and other philanthropic organizations including serving on the Board of the Westchester County Medical Center Auxiliary. She is survived by her husband; Paul Tucci, M.D., her children; John, Brenda and Andrea, her grandson Maxwell, daughter - in - law Lynn, and her family in Italy including brothers; Dino, Gaetano and sisters; Anna, Maria, Vera and Augusta. A remembrance of her life will take place at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY 10580, on Saturday October 18, 2008 from 3-6 pm.

The presidential candidates rarely discuss the impact of racial prejudice on the campaign, but voters are not nearly so shy. In interviews around the country, voters were open and often blunt in their own feelings about the candidacy of Senator Barack Obama, and how their own backgrounds shaped their thinking about his possible election. Many acknowledged that they and others they know harbor deep-seated emotions about race that may affect their vote.

LINDGREN--Robert Alf , formerly of New York City and Water Mill, New York, died on October 13th at Southampton Hospital. Born in Jamestown, New York in 1938, Bob attended Jamestown High School and received a BA degree from Yale College in 1960. A talented composer, choral director and pianist, he led the Whiffenpoofs of 1960 and accompanied the Glee Club throughout college. He graduated from the University of Chicago Law School in 1965 and joined the firm of Rogers & Wells, where he practiced law for 35 years, becoming a senior corporate partner. A lifelong bachelor, Bob is survived by his brother Richard and sister-in-law Anne, both of New York City and Shelter Island. He also leaves his niece Sarah Nussbaum of Moretown, Vermont, nephews Hugo Lindgren of New York and Douglas Lindgren of Fair Haven New Jersey, and seven grandnephews and -nieces. His family cherishes the memories of the wonderful man they called UB, Uncle Bob. Funeral services are at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Shelter Island, on Sunday October 19th at 1pm. A memorial service will be held in New York later this fall.

EngenderHealth mourns the loss of our friend, colleague, and Board member, Dr. Allan Rosenfield. A visionary advocate for women's reproductive health and human rights, innovative family planning policies, and the prevention and treatment of HIV among the most vulnerable, he touched the lives of countless individuals around the world. A man of extraordinary compassion, energy, and leadership, he will be sorely missed. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Clare and the entire Rosenfield family. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are saddened by the death of our dear colleague, IRC Overseer Allan Rosenfield, M.D., dean emeritus of Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health. He was a towering figure in his field and a powerful advocate for the health care rights of the world's most vulnerable people, especially women. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Clare, and their children and family. Alan Batkin Jonathan Wiesner, Co-Chairs of the Board George Rupp, President ROSENFIELD--Allan. We send his family our sympathy and deepest gratitude for sharing Allan with us. Adrienne Germain, President, International Women's Health Coalition Brian Brink, MD Chair, Board of Directors

Economics | Oddball recession indicator: In a 2004 study, researchers found that Playmates of the Year over the decades confirm an "environmental security hypothesis." In tough times, men prefer women good at production: older, taller, heavier, less curvaceous, with less body fat. In good times, it's women good at reproduction: younger, shorter, lighter, more curvaceous. (Gawker dissents.) [Marginal Revolution, Sage Journals]

In North America as in Russia, fans and commentators have expressed outrage over the chaotic emergency medical response to Alexei Cherepanov's heart failure on Monday at the Ice Hockey Arena 2004 in Chekhov. The absence of a rinkside stretcher, on-duty ambulance and working defibrillator, as well as a 15-minute wait for the arrival of a hospital ambulance, have been cited as evidence of a desperately poor level of organization that, in this case, cost a young player whatever chance at survival he may have had.

Virginia, with 13 electoral votes, becomes the latest state to move from the toss-up to the leaning Democratic column in The New York Times presidential map today. Based on polling, along with interviews with officials in both campaigns, that determination suggests that Senator Barack Obama now has an advantage over Senator John McCain in a state that was once reliably Republican. This is the third state won by President Bush in 2004 that The Times now has leaning blue, joining Iowa and New Mexico.

Today I wrote about troubles in the much-hyped world of peer-to-peer lending sites, where people can lend money to other people over the Internet. Zopa, a London-based start-up, has withdrawn from the United States, citing adverse market conditions, and two San Francisco-area companies, Lending Club and Prosper, have encountered problems with securities regulators and were forced to stop all trading on their sites.

Citigroup on Thursday reported a $2.8 billion loss for its third quarter, as the banking giant took more than $13.2 billion in charges related mostly to its store of toxic mortgage assets. As a result of American interdiction efforts, impoverished Guinea-Bissau has become a new hub for South American cocaine bound for Europe. "In the 19th century, Europe's hunger for slaves devastated West Africa. Today, its appetite for cocaine could do the same. The former Gold Coast is turning into the Coke Coast." [World Press, United Nations]

Big investors will be required to disclose their short positions to the Securities and Exchange Commission under an interim final rule the commission issued Wednesday night, Reuters reports. The commission said short-sale reports provide it with important information about sizes and changes of short sales.
Tesla Motors,the Silicon Valley electric car start-up, said Wednesday that it would lay off employees and delay production of its second car, the Model S. Tesla.

There is more bad news for digital advertising, which oh-so-many Web start-ups count on for revenue. The price advertisers are willing to pay for ad space online is down 27 percent this year, according to a PubMatic report released Wednesday.
GMAC, the former financing arm of General Motors, has "limited if any access to funding" for its mortgage and auto lending units, its chief executive, Al de Molina, has told employees.

New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo's threat of legal action against American International Group, unless its moves to recover bonuses and other payments from its former executives, had shades of former N.Y. A.G. Eliot Spitzer, whose sweeping attacks on Wall Street ended in a high-profile, industry-wide settlement, The New York Times's Jonathan D. Glater and Vikas Bajaj reported.

JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and State Street have weathered these bad times better than most banks. But things are about to get worse, The New York Times's Eric Dash writes.

President Bush went to Grand Rapids, Mich. on Wednesday to explain and defend his program to resuscitate the nation's economy, and he said any long-lasting federal intervention in the banking industry would be a mistake, The New York Times's Robert Pear reported.
JPMorgan Chase agreed to allow bankrupt savings and loan Washington Mutual Inc.'s parent company to access $4.4 billion of its funds that may be used to help pay creditors.

Citigroup will delay a planned merger of two of its Japanese units, the Nikkei reported Thursday, in what could be the latest sign the subprime-hit U.S. bank is looking to trim costs from its Tokyo operations.

Motorola has agreed to unload its biometrics business to France's Safran, a supplier of aviation components, as the company seeks to exit non-core businesses ahead of its split into separately listed companies.

Electricité de France, the world's largest operator of nuclear plants, said Wednesday it would not launch a rival bid for U.S. power company Constellation Energy Group because the credit crisis has made financing more difficult to obtain.

The volatility and risk aversion in global stock markets continued in Asia on Thursday, where sharp falls in the Nikkei 225 and other key indexes all but wiped out the extraordinary relief rally that had swept across the region earlier in the week.

Henry Kravis, the co-founder of buyout giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, said on Wednesday that the banking situation was beginning to stabilize, but that investor and business confidence had been shaken to the core by the financial crisis.

European leaders, gathering for a meeting dominated by the global banking crisis, were pressed on Wednesday to back a comprehensive overhaul of the world's financial structures, The New York Times's Stephen Castle reported.

Federal investigators have organized a task force to examine any wrongdoing at Washington Mutual, the troubled savings bank that regulators seized and sold to JPMorgan Chase late last month, The New York Times's Eric Dash reported.

The Internal Revenue Service is tightening up its oversight of foreign banks that sell offshore services to wealthy American clients, a move intended to stem what officials have called rampant tax evasion, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

World | "It took two world wars, a global depression and the onset of the Cold War to lay the British Empire low," a columnist says, so don't write off America yet. Rivals and petro-dictators like Putin and Chávez are hurting in the crisis too. And as a percentage of G.D.P., the American bailout is small compared with what the Europeans are ponying up. [Wall Street Journal]

Lexicon | Why is everyone saying "fail" all of a sudden? Using it as a noun ("epic fail!") instead of "failure"? It apparently evolved from a bad translation in a Japanese arcade game, and became a handy cliché or meme by which a putdown-obsessed Web culture could describe humiliating failure. Now "fail" shows up on protest signage at Senate financial inquiries and all over the place. [Slate]

History | A British lecturer writes that "there is something in the idea that a pirate ship is the equivalent of a modern corporation." Pirates had financial backers and "elected their captain, voted on major decisions, and distributed their booty in roughly equal shares." Their plunderings are "the roots of modern venture capitalism." So what happened to the plank? [Science Daily]

Politics | Once again, people have gotten it into their heads that the presidential election has turned ugly. You want ugly? How about that candidate in Austria complaining of women in Islamic dress running around "like female ninjas"? Or the Russian far right calling the eventual President a Jew? "He's a scoundrel! Look at his face! The guy's sick!" [Foreign Policy]

Keeneland will handle the sale of a minority share of Curlin, the richest American racehorse ever. Nov. 5 is the deadline for potential buyers to submit a sealed bid for a 20 percent stake in Curlin, the 2007 Horse of the Year and Breeders’ Cup Classic winner. A judge had ordered the minority share be sold to help satisfy a $42 million civil judgment against the horse’s minority owners, William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham. The 80 percent majority interest, held by Jess Jackson, is not affected by the sale.

IT was only a matter of time before technology took over the tee. Even though Global Positioning System units for golfers have been around since 2002, they weren't sanctioned by the United States Golf Association for tournaments, even for amateurs, until 2006. Since then sales of the portable devices -- designed to let golfers know how many yards they're standing from the pin and what obstacles might be in the way -- ''have exploded,'' said Bob Tucker, the purchasing manager for the Golf Warehouse, an online retailer. ''The latest GPSs are accurate to within three feet,'' said Brian Verdugo, president of L1 Technologies, the San Diego company that makes the iGolf Neo GPS unit. Battery drain was once a problem. In the early units, ''a charge would only last for four or five hours, barely enough for 18 holes,'' Mr. Verdugo said. Now players can expect a minimum of two rounds between charges. The newer generation of GPS units are also sleeker than the early models, which Mr. Verdugo likened to bricks.

ROSENFIELD--Dr. Allan . The Board of Directors and staff of the American Legacy Foundation join the legions of Allan's colleagues, friends and loved ones in conveying our condolences at the passing of this public health visionary. In over 20 years as dean of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University, he was a pioneer for maternal, adolescent and child health and HIV/AIDS. Allan once said ''You lead when you get people to come along with you.'' It is an honor to have been one of his followers and to have called him my mentor and friend. Our heartfelt sympathies go to his wife, Clare, and his family at this time of tremendous loss. Cheryl G. Healton, Dr. P.H. President and Chief Executive Officer American Legacy Foundation

Excerpts from the presidential debate on Wednesday night in Hempstead, N.Y., between Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama, as recorded by Federal News Service. The moderator was Bob Schieffer of CBS News. A full transcript and video: nytimes.com/politics. MR. MCCAIN A couple of days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio, and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber. Name is Joe Wurzelbacher. Joe wants to buy the business that he's been in for all these years. Worked 10, 12 hours a day. And he wanted to buy the business, but he looked at your tax plan and he saw that he was going to pay much higher taxes. You were going to put him in a higher tax bracket, which was going to increase his taxes, which was going to cause him not to be able to employ people. Joe was trying to realize the American dream.

LEWY--Esther . The Officers, National Commissioners and Staff of the Anti-Defamation League mourn the passing of Esther Lewy, beloved mother of Glen Lewy, ADL National Chair. We extend our sincerest condolences to Glen and Cheryl, his father Rudolph and sister Rhonda, and the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Abraham H. Foxman, National Director LEWY--Esther Rennert, 86, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 14, 2008 in Boynton Beach, Florida. Survived by her loving husband of 65 years, Rudolf; her children, Glen (and Cheryl) Lewy and Rhonda (and Joel) Koss; her grandchildren Adam Koss, Jordan Koss, Zachary (and Anja Langenbucher) Lewy, Marshall (and Heather Fowler) Lewy and Brooke Lewy; her great-grandson Yannick Lewy; predeceased by her brother Fred Rennert. Born in Mannheim, Germany, Esther emigrated to the United States in 1937 at the age of 14 and was raised in New York City where she graduated from George Washington High School. Esther and Rudolf raised their family in Fort Lee, NJ and New Milford, NJ before moving to Boynton Beach, FL. Active in the family business, Decora Imports, Esther found time to volunteer for ORT, travel and be a superb wife, mother and grandmother. Esther loved life and lived it to the fullest. A red head with a zest for living, whose glass was always more than half full, she will be missed by us all. Funeral services will be on Friday, October 17, at 1:30pm at Robert Schoem's Memorial Chapel, Route 4, Paramus, NJ 201843-9090. Contributions may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158.

KERR--Dr. Benjamin . Temple Israel of Lawrence mourns the loss of our esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jay H. Rosenbaum, Rabbi Garrett L. Gray, President KERR--Dr. Benjamin. Our hearts cry out in profound sorrow at the loss of our cherished friend Ben Kerr. The world is diminished and its light darkened by his passing. Ben Kerr was more than a friend. He was a member of our extended family, and we valued his friendship for over 50 years. His wisdom and thirst for knowledge made him a giant among physicians. His surgical skills and brilliance led him to diagnose our darling Michael's Crohn's disease when no other medical experts could identify it. A philanthropist, his generous commitment to research and finding a cure for Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis made a significant impact. Ben faced unspeakable odds with enormous courage, optimism and humor. We will miss our daily chats, frequent dinners and his favorite ice cream desserts. As we mourn his loss, our hearts go out to his beloved wife Evelyn, his wonderful children Michael and Carol and their families. We loved him and will miss him forever. Rest in peace dear Ben. Shelby, Leslie, Mitchell, Shawn, and the entire Modell Family KERR--Benjamin G., M.D., lived a full and wonderful life. He passed away on the morning of October 15, 2008 at his home on Long Island. Benjamin left behind his loving wife of 64 years Evelyn, a daughter Carol, son Michael, son-inlaw John, daughter-in-law Susie, grandchildren Wendi, Pamela, Joshua, Zachary, grandchildren - in - law Sean, Laura and Jessica and four beautiful great - grandchild ren, Max, Jenny, Roland and Jack. Benjamin was born in Brooklyn, New York and graduated from James Madison High School. He attended Columbia University later receiving a medical degree from New York Medical College. He served in World War II as a physician stationed in England. He married Evelyn in 1944 and initially settled down in Brooklyn, later moving to Hewlett, New York where he set up his practice as a general and vascular surgeon affiliated with St. Joseph's and Long Island Jewish Hospitals. The lessons of his life will live on through the generations as he set an outstanding example of someone who lived life to the highest moral and ethical standards. Services will be held at the Boulevard-Riverside Chapel at 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY at 11:30 Friday October 17th.
