ROGERS--Paul Grant . Research!America mourns the loss of The Honorable Paul G. Rogers, Research!America chair emeritus and former Florida Congressman. Paul was aptly known as ''Mr. Health'' for his 50year legacy as one of our nation's most accomplished, passionate advocates for health research. He was held in highest esteem by his colleagues, his peers in Congress, multiple Administrations, and leaders in all areas of health and science. Paul was truly a giant, and we were so fortunate to have shared his time and great talents. He often said, ''Without research, there is no hope.'' For the hope that research has brought to lives of Americans and people everywhere, the world owes a great debt of thanks to Paul Rogers. His achievements benefited the lives of Americans young and old, from every corner of the nation. As just one example, thanks to his work on behalf of the National Cancer Act, children's death rates from cancer dropped by more than 60 percent. He was a role model and the epitome of public service, whose optimism and tireless commitment to health research inspired generations of advocates. He was often honored, yet never wanted the light to shine on himself. Instead he seized accolades as a time to champion a cause and challenge others to make America the world leader in health and research for health. To those who knew and worked with Paul, he will be long remembered as the champion of hope that he was. The Hon. John E. Porter, Mary Woolley and Research!America's Board of Directors

MEISTRELL--Dr. Malcolm Edgar, Jr. , died on October 14, 2008 from complications of heart disease. Dr. Meistrell was born in Brooklyn, New York on May 12, 1938 to the late Dr. Malcolrn E. and Josephine Moody Meistrell. He maintained a private practice of orthodontics in Port Washington, NY and was a Clinical Professor of Orthodontics at Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, where he taught and inspired two generations of orthodontists. He was a diplomate of the American Board of Orthodontics. He was president of the Northeastern Society of Orthodontists and the Nassau County Dental Society. He was a fellow of the New York Academy of Dentistry and the American College of Dentists, and was chairman of its New York section. Dr. Meistrell graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1956 and Princeton University in 1960. He received his DDS from the University of Michigan Dental School in 1964 and his Certificate in Orthodontics from Columbia University College of Dental Medicine in 1967. He was the beloved partner of Joy Hudecz, the loving father of Victoria Pouncey and her husband Christian, Malcolm E. Meistrell III and his wife Lori, and Walter Meistrell and his wife Kendra, the esteemed brother of Gerard Meistrell and Patricia Monk, and the loving grandfather of Malcolm, Abigail, Walker, and Ryder Meistrell and Eliza Pouncey. A Funeral Mass will he held at 10am on October 18, 2008 at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Columbia University College of Dental Medicine for its Orthodontic Division, c/o Director of Development, CU College of Dental Medicine, 630 West 168th Street, P&S 3460, New York, NY 10032.

BERGEN--Peter J. , a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died on October 13th after a courageous battle with cancer. A proud patriot and a bon vivant extraordinaire, Peter had a talent for living life to the fullest. No one enjoyed a fine cigar, a good Scotch, a round of golf or watching a Mets game more than he. Peter was at his best firing bon mots around the table, belting out bar songs or hymns, or telling tall tales. He was a trustee of the Boys' Club of New York, a Senior Warden at the Church of the Epiphany and a member of the Holland Society and the Brook, Southampton and Piping Rock Clubs. Born in Brooklyn, he attended Poly Prep, New Hampton School and UVA before enlisting in the U.S. Navy. He is survived by his loving wife Susan, children Schuyler, Susan and Peter Jr. and grandchildren Angelica, Adriene, Graham, Claire and Sarah. Visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Thursday, October 16 from 24 and 6-8pm. Funeral service on Friday, October 17 at 10am at Church of the Epiphany, York Ave. at 74th St.

STEINBERG--Mrs. Evelyn Sachs , a mezzo-soprano soloist with the Metropolitan Opera, and wife of the late Dr. Morris F. Steinberg, died on Monday at New YorkPresbyterian Hospital. The cause was complications following a stroke said her niece, Barbara Tapolow Fei. Mrs. Steinberg, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Sachs, studied at Cornell University and was graduated from the Julliard School of Music. Her professional debut was with the Chicago Opera Company. Her Metropolitan Opera debut was in Charpentier's Louise in the 1947-48 season, for which Virgil Thompson wrote ''charmingly sung by a newcomer to the house, Evelyn Sachs.'' From there she went on to engagements with the ranking opera houses throughout the world, including the New York City Opera. During her lengthy career she sang in many operas and delivered a critically acclaimed performance in Rigoletto with famed Swedish tenor Jussi Bjoerling. American music critic and historian of the Metropolitan Opera, Irving Kolodin, called Ms. Sachs ''A Voice of Substance and Quality'' in the New York Sun. She is survived by many loving friends and family members. Funeral services will be on Friday, October 17, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Rogosin Institute or The Julliard School, Inc.

LINDGREN--Robert Alf , formerly of New York City and Water Mill, New York, died on October 13th at Southampton Hospital. Born in Jamestown, New York in 1938, Bob attended Jamestown High School and received a BA degree from Yale College in 1960. A talented composer, choral director and pianist, he led the Whiffenpoofs of 1960 and accompanied the Glee Club throughout college. He graduated from the University of Chicago Law School in 1965 and joined the firm of Rogers & Wells, where he practiced law for 35 years, becoming a senior corporate partner. A lifelong bachelor, Bob is survived by his brother Richard and sister-in-law Anne, both of New York City and Shelter Island. He also leaves his niece Sarah Nussbaum of Moretown, Vermont, nephews Hugo Lindgren of New York and Douglas Lindgren of Fair Haven New Jersey, and seven grandnephews and -nieces. His family cherishes the memories of the wonderful man they called UB, Uncle Bob. Funeral services are at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Shelter Island, on Sunday October 19th at 1pm. A memorial service will be held in New York later this fall.

McKEVITT--Margaret Theresa , known in religious life as Sister Amadeus, died on Tuesday, October 14, 2008 at Andrus Residence in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York. Born in Jersey City on September 11, 1917, she was the daughter of Hugh and Margaret Murphy McKevitt. She attended the Academy of Mount Saint Ursula, graduating in 1935. She entered the Ursuline Novitiate where she pronounced vows on January 24, 1939. She received a B.A. degree from the College of New Rochelle in 1943, and earned a Masters degree in American history at Fordham University in 1955. Sister began her teaching career in Middletown, NY and in years following taught at Blessed Sacrament School in New Rochelle and Saint Angela's and Ursuline Academy on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. In 1953 she became Principal of a new Ursuline Academy in Bethesda, MD where she inspired an atmosphere of cooperation, telling the students that there would be no rules in the school until they made them necessary. That spirit pervaded the school until its closing in 1976. Meanwhile Sister Amadeus served in both Rome and the United States developing programs for Sisters in various stages of formation as religious. She served as a local Superior of the Convent of St. Teresa's at the College of New Rochelle and at the Ursuline Convent in Bethesda, MD. In 1973 she was asked to serve as Associate Vicar for Religious in the Archdiocese of New York, a post she held until 1981 when she was asked by the Archbishop to study canon law at The Catholic University of America. After completing a JCL, she was appointed to the Archdiocesan Marriage Tribunal as the first woman to be named a judge. Those who brought their cases to the Tribunal were impressed by her intelligence, her empathy, her quick wit and her ability to expedite things. She is survived by a sister, Katherine Dullaghan and several nieces and nephews. A wake will be held at the Ursuline Convent at 39 Willow Drive, New Rochelle, NY 10805, on Friday, October 17th from 2 to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle on Saturday, October 18th at 10am.

It's a prime tenet of New York City real estate that there just isn't enough of it. And the city's lack of space can have theological ramifications, when apartment dwellers don't have room, say, for a full-size Christmas tree or a sukkah, a temporary shelter used to celebrate the Jewish harvest festival, which started Monday evening and continues through this coming Monday evening, with some celebrations continuing on Tuesday. So another tenet of city real estate kicks in: location, location, location. Which explains the popularity of the sukkah in Bryant Park, one of a handful of public huts where Jews eat and say blessings in during the festival, known as Sukkot. The shelters commemorate the 40 years Jews spent in makeshift dwellings while headed toward the Holy Land.

I do not know about you, but I was both surprised and pleased to hear during the presidential debate this week that the Democratic candidate, Barack Obama, was relying on the former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker for advice during the financial crisis. I was surprised because I did not realize that Mr. Volcker, who had been an extremely nonpartisan Fed chairman before Alan Greenspan, did that sort of thing -- roll up his sleeves in the middle of a heated campaign. I always had the sense that he preferred to be above the political fray.

The European Central Bank was created with a single mandate: keep inflation in check. But the bank has transformed itself into a crisis manager over the last month as it has battled to keep Europe's financial system and integrated economy intact, The New York Times's Carter Dougherty reports.

Its "privileged roughnecks" spent their time "whoring and brawling" and "terrorizing the local townsfolk by throwing stones and pouring water on their heads, vandalizing property, singing obscene songs, and in return being terrorized and beaten by the townsfolk." The Hungarian government struck a deal on Thursday to borrow up to 5 billion euros ($6.7 billion) from the European Central Bank in a bid to avoid becoming - like Iceland - a national victim of the financial crisis, The New York Times's Nicholas Kulish and Carter Dougherty reported.
Kazakhmys, the London-listed Kazakh copper producer, said on Friday that it ended reported merger talks with Russia's Metalloinvest, following a collapse in commodity prices.

Germany's lower house of parliament on Friday overwhelmingly approved a 500 billion euro ($675 billion) rescue package for the country's financial markets, clearing the way for approval in the upper house later in the day, The Associated Press reported.

The Red Bulls will play the final two games of the regular season without two starters — goalkeeper Jon Conway and defender Jeff Parke — after they were suspended for violating the Major League Soccer’s substance-abuse policy, the first drug suspensions in league history. The players were suspended for 10 games and fined 10 percent of their salaries after testing positive for androstatriendione and boldenone metabolites, performance-enhancing substances that were purchased at a vitamin store.

Seve Ballesteros developed a complication after brain tumor surgery, requiring doctors at a Spanish hospital to remove a piece of his skull to relieve pressure. Ballesteros, a 51-year-old Spaniard who won three British Opens and two Masters, was listed in stable condition but was still in intensive care. ¶Tom Watson, the winner of eight Grand Slam titles, said he planned to return for the Senior Skins Game in January after recovering from hip replacement surgery. Watson, 59, is rehabilitating at home in Kansas City, Mo., after the Oct. 2 operation. He won twice on the Champions Tour this year and was 12th on the money list in only 10 starts. watson.

Top-ranked Rafael Nadal and No. 2 Roger Federer powered into the Madrid Masters quarterfinals, while No. 3 Novak Djokovic lost to Ivo Karlovic, 7-6 (4), 7-6 (5). Nadal moved closer to clinching the season-ending No. 1 ranking by beating Richard Gasquet, 6-4, 6-2, while Federer eased past Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, 6-4, 6-1. Federer’s victory meant that he became the ATP Tour’s career leader in prize money, topping $43.3 million to overtake Pete Sampras. ¶Top-ranked Jelena Jankovic’s 12-match winning streak ended in a second-round match that left her bruised and bleeding, a 5-7, 6-3, 6-3 loss to Flavia Pennetta at the Zurich Open. Jankovic said she was tired after winning titles the last three weeks in Tokyo; Stuttgart, Germany; and Moscow. “I didn’t have any gas in the tank,” she said. “I am not a machine.” Zurich.

Denis Savard was fired as coach of the Chicago Blackhawks, only hours after the team’s first victory. He was replaced by Joel Quenneville, 50, who had been hired as a team scout in September after coaching the St. Louis Blues and Colorado Avalanche for most of the previous 11 seasons.

Professional cycling faced a bleak day in Germany on Thursday when the country’s biggest multistage race was canceled and two main national broadcasting outlets said they were dropping their live coverage of the Tour de France because doping scandals continue to mar the sport. The announcements from the Tour of Germany and the ARD and ZDF networks came less than a day after the Austrian cyclist Bernhard Kohl admitted to using CERA, a new generation of the blood-booster EPO.

North Dakota’s Board of Higher Education has approved a schedule for discarding the University of North Dakota’s Fighting Sioux nickname and Indian head logo if two Sioux tribes hold firm in their desire to have them dumped. The timeline directs William Goetz, the university system’s chancellor, to form a committee to discuss the issue with the Standing Rock and Spirit Lake Sioux tribes. The panel should meet at least twice with Sioux leaders in 2009. If there is no agreement, the timeline says, the university should begin planning in January 2010 to retire the nickname and logo.

Fifteen people were reported to have died last night on a burning train in Michigan as forest fires "swept towns and farms." With Alpena County "ablaze in every direction," the train, "consisting of three empty freight box cars and two coal gondolas," was sent to relieve Metz, "a little town 23 miles north of Alpena," from the fire "closing in on all sides," and "men, women and children hastily filled the cars." A few miles into the train's southbound trip, "the engineer saw blazing piles of cedar ties on both sides of the track" and "tried to dash through it at full speed." But the track gave out and the train stopped and caught on fire. "It will probably be a week or more before it is known definitively how many people perished." Forest Fires Grow, 15 Dead on Train

(TCM) '70s THRILLERS Friday night frights: this triple feature begins with ''The Day of the Jackal'' (1973), starring Edward Fox (above right, with Cyril Cusack) as an assassin hired to kill the French president, Charles de Gaulle. ''The Stepford Wives'' (1975), in which Katharine Ross plays a New York wife and photographer transplanted to an upstate suburb where the neighbors have a ghastly secret, follows at 10:30. And ''The Little Girl Who Lives Down the Lane'' (1976), the creepy shocker starring Jodie Foster as a precocious 13-year-old who lives alone and pretends that her father is alive so that she won't be assigned a guardian, wraps up the scarefest at 12:30 a.m. 8 P.M. This 3,200-square-foot house was formerly Cram's Tavern, built in 1808. It is on about 16 acres of meadow and woods with river frontage. The interior includes wide-plank floors, nine fireplaces and an updated kitchen with soapstone countertops. Original moldings and details are restored throughout. The house has one full and one half bathroom. There is a screened porch and an attached garage. Agent: Glenda Lewis, the Masiello Group, (603) 924-8373; www.masiello.com.

McDILL--Marie-Dennett Murphy, 71, died peacefully in her sleep October 15, in residence at the Carlyle Hotel in New York City. She was the sister of Elizabeth Murphy Lowe and the daughter of Marie-McIntyre Murphy and H. Gabriel Murphy, the former minority owner of the Washington Senators. MarieDennett McDill was born in Washington, DC on January 21, 1937. She was a graduate of Georgetown Visitation Preparatory School and Manhanttanville College. Mrs. McDill was a painter and an avid gardener at her home in South Woodstock, Vermont. She loved the paintings of Henri Matisse, the music of Cole Porter, and the works of Mark Twain, Robert Frost, Emily Dickinson, and Ogden Nash. She believed in living life out of doors and requested --in lieu of flowers or donations --that everyone who knew her (and everyone who reads this) plant a tree on her behalf in the next year. Mrs. McDill was preceded in death by her husband, Jonathan McDill. She is survived by her three children from her first marriage to Paul Gardner Jr. (David Gardner, Thomas Gardner, and Marie-McIntyre Sterrett) and her six grandchildren (Katherine, Gabriel, and Zachary Gardner; and Marie-Dennett, Virginia, and Anna Sterrett). The family would like to thank the entire staff at the Carlyle Hotel, along with Rose Marie (''Roses'') Moore and Shirley Innis, for their great care and affection. Reading Van Doren, by her stepchildren Phoebe Gould, Peter, Charles and David Van Doren and numerous stepgrandchildren. Catherine was very much beloved and will be very sorely missed. ROSENFIELD--Allan. The Board of Directors and staff of the Center for Reproductive Rights mourn the loss of Dr. Allan Rosenfield, our colleague, friend and hero. Allan was a visionary champion for women's reproductive health and early on recognized that women's ability to decide the number and spacing of their children and to survive pregnancy is a basic human right. Allan will be greatly missed and will always be an inspiration to take on injustice and never give up. Nancy Northup, President Center for Reproductive Rights

Mr. Venditti, 35, is manager of sales and customer service at Worksman Cycles in Ozone Park, Queens. The company, founded as a bicycle shop in 1898, produces heavy-duty industrial bicycles and tricycles. Sales to longtime customers in government, manufacturing and the military have been steady. But the company, with 60 employees, is limiting overtime and cutting overhead by means including the installation of solar panels. Everything that we purchase has gone up in price over the last year. We used to change our pricing moderately every three years. We've had to change pricing three times this year already, which we've never had to do before. If we got a 3 percent price increase from a supplier, that's understandable. But when it jumps 20 percent three times in a year, that's unprecedented.

THE Trinity Alps are about 286 miles from San Francisco International Airport and 67 miles from Redding Municipal Airport in Redding, Calif. For information on the area, see the Web site www.trinitycounty.com, maintained by the Trinity County Chamber of Commerce in Weaverville. Trail permits and backcountry information can be obtained at the Weaverville Ranger Station (360 Main Street, Weaverville, 530-623-2121), open 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. weekdays. The classic guide to the region is ''The Trinity Alps: A Hiking and Backpacking Guide,'' by Luther Linkhart and Mike White (4th edition, Wilderness Press, July 2004).

Mr. Villasante, 46, owner of V & V Construction in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, immigrated from Uruguay in 1986. He has been in business for 17 years, running a small contracting firm that specializes in painting and home renovations. He typically employs nine workers during the busy months. But with half as many jobs as he had last year, he has been operating with only his four regular workers. It's down. The economy is bad and people don't have the money, though I work in a neighborhood that is middle-class.

Mr. Menna, 47, the owner of Menna's Quality Meats and Salumeria in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx and the father of two young girls, has managed his family's 50-year-old meat market for the last 14 years. He is being squeezed by rising energy, transportation and food costs (he also took on two new employees this year) and declining demand: He estimates that business is down 20 percent this year. You see customers buying less. They are just buying what they need. Maybe one pound of chicken cutlets. They are buying much less in bulk. People are also using credit cards more. No one has cash anymore.

Ms. Blau, 34, president of On Location Tours in Midtown Manhattan, started her company in 1999 after graduating from Skidmore College. With a staff of six full-time employees and about two dozen part-time guides, she operates bus tours of New York locations from popular movies and television shows, most prominently ''Sex and the City.'' While foreign tourists have been a boon for her, sales to Americans have declined 20 percent this year. Now, with Europe's economy in trouble and the dollar rising, she is worried that international travel will also fall sharply. Travel's a luxury, so they're not going to come to New York. They're going to pay their gas bill first. We were pretty strong through the end of August. There's a natural drop in September, but we had more of a drop than normal.

KERR--Benjamin. The Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York are saddened by the passing of Benjamin Kerr, father of the dedicated, talented and generous ABO Co-Chairman, Michael Kerr. Benjamin Kerr was an extraordinary surgeon and doctor who practiced with great humanity and dedication. A great philanthropist, his passing will leave a void not only in his family's life but in his community's. our sympathy is extended to his wife Evelyn, children Michael and Carol and his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Jerome Belson, President Arnold Sollar , Co-Chair Nicholas Laporte, Jr., Executive Director KERR--Dr. Benjamin. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Dr. Benjamin Kerr, who with his wife, Evelyn, and children, Carol and John Harrison and Michael and Susie Kerr, expressed an admirable commitment to strengthening the New York Jewish community. Benjamin's legacy will continue through his daughter, Carol, a board member at the Jewish Community Center of the Greater Five Towns, a UJA-Federation beneficiary agency; through his son, Michael, a member of the boards of the JCC of the Greater Five Towns and UJA-Federation; and through their spouses--dear friends who have embraced their parents' commitment to generosity. We extend our condolences to Evelyn, to Carol and John, to Michael and Susie, to Benjamin's grandchildren, to his great-grandchildren, and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO KERR--Dr. Benjamin. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club record with sorrow the loss of our beloved member, Dr. Benjamin Kerr. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Evelyn and family. Geoffrey D. Lurie, President KERR--Dr. Benjamin. The Board and the staff of the JCC of the Greater Five Towns extend our sincere sympathy to the Kerr and Harrison families on the loss of their beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, Dr. Benjamin Kerr. May his memory be a blessing for all. Dr. Kenneth Berman, President Rina Shkolnik, Executive Director KERR--Dr. Benjamin. Our hearts cry out in profound sorrow at the loss of our cherished friend Ben Kerr. The world is diminished and its light darkened by his passing. Ben Kerr was more than a friend. He was a member of our extended family, and we valued his friendship for over 50 years. His wisdom and thirst for knowledge made him a giant among physicians. His surgical skills and brilliance led him to diagnose our darling Michael's Crohn's disease when no other medical experts could identify it. A philanthropist, his generous commitment to research and finding a cure for Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis made a significant impact. Ben faced unspeakable odds with enormous courage, optimism and humor. We will miss our daily chats, frequent dinners and his favorite ice cream desserts. As we mourn his loss, our hearts go out to his beloved wife Evelyn, his wonderful children Michael and Carol and their families. We loved him and will miss him forever. Rest in peace dear Ben. Shelby, Leslie, Mitchell, Shawn, and the entire Modell Family

Mr. Vayda, 65, sales manager at Parkfield Saab in Rochelle Park, N.J., has been selling cars for 17 years, the last four at Parkfield Saab. The dealership, with six salesmen, had done a booming business in lease-sales deals, but business has been off mainly because of high gasoline prices, tightening credit and financial industry layoffs. Now Saab's parent company, General Motors, is reported to be dangerously low on cash and in merger talks with Chrysler. My best estimate is we are three years out from having it all wash out. Apparently, the entire automobile landscape has been impacted. Sales are down across the board. Several years ago, they were talking about 16 million cars sold a year. Now they are down 20 percent from what they predicted.

LOS ANGELES -- For more than two months, Manny Ramírez played the role of a quirky, dreadlocked pied piper. The youthful Dodgers followed their new leader, his big bat serving as the clarion call, as they embarked on an inspired charge toward the World Series. But Ramírez could only carry the Dodgers so far. The Phillies clinched a World Series berth Wednesday by ousting the Dodgers with a 5-1 victory in Game 5 of the best-of-seven National League Championship Series. As Philadelphia celebrated its first pennant in 15 years, the Dodgers expressed regret that a team that came from behind to win the N.L. West in September and swept the heavily favored Cubs, did not play better.

Mr. Shami, 54, the owner of Alfanoose, a Middle Eastern restaurant on Maiden Lane in the financial district, came to the United States in 1974 and opened his restaurant in 1999, operating it with three employees: his wife; his daughter, who plans to attend law school; and his son, a junior at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Sales have dropped by nearly 30 percent as layoffs have mounted at nearby banks and brokerage houses, causing him to scrap plans to serve breakfast and to consider asking the deli next door to share his space and split the rent. It's scary, to tell you the truth. I can feel it, the cutting back. Our business depends on orders from the big financial companies. A.I.G., they used to order from us. Goldman Sachs, they cut down a lot. Citigroup, I hardly get any orders from them anymore.

A butcher's longtime customers stop paying their bills. A building contractor has half as many jobs as he did a year ago. A restaurant owner considers sharing space to stay afloat. Steadily, inexorably, the fallout from Wall Street's layoffs and the credit crisis is trickling down to small businesses across the region. Over the coming months, The New York Times will track six of those businesses to see how they are weathering the economic storm.

For more than a year, The Times has been running a series of stories, "If Elected," exploring what the presidential candidates say they'll do on various important issues -- and trying to get an idea of what each might actually do in office. My contribution is on global warming and the next president. One reality is that while human-caused climate change was mentioned in every debate, the issue remains low on Americans' list of worries, and the financial storm means that action -- from a climate bill to new spending on energy research -- will be tough to keep front and center.

5. A fairly sleepy afternoon in college football. None of the ranked teams that lost could really be considered upsets. When my mother, Carol, passed in 2004, I found myself spending hours at her empty apartment, sitting amid her things, desperate to find traces of her. I pored over her hundreds of books on art and antiques, looked through the baskets of art postcards she'd collected on her travels for scribbled notes, and flipped through years' worth of day-planners, searching for evidence of her presence: a signature, a sketch, a smear of her trademark orange lipstick. I found one manila envelope of old family photographs and another containing every postcard I'd sent her during my junior year abroad in London. I cursed my 19-year-old self for not being thoughtful enough to keep the ones she'd written back to me.

(Murray said a B.A. tells employers little about job skills.) The counselor focuses on poor value to students, especially the vast numbers who eventually drop out. Colleges "are businesses, and students are a cost item, while research is a profit center." [Chronicle of Higher Education]

Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer stayed on track to meet in another final by winning their quarterfinals at the Madrid Masters. The top-ranked Nadal downed Feliciano López, 6-4, 6-4, and the second-ranked Federer eliminated ninth-seeded Juan Martín del Potro, 6-3, 6-3. In Saturday’s semifinals, Nadal will meet Gilles Simon. Federer will face fourth-seeded Andy Murray. ¶Venus Williams beat Francesca Schiavone, 6-3, 6-3, in the quarterfinals of the Zurich Open. Williams, seeded third, next faces second-seeded Ana Ivanovic, who defeated Petra Kvitova, 6-1, 6-4. Flavia Pennetta and Anabel Medina Garrigues will also meet in the semifinals. zurich (AP).

The Palestinian soccer team will play its first international game at home when it faces Jordan on Oct. 26 in a renovated stadium. For 10 years the team has been playing home games in Jordan and Qatar. But its stadium in Ram has been upgraded to meet standards set by soccer’s governing body, FIFA, and will be opened by Sepp Blatter, FIFA’s president. “It is very important to FIFA that countries are able to play their home matches in their own stadium,” Pekka Odriozola, a FIFA spokesman, said Friday.

Andy Bean hit all 18 greens in regulation and finished with a seven-under-par 65 to take the first-round lead at the Administaff Small Business Classic at The Woodlands Country Club in Texas. Bean had a one-stroke lead over Jay Haas and Joey Sindelar.
Steelers running back Willie Parker will not play against the Bengals on Sunday after missing his third straight practice. Parker missed the past two games with a sprained left knee.

Doug Melvin will get a three-year contract extension as the general manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, but the team also said that Dale Sveum was no longer under consideration to become manager. Sveum was promoted from his coaching position and served as interim manager after Ned Yost was fired with 12 games left in the regular season. The Brewers reached the postseason for the first time since 1982, but lost to Philadelphia in the opening round of the playoffs.

The Yankees’ Chien-Ming Wang threw 25 pitches in his first throwing session off a bullpen mound since hurting his foot in June. “It’s better,” Wang said after the session in Tampa, Fla. “It’s good.” Wang partly tore a tendon and sprained his right foot running the bases.

The American yacht Puma Ocean Racing was leading the Volvo Ocean Race around the world as the eight yachts approached the Cape Verde Islands in the Atlantic, despite pressure from the Swedish favorite Ericsson 4. It was the seventh day of the race, which started in the Spanish Mediterranean port of Alicante. The boats are expected in Cape Town on Nov. 3 at the end of the first of the 10 legs of the race.

Surrounded by "suffragette banners," a picture of "Miss Christabel Pankhurst as Portia - she is a bachelor of law." Top left, "the bell-ringing belle of Dundee, Miss Dorothy Maloney, the suffragette who fought Mr. Winston Churchill." Top right, "Mrs. Pankhurst arrested for inciting riot." The pictures accompany a report from London describing the reaction there to a suffragist demonstration that was capped off by "Mrs. Travers Symons's incursion upon the floor of the House of Commons" [see the TimesTraveler of Wednesday, Oct. 14, 1908]. The Pankhursts along with "Mrs. Drummond" were "charged with inciting riot and disorder." When the case comes to trial, "it is quite likely that they will receive exemplary punishment, for Herbert Gladstone, the Home Secretary, has indicated that militant suffragettes will not, if sentenced again, be treated as first-class misdemeanants." Pert Young Woman Is Miss Pankhurst; Say Young Suffragette Posed for the Gallery with Indulgent Permission of Fatherly Magistrate

Honeywell International cut its fourth-quarter profit forecast and said it would brace for “recessionary conditions” in the United States and Europe next year. Third-quarter profit increased to $719 million, or 97 cents a share, from $618 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. That topped the average Wall Street estimate by 2 cents, according to Reuters Estimates. Revenue rose 6.2 percent, to $9.28 billion. Honeywell now expects to earn 97 cents to $1.01 a share on revenue of $9.4 billion in the fourth quarter. Analysts, on average, had looked for profit of $1.04 a share on sales of $9.8 billion.

VAN BUREN--Anne Hagopian, art historian, 81, died October 13 after a short illness in New York. Her husband Rev. Paul M. Van Buren predeceased her. The Stella Adler Studio's Harold Clurman Festival of the Arts, which began on Friday, features on Saturday a discussion called ''Movement: A Universal Language,'' whose panelists include Margie Gillis, Bill T. Jones, Beth Konopka and Irene Dowd, and is moderated by Deborah Jowitt. Tickets can be purchased at smarttix.com; the festival runs through Oct. 27.

TULIN--Miriam. It is with profound sadness that her loved ones announce thedeath of Dr. Miriam Tulin on Sunday, October 11, 2008. She was an extraordinary, loving, and creative woman who was the wife of Dr. Maurice Tulin and loving mother of Roger and Michael Tulin. She was also the beloved sister of Milton and Robert Stern and grandmother to Claire, Gwen, and May Tulin. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, Sunday, October 19, at Habitat/ Mass Audubon, 10 Juniper Rd., Belmont, MA 617489-5050, www.massaudubon. org. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to All Care Hospice, 16 City Hall Square, Lynn, MA 01901.

A woman Friday cleaned a sculpture by Carlos Altamirano, a Chilean artist, in the lobby of the Foreign Ministry in Caracas, Venezuela. The sculpture is a model of President Salvador Allende's glasses as found after the 1973 coup in Chile that led to his death.

LEWY--Esther. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the passing of Esther Lewy, beloved mother of our colleague and friend Glen Lewy, National Chair, Anti-Defamation League. We extend heartfelt sympathy and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Harold Tanner, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

It's over. I've studied the polls and the electoral map for months, and I no longer believe that John McCain can win. Unless Barack Obama slips up, Jeremiah Wright shows up or a serious national security emergency flares up, Obama will become the 44th president of the United States.*

MEISTRELL--Dr. Malcolm E., Jr., Clinical Professor of Dental Medicine within the Section of Growth and Development, Division of Orthodontics at the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on October 14. He was a faculty member at Columbia for the past 35 years, where he taught and inspired generations of orthodontists. He was a graduate of Princeton University, received his D.D.S. degree from the University of Michigan in 1964 and completed his orthodontic training at Columbia University in 1968. Dr. Meistrell was active in organized dentistry and served as President of the Nasssau County Dental Society and the Northeastern Society of Orthodontists in 1994-1995. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his beloved partner Dr. Joy Hudecz, his daughter Victoria, his sons Malcolm and Walter, his brother Gerard, his sister Patricia Monk, and his five grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday, October 18th at 10am at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine for its Division of Orthodontics, C/O Director of Development, 630 W. 168th Street, New York, NY 10032. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc. Dean, Columbia University College of Dental Medicine Thomas J. Cangialosi, D.D.S. Chairman, Section of Growth & Development Director, Division of Orthodontics

Viewed through night-vision equipment, American soldiers unloaded supplies in the dark this week from a Chinook helicopter at an Army combat outpost near Kamu, in northeastern Afghanistan. The soldiers' mission is to stabilize nearby villages and prevent insurgent fighters from moving freely in the volatile area near the Pakistan border. The outpost has been hit regularly in recent weeks with rocket-propelled grenades, mortar shells and small-arms fire. Insurgent snipers fire from wooded and mountainous terrain that provides cover and high ground from which to attack.

McCain Helps Letterman Beat Leno's Ratings An appearance by Senator John McCain on Thursday night boosted David Letterman, right, to his best ratings in almost three years. Mr. McCain, the Republican presidential nominee, returned to Mr. Letterman's CBS show after several weeks of battering from the host for his abrupt decision to cancel an earlier appearance. According to initial overnight ratings, the Letterman show attracted 6.53 million viewers, well above Mr. Letterman's usual total of about 3.5 million viewers and the best he has scored since Dec. 1, 2005. (That night's guest was another noteworthy figure with whom the host had had an on-and-off comic feud: Oprah Winfrey.) Mr. Letterman, who usually trails Jay Leno's ''Tonight Show'' by a significant margin, easily eclipsed that NBC star; Mr. Leno had 4.57 million viewers Thursday night for a show whose guests included Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic vice presidential nominee. BILL CARTER
KAPLAN--Charles Ira Esq., of Lauderdale by Sea, FL (Formerly Englewood Cliffs, NJ). Services Sunday 9:45 ''Eden Memorial Chapels'' Fort Lee, NJ (1-888-700-EDEN).

Iranian workers, left, assembled a giant sandwich of ostrich meat and chicken on Friday in Tehran in an attempt to set a world record. The effort to make a sandwich more than 4,900 feet long out of several thousand pounds of meat fell apart when people rushed to eat the completed sandwich before representatives from the Guinness Book of World Records could measure it. Above, the crowd asked for more of the sandwich, which used ostrich meat to promote Iran's fledgling ostrich farming industry.

GARVEY--Noreen R., of Bronxville. Born County Derry, Ireland and raised in Montreal, Canada, died October 16, 2008. Loving wife of the late Michael J. Mother of Evaleen Holden and grandmother of Michael. Beloved sister of Mary Tompkins, Una Regan, Sheena Laughlin, Patrick Regan and the late Eileen Flynn. Loving aunt to 11 and great-aunt to 13 nieces and nephews. Best friend to many. Retired Secretary from Lehman College. Lector and CCD bookkeeper at St. Joseph's. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4pm and 7-9pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church Bronxville, on Monday October 20, at 11am.

Monasteries Open To Travelers For centuries Europe's convents and monasteries have quietly provided inexpensive lodging to in-the-know travelers, but now they're increasingly throwing open their iron-bound doors to overnight visitors. At left, a feast inside the Monasterium Poortackere in Ghent, Belgium.

Ken Ogata, a versatile and prolific leading man in Japanese films and on Japanese television who also appeared in movies directed by Peter Greenaway and Paul Schrader, died on Oct. 5 in Tokyo. He was 71. The Mainichi newspapers of Japan said the cause was liver cancer, citing Mr. Ogata's family as the source.

ESHINSKY--Sergei A., on October 16, 2008 at age 72. Beloved life partner of Raymond Laccetti since 1969. Loving friend of Nicholas, Maureen, Irene, Charles and Dr. Ottaviano. He will be sorely missed and remembered for his big heart. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., Monday 9am-10am with Funeral Service at 10am. Interment to follow at Mountain Grove Cemetery, Trumbull, CT. Contributions in his memory may be made to The American Cancer Society.

FISHER-KOPPEL--Cybele Elizabeth, age 42, died peacefully on October 16 surrounded by her adoring family, loving husband, Dr. Todd Koppel, Phyllis and Jack Fisher, parents, and sister Remy Fisher-Baumann. Graduate of Vassar College, attended American Academy Dramatic Arts, french teacher at Caedman School and executive director at other arts organizations. She enjoyed her life to the fullest and she will always be remembered for her joie de vivre, creativity, wit and wisdom. Donations in Cybele's memory can be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, Bethesda, MD, cff.org. Memorial services Sunday October 19, 10:00am, Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave., Bronx.

MANDEL--Newton W., husband of Ellen T. Mandel, died on October 15, 2008 at the age of 82. He is survived by his son Harlan Mandel, daughter Sherry Mandel, sister Dr. Regina White, brother Stephen Mandel and four grandchildren who he cherished. Service Sunday October 19, 11am at his beloved Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. at 55th St. The family will be receiving at 1519 Albemarle Rd., Brooklyn following the funeral to 8pm and Monday from noon to 8pm. Also Tuesday at 2054 Holland Way, Merrick, NY from noon to 8pm.

COCHRAN--Jane Ehrlich, died after a long illness October 17, age 67. She was an oboist for 35 years with the New York City Ballet Orchestra and the Mostly Mozart Orchestra. Beloved wife of George and loving mother of Lara Cochran Davidson, mother-in-law of Alan Davidson, adoring grandmother of Ben and Aiden, sister of Irene Ehrlich Alpher and loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. Jane will be missed by all the family and friends who love her. Donations in her memory may be made to the Nature Conservancy or Susan G. Korman for the Cure.

For the first time in its 161-year history, The Chicago Tribune is endorsing a Democrat for president. The newspaper, which has links to the Republican Party that date back to the party's founding, said Friday that Senator Barack Obama was the strongest choice ''to lead us through a perilous time and restore in us a common sense of national purpose.''
Now is the October of our discontent. First of all, George W. Bush showed up on TV Friday morning to reassure the nation. What could possibly be worse?

A Republican congresswoman from Minnesota said Friday that some of Senator Barack Obama's associations raise the possibility that he has ''anti-American views.'' The lawmaker, Representative Michele Bachmann of suburban Minneapolis-St. Paul, made the remarks to Chris Matthews on MSNBC's ''Hardball,'' and cited Mr. Obama's ties to Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. and William Ayers, a founder of the radical group Weather Underground in the 1960s, whom she called ''over-the-top anti-America.''
She would walk on broken glass barefoot if it required her to do so in this campaign. MATT SALMON, a former Arizona congressman, on Cindy McCain. [A13]

Our heartfelt condolences go out to his family. Paul Meissner, MSPH, President Amy J. Schwartz, MPA, Executive Director

KORYN--Ted, our loving and loyal friend. We will miss you and all the smiles you brought us. Florence, Sheldon & Joe KORYN--Theodore G. Passed away on October 16, 2008. Beloved husband of Jane. Devoted father of Nanette Cohen of Scarsdale, NY, and Daniel Koryn of Lander, WY, and father-in-law of Robert Cohen and Bonnie Koryn. Cherished grandfather of Carly, Dustin and Rachel, former husband of Miriam. Loving brother-in-law of Sylvia Koryn and brother of the late Andrew Koryn. Services Sunday 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to UJA or Central Park Conservancy.

RUSSO--Alvira, at the age of 96, of Woodside, Queens. Retired teacher from St. Simon Stock High School, Bronx, NY. Beloved aunt of Rosemarie Doino, Jean and Zen Alexander, Gloria Doino and the late William Doino. Also survived by six grandnephews and niece. Arab-Muslims in Brooklyn are finding power in the voting booth.

Find futuristic funhouses, French-Japanese hybrid cuisine and some of the city's best shwarma in the Marais district.
A look at the varying film roles of Angelina Jolie. Her film “Wanted” is now on DVD.
Since mortgages are so hard to get, buyers are turning to their parents and other relatives to help with down payments and closing costs.

The Tampa Bay Rays are headed to the World Series one year after having the worst record in baseball, becoming the first team since the 1992 Atlanta Braves to advance to the World Series after squandering a three-games-to-one lead in a League Championship Series.
The Tampa Bay Rays are three outs from the World Series after Matt Garza and four relievers kept the Red Sox off the scoreboard in the eighth. They lead, 3-1, through eight.

One of the more amusing videos played at Tropicana Field during the postseason is Bon Jovi's "I Love this Town." It's a montage of Bon Jovi concert footage, Rays highlights, and shots of Evan Longoria and B. J. Upton hamming it up as they lip-synch to the recently released song. It's part of an M.L.B.-wide promotion during the postseason, featuring the Bon Jovi tune.

For New Yorkers and others, "early voting" still means getting up before the polls open on Nov. 4 and being among the first to cast a ballot on Election Day. But by the middle of this week, dozens of states will provide a way for at least some voters to cast their ballots in person before that first Tuesday in November, according to the Pew Center on the States.
Willy Aybar lined a full-count offering from Jon Lester into the left field stands to lead off the bottom of the seventh to extend the Rays' lead to 3-1 through seven.
Luis Soriano takes long treks on his “Biblioburro,” or Donkey Library, to bring books to rural communities in Colombia.

The Rays are hoping to do what only one team has done in a League Championship Series: Win Game 7 after losing Games 5 and 6. The Atlanta Braves did it in 1992, winning Game 7 at home after squandering a 3-1 lead in the series to the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Senator John McCain was in Toledo, Ohio, on Sunday, but not with the man who will forever be known as Joe the Plumber - even though Mr. McCain continued to talk about him at a rally there.
After scoring a run to tie the game in the fourth, the Rays took the lead in the fifth with three consecutive hits.

Red Sox starter Jon Lester was perfect through the first three innings, retiring all nine Rays he faced. But the Rays got on the board in the fourth when Evan Longoria doubled into the right-field corner with one out. Carlos Pena scored all the way from first, sliding under Jason Varitek's tag.

Since they debuted as an expansion team in 1998, the Tampa Bay Rays have grown accustomed to playing in front of large crowds whenever the Red Sox come to town. Often it has seemed like a Red Sox home game, with the majority of fans cheering for Boston.

Angel Hernandez joined the A.L.C.S. umpire crew for Game 7, replacing Derryl Cousins, who left Game 6 with a bruised clavicle sustained while working home plate. It will be the sixth L.C.S. assignment for Hernandez, who will work right field.

I recently bought a MacBook Air so that I could have an ultra lightweight computer for traveling and for days when I need to work outside my home office. Because it's my second computer, I didn't want to spend money on software. Whenever I used it to create documents, I figured I'd just work in "the cloud," meaning that I'd store things on the Internet rather than on the computer's hard drive. I was already a heavy user of Google Docs, a free word-processing application that allows users to easily share documents with other people. So I thought I'd just use that as my word processing program on the new computer. Then I started worrying -- did I really want to rely on being able to get Internet access every time I wanted to work on a document?
Last week's column about the propriety or impropriety of teachers wearing campaign buttons in class provoked many questions, and today I would like to respond to those that were asked most often.

Matt Garza retired the Red Sox in order in the second. He struck out Jason Bay. Mark Kotsay hit a shot up the middle, but shortstop Jason Bartlett was able to range to his left and throw him out. Garza then struck out catcher Jason Varitek.

Don Zimmer, the former Yankees bench coach, threw out the first pitch before Game 7. Zimmer is a senior adviser for the Tampa Bay Rays and is in uniform before games. He wears No. 60 to acknowledge his 60 years in professional baseball.
Just call her Mama Bear.
Dustin Pedroia hit a home run against the Rays' Matt Garza just inside the left-field foul pole in the first inning, giving him three homers in the A.L.C.S. Boston leads, 1-0, after one inning.

With the Red Sox starting the left-hander Jon Lester, Rays Manager Joe Maddon inserted the right-handed Rocco Baldelli into the lineup in right field and the switch-hitting Willy Aybar at designated hitter.
Spend any time inside or outside Tropicana Field and it quickly becomes clear which player is the fan favorite: the rookie third baseman Evan Longoria.

You might think that an economic recession would be bad news for art collectors. With wages sinking and savings evaporating, you might think art lovers would have difficulty expanding their collections.

Daniel Alpert's plan to help homeowners with impaired mortgages, which was the subject of my column on Saturday, received many thoughtful comments. Many readers were as enthusiastic about his plan as I was, but many others raised objections that deserve to be addressed. I asked Mr. Alpert to respond to the critics. Here is what he wrote:I greatly appreciate all the comments and e-mails I received this weekend about the Freedom Recovery Plan (FRP). They reflect considerable thought and attention from respondents from all over the country. It is clear that this is a subject that resonates profoundly and with great emotion. For those who are just coming to this debate now, you can read my detailed description of the plan here. (It's the document on the bottom right.)
Even though it's the biggest sports event to take place in the Tampa Bay area since the Stanley Cup finals in 2004, Game 7 of the A.L.C.S. between the Rays and Boston Red Sox is not a hot ticket.
As expected, Texas took the top spot in the Bowl Championship Series standings, which were released for the first time this season on Sunday night. Here are the top 25; the full breakdown is here.

There have been all sorts of bad feelings, bad vibes and bad thoughts about the results of the recent races and perceived bias towards Ferrari by the International Automobile Federation. But look at today's race. Who could have imagined that Lewis Hamilton would do all that was necessary to win the championship, while Ferrari, Kimi Raikkonen and Felipe Massa would do all that was necessary to prevent Hamilton from winning. And all just at the absolute limit of what was possible - with the final outcome that Hamilton will go to Sao Paulo not on the top of the world, really, but with the exact same points lead that he had last year before Raikkonen took the championship by one point.

Hunched over a carved wooden coffee table in his office, studying drawings of a river relay race that "Survivor" contestants will soon endure, Mark Burnett sounds every bit the acclaimed television producer he is.

The Dutch government said Sunday it will inject 10 billion euros ($13.4 billion) into ING Groep to shore up the bank and insurance company amid market rumors it was running out of capital, The Associated Press reported.

In an effort to shore up domestic banks and keep its markets from sinking further, South Korea announced Sunday that it would guarantee up to $100 billion in foreign debt held by its banks and would pump $30 billion more into the banking sector.

The hugely anticipated appearance on "Saturday Night Live" by the Republican vice presidential nominee, Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, pushed the three-decade-old NBC late-night show to its best overnight ratings in more than 14 years.

AMC has announced that it will broadcast a third season of "Mad Men," its hit drama about a 1960s New York advertising agency, The New York Times reports.

Week 7 of the 2008 season features a number of good games, such as the Chargers at the Bills, the Colts in Green Bay to take on the Packers and the resurgent Browns in Washington to take on th 4-2 Redskins. While we're going to focus on the Giants and 49ers at 1 p.m. and the Jets in Oakland at 4:15 p.m. EDT, I'll be sure to give you the important updates from around the league throughout the day. Senator Barack Obama took his Red State trending Pink-could-be-Blue state tour to Fayetteville State University in North Carolina, where the mood was dance party festive. On the floor before the candidate walked out, audience members practiced synchronized dance steps, to roars from the crowd.

With the Canadiens leading Phoenix by 2-0 last night, in a game they'd ultimately win 4-1, the Coyotes' Kurt Sauer creamed Andrei Kostitsyn into the boards and KO'ed him from the game. On the English-language "Hockey Night in Canada" telecast, the immediate reaction from Bob Cole, Greg Millen and Yvon Pedneault was to repeat a number of times that this was a clean hit without question, and Kostitsyn was caught making one too many moves with his head down.
It wasn't the fact that I still had two-month-old magazines sitting around the apartment, waiting to go to the recycling bin. It was the ad on the back of The New Yorker from Aug. 25 that struck me.

This week's guest blogger is Bonnie Fuller, the C.E.O. of Bonnie Fuller Media. Most recently, Fuller served as vice president and chief editorial director of American Media (Star, Shape, Men's Fitness, Natural Health and Fit Pregnancy) and was previously editor in chief of US Weekly, Glamour, Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire, YM and Flare magazines. In this her final post, Fuller gives her take on the style world's latest parlor game: analyzing where Madonna and her husband, Guy Ritchie, went wrong. But the Val-d'Or Foreurs tied a Quebec Major Junior Hockey League record with their 14th consecutive loss from the start of the season. The report follows.
Brad Isbister joined his 13th pro team in 13 years on Saturday, skating for the first time with EV Zug in the Swiss Nationalliga A -- and accounting for most of his new team's attack.

A new vineyard has joined a growing regional industry serving consumers and tourists.

COLUMBUS, Ohio - While Former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was giving his much-anticipated endorsement Sunday morning to Senator Barack Obama on NBC's "Meet the Press,'' Senator John McCain was across the dial on Fox News Sunday, defending himself in an interview that began with the question: "Aren't you in a world of trouble?"

On "Meet the Press" today, Colin L. Powell concluded his endorsement of Sen. Barack Obama by referring to the death of a Muslim soldier, Kareem Rashad Sultan Khan of Manahawkin, N.J., who was killed in Iraq on Aug. 6, 2007, and whose remains were buried in Arlington.
It was a week of firsts for the New York Red Bulls and Major League Soccer -- incredible and ignominious.

Updated WASHINGTON-Former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell endorsed Senator Barack Obama for president on Sunday morning as a candidate who was reaching out in a "more diverse and inclusive way across our society" and offering a "calm, patient, intellectual, steady approach" to the nation's problems.

Internet | In an essay on blogging and its significance, Andrew Sullivan likens a blog to a ship's log -- in the sense of "moving backward in time as you move forward in pages-the opposite of a book. As you piece together a narrative that was never intended as one, it seems-and is-more truthful." Thanks to blogs, it's "actually a golden era for journalism." [Atlantic]

Sport | With corporate America reeling, its sports skyboxes need a bailout, says Joe Queenan -- for "without constant access to sporting events ... most American men would simply curl up and die. And that wouldn't help the economy one bit." But wait: maybe the tycoons aren't hurting so much. Some still have enough money to play in a secretive fantasy football league where the total purse is $1 million. [Wall Street Journal, here and here]
The Obama campaign announced this morning that it had raised a record $150 million last month, and had added 632,000 new donors to its total.
From The Caucus blog:

Film | Oliver Stone's writing partner on "Wall Street" feels bad that people drew the wrong moral lesson from Gordon ("Greed is good") Gekko: "What I find strange and oddly disturbing is that Gekko has been mythologized and elevated from villain to hero," giving people "hope to become greater asses than they already may be." How true. [Los Angeles Times]
A field goal from Jay Feely tied the game to send it into overtime, but kicker Sebastian Janikowski won the game for the Raiders with a 57-yard field goal.

Religion | Food for Sunday thought: a study by two University of British Columbia psychologists finds religious faith does appear to make people more altruistic. Why? "Being watched by a Big-Brother-in-the-Sky tends to make believers nervous about being selfish." A problem is when groups have different Big Brothers. But we already knew that. [Reason, Science]

Books | Thanks to the meltdown, "Marx is in fashion again," says a publisher in Germany, where sales of "Das Kapital" have more than tripled. "Generally one has to admit that certain parts of Marx's theory are really not so bad," says the finance minister cheerily. So, now that the work is in the public domain, will the profits be collectivized? No. [Guardian, Associated Press]
Lewis Hamilton put himself in prime position to claim the Formula One title this weekend by taking the pole position for the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai.

Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer were knocked out in the semifinals of the Madrid Masters. Nadal was beaten by Gilles Simon, who rallied for a 3-6, 7-5, 7-6 (6) victory. Simon advanced to Sunday’s final against Andy Murray, who stopped Federer, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5, in a rematch of last month’s United States Open final. The results mean that Nadal will finish the year with the No. 1 ranking.

Danny Cepero became the first goalkeeper to score in a Major League Soccer game and Juan Pablo Ángel had two goals to lead the Red Bulls to a 3-1 victory over the Columbus Crew on Saturday night at Giants Stadium. Cepero, who has been with the Red Bulls (10-10-9) for two seasons but never played, started because Jon Conway, the regular goalkeeper, was suspended 10 games for using a banned substance.

Eight course records were set on the first day of the 44th annual Head of the Charles Regatta in Cambridge, Mass. Emma Twig and Juliette Haigh of New Zealand, the winners in the women’s doubles, set a record of 17 minutes 46 seconds over the three-mile upstream course. Gevvie Stone of Newton, Mass., won the women’s single championship 31 years after her parents captured the singles championship.
Alberto Contador of Spain, the winner of the 2007 Tour de France, has confirmed that he will ride for Astana in 2009. Contador’s future had been unclear after Lance Armstrong joined the team.

Venus Williams rallied from a set down to beat Ana Ivanovic, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the final of the Zurich Open. She will face Flavia Pennetta, who defeated Anabel Medina Garrigues, 6-3, 7-6 (6), in the other semifinal. Pennetta is 3-1 against Williams and beat her in the first round in last week’s Ladies Kremlin Cup in Moscow.

Bernhard Langer shot a five-under-par 67 and was tied for the lead after the second round of the Administaff Small Business Classic in the Woodlands, Tex. Langer, Lonnie Nielsen and Brad Bryant were all one shot better than Denis Watson.

Nets center Josh Boone watched but did not participate in Saturday’s practice, a day after he experienced chest discomfort and went to the hospital as a precaution. Boone stayed behind as the team traveled to Boston to play the Celtics in a preseason game. He is scheduled to be evaluated Monday.
Steve Yzerman, the Detroit Red Wings’ vice president, will assemble the Canadian men’s team for the 2010 Vancouver Olympics after being named Canada’s executive director, replacing Wayne Gretzky.
The Giants managed to make fewer mistakes than the San Francisco 49ers in a 29-17 victory in a sloppily played game.

Right after Giants' games and in the days between them, reporters get to ask players and coaches about individual plays and broader strategies. But fans watching from the stands or on television rarely get such a chance. Perhaps that can change.
Nejla Winters Liias and Peter Clayton Orr were married Saturday in Manhattan.
Yankees pitcher Joba Chamberlain has been arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence.

After his scintillating victory in Game 3 of the world championship match in Bonn, Germany, Viswanathan Anand of India, the title holder, played a relatively unambitious opening in Game 4, obtaining only a cosmetic advantage against Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the challenger. The result was a pretty mundane draw, although that was enough to preserve Anand's lead, which now stands at 2.5 to 1.5. More information about the match and the players is on the match Web site.
Channeling 20 years of experience and excellence, the 43-year-old Bernard Hopkins dominated Kelly Pavlik, who was 17 years younger. It was Pavlik’s first defeat in 35 fights.

Gov. Sarah Palin appeared on “Saturday Night Live,” but she left most of the comedic heavy lifting to Tina Fey.
Barack Obama at the Alfred E. Smith dinner in New York City.

Anyone tuning in to "Saturday Night Live" hoping to see side-by-side versions of Gov. Sarah Palin - the real thing and the phony Tina Fey version - may have been disappointed.

Nejla Liias and Peter Orr discuss how a jog together after work turned into an impromptu first date and an all-night bar crawl through Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

According to a report from Paris, Balkan war tensions rose precipitously yesterday when the Turkish Cabinet received word that "the Bulgarian Cabinet was about to resign, and would be succeeded by a council for National defense. This was interpreted as a preliminary move to a declaration of war." Turkey was set to mobilize its troops in Asia Minor and Macedonia. French diplomats, aided by the telegraph, went into action with the result that "Bulgaria has backed down" and "the order for the mobilization was countermanded." Czar Ferdinand of Bulgaria "has evidently won a victory over the war party" but "there is still dread of complications." War Looms, Wanes, All in Three Hours
Texas’ victory was a declaration to the rest of the national title contenders that these Longhorns are rising as quickly as oil prices are dropping.

An article on Feb. 17 about religious tribunals misstated the reason an arbitration before the Texas Islamic Court did not go forward. A Texas appeals court had authorized arbitration before the tribunal in a divorce case, but a lower court there granted a motion to set aside the parties’ arbitration agreement. The arbitration did not fail to proceed because, as a lawyer involved in the appeal had said, the parties could not agree on a panel of arbitrators. The error was pointed out last month in an e-mail message by Rola Qaddura, a party to the case.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Irish playwright Ronan Noone referred incorrectly to Connemara, where Mr. Noone’s hometown, Clifden, is located. It is a region of County Galway, not a county itself.

An entry in the Playlist column last Sunday misstated the surname of the woman who sang “Coffee Grindin’ Blues” on the compilation album “Oh, Run Into Me, but Don’t Hurt Me!” She was Lucille Bogan, not Brown.

A review on Oct. 5 about “Nothing to Be Frightened Of,” a memoir by Julian Barnes, misstated the medium of works by Donatello in which Barnes finds a sense of purpose and belief. It is sculpture, not painting. (Donatello was not a painter.).
Some women fantasize about their weddings from early childhood. Jill Clark was not one of them.

An article last Sunday about a meal cooked at the reporter’s home by the Spanish chef Ferrán Adrià referred incorrectly to Congregation Beth Chaim, a synagogue where the reporter, who is Jewish, sought advice on whether he should eat the meal on Yom Kippur. It is a Reform synagogue, not Reformed. The article also misstated its location. It is in Princeton Junction, N.J., not Princeton.

Queen Latifah doesn’t seem to have any problem whatsoever discussing the details of her personal life — except those related to her sexuality (Alex Witchel, Oct. 5). She opens up about her most intimate feelings as a child but shuts down completely when asked about a romantic life. That she doesn’t see the hypocrisy in that is just plain sad in this day and age. There is much to respect in what Queen Latifah has achieved and what she stands for. Imagine how much more good she could do if she had the courage to be honest with her fans regarding “that part of me.”.

To the Editor: Regarding “Fashionista Paris” (Sept. 28): I have loved fashion since I was a child, so I was eager to connect with Jean-Paul Gaultier after asking the couple from England, “What’s all the buzz about?”.

To the Editor: Readers of “When Weimar Luminaries Went West Coast” (Oct. 5) should seek out “Lost in Paradise: A Journey Through the Los Angeles Homes of European Expatriates During the Nazi Years,” written by Giovanna Franci, with 2006 photographs by Federico Zignani, and published in English and Italian in Bologna by Bononia University Press in 2007.

To the Editor: Regarding “Skirting the Pitfalls of Private Rentals” (Oct. 5): My husband and I have rented vacation properties many times, primarily in Europe. I rent from the Web and rent only properties with many pictures of both the inside and the outside of the building. A good Web site will list local attractions as well as details of the property.

A review on Sept. 21 about “September Songs: The Good News About Marriage in the Later Years” misinterpreted some of the data in a life-expectancy table contained in the book. An average life expectancy at birth of 49.2 years for people born in 1900 would mean that for all persons of that time, the average number of years lived would be less than 50, not that “those who made it to adulthood usually succumbed before reaching 50.” (Of those who survived childhood, a high proportion lived past 50 and many for much longer.).

An article in some copies last Sunday about Senator John McCain’s criticism of Senator Barack Obama for his association with William Ayers, a founder of the Weather Underground, misspelled the given name of a political scientist who said Mr. Ayers was a potent symbol. He is Darrell West, not Darrel.

An article on May 11 about Senator Barack Obama and Chicago politics misspelled the given name of a member of the radical Weather Underground of the 1960s whom Mr. Obama’s aides said he met in 1995 at a meet-and-greet held in her home. She is Bernardine Dohrn, not Bernadine. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

The “Living In” article last Sunday about Canarsie, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to an assertion by Jean-Paul Ho, a real estate agent, about the regional origin of many homeowners who were in financial difficulty because they had been the targets of predatory lenders. He was speaking only of immigrants from the Caribbean, not also of immigrants from China and Russia. The article also misstated the end point of the L subway line. It is Rockaway Parkway, not Rockaway Avenue.

Your breakthrough role was in “The Dreamers,” in 2003, which was directed by Bernardo Bertolucci. It was the story of a ménage à trois set in Paris in 1968. In America, it was rated NC-17 due to the amount of sex and nudity. How did you and Bertolucci find each other?.

louche / (loosh) / adj. / Newly relevant Gallicism, now that Parisian-inflected decadence and questionable morality are making a powerful return to fashion, e.g., “Her Serge Gainsbourg look-alike boyfriend is the perfect accessory for that divinely louche Balmain minidress.”.

The Harlequins and Columbines, the lovers clad in silk knee breeches and luminous satin gowns — whoever the people in Jean-Antoine Watteau’s paintings may be, they are so far from anyone we know, inhabiting some sylvan park light-years from the world in which we live, that we can surely be forgiven for greeting Jed Perl’s claim that Watteau is his favorite painter with suspicion. In 2008? Is this some kind of pose he has adopted in defiance of his fellow critics and their embrace of artists whose work is more contemporary, more patently relevant to our times? But in “Antoine’s Alphabet: Watteau and His World” (Alfred A. Knopf), Perl’s affection for Watteau turns out to be genuine and contagious in a series of meditations, organized alphabetically. This book is that rare instance of a gifted writer opening a window on a world most readers never knew existed, giving us the benefit of ruminations that span many years. Perl’s insights send us back to Watteau’s work, and as a result of his enthusiasm, we see more.

The Samurai Shopper is in a snit: some ink-stained bureaucrat tampered with the English translation of Marcel Proust’s “À la Recherche du Temps Perdu,” in which a guy sniffs a goodie and cranks out seven volumes of deathless prose. Imagine if Twinkies were involved. Formerly called “Remembrance of Things Past” — a snippet of Shakespeare’s — Proust’s epic became “In Search of Lost Time.” Letter-perfect, yes, but its spirit has been crushed in the wood chipper of literalism. And searching for lost time is a fool’s errand. Better to enjoy some aiguillettes de homard à la truffe noir. Or a hot dog even.
Sophie Calle is a reckless provocateur, a woman who mines the most intimate moments in life, even the death of her mother. Is this art?

This month, the Musée de la Musique will pay a long-overdue tribute to Serge Gainsbourg. Curated by the sound stylist Frédéric Sanchez, the exhibition, which opens this week and runs through March 1, aims to rehabilitate Gainsbourg’s reputation as an artist whose approach to music — sampling, remixing, using found text — was at once in tune with his times and well ahead of it.
For Catherine Malandrino and her gang, it’s a movable feast.
For Gallic-bred expats and tourists, sharing a sidewalk table or a glass of Bordeaux with friends.
When it comes to haircuts and pedicures, Frenchwomen are all secrets and lies. Janine Di Giovanni tattles.
Elegant trash is the specialty du jour at Balmain, where Christophe Decarnin has become the “It” designer for pretty young things.

The French are historically hostile to eccentrics — they’re scared of them. Still, they’re inclined to make an exception for a spectacular example like Madeleine Castaing. For more than 50 years, her Paris neighborhood, St.-Germain-des-Prés, where she lived and worked as a dealer, decorator, art patron and collector, lowered its guard long enough to embrace her flamboyant style and transgressive fashion. At the height of her dotage, Castaing was viewed as part of the quarter’s cultural heritage, a living monument whom you acknowledged with a small bow as you turned sideways on the sidewalk to let her pass. A new biography, the first on Castaing, and a new documentary deconstruct the baffling, if not to say clownish, facade.

For 150 years, Boucheron seduced maharajahs, Middle Eastern princesses, czarinas and Old Hollywood icons with its menagerie of precious creepy-crawlies — diamond snakes, emerald owls and chameleons galore. Until recently, it was an insider thing. V.I.P.’s would visit its clubby Paris headquarters or they’d fly the collection in for a private viewing. To reach today’s young stars and royalty, Boucheron is taking its show on the road. Spiegelworld, the traveling cabaret, is extending its production of “Désir,” a show inspired by Boucheron that played during fashion week in New York. The setting, fittingly, is a velvet-draped tent that’s more jewel box than big top. And you can shop right there or at select Neiman Marcus stores. Go to spiegelworld.com for sites. [?][?][?]SHYAMA PATEL.

In the vampire picture “The Hunger,” Catherine Deneuve’s character acts as a Fountain of Youth; by mixing her blood with her lover’s, she prevents their growing old, at least for a while. If only it could be that simple! When it comes to the topic of aging, Deneuve is known for saying (to quote loosely), “You choose either your face or your fanny.” We put this theory to the test on some of her countrywomen. [?][?][?]KATHLEEN EGAN.

Caudalie is a skin-care line best suited for fans of the good life: it was founded in Bordeaux on the philosophy that the grape has medicinal powers. At Caudalie spas, which are set in lush vineyards in Europe, visitors get sloughed with crushed grapes, soak in wine-barrel hot tubs and wash it all down with a glass of Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte. This fall, vinotherapy arrives in Manhattan with the opening of the 8,000-square-foot Caudalie spa in the Plaza Hotel. While there are no vines to be found at this location — the closest fresh fruit is at Whole Foods three blocks away — there are 15 treatment rooms in which to experience the Pulp Friction massage or be wrapped in honey and wine. But perhaps most exciting for the truly sybaritic: it will be the first spa in the city to feature an in-house sommelier. [?][?][?]AMY LAROCCA.

1. Carita is synonymous with a certain kind of French beauty (Juliette Gréco, Polly Maggoo), so to celebrate more than 60 years of success, the company has introduced Perfect Gold Serum, the 24-karat answer to aging. $340. 11, rue du Faubourg St.-Honoré.

Mauboussin’s lavishly appointed new Madison Avenue shop offers much more than diamonds. The five-story town house, designed by the Rockwell Group, has a floor for the Parisian jeweler’s “lifestyle” bijoux, another dedicated to more serious bling, a bridal salon, a chocolate atelier (clients can try on sparkly confections while sampling edible ones) and a penthouse where the company will hold monthly dinners whipped up by the Michelin three-star chef Yannick Alléno. This superchic superstore is proof that these days a simple breakfast at Tiffany’s isn’t enough. (714 Madison Avenue; 212-752-4300; mauboussin.com) [?][?][?]SANDRA BALLENTINE.
Catherin Deneuve on the iconic trench coat.

In Julian Schnabel’s film “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” Céline, played by Emmanuelle Seigner, sits faithfully at the bedside of the father of her children, Jean-Dominique Bauby, editor of French Elle. Once a bon vivant and serious playboy, Bauby now has locked-in syndrome, a condition that has left him unable to move anything but his left eyelid. In the film, beautiful women come and go. But a mysterious character known only as Inès, for whom Bauby had left Céline, never visits. She is only imagined: a selfish woman who can’t bear her lover’s illness.

After nearly 10 years dealing high-end design from Paris’s gritty 13th Arrondissement — which they helped transform into an enclave for up-and-coming galleries — Didier and Clémence Krzentowski have moved Galerie Kreo into more glamorous quarters. At their new 17th-century landmark building in St.-Germain-des-Prés, they’ll have twice as much room to show pieces by the likes of Marc Newson and the Bouroullec brothers. Despite the posh address, the Krzentowskis haven’t lost their edge entirely. They’ve gutted the new space (previously a nightclub called Ruby’s) in favor of concrete floors, exposed metal beams and remnants of the building’s original archway. “A lot of other galleries are so hermetic, with white walls and floors,” Didier says. “Here you feel the past when you enter.” [?][?][?]MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Designer cellphones aren’t a novel concept, but the new Dior Phone has a bit more panache than its predecessors. The fancy new flip phone bears the brand’s signature cross-hatching and comes with a matching Bluetooth-enabled mini-phone that you can hide in your hand (or hook to your Croisette, the house’s latest must-have handbag). Ranging from $5,100 for the sapphire crystal model (above) to a whopping $27,000 for a diamond-encrusted version, the phones hit Dior boutiques this month. Now, if only Carla Bruni-Sarkozy would croon the ring tone. [?][?][?]SANDRA BALLENTINE.

A star model of the 1980s, the former director of Jean Paul Gaultier’s couture studio, an official witness to the Bruni-Sarkozy wedding: Farida Khelfa’s résumé is not typical for an indie actress. But her topsy-turvy rise through the fashion ranks — she was a muse to the photographer Jean-Paul Goude and a favorite of Azzedine Alaïa — has in fact been the perfect way to hone her chops. “Fashion and acting are not completely different,” says Khelfa, who next appears in the French comedy “Le Petit Prince.” “After all, they are both about image.” As a young clotheshorse, Khelfa was famous for her colorful flea-market finds. Now she admits that age has taken a pricey toll on her sartorial choices. “Most of the time I wear prêt-à-porter but de luxe.” [?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

1. Not many stores can claim to have inspired a book by Émile Zola. Or boast a 344,000-square-foot glass-and-steel structure engineered by Gustave Eiffel. According to Christine Chapellu, who, along with Régine Beraud, heads up the women’s fashion buying team: “Our clients don’t even like department stores. They not only come to shop, but they come to wander around, take in art exhibitions and literary workshops and generally discover beautiful things.”.
