Jon Gertner (Oct. 5) fails to make explicit the crucial role of oft-derided government regulation in harnessing private enterprise for public good. Public policy can anticipate societal needs not detected by economic forces. Venture-capital firms with green-tech funds like Kleiner Perkins serve a valuable role, but must provide short-term (5- to 10-year) returns in an economy in which the benefits of those investments will be long-term. (Paradoxically, part of the bet of green-tech investment is that government policy, like a carbon tax, will catch up to societal needs.) In the coming decades, it might turn out that doing the most good will be manifestly more important than maximizing return on investment and that waiting for the market to respond to the need for action will mean waiting too long. paul flikkema.

Survived by his wife Shirley, son John, grandchildren Justin and Ashley, brother Jack, niece Paige Peck, other nieces and nephews, and daughter-in-law Linda Willig. Will be remembered by his family and many friends at Blakehurst for his smile, his happy nature, and his great sense of humor. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

WALKING THROUGH THE LORRAINE AMERICAN CEMETERY AND MEMORIAL, NEAR ST.-AVOLD, FRANCE, Aug. 17, 2008: Bruce Lowry, 56, a tax attorney from Seattle, with his wife, Kathy, a retired economics professor. ''I was there on business. We had been the day before at Metz, and we were just driving to Luxembourg and it was time for lunch so we pulled over. On the way in to this little French town called St.-Avold, we saw a sign that said 'American cemetery.' We stopped in on a whim, and it turns out there are more Americans buried there from the Second World War than any other place in Europe. It was a beautiful day, and as we walked out of the chapel toward the cemetery, there's a clock, and it chimed 2. Neither of us had lost relatives in the war, but the place was just so quiet, and when that clock chimed, you couldn't help but think that all these young people -- even now I get choked up a bit -- time stopped for them at that point. It was very peaceful, and this clear chiming of the clock was very appropriate somehow. We were looking out over this sea of crosses, and it was just really quite overwhelming.'' As told to J. R. Romanko
Film Mike Hale

A review on Sept. 21 about ''September Songs: The Good News About Marriage in the Later Years'' misinterpreted some of the data in a life-expectancy table contained in the book. An average life expectancy at birth of 49.2 years for people born in 1900 would mean that for all persons of that time, the average number of years lived would be less than 50, not that ''those who made it to adulthood usually succumbed before reaching 50.'' (Of those who survived childhood, a high proportion lived past 50 and many for much longer.) In addition, the review repeated the book's misstatement of childhood mortality rates in the early 1900s. Around 1900, fewer than 20 percent of the children born in the United States died before the age of 5, not ''half of all children.''

THERE is a bitter feud going on between two unlikely rivals: Nissan and Porsche. Over a span of several months earlier this year, the Nürburgring Nordschleife, the 14-mile road circuit in the lush Eifel mountains of Germany, was the scene of aggressive attempts by a handful of automakers to claim the unofficial honor of fastest time by a road car. The Dodge Viper ACR was the fastest with a time of 7 minutes and 22 seconds. The Corvette ZR1 was second at 7:26.

LARKIN--Racelle, died peacefully on October 2 at her home in Bridgehampton, NY, after a long illness, surrounded by her husband and children. She was 80 years old. Racelle was raised in Brooklyn, the daughter of Harry Kessler and the former Marlye Rothstein, and attended the High School of Music and Art. She went on to study at Brooklyn College, Syracuse University, Hunter College and the Columbia University School of Painting and Sculpture, where she earned her bachelor's degree in Fine Arts. As Racelle Strick, she had her first solo exhibition of paintings at the Rose Fried Gallery in New York in 1966. She also showed frequently at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton where she summered, beginning in 1968. In the 1970s, Racelle exhibited her work at 55 Mercer and the SoHo Center for Visual Artists. In the 1980s she showed at the Anita Shapolsky Gallery and Haber/Theodore, both in Manhattan, as well as at Dowling College in Oakdale, NY. In addition, she participated in many group shows, at Franklin Furnace, American Abstract Artists in Westbeth, the Portland Museum of Art, the Corpus Christi Museum, the Baltimore Museum, and the Jewish Museum in New York, among others. Racelle's work is represented in the NYU Art Collection, MoMA Lending Services, and many private collections. For over 30 years, she divided her time between Manhattan and Bridgehampton, eventually moving to Bridgehampton in 1998 with her husband Peter Larkin, the noted Broadway and Hollywood production designer. In addition to her husband, Racelle is survived by her two children from her previous marriage, Ivy Hamlin of Forest Hills, and Wesley Strick of Los Angeles, her brother, Alan Kessler, of Bedford Hills, NY, and five grandchildren and two nieces who adored her. A graveside service was held for Mrs. Larkin on October 3 at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY. Contributions in Racelle Larkin's memory may be made to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978, and the Dominican Sisters Family Health Service, P.O. Box 209, Hampton Bays, NY 11946.

TODAY, Americans save less andearn a lower minimum wage -- inreal, or inflation-adjusted, terms-- than at nearly any other time since1950. Can voters reasonably expectthese and other indicators to changesignificantly after a new presidenttakes office in January?As important as the economymay be for voters when they go tothe polls, many economists contendthat presidents have little power overgeneral economic performance duringtheir terms of office, even though somethings, like the minimum wage, are setby the government.David Backus, an economist at NewYork University, recently wrote onthe blog of the economist N. GregoryMankiw that while presidents mightcontribute to long-term performance,the normal ups and downs of thebusiness cycle had more of an effecton the economy in the short term.''There's some debate about wherebusiness cycles come from, but thepresident's actions are rarely on thelist,'' he wrote. Changes in incomes,jobs and home prices reflect this cyclicalbehavior, while other indicators,like personal savings as a percentageof disposable income, have shown agradual decline over decades. If thereis a president to praise -- or blame --for longer-term trends, he is probablynot in office now.Kevin Feltes, associate director ofthe Jerome Levy Forecasting Centerin Mount Kisco, N.Y., said that the nextpresident would most likely be reactingto the economy -- not the other wayaround.''Given the current condition of theeconomy, the next president could verywell end up running trillions of dollarsin federal deficits over the next severalyears,'' he said, ''whether he likes itor not.''

FROM the looks of the spring and fall fashion shows, eyebrows are in for an extreme makeover. Simple grooming is no longer sufficient. Either they're big and bold, as they were at Prada (right), or bleached to oblivion, as on Louis Vuitton's spring runway (below). ''Both are dynamic looks for the season,'' said the makeup artist Pat McGrath, who created the two styles. ''But they can be tricky to wear.'' So what is one to do? Go easy. ''As a general rule, I like to lighten dark brows a couple shades to open the face and give a brighter appearance,'' Ms. McGrath said, adding that brushing a blond-tone brow gel, or a concealer in a lighter shade, through the brow with a clean mascara wand would temporarily do the trick. ''With pale brows, I prefer to make them a little stronger by feathering with a pencil throughout. I use two shades, one matching and one slightly darker.'' Southern California and Ohio State, the teams at the center of the preseason debate about the Bowl Championship Series title, tumbled out of the conversation after September losses. But don't look now -- the Trojans and the Buckeyes may be playing their way back into a title shot. No. 12 Ohio State (7-1) routed No. 20 Michigan State, 45-7, on Saturday. It can take control of the Big Ten race with a home victory next week against No. 3 Penn State, which looked shaky before pulling away for a 46-17 win over Michigan.

WILLIAMS--Lois Kuchman, loving wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, passed away on October 17, 2008 after bravely confronting Parkinson's Disease for many years. Lois, an only child, was born April 1, 1928, in St. Albans, Queens, New York to Jennie and Harold H. Kuchman. She graduated from Manhasset High School in 1945, and from The University of Rochester in 1949. While at The University of Rochester, Lois met her husband and the love of her life, James B. Williams. Lois and Jim were married on July 30, 1949, in Manhasset, New York, and recently celebrated their 59th wedding anniversary. Together they lived in Garden City, New York, and York, Pennsylvania before moving to Dallas, Texas in 1955. While dedicating her life to her husband and children, Lois was also involved in many local activities and organizations. She was a member of the Dallas Womens Club, The Dallas Garden Club, The Village Gardeners, The Heritage Club, The Calliope Club, TriClub, The Theta Mothers Club, The Crystal Charity Ball Committee, Discussion Group ''C'' Sunday School Class at Highland Park Presbyterian Church, and HPPC Women of the Church. Lois was known and admired for her devotion to her family, her friends, her church, and her community. She is survived by her loving husband, James Bowman Williams, her five children, Linda Williams Rush and husband Robert H. Rush of Frankfort, Kentucky; James Bowman Williams, Jr. and wife Mary R. Williams of San Antonio; Cynthia Williams Beecherl and husband Louis A. Beecherl, III of Dallas; Jayne Williams Bass and husband W. David Bass of Dallas; and Margaret Williams Kuykendall and husband Marshall E. Kuykendall of Austin; her grandchildren, Cynthia R. Yeiser and husband Jordan, Robert Rush, Campbell Williams and wife Anne, Alan Williams and wife Amanda, Bowman Williams, Arthur Beecherl, Rebecca Beecherl, Ben Beecherl, Edward Beecherl, Nancy Bass, Wade Bass, Jim Bass, Henry Bass, Wylie Kuykendall, and Jennie Kuykendall; and by greatgrandson Campbell Williams. The family gratefully acknowledges the wonderful care given by caregivers Virginia Hunter and Sharon Sinclair, and for the excellent care provided by the staff of Faith Presbyterian Hospice. A Memorial Service celebrating her life will be held on Monday, October 20 at 2pm in the Sanctuary of Highland Park Presbyterian Church with Rev. Dr. Ronald W. Scates and Rev. Dr. Sherwood M. Strodel officiating. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Highland Park Presbyterian Church Foundation, 3821 University Blvd., Dallas, TX 75205, or Faith Presbyterian Hospice, 6100 Colwell Blvd., Ste. 225, Irving, TX 75039.

STIMULUS After meeting with the heads of nine major financial institutions, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. announced that the government would inject up to $250 billion directly into banks in return for ownership stakes, to guarantee some of their debts and to expand deposit insurance. RESPONSE: BUY! The action, meant to thaw out credit markets so customers would do business with banks without fear that the banks could fail, elated a stock market reeling from its worst week since 1933. The Dow Jones industrial average posted its biggest single-day percentage gain in 75 years. But there were few signs of loosening in the fear-choked world money markets.

WITH feathers being in, and necklaces now the size of lobster bibs, the jewelry designer Doug Abraham is having a major moment. ''I've been working with feathers for I don't know how long,'' he said. ''White, black, brown, peacock ... I've always liked a big, messy, feathery necklace.'' And he is having a hard time keeping his latest collection -- a gothic grouping of suede, lace and ravenlike feathers -- in store. Carine Roitfeld, Fabiola Beracasa and Vanessa Traina are a few fashion gluttons who have bought one. ''I think people like that it's a whole outfit,'' he said. ''You put it on with a dress, or even jeans and a T-shirt, and you're done.'' Feather necklaces, $420 to $560 at Bess, 292 Lafayette Street (between Prince and Houston Streets); (212) 219-0723.

GIVEN today's chaotic state of affairs, a return to regimented clothing would seem rather fitting. Certainly it would explain the rise of military jackets, which appeared on this season's runways (Alexander McQueen, Givenchy) and next spring's (Balmain, Chris Benz) -- and on chic French starlets like Clémence Poésy (left), who wore a vintage Balenciaga to the house's spring show. But fashion nowadays is complicated. Influences are myriad; and politics are only partly responsible for the Sgt. Pepper revival. ''I think it has a lot to do with the '80s,'' said the stylist Keegan Singh. ''I went to Versailles when I was in Paris and saw Jeff Koons's ceramic sculpture of Michael Jackson with Bubbles. The next day I went to the Balmain show. Those jackets are very M. J.'' Or very Madonna in ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' which Christophe Decarnin of Balmain actually cited as his inspiration.

TESLA MOTORS, the fledgling maker of electric sports cars, admitted last week that it was losing money and in a ''critical phase'' financially. An undisclosed number of Tesla's 250 employees will be laid off and its Detroit-area office will be shut down. Further delays and setbacks for the company's production and growth plans were also announced. In a blog posting on the company's Web site, Elon Musk, Tesla's chief investor, described the moves as ''a modest reduction in near-term headcount'' at the company's San Carlos, Calif., headquarters and a consolidation of satellite operations.

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES I was trying out a new medication because my chronic headaches had become much worse again after a nine-month period in which, thanks to acupuncture, they had gotten much better. With acupuncture, I'd been able to lower my dosage of amitriptyline, an old tricyclic antidepressant now used to help manage migraines, by a third, and had, at the same time, reduced the frequency of my headaches by more than half.

JACOBS--Father Peter a high profile and controversial Catholic priest, passed away Sunday September 7th in Rome. The cause of death was a heart attack. Fr. ''Jake'' Jacobs was born on February 10, 1926, to a Jewish father and an Irish Catholic mother. Father Jacobs developed a lifelong affinity for Jewish religious thought and was an advocate for better relations between Catholics and Jews. His 53 years as a priest was marked by limitless generosity and dedication toward the youth, firefighters, prisoners, politicians and royalty. In 1960 he moved to NYC where he continued his true service of a much more unorthodox nature, and he dedicated his life to serving prisoners, the sick and indigent, often taking confessions in bars and other non-traditional locations. In 1982 Fr. Jacobs opened a restaurant in NYC called The Palatine, which became an instant hit. In the early 1990's he resided in Italy, maintaining close ties with the Vatican in Rome, and living in Venice near close friend Arrigo Cipriani. In March 1996 he received the D'Oro Award from the Boy's Town of Italy. In 2005, a party held at Da Silvano to honor his 50th anniversary as a priest and his 80th birthday was attended by many of his longtime associates, including Dr. Alan Kessler, Mr. Walter Cronkite, Mr. Edgar Bronfman Jr. and Yoko Ono. He is survived by two nephews, niece and second cousin, Deborah Jacobs. He will be sorely missed by those whose lives he touched so deeply and unconditionally.

OSEROFF--Allan R., M.D. Ph.D. October 16, 2008, a giving man very much devoted to his work and family. He was the cherished husband of Stephanie Pincus, and is survived by his children Matthew, Tamara, and Ben; his grandchildren Noah and Jonah; and his nephews Michael and David. Allan was the Chair of Dermatology at the University of Buffalo, as well as at the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, where the Castellani Family Chair was established in his honor. A graduate of Princeton (A.B.), Harvard (Ph.D), and Yale (M.D.), he was a physician and scientist internationally recognized for the photodynamic treatment of skin cancer. Never one to accept credit, even when it was due, Allan was known by all for his gentle humor. Allan's limitless kindness and profound thoughtfulness will be dearly missed. Graveside services will be held at Forest Lawn Cemetery (Delaware Ave. Entrance) Sunday at noon. A memorial in Allan's honor is scheduled for the 19th of December at the Roswell Park Cancer Institute. Donations may be made to Roswell Park Cancer Institute's Alliance Foundation at Elm and Carlton, Buffalo, NY 14263 in honor of Dr. AlIan Oseroff.

Before the typical studio banter at the start of halftime of the Georgia Tech-Clemson game on Saturday, the ESPN host Rece Davis yielded the microphone to Lou Holtz for an awkward apology. Without being specific, Holtz said he was sorry for a comment he had made in reference to Michigan Coach Rich Rodriguez. On Friday, Holtz mentioned Hitler while making a point about good and bad leadership during a discussion of the struggles of Rodriguez, the Wolverines' first-year coach. An online search revealed that Holtz had said that ''Hitler was a great leader, too.''

SCOTT--Lt. Col. Clark S., a 33 year career Air Force intelligence officer who was considered a military expert on the political-economic affairs of the Middle East, died in Denver on October 9, 2008. He was 87. The University of Denver granted Lt. Col. Scott a BA degree in economics in 1949. He later completed advanced studies in Middle Eastern affairs and Arabic at the University of Michigan and Georgetown University. During WWII, Lt. Col. Scott received the Distinguished Flying Cross medal while serving as an air crew member with 15 missions over Germany and France. He was awarded other medals of note during his career, including six Air Medals, the Air Force Commendation medal, and the Republic of Vietnam Gallantry Cross. Lt. Col. Scott was a skilled ROTC instructor, adroit diplomat, and an outstanding worldwide intelligence analyst. He developed these qualities as a Flight Commander with the 6911th Radio Group, Wheelus AFB, Libya; an assistant Professor of Aerospace Studies at the University of Iowa; Military Attache attached to the American embassy in Jidda, Saudi Arabia; Staff Officer SAC Headquarters, Offutt AFB, Omaha; Deputy Director of Intelligence 7th Air Force, Saigon; and Chief of the Air Force Intelligence Training Center, Lowry AFB, Denver. Lt. Col. Scott is survived by his wife, Elberta L. Scott, and three children: Lt. Col (Ret) Steven R. Scott, Jacqueline B. Scott, and John M. Scott.

FOX--Terry. We mourn the loss of Terry Fox who died on October 14th at the age of 65 in Cologne, Germany. A performance, video, and conceptual artist, based in San Francisco and then working in Europe, Terry was as natural an artist as there ever was. Music was extracted, released from the most unexpected, yet perfectly chosen, places. Language and images move fluidly through the long history of creativity to rest in the ever elusive present which his art so gently evokes. Terry, with his beloved Marita Loosen, touched us all. Paule Anglim and Ed Gilbert of Gallery Paule Anglim, San Francisco Frayda and Ronald Feldman and the staff of Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, Inc.

Over the last century, a retirement portfolio of 100 percent stock has out-performed bond or stock-bond mixed portfolios in all but three years: 1932, 1941 and -- unsurprisingly -- this year so far. Stocks are the better bet, clearly, but the real winners are those workers who are able to tap into those retirement funds at market peaks, like 1999, when the rate of return on stocks was at 10 percent. Workers who retire this year are not quite so fortunate.

SUTIN--Hillard A. (1915-2008), Hillard A. Sutin of Albany, New York passed peacefully at the age of 93 on October 12, 2008 at The Daughters of Sarah Nursing Home surrounded by his loving family. Hillard was born in Albany, NY to Fannie and Morris Sutin in 1915, the youngest of six children. He attended Albany High School (1933), graduated from The University of Michigan School of Mechanical Engineering (1937), and he was a member of the Tau Beta Pi Engineering Honorary Society. He worked as Chief Mechanical Engineer in New York City and then in Philadelphia for Ingersoll Rand on defense-related contracts. With the start of the war, he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps as an Aircraft Engineering Officer, repairing and maintaining military aircraft in Burma, India. After two years, he was reassigned to the Air Transport Command in Washington D.C., where as the Executive Officer, he oversaw the 45,000 personnel throughout the world assigned to the Maintenance Engineering Division. Hillard achieved the rank of Major and was honorably discharged in 1946. After almost four years in service of this country, Hillard moved to Albany and worked briefly as an engineer at Albany Castings Company in Voorheesville. He then moved to Rochester, where he was a partner in M.J. Fitzsimmons Manufacturing Corporation and shortly thereafter, he wed Ann Bakrow of Rochester (1946). Later, he partnered with Linsley Fischer to form Standard Supply Hardware Corporation, which he sold in 1960. Hillard then returned to Albany to work for his brother William, the owner Cromwell Printery. Following the sale of Cromwell, Hillard founded Capitol Microfilm Services Inc. in Schenectady, which serviced many needs of General Electric and the company became one of the largest microfilm production houses in the tri-state area. Hillard sold his business in 1982 to enter retirement. Although Hillard's passion was his family and friends, he also enjoyed reading, playing tennis and bridge, and volunteering for charitable causes. Although well into his retirement years, Hillard continued to learn new skills, including use of the internet to learn about history, politics, and business. Hillard is survived by his loving children, Judith A. Sutin, M.D. of Buffalo, NY and Ken Sutin, M.D. of New York, NY, and his nieces and nephews. Interment was held on Wednesday morning at the Temple Beth Emeth Cemetery in Loudonville, NY. In lieu of flowers, kindly consider donations to the University of Michigan School of Engineering. To sign the online family guest book please visit, www.levinememorial chapel.com.

Girls with blond braids circled boys in jewel-colored Slavic costumes in a Bosnian folk dance. A man from the Ivory Coast, in a blue robe and skullcap, sang a haunting melody. An Egyptian dancer whirled in circles, his upper body serene, his bright red skirt wafting outward as he spun, his feet tapping madly beneath it.All were Muslim New Yorkers, performing the other night at the annual celebration of the Muslim holiday Id al-Fitr at the City Council chamber in New York's City Hall. Above them, time-darkened ceiling panels spelled out ideals of American government: "Equal and exact justice to all men of whatever state or persuasion - Jefferson."

(Too often, this process is called "clean coal" technology; I've proposed a new name, "cool coal," to distinguish it from established methods for scrubbing directly harmful pollution, such as sulfur dioxide, from emissions.) WideOrbit, developer of advertising management software, has raised $9.5 million in the first installment of a fourth round of funding, led by Mayfield Ventures, peHUb reported, citing a regulatory filing.

Federal prosecutors from three jurisdictions have stepped up their investigations into the collapse of the investment bank Lehman Brothers, issuing at least a dozen subpoenas including one to the chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., The New York Times's Ben White reported, citing people close to the matter.

General Motors, looking to raise cash as sales slump in the United States, said it had started distributing financial information to potential buyers of its Hummer Sport Utility Vehicle Unit, Bloomberg News reported.
A tightening economy has led another retailer in bankruptcy to shut down its operations.
Nothing makes lawyers more popular than bad times, according to The New York Times's Jonathan D. Glater.

Politics | Newsweek's cover article ponders "how a President Obama might govern a center-right nation," but of course neither the writer nor anybody else knows. The piece does offer lessons of history: "it tells us that Democratic presidents from F.D.R. to J.F.K. to L.B.J. to Carter to Clinton usually wind up moving farther right than they thought they ever would, or they pay for their continued liberalism at the polls." [Newsweek]

The presidential race grabs the headlines, but it is hardly the only contest that matters for the future of energy and climate policy. With the aid of many sources, we have compiled a list of energy-related Congressional races around the country. Particular thanks to Jennifer Duffy of the Cook Political Report.

In the video below, CNBC reports anew on New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to put small, rooftop wind turbines on top of buildings throughout Manhattan - an idea that has received some critical analysis from Green Inc.'s Kate Galbraith and The Times' Metro reporters before.

This week, John Steele Gordon, the author of "An Empire of Wealth: The Epic History of American Economic Power" answered selected readers' questions about the history of wealth in New York. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.

Giants fans are welcome to share their thoughts on the team's shaky victory over the Niners. The Times's Giants beat writer, Joe Lapointe, is asking readers to submit questions in the comments section below. He will then take the best of them to the Giants' facility Monday for his interviews.

Jay Glazer of FoxSports.com reported Sunday morning that Brett Favre gave the Lions a lengthy scouting report on Green Bay's offensive schemes before the Lions-Packers game in Week 2. The story was based on anonymous sources. Favre strongly denied the report, according to Peter King of SI.com, who reported that a Lions executive, Tom Lewand, also called the report false.

Pictures posted on Panama Investor Blog show construction progressing rapidly on the Trump Ocean Club, one of the bellwether residential towers in Panama City. "Looks like much of the parking garage is completed and soon they will start on the hotel, casino and apartments," Sam Taliaferro reports.

Geography | A nifty map graphic shows a new waterway between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans being created by Arctic melting "before our eyes." This is "akin in historic significance to the opening of the Suez Canal, in 1869, or its Panamanian cousin, in 1914." It means access to new energy resources and "a recalibration of geo-strategic power." [Atlantic]

India | A tricky new role for the well-spoken folks at Indian call centers: phoning Americans and politely asking them to pay up. As the financial crisis plunges Americans into debt, collection "is one of the fastest-growing sectors in Indian outsourcing." Because the world is flat, broke. [Washington Post]

Russia | The financial crisis and collapse of oil prices look sure to worsen long-term trends in Russia like a declining population and grim mortality rates. But, in the short term at least, Vladimir Putin is still quite flush, so look what else is happening: he's only too happy to oblige Russian oligarchs with bailouts -- in return for state control. [Bloomberg, Washington Post]

Some "big men on Wall Street" - Charles M. Schwab, John W. Gates, Isaac Guggenheim and John F. Carroll - testified yesterday that they had been hit in "Charles W. Morse's ice operations." Morse, who had controlled the National Bank of North America, now in liquidation, is on trial in United States District Court on charges of violating National banking laws. The testimony, concerning positions taken in the stock of the American Ice Company by a pool of investors, was introduced "as tending to show how Mr. Morse had manipulated the stock on which he had allowed large loans to be made" by the bank. Marc Turnesa completed a wire-to-wire victory for his first PGA Tour title, closing with a four-under-par 68 to hold off Matt Kuchar by a stroke at the Justin Timberlake Shriners Hospitals for Children Open in Las Vegas. Turnesa became the eighth rookie to win on the tour this season.

Venus Williams won the Zurich Open on Sunday for her second singles title of the season. Williams beat Flavia Pennetta, 7-6 (1), 6-2, to take the tournament she last won in 1999. The victory should seal the 28-year-old Williams’s place at the season-ending WTA Tour Championship next month in Doha, Qatar.

Red Giant and Tropic Storm were declared out of their respective Breeders’ Cup races. Red Giant, a 4-year-old colt, was one of the favorites in the $2 million Turf next weekend at Santa Anita in California. He did not finish his feed from the previous night and had a high temperature Sunday. The trainer Craig Dollase said Tropic Storm was out because of a soft tissue injury. Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a new school in Wyoming that will teach students in Arapaho in hope of preserving the language described similar schools in Hawaii incorrectly. They are native Hawaiian language schools; they are not Indian immersion schools like ones in Wyoming, Montana and New York.

THE STREETS ''Everything Is Borrowed'' (Vice) Has haplessness figured in the work of any popular musician more than the British rapper Mike Skinner? As the Streets, he's been a poet laureate of lost nights and missed opportunities, his songs proud chronicles of emptiness. Often he has appeared to be checking in from somewhere outside the song itself, both in his absent tone and his lack of interest in adhering to conventional rhyme structures.

TERSHAKOVEC--Vasyl (Basil) Loving husband of Mary, adored father of Anya Tomko and Alexandra Zawadiwsky, and dear grandfather, died on October 17, 2008, with love for life and family until the end. He will be remembered for the joy he brought to everyone. A truly exceptional and charming man now rests with God. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Ukrainian Chorus Dumka of New York. A wake will be held on Tuesday, October 21st at 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Union Funeral Home--Lytwyn & Lytwyn, 1600 Stuyvesant Avenue, Union, NJ. The funeral and burial will begin at St. John's Ukrainian Catholic Church, 719 Sanford Ave, Newark, NJ on Wednesday, October 22nd at 8:30am.

For New Yorkers and others, ''early voting'' still means getting up before the polls open on Nov. 4 and being among the first to cast a ballot on Election Day. But by the middle of this week, dozens of states will provide a way for at least some voters to cast their ballots in person before that first Tuesday in November, according to the Pew Center on the States. Among them are Colorado, Florida and Texas, three of the most important states, electorally speaking, in the presidential election this year. Those states, as well as Alaska, Arkansas, Idaho and North Dakota, begin early voting on Monday, with Hawaii and Louisiana opening the polls to in-person voters on Tuesday, according to the Pew Center.

AWASH IN A FLOOD OF DEBT Like water rushing over a river's banks, the federal government's rapidly mounting expenses are overwhelming the federal budget and increasing an already swollen deficit. CRAMER VS. CRAMERJim Cramer, CNBC's star stock-picker, is more muted after making some bold predictions that were proved wrong during the crisis. But even with the finger-pointing, Mr. Cramer still loves running his show and his mouth about the market, even if the market is not loving him back. David Carr: The Media Equation. [B1.]

THE SECRET MACHINES ''Secret Machines'' (TSM/World's Fair) The future, inexorable and uncertain, looms large on the self-titled third album by the Secret Machines. Brandon Curtis, frontman, bassist and keyboardist, sings lyrics that wallow in the ominous, though his dispassionate delivery suggests a managed dread. The music, meanwhile, begs for smoke and lasers: its distortion-laced guitars, booming drums and echo-treated vocals make a stylish setting for alarmism.

Contemporary slasher movies are typified by graphic and gory on-screen killings, with victims being picked off one by one. The horror/suspense genre is hard to define. This list, for example, features only R-rated films and includes ''Sleepy Hollow'' with its bloody beheadings but avoids ''Hannibal,'' which featured the cooking of cannibalistic meals. ''Saw V,'' which opens on Friday, joins ''Saw'' (2004), above with Cary Elwes, and three sequels, each released around Halloween. ''Saw, '' after an initial NC-17 rating, was edited to an R and made $63.9 million. SHELLY FREIERMAN

No more debates, no joint appearances, not even half-hour infomercials. This week it will be just intense on-the-ground campaigning as the Democratic and Republican presidential tickets press toward Election Day. On Monday, the Democratic presidential nominee, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, will be joined by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at a rally in Orlando, Fla. Mr. Obama plans to spend two days campaigning in the state, and his wife, Michelle, will also be at events in northern Florida. Over the next 10 days, the Obama campaign will focus on other states that went for President Bush in 2004, including Colorado, Iowa, New Mexico, Ohio and Virginia.

The Steelers' Bryant McFadden and Troy Polamalu were hurt on the same play in the fourth quarter. Neither returned. ... Devin Hester left the Bears' victory with a quadriceps injury.

A memorial service for the author David Foster Wallace is to be held at 4 p.m. Thursday at New York University's Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 LaGuardia Place in Greenwich Village. It will be open to the public. It is being organized by Little, Brown & Company, which published many of Mr. Wallace's books, including ''Infinite Jest,'' ''Brief Interviews With Hideous Men'' and ''Oblivion: Stories.'' The service will feature tributes from colleagues and friends of Mr. Wallace, who died on Sept. 12.

[********] ''The Chemistry of Common Life'' (Matador) One of the great North American rock bands right now has a singer who wants to nail you to the spot. He shouts, bullishly, rabble-rousingly, hardcore-style, and does nothing else. The implication is that you have to pay attention in real time, and continuously through the record. But the band underneath him, often as not, plays repetitions and drones, suggesting that you take the long view and let the music wash over you.

REID--Harry G., 85, Charlton, MA, born February 24, 1923, Providence, RI, died October 13, 2008. Harry, son of D. Albert Reid and Marguerite Page Reid, grew up in Cranston, RI, resided in Brooklyn, NY, and retired to Nantucket Island, MA. He served in the Merchant Marine during World War II. He is survived by his life partner, Howard L. Lewis, sister Virginia Bentsen Arnold and four nieces and nephews and eight great nieces and nephews. Celebration service October 24, 11am, Overlook Masonic Chapel, 88 Masonic Home Road, Charlton, MA 01507. Memorial gifts to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087 or Mount Vernon Ladies' Association (for the preservation of Mount Vernon), Attn: Development, P.O. Box 110, Mount Vernon, VA 22121.

ARATA--Kenneth, age 57 of Frenchtown, NJ and New York City, died suddenly October 15th, 2008. Survived by his beloved wife Judy Zatz, his mother Phyllis Oschman, his brother Victor and many loving relatives. A memorial gathering will be held in Frenchtown at his home on Sunday, October 26, 1pm. Contributions to the Arthritis or the Scleroderma Foundation are appreciated.

MOSKOWITZ--Bessie F. (Bonnie), of Great Neck, formerly of Jericho, NY, on October 19, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Alexander Moskowitz, cherished mother of Roberta Mandell (Howard), and Arthur Moskowitz (Michele), adored grandmother of Joshua Mandell, Julie Feldman (Nate) and Laurie Mandell, and of greatgrandchildren Alex and Ezra Feldman. Bonnie was a 1938 graduate of Brooklyn College and taught for many years in the New York City schools. She was a kind, intelligent, gracious and gregarious lady. Services today, 2pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

CALLE 13 ''Los de Atrás Vienen Conmigo'' (Sony BMG) Residente (René Pérez), the rapper in the Puerto Rican duo Calle 13, keeps insisting he's crazy on the group's third album, ''Los de Atrás Vienen Conmigo'' (''Those From Behind Are Coming With Me''). Green worms are eating his brain, he announces in ''Fiesta de Locos'' (''Crazy People's Celebration''). But he's crazy like a visionary, seeing trouble and utopia, vulgarity and exaltation, competitive put-downs and universal brotherhood all at once. In his world, he declares in ''Bienvenidos a Mi Mundo'' (''Welcome to My World''), everything is possible. Calle 13's music, composed by Residente's cousin Visitante (Eduardo Cabra), pushes in just as many directions; one song categorizes it as ''urban music at a crossroads.''

RICH--Mel. Your love and strength will always live within us. A devoted son to Charlotte and Sidney Rich. Loving brother and uncle to Judi, Andy, Brian, and Stefani Marcus. RICH--Mel. He graduated from Columbia University as a pharmacist and, among other successes, was the President of Great Earth Vitamins as well as a leader and innovator in the nutritional supplement industry. He was a passionate, creative, and generous man who always had a positive outlook on life. All those who met him instantly loved him. He will be forever missed. The funeral will be held today, October 20, at 10am at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to Rich in Love Charity, Inc. at www.richinlove.org RICH--Mel. RUDD--Michael, 66, of Leawood, KS, passed away Friday, October 17, 2008 at the Kansas City Hospice House. Memorial services were held at 3pm Sunday, October 19, at The New Reform Temple, Gregory and Main, Kansas City, MO. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to The Kansas City Hospice House, 12000 Wornall Road, Kansas City, MO 64145, Rolling Dog Ranch Animal Sanctuary, 400 Rolling Dog Ranch Lane, Ovando, Montana 59854 (www.rollingdogranch.org) or www.barackobama.com. Mike was a member of The New Reform Temple, Sertoma Club, Titanic Historical Society and was a passionate animal and human rights advocate. He served in the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam Conflict. Mike is survived by his wife of 42 years, Gloria Rudd; son and daughter-inlaw: Paul and Julie Rudd, New York, NY; daughter: Mandi Rudd Arnold and her husband Bill, Denver, CO; brother and sister-in-law: Barry and Isabel Rudd, Fairlawn, NJ; grandsons: Jack Sullivan Rudd, New York, NY and Henry Sullivan Arnold, Denver, CO coproprietors of Sullivan's Irish Pub. Online guest book @ louismemorialchapel.com. Services: The Louis Memorial Chapel 816-361-5211.

NIERENBERG--Grace S. It is with profound sorrow that Selfhelp Community Services mourns the untimely loss of it's beloved Senior VP, Grace S. Nierenberg. The world has lost a shining light of goodness and love and the city's elderly have lost one of their staunchest advocates. A driving force in the world of independent living for the elderly, for 31 years, Grace spearheaded numerous innovative programs at Selfhelp, including construction of affordable housing complexes for the elderly, where 1,000 residents now live with dignity. All told, her strong leadership abilities positively impacted the lives of over 20,000 individuals each year. Grace's tireless work will stand forever as a model of inspiration for generations of Selfhelp staff as well as the countless colleagues whose lives she touched throughout New York State. She left an extraordinary legacy for which she will always be remembered. On behalf of the Board of Directors and staff, we extend our heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Eric, her children, Noah, Rachel, and Deborah, and the entire family. Victor A. Wyler, President of Board of Directors Stuart C. Kaplan, Chief Executive Officer Selfhelp Community Services Inc.

Cherished grandfather of Eric, Alexandra, Stephanie, Ian, Dane and David. Services Monday 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 81st St. and Madison Ave.

The Patriots will need to rattle Jay Cutler to get the Broncos out of their offense, but it will not be easy. Denver has allowed only two sacks; New England has just seven, and they did not lay a hand on Philip Rivers in San Diego last week. If they give Cutler that much time, Brandon Marshall could use his size advantage against the Patriots' cornerbacks to add to his total of 43 catches, which led the league entering the weekend. What New England would probably rather do is keep the ball on the ground, to take the pressure off Matt Cassel when the Patriots have the ball and to keep it on the Broncos' 30th-ranked defense when they don't. ANDREW DAS

BORNHUETTER--Ronald L. 76, a resident of Greenwich, CT, died on October 16, 2008. Ron graduated from the College of Wooster and also received an MBA from Columbia University and an AMP from Harvard University. For over 40 years, Ron worked in the insurance and reinsurance industries including serving 14 years at NAC Re Corporation as its Chairman and CEO and approximately 20 years at General Re Corporation, where he served as Chief Financial Officer. In 1972, he co-authored an award winning paper, which is still considered to be the standard model for determining loss-reserving procedures for liability lines of the insurance business. He was a former President of both the Casualty Actuarial Society and the American Academy of Actuaries. He also served as a Director of eight companies including XL Capital Ltd. and as a Trustee of The College of Wooster, where a dormitory ''Bornhuetter Hall'' has also been built. He is survived by his loving wife Carol, his two children Ronald Jr. and Linda and his grandchildren Daniel and William Gridley; and two step-daughters Jenette and Christine and his grandchildren Harley, and Tilly Griffiths and Chrystal deGarmo. Visitation will be at the Leo Gallagher & Son Funeral Home in Greenwich on Tuesday, October 20 from 6-8pm with the funeral service on Wednesday, October 22 at 9:30am at the First Presbyterian Church, Greenwich CT. Memorials may be sent to the College of Wooster, Wooster, OH.

IVRY--E. Billi, died peacefully at home October 18, 2008 at age 102. She was the youngest of nine children of Rebecca and Israel Isaac Ivry and the favorite aunt and great-aunt of many nieces and nephews. She was educated in NYC public schools and had a successful career in business and finance. She was highly philanthropic and served on the boards of many institutions including the Jewish Theological Seminary, Yeshiva University and its Stern College for Women, Cardozo Law School, and the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies. Services today at 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory may be made to the Stern College for Women or the Ivry Prozdor at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

Senator John McCain was in Toledo, Ohio, on Sunday, but not with the man who will forever be known as Joe the Plumber -- even though Mr. McCain continued to talk about him at a rally there. It might be just as well. Joe, whose name is Samuel J. Wurzelbacher, talked on Saturday as if he had had enough of his 15 minutes of fame. After Mr. McCain used him to attack Senator Barack Obama's tax policy in the final presidential debate, Mr. Wurzelbacher found his life picked over by the news media.

KENNY CHESNEY ''Lucky Old Sun'' (BNA Records) Kenny Chesney became a reigning 21st-century country star by making himself the voice of sheer contentment. In his honey-dipped baritone, Mr. Chesney just about always sang about the pleasures of a stable, settled life and about how everything works out for the best, from beachfront getaways (''No Shoes, No Shirt, No Problems'') to an unexpected pregnancy (''There Goes My Life''). His music stayed on the cozy side of arena country, putting a little bit of modern Nashville into his mixture of 1970s soft rock with Jimmy Buffett's Caribbean lilt.

REILLY--William F. 70, passed away peacefully on Friday October 17, 2008, surrounded by his family after along battle with prostate cancer. The former Chairman and C.E.O of PRIMEDIA, he was a successful executive, philanthropist, veteran and mentor to many friends and colleagues. He was the devoted father of Jane Reilly Mount and Anthony Chapman Reilly and beloved brother of Elizabeth Smith. He is also survived by four grandchildren and former wife, Ellen Reilly. Mr. Reilly was most recently Chairman of Summit Business Media and a trustee of the University of Notre Dame. He was on the Board of Directors of Barnes and Noble, FMC, Channel 13/WNET, BizBash Media and Harvard Business School Press. Mr. Reilly was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame and Harvard Business School and also served as a first lieutenant in the 82nd Airborne Division of the U.S. Army. The wake for Mr. Reilly will be held on Tuesday October 21 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave/ 81st from 2-4pm and again from 7-9pm. The funeral mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave/84th on Wednesday October 22 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Mr. Reilly's name to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center or to the William F. Reilly Technology Center at Cardinal Hayes High School, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx, NY 10451. REILLY--William F. Bill Reilly was a business man extraordinaire, a gentleman extraordinaire, a philanthropist extraordinaire and a colleague extraordinaire. He was a builder of businesses, a shaper of and mentor to many of the business leaders in media today, a true Renaissance man, and proof that good guys can finish first. Bill, you will be sorely missed by your friends, associates and family. Beverly and Robert Chell

WILLIAMS--Lois Kuchman, loving wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, passed away on October 17, 2008 after bravely confronting Parkinson's Disease for many years. Lois, an only child, was born April 1, 1928, in St. Albans, Queens, New York to Jennie and Harold H. Kuchman. She graduated from Manhasset High School in 1945, and from The University of Rochester in 1949. While at The University of Rochester, Lois met her husband and the love of her life, James B. Williams. Lois and Jim were married on July 30, 1949, in Manhasset, New York, and recently celebrated their 59th wedding anniversary. Together they lived in Garden City, New York, and York, Pennsylvania before moving to Dallas, Texas in 1955. While dedicating her life to her husband and children, Lois was also involved in many local activities and organizations. She was a member of the Dallas Womens Club, The Dallas Garden Club, The Village Gardeners, The Heritage Club, The Calliope Club, TriClub, The Theta Mothers Club, The Crystal Charity Ball Committee, Discussion Group ''C'' Sunday School Class at Highland Park Presbyterian Church, and HPPC Women of the Church. Lois was known and admired for her devotion to her family, her friends, her church, and her community. She is survived by her loving husband, James Bowman Williams, her five children, Linda Williams Rush and husband Robert H. Rush of Frankfort, Kentucky; James Bowman Williams, Jr. and wife Mary R. Williams of San Antonio; Cynthia Williams Beecherl and husband Louis A. Beecherl, III of Dallas; Jayne Williams Bass and husband W. David Bass of Dallas; and Margaret Williams Kuykendall and husband Marshall E. Kuykendall of Austin; her grandchildren, Cynthia R. Yeiser and husband Jordan, Robert Rush, Campbell Williams and wife Anne, Alan Williams and wife Amanda, Bowman Williams, Arthur Beecherl, Rebecca Beecherl, Ben Beecherl, Edward Beecherl, Nancy Bass, Wade Bass, Jim Bass, Henry Bass, Wylie Kuykendall, and Jennie Kuykendall; and by greatgrandson Campbell Williams. The family gratefully acknowledges the wonderful care given by caregivers Virginia Hunter and Sharon Sinclair, and for the excellent care provided by the staff of Faith Presbyterian Hospice. A Memorial Service celebrating her life will be held on Monday, October 20 at 2pm in the Sanctuary of Highland Park Presbyterian Church with Rev. Dr. Ronald W. Scates and Rev. Dr. Sherwood M. Strodel officiating. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Highland Park Presbyterian Church Foundation, 3821 University Blvd., Dallas, TX 75205, or Faith Presbyterian Hospice, 6100 Colwell Blvd., Ste. 225, Irving, TX 75039.

The Rangers have spent the first nine games of their season in bizarre limbo, carrying three extra forwards on their roster and having no spare defensemen. So, while Coach Tom Renney has been evaluating which ones the Rangers should keep long-term, he has rotated a set of forwards in and out of the lineup in frenetic fashion. It has not allowed Petr Prucha, Nigel Dawes, Dan Fritsche, Patrick Rissmiller or Lauri Korpikoski to find any kind of rhythm or role on this team. And each game, the Rangers have more than $3 million of salary invested in healthy scratches.

The Gulf of Aden is earning its reputation as the world's most dangerous waterway. So far this year, pirates have hijacked 30 ships from the waters that divide the Arabian Peninsula from the Horn of Africa. In the latest incident, an Indian ship was freed by hijackers after a successful intervention by Somali gunmen. Ten ships remain in pirate hands - including the MV Faina, a Ukrainian ship loaded with 33 tanks and ammunition that is currently surrounded by a flotilla of U.S. Navy warships.

Tuesday was a special day in the K.H.L. Vyacheslav Fetisov, formerly the Russian Minister of Sport and as of last week a senator in the upper house of the federal legislature, was elected chairman of the league board of governors. The 50-year-old ex-CSKA, U.S.S.R., Devils and Red Wings star promptly told the K.H.L. Web site, "We should develop in the direction of the Far East, and make the league not only European but also Asian." He said there was interest in joining the K.H.L. from businessmen in Japan, South Korea and China.

World | In the current climate of financial disquiet, how hard would it be to destabilize a nation? Not hard at all, a columnist says. Look at the bank run that nearly toppled Poland's economy last week, a panic prompted by a sensationalized story. Political instability follows economic instability "like night follows day," she writes. Beware Pakistan. [Washington Post]

On Sunday afternoon I received a call from the Barneys women's buying office saying my black Balenciaga dress was in. It was heartening to know in these difficult times that somebody wanted to make a sale. About six weeks ago I'd stopped by the store with a copy of a Barneys ad featuring the dress, Exit #2 from the fall runway collection, a dress that also received tons of editorial attention. With sleeves reduced to seductive armbands, a deep slit up the left leg, and planes of stiff black fabric intersecting across the front, the dress has a very modern look. I was curious to see and touch it. Owning the dress wasn't necessarily the objective. We see a lot of great fashion on the runways, but as I've pointed out here and in several columns recently, we seemed to see less and less of these clothes in the stores. (Indeed, I interviewed Balenciaga's president Isabelle Guichot, among other chief executives, about this widening gap.) What we mostly see are pre-season collections, which stores like because the clothes arrive early in the season and have a longer selling time at full price than the runway pieces, which tend arrive later.

By any standards, the past two years have been anything but easy for Lisa Marie Nowak.

Updated, 3:57 p.m. | The City Council has scheduled a Thursday vote on a bill that would extend term limits to allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials to seek a third term in office, nullifying the outcome of two public referendums, in 1993 and 1996, that imposed term limits.

KeyCorp, U.S. Bancorp, the Regions Financial Corporation and the National City Corporation said Tuesday that they might join the government's $250 billion plan to recapitalize banks and were considering whether to use the money to shore up capital or make acquisitions, Bloomberg News reports.
Edward was inspired by the potential in star anise on his trip to London. -MB
Imagine you had the cash to build the home of your dreams. What investment strategy would you follow while the house was being built?

The question was posed in an earlier post: If you had to explain football to someone who knew nothing about it in three sentences or less, how would you do it? (Saints Coach Sean Payton was asked by a British reporter to "explain" American football.)

Updated, 3:18 p.m. | Olafur Eliasson's "Waterfalls," which graced the East River from June 26 to Oct. 13, generated an estimated economic impact of $69 million, exceeding the initial estimate of $55 million, the Bloomberg administration announced on Tuesday. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the first deputy mayor, Patricia E. Harris, provided a breakdown of the estimated impact, which included the costs of the exhibition:

An evangelical friend from Texas forwarded an email that she had received from her friends; it counsels her to watch this video "showing" Barack Obama mocking the Bible and insulting Christians. Watch the video and you can imagine that if you were an evangelical, you would be enraged at Obama as well.

The smart and eminently readable new book, "Economic Gangsters," by Raymond Fisman and Edward Miguel, has a blurb on the cover from Steven Levitt, of "Freakonomics" fame. It fits, because Fisman and Miguel try to do for global poverty what Levitt did for domestic economic issues. For example, they look at the way "witches" are killed in Tanzania whenever rainfalls fail and food is scarce; it turns out that families try to save food by executing less-productive elderly women as witches.

Hedge funds and creditors have already voiced concerns about how Lehman Brothers' gargantuan bankruptcy case is progressing. Now, you can add Walt Disney Corporation to the list of those who want a deeper look at the complex and unusually fast-paced proceeding.

Drugs | There are encouraging signs that compounds in certain foods (nuts and turkey, for e.g.) can be enlisted in the fight against drug addiction. Elsewhere, researchers are again studying whether long-taboo psilocybin and LSD can bring about positive mystical experiences. Wait, we thought getting high and the munchies were bad for you. [Economist, Drug Reporter]

Updated, 3:45 p.m. | No matter what one thinks of South Street Seaport's future design, most agree its past deserves respect. Developers and preservationists are now wrangling over a question: Can the past be preserved by moving it?

In case you ever wanted a concise definition of stagflation to go with your pumpkin soy latte, GOOD Magazine is distributing a brief timeline of United States economic history at Starbucks stores across the country.
Each broadcast network, save for ABC, has ordered a full season of one new fall show.

"Rachel Maddow, a woman who does not own a television set, has done something that is virtually unheard of: she has doubled the audience for a cable news channel's 9 p.m. hour in a matter of days," I reported in today's edition of The New York Times.
The Times's Christine Haughney reports on delays for buyers of new luxury condominiums in New York.
If the federal government runs low on cash, it might want to think about borrowing some from the campaign fund of Senator Barack Obama.

Before James Sanders Jr. was elected to the City Council in 2001, he was a president of a local school board in southeast Queens and something of a community and political activist. He also worked as a youth coordinator where he spoke with young people about the importance of voting. To hear his political allies tell it -- and by his own admission -- the James Sanders of that era might well have been a leader in the opposition to oppose a measure to extend term limits.

Here is another idea for stopping the wave of foreclosures and doing something about the financial crisis at the retail level -- i.e. the homeowner -- rather than the wholesale level -- the banking system. It comes from William R. Hambrecht, a lifelong out-of-the-box thinker, and founder of W.R. Hambrecht & Company, which takes companies public using a Dutch auction method instead of the traditional fee-laden, insider-driven Wall Street process.For those of you just joining this "Should Homeowners Be Rescued?" discussion, here is my column on the subject. And here are the details of the proposed Freedom Recovery Plan, which I wrote about on Saturday. (It is the document on the bottom right.) The Hambrecht Plan involves, fundamentally, a debt-for-equity swap at the residential housing level. Like the Freedom Recovery Plan, its primary aim is to prevent foreclosures and keep people in their homes, while acknowledging that housing prices will surely have to decline further before any kind of recovery can begin. I'll let Mr. Hambrecht take it from here.
Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The New York Times, was online this morning answering questions from readers. (He will try to do this every Tuesday.)

The trend for the day: mixed blessings. For example, the phone companies are selling more smartphones at lower profit margins. On the other hand, Netflix is selling fewer new subscriptions at higher profit margins. You might even call the seeming reluctance of the Justice Department to okay Yahoo's deal to have Google sell some of its ads a mixed blessing, at least for Google. Now that Microsoft doesn't seem to want to buy Yahoo, a blocked deal could leave Yahoo, Google's biggest rival, to wither with no savior in sight.
Mark Bittman prepares his mother's classic Kasha Varnishkes.

BAGHDAD -- Mohammad Raheem looked out the window of his home and showed me where the blast shattered his windows four years ago to the day. The shards went flying through the room where he slept on the floor with his wife and three children between them, he told me.

Worldwide investor confidence fell to its lowest level on record in October as investors, especially in North America, fled from risky assets amid the crisis in the financial markets, State Street said Tuesday.
Images of Paul Binder and the Big Apple Circus.
Goldman Sachs transformed itself in 1999, when it went from a private partnership to a public company. Now it must transform itself again -- but under far less happy circumstances.
Steven Heller is the co-chairman of the MFA Design program at the School of Visual Arts. (Full biography.)
Today Baghdad Bureau begins Photographer's Journal, a regular feature which will showcase the work of photographers who work for The New York Times in Iraq.
High-speed photography from WebUrbanist.

As the price of oil roared to ever higher levels in recent years, the leaders of Venezuela, Iran and Russia muscled their way onto the world stage, using checkbook diplomacy and, on occasion, intimidation.

Philosophy | An irreverent review of "Das Kapital" says it has "a beginning, a muddle and an end" and "will be read long after Milton and Shakespeare have been forgotten - only not until then." But along with the review, Marxist heavyweights comment on whether they feel vindicated. Eric Hobsbawm says it's nice to be taken seriously: "a phase of this particular world system has passed and we must think of another one." [Times of London]
More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Oct. 21:

BENSALEM, Pa.-John McCain has hit Barack Obama on taxes, the economy, national security, health care, earmarks, the mortgage crisis and his association with a 1960s radical. Now, Mr. McCain has gone after what he suggested was Mr. Obama's flip-flopping on his choice of World Series teams, the Philadelphia Phillies and the Tampa Bay Rays.

"As they have watched their 401(k)'s shrivel in recent weeks, entertainment executives have started to grapple with how best to reflect the global economic crisis in movie and television story lines, or whether to bring the topic up at all," Brooks Barnes reports in The New York Times today.

Artists - painters, poets, musicians, novelists - tend to listen to a lot of National Public Radio. They're home; it's on; the calm, shy, serious patter of NPR is better than anything else on the low end of the FM dial. I half-suspect you could fill a small anthology of observations about NPR culled from the novels of the last decade or two.

Felix the doorman helped with the boxes, which were heavy with books and piled onto a luggage roller: tales of intrigue and adventure, histories and biographies, accounts of war and dynasty -- the treasures of stolen nights and forgotten afternoons.
There is no better standby for weeknight meals than a stir-fry, and the less complicated the better.

-- Entertainment Weekly reports that the "Survivor" executive producer Mark Burnett and host Jeff Probst are teaming up to produce a pilot of "Live Like You're Dying," a reality show where the final dreams of terminally ill patients come true. Lisa de Moraes reacts: "If you're left wondering how long it will take before someone snookers Probst by faking a terminal illness to get on the show -- get in line."
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
There were no games in any of the junior leagues on Monday night but the Western Hockey League will return on Tuesday. The report follows.

"Heat" is here. The PBS Frontline documentary, written and directed by Martin Smith, explores the world to explain why there has been such a persistent gap between the growing body of science pointing to an increasingly human-warmed world and action by policymakers, politicians and the public to limit risks.
So gasoline prices are dropping.
The Federal Reserve announced Tuesday that it would help finance purchases of up to $600 billion in assets of money market mutual funds that have been hit with redemptions by investors.

At a party last week to celebrate the 10 years of Gran Turismo, a racing simulator for the Sony PlayStation, the artist Haze unveiled a hand-painted Lotus Exige. After the event, held at the Classic Car Club Manhattan on Hudson Street, the car was to be auctioned to benefit Studio in a School, which brings young people together with professional artists in New York.

Boston College was rated among the teams least likely to make a run at the Atlantic Coast Conference championship going into the 2008 season. Without quarterback Matt Ryan, among other departures from last year's 11-3 squad that reached the conference championship game, the news media predicted the Eagles would finish fourth in the division with one particularly dour forecast of sixth.

Language | Steven Pinker questions Washington's crusade against cursing on air. As he's written before, naughty words shed their original meaning over time and "retain only a coloring of emotion, and then just an ability to arouse attention." So why curb them? Doing so restricts criticism of the curbs themselves, "mocking the very rationale for free speech." [Atlantic]

On Tuesday, The Times published an article I wrote about Twitter and Yammer, two microblogging services that let users blast short messages to a group of virtual followers. Twitter has gotten a lot of buzz since it was created in 2006. Yammer is new on the scene, just six weeks old, with a different goal: to be Twitter for businesses.

Three large regional banks all reported losses on Tuesday, and one, National City, announced that it would lay off about 14 percent of its work force. A fourth regional bank, U.S. Bancorp, said that its quarterly profit fell a larger-than-expected 47 percent.
As part of an effort to thaw the frozen credit markets, the government plans to offer some of its $250 billion rescue package to banks that are willing to buy up struggling competitors.

The New York Times: Tongue-tied politicians and would-be plumbers aren't the only ones to have their visibility raised by "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart:" Rob Riggle, the burly on-air correspondent for the Comedy Central news satire, has signed a deal to develop his own sitcom for CBS, Variety reported.
Frank Bruni is answering more readers' questions today on the the Times homepage, including this one.

Four years ago George W. Bush narrowly won the presidential election, and Republicans achieved a 30-seat majority in the House and a 10-seat majority in the Senate. Immediately there was a vast chorus from the commentariat, proclaiming the death of liberalism; America, everyone said, was a conservative nation. I have a whole shelf of books with titles like Building Red America and One-Party Nation.
"They found a piece of Joe's elbow first."

Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Colin Powell is in the news because he endorsed Barack Obama. I wonder how John McCain feels about Colin Powell endorsing Obama. He's probably all right with it. Men his age are used to having colon problems.
Has Kirk Kerkorian had enough of Detroit?
Edward L. Glaeser is an economist at Harvard.

The most surprising endorsement of the campaign: Ken Adelman, the man who predicted a "cakewalk" in Iraq on the op-ed page of The Washington Post in 2002, tells The New Yorker's George Packer that he is going to vote for Barack Obama.

The Tracinda Corporation, the investment company controlled by the billionaire financier Kirk Kerkorian, said Tuesday in a regulatory filing that it had sold 7.3 million shares of the automaker, the Ford Motor Company, and might sell the rest of the stock.

After threatening to fight Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to seek a third term, then agreeing to sit on the sidelines, then waffling, then backing down again, Ronald S. Lauder is tossing a new -- and potentially serious -- hurdle into the mayor's path (at the same time that another billionaire, Tom Golisano, is pledging all-out opposition to the plan).
Anyone who has struggled with depression -- either in themselves or a loved one -- will be moved by the story of Douglas C. Prasher.
In its final burst of campaigning, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is pushing to get one of the hardest to persuade groups -- retirees - to support Barack Obama for president.

By a narrow but significant margin, 51 percent to 45 percent, New York City voters oppose extending the eight-year term limit to 12 years so that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg might serve a third term, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released Tuesday morning.The poll suggested that a remarkable shift in public opinion had occurred in recent weeks, as the mayor's proposal to extend term limits through City Council legislation -- nullifying the results of two voter referendums -- has been engulfed by controversy. In the new poll, 89 percent of respondents said the issue should be decided through another referendum, not by the Council.

Politics | A Princeton academic has a contrarian take on voter ignorance: So what? "The political consequences of 'public ignorance' must be demonstrated, not assumed," he says. "Do they manage to make sensible choices despite being hazy about the details of politics and government? (Okay, really hazy.) If they do, that's not stupid-it's efficient." It's human and "predictably irrational." Which may be bad enough. [Wilson Quarterly]

In a taped interview on the CBS "Early Show"Tuesday morning, Senator John McCain, defended the robocalls his campaign and the Republican Party are running that tie Senator Barack Obama to Bill Ayers, the former member of the radical group, the Weather Underground.

More than 90,000 of New York City's elementary school students - roughly 20 percent - missed at least a month of classes during the last school year, with attendance problems most acute in central Brooklyn, Harlem and the South Bronx, according to a report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

In my colleague Larry Altman's expert analysis of the presidential candidates' health, Barack Obama's doctor reports that Mr. Obama has switched from cigarettes to Nicorettes "with success." As Larry notes, it's not clear what "success" means, since Mr. Obama has also been bumming the occasional cigarette during the campaign, so there may be risk of him going back to his former smoking habits.

A hearing is underway in a Wisconsin courtroom, for Barry Barnett, a 43-year-old pastor. He and the state department of social services both agree that the father of nine and minister at the Lighthouse Family Ministries in Poynette, Wisc., used a wooden paddle to punish his 12-year-old son for lying last spring. But they differ on whether that paddling, which left bruises on the boy, was child abuse.
A violent escalation after the gambit is within their ambit:
BlackRock, the big money manager that has navigated the credit crisis better than most, said Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell 24 percent, as its assets under management dropped.
