As the drive to regulate credit default swaps gains momentum, three federal agencies could be heading for a "turf war" over who will oversee these derivative securities, which played a major role in the near collapse of American International Group, The Washington Post reports.
Didn't you try this at your last family wedding?
A former Merrill Lynch executive has found a new home at Citadel Investment Group, where he will head the hedge fund firm's push into the capital markets business.

For all the support that the presidential candidates are expressing for renewable energy, alternative energies like wind and solar are facing big new challenges because of the credit freeze and the plunge in oil and natural gas prices.

HLTH and its majority-owned subsidiary, WebMD Health, said they have canceled a $2.31 billion cash-and-stock merger because of recent turmoil in the financial markets. The boards of both companies favored ending the deal, the companies said.

Shares in France's top banks rose sharply on Tuesday after the French government said it would lend 10.5 billion euros ($14.12 billion) to bolster their capital reserves, which had been eroded by the global credit crisis.
Japan's Toshiba is buying $1 billion worth of equipment from joint venture partner SanDisk, shoring up the California-based company as it faces a takeover bid from a South Korean rival Samsung.
Shares in Pacific Sunwear, an embattled purveyor of surfing-influenced clothing, rose more than 5 percent after it received a $295 million takeover offer on Monday.

Nearly three years ago, the billionaire oilman T. Boone Pickens donated $165 million to Oklahoma State's athletic department so it could remake its facilities into a Shangri-la for Cowboys sports, complete with an indoor practice center and new facilities for baseball, equestrian, soccer, tennis, and track and field.
Sprint Nextel, with its market capitalization now at about $10 billion, is looking like a bargain acquisition, The New York Times's Laura M. Holson writes.

In a step that could accelerate a shakeout of the nation's banks, the Treasury Department hopes to spur a new round of mergers by steering some of the money in its $250 billion rescue package to banks that are willing to buy weaker rivals, The New York Times's Mark Landler reported, citing government officials.

Just a few months ago, Lifetime Television started adapting the Candace Bushnell novel "Trading Up" into a movie, figuring an aspirational story about the entitled rich and their limousine culture nailed the cultural moment.

Tuesday's deadline to settle an estimated $400 billion in credit default swaps on debt in failed investment bank Lehman Brothers is unlikely to trigger new havoc in the market, derivatives analysts said.

Despite signs that the credit markets may be thawing, don't expect banks to start handing out loans to Main Street -- at least not to anyone who needs them, Andrew Ross Sorkin says in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times.
Swiss drugmaker Roche confirmed its commitment to a $43.7 billion bid for the rest of Genentech and reported a 2 percent fall in nine-month sales to 33.3 billion Swiss francs ($29.26 billion).

Just six months ago, five or six "bulge bracket" investment banks stood astride the globe virtually dictating the terms of engagement of international finance - managing deals, pronouncing companies (or countries) investment-worthy or not, and dispensing advice that companies (and countries) ignored at their peril.

A top executive at Merrill Lynch, which last month accepted a takeover offer from Bank of America, is likely to leave with more than $10 million in compensation, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Monday that he supported a second round of additional spending measures to help stimulate the economy.

The Exelon Corporation's unsolicited bid to buy NRG Energy, a power generator based in Princeton, N.J., would create the largest power company in the country, in terms of assets, market capitalization and generation capacity, and would benefit shareholders of both companies, Exelon said on Monday.

Goldman Sachs and its chief executive Lloyd C. Blankfein is behind a deal to help bankroll a new $100 million stadium catering and merchandising venture for the New York Yankees and the Dallas Cowboys, The New York Post reported.
When a billionaire Russian industrialist tries to renege on a deal, how do you collect?
After weeks of extraordinary efforts by the world's governments and central banks, the frozen flow of credit began to thaw on Monday.

Customers who are suing the Reserve Fund have asked a federal judge to allow the release of audio tapes of calls that the fund's sales staff made to customers on Sept. 15, the day before the money market fund's share price fell below a dollar, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.

A Hong Kong conglomerate controlled by China's biggest state-owned investment company announced on Monday that it had realized losses of $104 million on ill-timed currency transactions and would lose $1.9 billion more if it were to mark the transactions to market now.

For all the support that the presidential candidates are expressing for renewable energy, alternative energies like wind and solar are facing big new challenges because of the credit freeze and the plunge in oil and natural gas prices, The New York Times's Clifford Krauss.

The German cabinet approved conditions on Monday for banks that make use of its rescue package of 500 billion euros, but loosened a strict pay cap of 500,000 euros (about $667,000) a year for top managers amid concerns that it would scare off banks that needed help, The New York Times's Judy Dempsey reported.

In the aftermath of the dot-com bust, many chastened venture capitalists pledged never again to finance an idea scribbled on a cocktail napkin with no viable business model. Too many poorly conceived companies like Pets.com and Webvan had flamed out. The new breed of Internet start-ups needed to have a clear path to profitability.

History | The Times of London has an "archive blog" riffing on the history you can find in its searchable, digitized trove of every published issue of the newspaper from 1785 to 1985. For example, did you you know about the Great London Beer Flood of 1814, a tragic case of brewery hubris? And that Tolstoy's death was another one greatly exaggerated? [Times of London]
European stocks were mostly higher Tuesday, a day after France announced a big injection of cash into French banks, The New York Times's David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.
Universal Studios is in advanced talks to sell one of its two specialty film labels to Relativity Media, a private production and financing company, The New York Times's Brooks Barnes reported.

Regulators filed a lawsuit on Monday to block the world's largest beef packer from buying the nation's fourth-largest such operation, saying such a deal could increase beef prices for consumers and drive down prices paid to ranchers and feedlots.

Culture | Browse inside the New England home library of the 52-year-old Internet entrepreneur Jay Walker (Walker Digital, Priceline.com.). He wanted to build a library "about human imagination." The result is a three-level, 3,600-square-foot "ziggurat" stuffed with landmark tomes and eye-catching historical objects, including an original Sputnik. [Wired]

Terminally ill patients in California are the first in the nation to have a legal right to information from their doctors, upon request, about end-of-life options, including hospice, palliative care, refusing or withdrawing life-prolonging treatments, and making the choice to refuse food and hydration.
Brightstorm, a start-up introduced Tuesday, offers online courses to augment what teenagers learn in school and help with the ever-more-challenging process of honing their resumes for college.

Economics | Do you think free-market capitalism is over? If you do, you might enjoy Jacob Weisberg's "End of Libertarianism," which likens its adherents to old Communists complaining that their theories were never properly applied. The Economist, meanwhile, says "capitalism has always engendered crises, and always will," but it's still "the best economic system man has invented yet." Take your pick. [Slate, Economist]

Britain | A British wag says don't make Oprah ambassador to Britain. It's just a rumor, but the plum jobs nearly always go to big campaign donors, don't they? "Does anyone really believe that Oprah is the person best placed to explain to the British public why America felt it had to strike Iran's nuclear facilities?" [Spectator, Financial Times]

Economics | A columnist proposes a "Starbucks theory of international economics": The more Starbucks in a financial capital, "the more likely the country is to have suffered catastrophic financial losses." That's because the chain's expansion was heavy both in areas of the real estate bubble and global financial centers exploiting it. Now the froth is off the latte. [Slate]
As markets crash around the world, buyers continue to shell out outrageous amounts for U.S. property.
Photos of Les Sources, a house in the town of Veules les Roses.
Ms. Warwick was a soul singer who won recognition for both her solo work and her performances with her older sister Dionne Warwick.
Ms. Robinson sang with the Met for nearly two decades and went on to a career as a teacher and guide to emerging singers.
On Saturday, Tom Brady announced on his Web site that he had had a second knee operation to deal with an infection that developed after his first one. Here's his statement:
Mr. Blackwell was a designer of over-the-top fashions and originator of the outlandishly satiric, but globally ballyhooed worst-dressed list.
Brett Favre is giving people in Wisconsin a reason to drink.Not that coming up with an excuse has been a problem.
Gov. Rick Perry has ordered a lockdown and search of the state’s prisons after death row inmates made thousands of calls on a smuggled cellphone.
Another arrest has been made in the investigation stemming from the abduction of a 6-year-old Las Vegas boy who was found safe over the weekend.
The wife of Representative Tim Mahoney, who is embroiled in an adultery scandal, has filed for divorce.
The Federal Aviation Administration is realigning the duties of air traffic controllers in some cities.
A former environmental activist who committed arson at Michigan State University in 1999 and later became a government informant was sentenced to nine years in prison.

The Utah Jazz will be opening the regular season without its top player. Point guard Deron Williams would be out for at least two weeks with a sprained ankle, the Jazz said Monday, two days after Williams was injured in a preseason game at Chicago.

Four months after his United States Open victory, Tiger Woods returned to Torrey Pines without a limp. Hopping from a cart, Woods walked up to John Abel, 59, doffed his cap and extended his hand. “Hey, I hear you’re looking for a caddie. I’m Tiger Woods — pleased to meet you.”.
BUSINESS DAY.

Winners have been chosen in an online video contest aimed at inspiring the next president, Congress and the public to take meaningful action on human-caused climate change. The goal, in essence, was to solicit fresh messages on global warming that might punch through the "something, someday, somewhere" aura that sociologists say makes this a particularly tough issue to build a movement around. The contest was organized by the climate coalition called 1Sky.org and Brighter Planet, a company offering ways to invest in nonpolluting energy projects through "carbon offsets." (It has a detailed description of how it chooses CO2-offsetting projects to avoid some of the pitfalls that have tarnished the reputation of this business sector.)• First Place, "Climate Matters," Steve Dempsey, Sammamish, Wash.
KitchenAid is returning to direct response television to promote its iconic stand mixer.

Capt. Quentin Ranken, chief counsel of the West Tennessee Land and Improvement Company, was killed Monday night at Walnut Log, near Reelfoot Lake in Tennessee. Col. R.Z. Taylor, a lawyer and the company's president, who was with him, is missing and assumed to have been slain. "The murders are the result of animosity over movements against fishermen on the famous lake, with which the two lawyers were prominently identified." Their company "had begun injunction proceedings against persons living near the lake, enjoining them from operating on the lake and deciding, among other things, that the land company was the owner of the lake." Rankin, 45, was found "hanging on a limb, with head and body riddled with bullets." Taylor, 70, "is supposed to have been shot and thrown in Reelfoot Lake." The lake "was formed by the earthquake of 1811, and since has been one of the most famous fishing lakes in the country." Night Riders Slay Lawyers

Can there be any upside for green industries in this financial crisis? Investment is drying up, the prices of fossil fuels are falling and governments are backing away from their emissions and renewable energy targets to spend billions of dollars propping up the financial system.

An article on Friday about Senator Barack Obama’s recent electoral gains in Missouri omitted three areas of the state he won in the Democratic presidential primary. In addition to winning the cities of St. Louis and Kansas City, he also won Boone, Cole and Nodaway Counties. He did not lose “everywhere but the two big cities.”.

An article on Saturday about J. Michael Barone, who is celebrating the 25th anniversary of his “Pipedreams” radio program about organ music, misspelled the given name of one of the many organists he has admired. She was Catharine Crozier, not Catherine.

An article last Tuesday about a Czech research institute’s report indicating that Milan Kundera, one of Eastern Europe’s best-known writers, had been a secret-police informer as a student in 1950 misstated the date that Miroslav Dvoracek, a man who served a 14-year prison term on spying charges, was told about Mr. Kundera’s possible role in his arrest. It was in early October, not June.

An article on Thursday about Kris Jenkins, a nose tackle for the Jets who developed a passion for cooking while growing up in a single-parent household headed by his father, misspelled the father’s given name. He is Darome Jenkins, not Darmone. The error also appeared in an article on March 16 about Kris Jenkins’s involvement in a nonprofit program that teaches children about life through art.

An article on Saturday about Tampa Bay’s resilience against the Boston Red Sox late in the regular season and during the American League Championship Series referred incorrectly to the circumstances of the Rays’ 2-1 victory over the Red Sox on Sept. 16. Dioner Navarro hit a single in the ninth inning of that game to lift Tampa Bay; his teammate Dan Johnson did not hit a home run to tie the score in the ninth. (Johnson did, however, hit a ninth-inning homer in a 5-4 win against Boston on Sept. 9.).

A Sports of The Times column on Monday, about the success of the young Tampa Bay Rays against the more experienced Red Sox in the American League Championship Series, misstated, in some copies, Boston’s winning streak before Sunday night in postseason games when facing elimination. It was five games — not nine, which had been its streak in such games only in the A.L.C.S.

An article on Monday about a capital injection from the Dutch government into the ING Group, a financial services company, described the nature of the investment incorrectly. The government is buying nonvoting securities that pay an 8.5 percent dividend; it is not buying an 8.5 percent stake in the company.

The On the Road column in the Itineraries pages last Tuesday, about hotels’ increasing fees on travelers, miscalculated the amount available to apply toward a new ticket after a $150 change fee was assessed on a $375 round-trip ticket on Continental from Newark to Denver. A traveler would have $225 to apply to the new ticket — not $125.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about concerns over the safety of metal bats in youth baseball referred incorrectly in some editions to a test used by Little League to evaluate bats called Bat Performance Factor. It is considered by its creator, Richard A. Brandt, to be a true gauge of a bat even though it does not account for swing speed or the outgoing speed of the ball. Brandt does not view it as an untrue gauge because of those factors. The error was repeated in some editions in a caption for a photograph of Brandt, a New York University physics professor who created the test in the mid-1990s. Because of an editing error, the professor’s surname was also misspelled as Brant in one instance in some editions.

An article in the Itineraries pages last Tuesday reported about the increasing stress on business travelers, and cited the findings of “Stress in America,” an annual survey of the American Psychological Association. That survey found that economic factors were the leading causes of stress levels in 2008, but it did not say, as the article did, that “the crisis on Wall Street was the No. 1 cause of anxiety,” nor did participants in the survey say they felt most vulnerable to stress “in the office and on a business trip.”.
Most breast lumps are benign, but they shouldn’t be ignored.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
These days, Gov. Sarah Palin seems like a candidate trying to wriggle free of her handlers.
Charles J. O’Byrne turned to the Kennedy family, his own family, a college friend and a number of banks to raise money to pay off delinquent state and federal taxes and penalties.
Roselli Movers, a Long Island moving company, has been indicted on charges that it stole $258,000 from New York City’s transit authority.

The release of a highly anticipated video game for the PlayStation 3 console has been delayed after the discovery that its background music included quotations from the Koran. Little Big Planet, right, which was supposed to be released Tuesday, has long been in development, and Sony had hoped to have it in stores for the holiday retail season. According to a post by a Sony spokesman, Patrick Seybold, on the official Sony PlayStation blog (blog.us.playstation.com), the game’s developers discovered that one of the “background music tracks licensed from a record label for use in the game contains two expressions that can be found” in the Koran, which some may find offensive. Sony has apologized and removed the music. It plans to ship Little Big Planet to stores in North America next week.

MEYER--Arthur I . Beloved father, husband and grandfather of Palm Beach and formerly of Harrison, NY, passed peacefully on October 18, 2008. Arthur was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from New York University with a B.A. in accounting and New York University Law School in 1938. Mr. Meyer had a diverse and successful career as an attorney, a businessman and venture capitalist. At the peak of his career he was President and CEO of Servico, Inc., owners and operators of 58 hotels. Mr. Meyer and his wife, Sydelle, are benefactors of numerous organizations in New York and Palm Beach. In addition to his wife, Mr. Meyer is survived by his son William (Denise), his daughter Gail Asarch (Dr. James Satovsky), four grandchildren Candice and Andrew J. Meyer, and Melissa and Allison Asarch, and his sister, Isabel May of Miami. Memorial donations may be made to the Arthur I. Meyer Jewish Academy in West Palm Beach or to the Community Foundation for Palm Beach and Martin Counties.

The Screen Actors Guild wants the government to become involved in its prolonged quest for a contract that is sharply richer than agreements reached by Hollywood's writers and directors unions. The actors union's national board, meeting over the weekend for the first time since September elections tilted the guild in a less confrontational direction, decided to ask for a federal mediator to join stalled contract talks with the major film and television studios. The board also decided not to put a strike authorization vote before its membership. The studios in July issued what they called a final offer to the actors and have refused to reopen talks despite the guild's repeated requests. Although the studios will probably accept the addition of a mediator -- they want to spend a few days mulling it over -- a spokesman indicated that a mediator would not make a difference.

8 P.M. (13, 49) PARALLEL WORLDS, PARALLEL LIVES Mark Oliver Everett, known as E, is the leader of the band Eels. His father, whom he never really knew, was the quantum physicist Hugh Everett III, who in 1957 proposed what came to be known as the ''many worlds'' theory: that every time a human makes a decision, a parallel universe splits off from his or her everyday reality. Ridiculed at the time, the multiple-universe theory has since been explored by renowned physicists and inspired pop-culture creations like ''Star Trek'' and the trilogy ''His Dark Materials.'' In this ''Nova'' episode Mark Everett retraces his father's footsteps, meeting with his college friends (above), colleagues and admirers, including the Massachusetts Institute of Technology physicist Max Tegmark, and tries to understand how his father's mind worked and why he seemed to retreat to his own parallel universe. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS The team answers questions about embarrassing ailments like hemorrhoids, gas, bad breath, erectile dysfunction and food odor.

It may not rank as one of the great scientific mysteries of all time, but the riddle of worm grunting has been solved, apparently. Worm grunting, also known as worm fiddling or charming, involves driving a wooden stake into the ground and rubbing the top of it with a leaf spring or other flat piece of steel to make a grunting or snoring noise. Done in the right place under the right conditions, the result will be hundreds of earthworms appearing on the surface of the ground. Worm grunting is practiced in parts of the southeast to obtain fish bait. (A video is at nytimes.com/science.)

David Angus has been appointed the music director of Glimmerglass Opera, effective Nov. 1, it was announced on Monday. Mr. Angus, who has served as chorus master and staff conductor for the Glyndebourne Festival and conducted the London Philharmonic Orchestra and the London Mozart Players, among many others, made his United States conducting debut with Glimmerglass Opera's 2006 production of Rossini's ''Barber of Seville''; he returned to Glimmerglass, in Cooperstown, N.Y., this summer to conduct ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi'' by Bellini. His appointment concludes a two-year search after the departure of Stewart Robertson in 2006.

John McCain may be one of the wealthiest members of the Senate, but he is going to have to watch his dollars when it comes to financing the last two weeks of his campaign. Because of his decision to take public money for his presidential campaign, Mr. McCain ended September with $47 million in cash on hand, according to Federal Election Commission filings. The public financing system provides Mr. McCain with $84 million for the two months from his nomination until the Nov. 4 election, and he has already spent nearly half of it.

IVRY--E. Billi . The Jewish Theological Seminary community mourns the death of E. Billi Ivry, longtime member of the JTS Board of Trustees. Her deep devotion to Israel and Jewish education were core values that led her to endow the Rebecca and Israel Ivry Prozdor, the supplementary high school of JTS. She was inducted into the JTS Society of Fellows in 1994 for her ongoing commitment to the work of the institution, including the establishment of the E. Billi Ivry Chair of Talmud and Rabbinic Culture. The breadth of her vision and the generosity of her heart transcended denominational lines. Her exemplary character and magnanimous spirit will continue to inspire members of our community in the years to come. She is survived by many loving nieces and nephews. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Chairman IVRY--E. Billi, was a founding member of the Board of Overseers of Hunter College's Brookdale Center on Aging and my dear friend for three decades. My sympathies to her nephew, Alfred and his wife, Joann, and their family. Rose Dobrof

In a couple of months, Roger Y. Tsien and Martin Chalfie will head to Stockholm to collect the Nobel Prize in Chemistry and $450,000 each in prize money in recognition of their development of a revolutionary technique that lights up the inner workings of living cells. Meanwhile, the scientist who provided the essential piece that made Dr. Tsien's and Dr. Chalfie's work possible -- a jellyfish gene that produces a fluorescent protein -- is out of science.
International PAKISTANIS SHOW LITTLE ENTHUSIASM

American and Iraqi officials began a two-year, $14 million plan on Monday to help preserve Iraq's cultural heritage, which includes a frieze with an Assyrian king, left. The State Department grant will create a conservation and historic preservation institute in Erbil, help refurbish the Iraqi National Museum and train museum employees. Goli Ameri, the assistant United States secretary of state for education and cultural affairs, unveiled the program at the Iraqi National Museum, which she said ''will remain closed in the near term.'' Thousands of cultural artifacts were stolen from Iraq after the war began in 2003. At least 15,000 items were taken from National Museum and about 6,000 have since been recovered.

The supersonic Concorde airliner that was moved five years ago from the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum, which would undergo renovations, was returned by barge and crane to the museum at Pier 86 on Monday, with a new nose cone replacing the one damaged at its temporary parking place in Brooklyn. The museum is to reopen in November.

Weekend art auctions in London fell far short of the minimum estimates of the major auction houses, Bloomberg News reported. Sales at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips de Pury & Company brought in a combined $102 million, against minimum estimates of $184 million, according to Bloomberg's calculations. The auctions, coinciding with the Frieze Art Fair, were the first big test for the art market since the recent plunge in global stock markets and the government bailouts of banking institutions. Dealers were watching for clues to what will happen at New York sales in November. ''These are old prices,'' said the New York dealer Alberto Mugrabi, whose family owns one of the largest Andy Warhol collections, explaining why he let a Warhol pass by at Christie's on Sunday night. ''They would have to be readjusted.'' The contemporary-art market has enjoyed a bull run for the past five years, with prices for artists including Warhol, Takashi Murakami and Richard Prince more than quadrupling.

Forget red state/blue state, socialist, anarchist, Alaskan Independence Party, Iranian mullahs, whatever. Barack Obama walked perhaps the most diplomatically precarious line of all, that separating ardent baseball fans of one swing state from the fans of another. The World Series offers the Philadelphia Phillies versus the Tampa Bay Rays, and Mr. Obama, the Democratic nominee, finds himself caught between temporary allegiances. Mr. Obama is a confirmed Chicago White Sox fan. But as his team now resides in the dustbin of also-rans -- eliminated by the Rays, no less, in Round 1 of the playoffs -- he has switched to the Phillies for now.

GILBERT--Phil Edward, Jr. Attorney and Senior Partner at Gilbert, Segall and Young, LLP of New York City. He passed away Thursday, October 16th of complications of Alzheimer's disease. He was 93. Born in Illinois, he graduated from Evanston Township High School at age 16, followed by a postgraduate year at Phillips Andover Academy, Andover, MA. He then entered Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH where he earned Phi Beta Kappa his junior year, graduating AB, Magna Cum Laude, in 1936. A strong swimmer and music lover, he excelled as a member of the swimming team as well as the Glee Club, remaining passionate about both hobbies throughout his life. He attended Harvard Law School, Cambridge, MA, where he served as Lead Attorney for the Appellee with the Powell Law Club in January, 1939, winning the coveted Ames Competition, graduating LLB later that year. A member of the New York Bar beginning in 1941, he worked at Donovan, Leisure, Newton and Lumbard, 193941, followed by a brief service at Debovoise, Stevenson, Plimpton & Page. Commissioned a 2nd Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Reserve in 1940, he was called to active duty on December 8, 1941. Ultimately reaching the rank of Major, he served in General Patton's Third Army in its XII Corps Headquarters under Chief of Staff Brig. Gen. Ralph Canine. Coordinating tactical aerial reconnaissance and photography, he was decorated with not only the Bronze Star, but also the French Croix de Guerre with Silver Star for saving hundreds of French lives. He was also awarded four European Theater campaign stars. A member of the U.S. Army Reserve until December, 1952, upon his return to New York he co-founded the law firm of Thayer and Gilbert in 1946 with offices on Wall Street. The firm was renamed Gilbert and Segall in 1956, moving uptown to Park Avenue in 1959, and finally becoming Gilbert, Segall and Young in 1963. He served as lead outside counsel (U.S.) to Rolls-Royce, L.td. (Derby and London, England) for the better part of four decades and was President of RollsRoyce, Inc. (Autos, U.S.) 195771. He served on the Board, and as Deputy Chairman of Magnesium Elektron, Inc., 1957-88 and as Secretary, 1988-92. A member of the National Council of the Salk Institute, La Jolla, CA. from 1977-83, he was a trustee from 1983-97. A Life Fellow of the American Bar Foundation and member of the American Bar Association, he was also a member of both the Federal and Westchester County Bar Associations and the Bar Association of the City of New York. Listed in Who's Who in the World, over the years his client list included such firms as General Electric, Firestone Tire & Rubber, and International Telephone & Telegraph. He successfully represented the Chairman of the latter, Harold S., Geneen, in 1972 during Geneen's testimony before two U.S. Senate Committees, among other investigative bodies, regarding his role in the so-called ITT/Watergate matter. A lifelong Democrat, Phil even found time to run for the U.S. House of Representatives in 1958 and 60, losing both times to Republican incumbent Edwin Dooley. He retired in 2001. He is survived by his three children by his first wife, Nancy Merrick, of Redding, CT: Mary Hyman of Paris, France, John of Somers, NY, and Clinton of Westport, CT. Divorced in 1967, he remarried in 1968 to Joan Stulman, his wife of 40 years, who survives him along with her three daughters from her previous marriage: Linda Cooper of Yorktown, NY, Dana Halsted McGurk of Los Angeles, CA, and Patricia Novajosky of Wallingford, CT. He is also survived by his brother Richard of Chapel Hill, NC as well as four grand children: Anna and Kevin Cooper as well as Ryan and Evan McGurk. Under the loving care of Tony Wiredu at his home in Yorktown, NY, he played his beloved piano to the last. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at the family home on October 24th at 1:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Salk Institute for Biological Studies 10010 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037.

WIESEN--Lawrence E. , died October 19th of complications stemming from progressive supranuclear palsy. Larry is survived by his beloved wife, Judy, his children Eric (Marika), David and Jeff and his brother Rob (Erica). He was predeceased by his father, Leo, and his mother, Irene. Larry was born on March 23, 1945 and grew up in Valley Stream, New York. He was a graduate of Cornell University, and received a Masters of Arts and Ph.D. in Psychology from Case Western Reserve. He also received an MBA from the Stern School of Business at New York University. He was a resident of Chappaqua, New York before moving to San Rafael, California in 1985. Larry was an executive of American Express Company and Fireman's Fund Insurance Company before striking out on his own, opening a restaurant and becoming a founding partner in a consulting firm. A memorial service will be held at his home, 60 Margarita Drive, San Rafael CA, 94901 on Tuesday October 21 at Noon. The family will be receiving visitors after the service, Tuesday evening from 5-9 and on Wednesday from 3-9. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to UCSF Memory and Aging center c/o Tamara Scott, Practice Manager, PO Box 1207 San Francisco, CA 94143-1207.

A Sunday night episode of the Fox animated series ''Family Guy'' stirred up trouble by suggesting -- rather directly -- that Nazi officers would have supported the McCain-Palin ticket. And it was another arm of the News Corporation conglomerate, Fox News Channel, that first raised questions about the episode. Fox (the broadcast network) ran the episode in which Stewie, the obnoxious baby character at the center of the series, and Brian, a talking dog, traveled back in time to Poland during the 1939 German invasion. The characters ambush Nazi soldiers in an alley and steal their uniforms so they can travel without drawing attention. Putting on an overcoat, Stewie notices a McCain-Palin campaign button affixed to the lapel. ''Huh, that's weird,'' Stewie remarks.

New features include commentary by Peter Bogdanovich, Bill Krohn and Patrick McGilligan, as well as excerpts from Hitchcock's interviews with François Truffaut. (MGM-Fox, $119.98, not rated)

MAUER--Irving . In San Francisco on October 14, 2008 at age 93. Beloved father of Eric (Inna Yerikhova) Mauer of San Francisco; dear brother of Myron Mauer of Yonkers, NY; dear uncle of Amy Mauer-Litos, Eliana Sarah Litos, Carole Schwack and Michael Mauer. A loving devoted husband, father, brother and uncle. A just and honorable Jew, a wonderful teacher for 45 years in New York City. A proud progressive and truly decent human being. SAXE--Marie P . Beloved wife of 34 years of Bob Saxe, she died of Pneumonia and Ovarian Cancer on October 19, 2008. Born in Atlanta, GA. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 82nd St.

REH--Sheila Natkins , died peacefully on October 20. Beloved and extraordinarily devoted mother of Virginia, sister of the late Morty and Ephraim and wife of the late Bill. Adored sister-in-law, mother-in-law, and aunt. Sheila's smile, ''gift of gab'' and love of family and friends will always be remembered. She was a woman of style, substance, strength and grace. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at 1pm on Sunday, October 26 at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, Veterans' Memorial Hall, 1000 Richmond Terrace, SI, NY 10301, to which donations may be sent in lieu of flowers.

MORRIS--Herbert , passed away on October 19, 2008, at age 79. Survived by wife Susan, former wife Myrna, children Monte, Marcie, Westly, Wade, Zachary, and Joshua, and seven grandchildren. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, October 22, at 10am, Riverside Chapel, at 76th and Amsterdam.

BOONE--Geraldine Living ston Babcock , 86, died from leukemia October 8 at her home of 58 years in Princeton, NJ. She was the widow of the late Rowan Boone. She graduated from The Brearley School in New York City and Benningtion College. She attended the University of Pennsylvania for graduate school in social work. Born in New York City, she made her home in Princeton where she committed her life to civil rights, social justice and humanitarian concerns. She helped organize the Princeton Association for Human Rights, The Youth Employment Service, The Princeton Study Center, and The Child Placement Review Board for abused and neglected children. She was also very active with the Juvenile Conference Center during the 60s and 70s. She received the Winifred Latimer Norman Award from the Unitarian Universalist New York Metropolitan District and the Frances Riker Davis Alumnae Award from the Brearley School. She also received outstanding service awards from the Princeton Area Council of Community Services and the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges. She is survived by her children, John Boone and wife, Jenny Dixon, of Brooklyn, NY, Louise Hanson and husband, Ed, of Chevy Chase, MD, Serena Constantinides and husband Perry of Potomac, MD, Doug Boone and wife Jenny of Providence, RI, Roger Boone of San Francisco, CA, her sister Betsy Moulton of Naples, FL, five grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at the Unitarian Church in Princeton, NJ on Saturday, November 29 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation in her name to The Mercer Street Friends in Trenton, NJ (www.mercer streetfriends.org).

ROBINSON--Gail . The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our beloved colleague, soprano Gail Robinson. Gail made her Met debut in 1970 and went on to sing such leading coloratura parts as Lucia, Gilda, Oscar, and Konstanze. Retiring from the stage in 1987, she immediately began to work with young singers at the Met, directing both our Lindemann Young Artist Development Program and the National Council Auditions, which she herself had won in 1966. Her kindness, warmth, and profound understanding made her an ideal guide for the hundreds of young singers she advised. She was loved and admired by all who worked with her-artists, administrative staff, donors, and volunteers alike. We will miss her deeply and offer sincere condolences to her husband Henno, her children Jennifer and Patrick, and her three grandchildren. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

The release of a highly anticipated video game for the PlayStation 3 console has been delayed after the discovery that its background music included quotations from the Koran. Little Big Planet, right, which was supposed to be released Tuesday, has long been in development, and Sony had hoped to have it in stores for the holiday retail season. According to a post by a Sony spokesman, Patrick Seybold, on the official Sony PlayStation blog (blog.us.playstation.com), the game's developers discovered that one of the ''background music tracks licensed from a record label for use in the game contains two expressions that can be found'' in the Koran, which some may find offensive. Sony has apologized and removed the music. It plans to ship Little Big Planet to stores in North America next week.

Hollandaise sauce, an emulsion of egg and butter, is supremely tempting, but it has two problems: It is overly rich and a bit of a hassle to produce. Fortunately, its flavor and spirit are captured in a leaner, more contemporary sauce made with hard-cooked eggs, a relatively small amount of butter and some stock. Over plain steamed fish, it's a winner.

The Russian K.H.L. announced that two fully equipped ambulances must be present at all league games under a new set of regulations governing emergency medical response, passed in the aftermath of Alexei Cherepanov's death last week. [Weekly Standard]
The financial crisis has stoked widespread concern that momentum toward policies on climate change and sustainability is about to stall.

Following is the first set of answers from John Steele Gordon, the author of "An Empire of Wealth: The Epic History of American Economic Power," answered selected readers' questions about the history of wealth in New York through Friday. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.
How well in the front of the Heisman campaign is Colt McCoy?

The week that Russia invaded Georgia, I received a rather flattering e-mail message from a colleague asking if I would be interested "in doing a quick list of good books about Russia/Georgia" for Paper Cuts. It was flattering because even though I'm one of the Book Review's editors responsible for foreign affairs, my fellow-editor assumed I had much more knowledge than I did. As I explained to him, just about the only thing I knew about Georgia was that Stalin came from there. I didn't even know how to pronounce "South Ossetia." (I'm exaggerating: actually, I did pretty well with "South.") I was still busy trying to get my mind around South Waziristan.
More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, Oct. 22:

GOFFSTOWN, N.H.- Things do not look good for Senator John McCain in New Hampshire, but he came here on Wednesday anyway, just 13 days before the election, to offer what sometimes sounded like a last goodbye.

Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway personal gliding transporter and other gadgets for the world's well-to-do, has joined a growing array of innovators and entrepreneurs focusing their skills on the persistent plight of the world's poorest billion people or so (hat tip to GreenTech). As Paul Polak, Amy Smith and others have been stressing, the best route forward is not charity, but availability of suitably scaled sources of nonpolluting energy for lighting, cooking, and communication and other technologies that can become a source of jobs and income.
From our friends at Dot Earth

Politics | An academic says polls would be more accurate if the media weren't so cheap and interested in hyping the horse race. He says "a survey of four times as many people would reduce uncertainty by a factor of two. But why pay four times as much for data that generate a lower likelihood of an apparent - and reportable - swing?" [Princeton Election Consortium]
(AP)
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
General Motors has revealed another asset that might land on the auction block as the giant automaker seeks to raise as much as $4 billion from divestitures.

Lexicon | The meltdown is really forcing us to beef up on our business vocabulary. Let's see, there's the Libor (the interest rate for banks lending to each other); the Ted spread (the difference between the rate for minimal-risk Treasury bills and the Libor rate); and now the Baltic Dry Index, which measures global demand for shipping -- i.e., what's likely to happen in the real economy. And this index has been plummeting like a rock: 86 percent from its peak in May. It's not a good sign, folks. [Economist, Agence France-Presse]

First the easy part: Cruz Azul of Mexico eliminated D.C. United of Major League Soccer from the Concacaf Champions League in a match played Tuesday night in Mexico City. Nicolas Vigneri and Pablo Zeballos scored for the Cement Mixers.
So the McCain campaign spent $150,000 during the month of September to outfit "hockey mom" Sarah Palin in a new set of designer duds every day?
Of the many thousands of men's softball teams around the country, how many are run by a guy who also owns a Major League baseball team that is playing in the World Series?

Updated, 5 p.m. | A state judge on Wednesday afternoon denied a petition by two City Council members to bar the Council from voting Thursday on a bill that would allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and most of the city's elected officials to serve a third four-year term. (See related post on other term-limits developments on Wednesday.)
A simple Sharpie pen is emerging as an effective tool to prevent surgical errors and infections.

Today's Minimalist column and video, about kasha varnishkes, the Eastern European Jewish thing I grew up eating -- kasha, noodles and onions fried in chicken fat -- was an odd one. First, because I've been writing this column for more than 11 years, and was stunned to find that I'd never covered it. Second, because it helped me realize that we all grow up eating "ethnic" or international food -- at least it's ethnic or international to someone -- and that's the food we most take for granted. (And, often, have the warmest, strongest feelings about; I was hearing interesting comments about this column even before it was officially published.)
BAGHDAD -- So, a few weeks ago I met a guy on a highway near Abu Ghraib.
Tillandsia air plants available at Design Within Reach.

Updated, 12:15 p.m. | For years, Fred Hadley, a longtime resident and gadfly at the North Shore Towers in Queens, had been infuriating the complex's management. This month, they swatted Mr. Hadley all the way to Florida.
A light schedule in junior hockey, with only the Western Hockey League in action. The report follows.

Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Remember John Kerry? He ran for president and didn't do that well. He's being criticized for telling a joke about John McCain wearing adult diapers. How dare you, sir! That's my job! Knock it off, Kerry! I'll tell the McCain diaper jokes; you stick with losing elections to the least popular president ever in the history of America.

Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Barack Obama is taking time off from campaigning to visit his sick grandmother in Hawaii. Normally, it would be a bad idea to take time off two weeks before the presidential election. But at this point, Obama is far enough ahead that the only thing really that can stop his campaign is if he finds a mysterious bad luck Tiki doll on the beach.

Many corn producers in the United States, invigorated by high food prices, government subsidies and increased demand for their crops as feedstock for ethanol production, had much to celebrate this year.
Move over, London and Frankfurt. By one measure, the capital of European finance these days is farther east: Warsaw.
Todd Hasak-Lowy is the author of "Captives," a novel.

"Midnight Club: Los Angeles" was released on Tuesday. It is the fourth installment of a street-racing video game series produced by the makers of Grand Theft Auto, but it is the first Midnight Club made for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, which means it is technologically more sophisticated than its predecessors in every way.

While there have been signs this week that the icy credit markets are thawing, Wachovia provided a reminder that the nation's banking troubles are far from over. The Charlotte, N.C.-based bank today reported the largest quarterly loss by any lender in the United States during the current financial crisis. Earlier this month, Wells Fargo agreed to buy Wachovia for $15.1 billion.
Don't expect to see Kimbo Slice fighting on CBS again soon.
How else would an airline inaugurate a new terminal these days, except by Twittering it?

It's been almost a week since the Philadelphia Phillies played a baseball game. Six days to be exact. It's also been a while since baseball fans have seen a competitive and exciting World Series. Will the dreariness end tonight when the Tampa Bay Rays host the Phillies in Game 1?
Bob McTeer is a former president of the Dallas Fed.

AC Milan's chief executive said the Serie A team was in talks to bring David Beckham to the San Siro on loan in January. Milan was one of Beckham's suitors when he decided to leave Real Madrid in 2007, but it lost out to the L.A. Galaxy. With the Major League Soccer season winding down (the Galaxy will probably miss the playoffs for a second straight year), Beckham is looking to keep playing in order to secure a spot in Fabio Capello's England lineup.
The latest campaign news, including interviews with Times reporters.

Election Day is in two weeks. Or is the campaign already over? "At this point it would be difficult to see Republican losses in the Senate and House to be fewer than seven and 20 respectively," Charlie Cook writes in his National Journal column. "A very challenging situation going into September turned into a meltdown last month, the most dire predictions for the G.O.P. early on became the most likely outcome. The metrics of this election argue strongly that this campaign is over, it's only the memory of many an election that seemed over but wasn't that is keeping us from closing the book mentally on this one." Among Cook's reasons:
Wachovia's deal to buy Golden West Financial was a textbook case of terrible timing: That much was already clear even before Wachovia
The Champions Hockey League moves to Match Day 2 with four games on Wednesday, all telecast live, two of them live on the Web in North America.

Let's, for a moment, jump into the ol' way-back machine and travel back in time to mid-September. It seems like so long ago: Wisconsin and Auburn were top-10 teams and East Carolina (now 4-3) was the news media darling du jour. Ah, what an innocent time it was.

A federal judge has awarded $4.6 million in back pay and damages to 36 delivery workers at two Saigon Grill restaurants in Manhattan, finding blatant and systematic violations of minimum-wage and overtime laws. In a decision dated Monday and released on Tuesday, Magistrate Judge Michael H. Dolinger of United States District Court in Manhattan found violations of federal and state wage laws in awarding up to $328,000 to some of the deliverymen.

Education | A look at the "most controversial figure in American public education": Michelle Rhee, 38-year-old, Korean-American chancellor of Washington, D.C.'s long-neglected public schools. She's pushing charter schools, vouchers and the No Child Left Behind Act and wielding a "giant axe." She's "colliding head-on with the political wants of adults," some who see her as the vanguard of a gentrified, post-black Washington. [Atlantic]
The folks at Crooked Timber are having some fun with right-wing bloggers who say things like this:

My colleague David Leonhardt has a column this morning in which he points out something that often gets overlooked: not everybody with a mortgage that's "in trouble" is going to default. Yes, there are plenty of people who bought homes they couldn't afford, or agreed to adjustable interest rates that have risen too high, or, as David points out, find themselves in reduced circumstances as the economic contraction causes them to lose their jobs.

Shifts in advertising buys from state to state signal a candidate's strategy. The Times's Jim Rutenberg reports that the McCain campaign is scaling back its ad buys in key states: New Hampshire, Wisconsin, Colorado, Maine and Minnesota. Mr. Rutenberg writes: "Democrats were predicting Mr. McCain would use the savings to increase his advertising in Pennsylvania and, possibly, Ohio and Florida, all of which have become that much more vital should Mr. McCain have to concede states like Colorado and Wisconsin."
More of your "late night" humor (send via the comment link below):

Distressed debt prices have been plummeting. But despite the availability of increasingly cheap targets, the growing committee of so-called vulture funds that invest in shaky bonds and loans is only dipping in an occasional talon, Breakingviews notes.

Industry observers were predicting Tuesday a fresh round round of M&A to sweep the regional banking industry, as five such institutions, including National City and U.S. Bancorp, reported another round of painful results and analysts said their business will worsen as the economy deteriorates.

Cerberus Capital Management's talks to sell Chrysler to General Motors may not include selling the auto maker's finance unit, an industry which the private equity giant thinks plays to its strengths, Bloomberg News reported.

One of the biggest boosters of the American auto industry said Tuesday that he was bailing out of his large stake in the Ford Motor Company - a stinging no-confidence vote that raised the anxiety level in this city over the deepening troubles of the Big Three car companies, The New York Times's Bill Vlasic writes.
For decades, Americans have considered money-market mutual funds as safe as bank accounts. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve pledged $540 billion to make sure they really are.
Conventional wisdom across the globe is that American authorities made a ghastly error in not saving Lehman Brothers.
From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

Argentina's government said Tuesday that it would seek to nationalize nearly $30 billion in private pension funds to protect retirees from falling stock and bond prices as the global financial crisis continues, The New York Times's Alexei Barrionuevo reported.

Texert, a provider of risk-management software, has nabbed $3 million in first-round financing from New Venture Partners. The start-up said it will use the cash to update product line and expand sales and marketing efforts.
The Bank of Canada reduced its key lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point on Tuesday, about half the amount most analysts had expected, The New York Times's Ian Austen reported.

Politics | With Pennsylvania looking like an electoral O.K. Corral, Scranton, part of the state's current blue-collar mythology, is actually bucking its stereotype of an industrial center in decline. It's getting more white-collar; the population's growing; downtown's being renovated; and tourism is spiking "thanks in no small part to 'The Office.' " [Wall Street Journal]

Falling confidence in the corporate sector sent stocks lower on Tuesday as investors digested a discouraging batch of earnings reports and a new initiative from the Federal Reserve to shore up money-market mutual funds, The New York Times's Michael M. Grynbaum reported.
It was just another business-as-usual day at the annual convention of the nation's mortgage bankers: a few panels, a few presentations and an attempted abduction of Karl Rove.

This month, as markets plummeted and investors panicked, Italy's billionaire prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, watched shares in some of his own companies nose-dive 40 percent. Yet he seemed buoyant as ever, reveling until dawn at a disco in Milan after returning from a meeting with European leaders on how to tackle the financial crisis.

A fresh report has surfaced that hedge fund manager James Pallotta plans to relaunch his Raptor Global Fund as a spinoff from Tudor Investment Corporation, the firm run by his longtime partner, Paul Tudor Jones.

Wachovia reported a $23.9 billion net loss for its third quarter, as the struggling bank took nearly $19 billion in goodwill impairment and $6.6 billion in charges related to potential losses on its troublesome mortgages.
The former chief executive of E*Trade Financial, Mitchell Caplan, has signed on at private equity firm Aquiline Capital Partners as an executive adviser, the firm announced Tuesday.
Deal talks may be continuing between Chrysler and General Motors, but both companies are reportedly mulling alternatives to a hook-up.
Does Carl C. Icahn fancy himself a movie mogul?
The Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday said emergency conditions warranted its expedited action to approve Wells Fargo bid to acquire weakened banking rival Wachovia Corp..

Terror | Speaking on the release of his book, an incognito ex-Delta Force tracker of Osama bin Laden says he learned two surprising things about his prey: He keeps around him people of his same blood type in case he needs a transfusion, and he was prepared to send women and children into battle when things got dicey in Tora Bora. So, he seems like "an actual human being, with actual fears and concerns for his own health, his own survival." [Time]

U.S. federal prosecutors probing the collapse of Lehman Brothers Holdings have subpoenaed other securities firms, asking whether their analysts were misled by Lehman about its financial health, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

Zoe Cruz, the former Morgan Stanley co-president pushed out of the securities firm late last year, is considering a job at an asset-management firm or raising money for a hedge fund, TheStreet.com's Dan Freed reported, citing a person familiar with her thinking.

The turmoil in global markets deepened Wednesday, as stocks fell sharply in Europe and Asia, and the euro and British pound fell to their lowest points against the dollar in years, The New York Times's David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.
Shares in Rio Tinto, the global mining giant, jumped 5 percent in a weak market on Wednesday, swept up by rumors ranging from a sweetened cash bid by BHP Billiton to a Chinese counterbid.

Top Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives on Tuesday called for the appointment of a special counsel to investigate "fraud and mismanagement" at troubled mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

The International Monetary Fund, onetime firefighter for the global economy, is suddenly being called back into action, even as its chief stumbles on his way to the rescue, The New York Times's Mark Landler writes.

Sergei A. Storchak, a former chief sovereign debt negotiator for Russia and a close ally of the country's finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, was released Tuesday after spending 11 months in pretrial detention in an embezzlement case viewed as having political undertones, The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer reported.
Elvis could get a second chance at life, Bat Boy may yet outwit government scientists, and politicians' chances of adopting alien babies just improved.

The global credit turmoil and the grim outlook for economic growth claimed another victim in mergers and acquisitions on Wednesday as Samsung Electronics withdrew its $5.9 billion takeover bid for the flash memory card maker SanDisk, citing poor earnings potential at the American company and the current financial crisis, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.

The Nasdaq Stock Market's decision to suspend one of its own listing rules comes as an avalanche of shares tumble below the $1 threshold, and is intended to avoid the mass delistings that followed the burst of the dot-com bubble.

History | An article casts doubt on the accepted wisdom that Orson Welles' infamous 1938 "War of the Worlds" radio broadcast caused a big panic among credulous listeners. It says the panic idea was hyped by a hucksterish Welles; the media, which loved it; and a researcher who spun iffy listener-survey data. The "ultimate irony" here: "the discovery that the media are not all-powerful." Exact opposite of the myth. [Chronicle Review]

Apple generates so much hype and gratuitous superlatives that it can be hard to distinguish when it has done something that is truly remarkable. But going over what Apple said in its earnings release and conference call Tuesday, it's clear that the dimensions of its cellphone business - its sales, profits and market share - deserve the strongest words of praise that can be summoned.
If the nation is seriously considering electing a black president, aren't we past the point of caring about the race of a quarterback?
Donovan McNabb started a controversy last fall when he said black quarterbacks were judged more harshly than white ones.

Society | Noting the fascination with the large families of Sarah Palin and Angelina Jolie, the founder of Larger Families lists the upsides to a big brood. For one, "the fact that I have to divide my time between them pretty much eliminates the danger of my turning into a 'helicopter parent.' " Across the pond, a father of five agrees. [Christian Science Monitor, Daily Mail]

Economics | A Harvard economist responds to a declaration of "The End of Libertarianism" (noted here Tuesday): "Excuse me? Are you serious?" The United States has not pursued libertarian policies for a century, he says. "Indeed, except for a brief moment before Alexander Hamilton engineered the first U.S. bailout of financial markets, not ever." If the libertarians had run things, he says, there would have been no federal promotion of home ownership, no Fed, no S.E.C. And things would be different now. [Reason]
Bobby Thomson's 1951 home run for the Giants was a great event in baseball. But, more important, it brought sporting events into American living rooms.

The number of home sales in the U.K. dropped 53 percent in the last year, according to government data released Tuesday. Even in the current financial climate, Global Insight analyst Howard Archer called the numbers "dismal" news.

Despite the financial crisis, the trend toward putting a price on trees, water and animals, and then creating markets for these goods, seems to be gaining momentum. Investors like the idea of environmental markets because the goods generate "credits" that can be bought and sold just like other commodities.

The world championship match in Bonn, Germany, may not be over, but it is certainly not looking good for the challenger, Vladimir Kramnik of Russia. Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, won his third game of the match yesterday and now leads the best-of12 contest 4.5 to 1.5. More information about the match and the players is on the match Web site.

The Department of Defense has identified 4,180 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 611 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week :.

Surgical mesh has been linked to serious complications in women undergoing procedures to treat incontinence or hold their pelvic organs in place, the Food and Drug Administration said. The complications include infection, urinary problems and pain during sexual intercourse, the agency said. Nine manufacturers of the mesh, who were not identified, have sent the F.D.A. more than 1,000 reports of complications over the past three years, the agency said.

Dozens of members of the Mongol motorcycle gang were arrested by federal agents in six states after a three-year undercover investigation in which four agents infiltrated the group. More than 60 members of the gang, based in Southern California, were arrested under a federal racketeering indictment that included charges of murder, attempted murder, assault, and gun and drug violations, a Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives spokesman said. Arrests were made in California, Colorado, Nevada, Ohio, Oregon and Washington.

A man whose conviction in a murder case was thrown out earlier this year after he had served nine years in prison filed a federal lawsuit against the City of Fort Collins, the prosecutors and the police. The suit, in Federal District Court in Denver, says that the man, Timothy Masters, who lived near the crime scene in Fort Collins, was framed by overzealous investigators who suppressed evidence that might have cleared him. A psychiatrist, who was the star prosecution witness at the trial in 1999, told Mr. Masters’s lawyers, the suit said, that he would never have testified as he did if he had been shown the entire police file.

The Web site of the state agency that handles voter registration and other election information was shut down briefly after it was hacked, Secretary of State Jennifer Brunner said. It was restored to partial service after it was determined that no information could be compromised. Republicans and Democrats in the state have been battling over registration rules and early voting procedures. Ms. Brunner, a Democrat, said her office had also been assaulted in recent weeks by a barrage of phone calls and e-mail messages containing “menacing messages and even threats of harm or death.” Last week, a suspicious package covered with threatening messages and containing an unidentified powder was mailed to the office, Ms. Brunner said.
To the Editor:.
Conventional wisdom across the globe is that American authorities made a ghastly error in not saving Lehman Brothers. But was it really such a tragedy?
The Tanger Outlets at the Arches, a $300 million outlet center, is to open in Deer Park, N.Y., on Thursday with 75 stores as well as some entertainment options.
President Nicolas Sarkozy suggested that European leaders set up sovereign wealth funds to buy stakes in crucial industries to shield them from foreign raiders.
Mr. Moore’s standup comedy, records and movies — notably 1975’s “Dolemite” — related earthy tales that helped shape today’s hip-hop.
Wal-Mart plans to announce that it will require manufacturers supplying goods for its stores to adhere to stricter ethical and environmental standards.
A jury ordered Boeing’s satellite division to pay at least $370 million for breaching a contract to build and launch satellites for ICO Global Communications.
Samsung Electronics said that it withdrew its bid to acquire the flash memory card maker SanDisk, citing “growing uncertainties” in SanDisk’s business.

Gov. M. R. Patterson of Tennessee "has proposed a conference of Governors of six Southern States" to take action against the "night riders" who on Monday night killed Capt. Quentin Rankin, chief counsel of the West Tennessee Land and Improvement Company, in apparent retaliation for company moves to take over Reelfoot Lake and bar them from fishing in it. Col. R. Z. Taylor, the company president who was believed to have been slain with Rankin, is alive and well. His story is that when the night riders lynched Rankin and riddled his head and body with bullets, emptying their guns, Taylor, who is "near 70 years of age," saw his chance and "dashed away in the darkness and swam across a creek." Then "over 100 shots were fired at him in the water," he said, so "he dropped dead, employing a trick that he says he put in action during the civil war." When he was "left for dead," he got up and "walked through Monday night and all day Tuesday, spent Tuesday night in the woods without food or water," and walked out yesterday "near the Mississippi River." Six States Will Fight Raiders
More than 100 suspects were arrested in Colombia and overseas on charges that they trafficked drugs and laundered cash for Colombia’s Norte del Valle cartel and outlawed paramilitaries.
The ballot proposal to eliminate Massachusetts’s income tax is reckless and would hurt all taxpayers.
Allowing parents to opt out of a New Jersey mandate that requires flu vaccination for preschoolers would be a serious mistake for children and their parents.
If it is premature to protect beluga whales in Cook Inlet now, then the time will be mature, by Gov. Sarah Palin’s logic, only when there are none left.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
A recipe for Almond-Crusted Fillet of Sole.
A recipe for Even Greater American Pound Cake.
A recipe for Steamed Fennel With Red Pepper Oil.
A recipe for Green Chili Milk Sauce (Ají de Leche).
A recipe for Braised Collard Greens With Cranberry Beans and Andouille Sausage.
A recipe for Kasha Varnishkes.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
The Delta Queen, America’s last original paddle-wheeled, steam-driven, overnight passenger boat, may be close to making its last commercial voyage.
In a gratifying “have you no sense of decency, Sir and Madam?” moment, Colin Powell went on “Meet the Press” and pushed back on ugly innuendo.
We can’t afford a financial bailout that also isn’t a green buildup — a buildup of a new clean energy industry that strengthens America.
Unless something is done quickly to help American homeowners avoid foreclosure, the losses could swamp the bailout effort.

Somebeachsomewhere was drawn outside of his five rivals and made the 1-2 early favorite for Yonkers Raceway’s Messenger Stakes. Somebeachsomewhere, the fastest 3-year-old in harness history, will be driven by Paul MacDonell. The Messenger Stakes, the final race in pacing’s Triple Crown, is Saturday.

The Mexican featherweight Daniel Aguillon died after a five-day coma induced by a knockout blow, his family said. Alejandro Sanabria, another Mexican, knocked out Aguillon, 24, last Wednesday, 40 seconds before the end of a Central American featherweight title fight. Doctors operated to treat a blood clot in Aguillon’s brain, but he did not regain consciousness. He was 16-2-4 in his career, with 9 knockouts.

Trevor Graham, the former track coach who trained Marion Jones, Tim Montgomery and other elite runners, was sentenced on Tuesday to one year of home confinement and five years of probation for making false statements to a federal agent in connection with the Balco investigation.

The former Kentucky linebacker Wilbur Hackett Jr.’s latest hit may be his most popular of all. Hackett, a Southeastern Conference official, was the umpire in Saturday night’s L.S.U.-South Carolina game and became an instant Internet sensation for his shoulder-first shot on Gamecocks quarterback Stephen Garcia.

Three Hall of Fame coaches have been chosen to receive the inaugural Joe Lapchick Character Award. Pat Summitt, Lou Carnesecca and Dean Smith will receive the award next month at Madison Square Garden. The award, conceived by Gus Alfieri, a former St. John’s player and a longtime high school coach, was established to recognize basketball coaches who have shown the character and coaching ability of the Hall of Famer Lapchick, who coached St. John’s and the Knicks.

The defending champion Manchester United, Arsenal and Bayern Munich took big strides toward the next round of the Champions League with easy victories, and Juventus beat Real Madrid, 2-1, on a night of high scoring across Europe. Dimitar Berbatov had two goals and Wayne Rooney scored for the ninth time in seven games as Manchester United outplayed the Scottish champion Celtic, 3-0. Arsenal won at Fenerbahce, 5-2, and Bayern shrugged off its poor play in the Bundesliga with a 3-0 victory over Fiorentina.

The reigning champion bull rider, Justin McBride, said he plans to retire after the PBR World Finals next month in Las Vegas. McBride, 29, said he has been thinking about retiring since last year but wanted to make sure he would not miss the competition. McBride, from Elk City, Okla., was sidelined for more than six months with surgery on his left shoulder after winning the title last year. He also won in 2005.
Trevor Graham, the former track coach, was sentenced to one year of home confinement and five years of probation for making false statements in the Balco investigation.
Ten immigrants were arrested on charges that they blocked a sidewalk at a popular gathering place for day laborers in Jackson Heights, Queens.
INTERNATIONAL.
Two priests who lived at Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx sexually abused teenagers there in the 1960s and ’70s, two advocacy groups said.

A report in the Vital Signs column on Tuesday about a new study that suggests the synthetic compound hydrocortisone offers little benefit for premature babies misstated the chemical’s function. Hydrocortisone is intended as a substitute for cortisol, a hormone that is ordinarily produced by the adrenal gland; it does not provoke the gland to produce more cortisol.
After three weeks in rotation purgatory, Stephon Marbury was front and center again, albeit probably temporarily and not without some predictable static.
After a junior linebacker at Montclair High School died from a head injury, the athletic director said that school officials will develop a policy for dealing with concussions.
A picture credit on Tuesday with a dance review of the Mark Lamb company, at Metro Baptist Church, misspelled the photographer’s surname. He is Brad Shew, not Shaw.
Thomas Vanek scored the decisive shootout goal and Ryan Miller stopped four of five chances to cap the Buffalo Sabres’ come-from-behind victory over the Boston Bruins.

The caption for a picture in some editions on Tuesday about the return of a supersonic Concorde jet to the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum at Pier 86 in Manhattan misstated the timing of its removal. It was moved from the pier two years ago, when the Intrepid left to make way for pier repairs — not five years ago.
One officer is in critical condition, the other is stable, after a man they were arresting shot them with one of the officer’s guns.

An article on Monday about criticism of the Bloomberg administration’s move to enlist the support of nonprofit groups for legislation that would allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek a third term in office misstated, in some editions, the job title of one critic, Gene Russianoff of the New York Public Interest Research Group. He is a senior lawyer for the group, not its executive director.

An article on Friday about a NATO airstrike in Afghanistan that local officials said may have killed up to 30 civilians erroneously included a country in the group of NATO members that contribute most of the combat aircraft to the military campaign against the Taliban insurgency. The group includes the United States, Britain and France — but not Canada, which contributes a large contingent of troops to the NATO forces in Afghanistan.
Some time Wednesday morning, Brett Favre will face a sprawling media assembly to explain — what else? — more drama.
Although no arrests were made at the mortgage bankers convention on Tuesday, stage-storming was just one of the latest outbursts to plague the event.
Federal tax officials ruled that the developer of a billion-dollar basketball arena at Brooklyn’s Atlantic Yards can use tax-exempt bonds to pay for the building.
An article on Saturday about Cindy McCain, the wife of the Republican presidential nominee, Senator John McCain, misspelled the surname of one of his former aides. She is Victoria Clarke, not Clark.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the health of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates misidentified the place in Alaska where Gov. Sarah Palin has said her son Trig was born. It is Palmer, a town about 45 miles northeast of Anchorage; she has not said he was born in Anchorage.

An article in some editions on Saturday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s enlistment of nonprofit groups that rely on his private donations to support his efforts to ease term limits overstated the action taken by Safe Space, a charity that works to keep children out of foster care. Safe Space collected signatures for a letter to send to New York City Council members supporting Mr. Bloomberg’s plan, but never lobbied the council members “behind the scenes.” (It ultimately decided not to send the letter.).

The Memo From London article on Tuesday, about the mood of austerity caused by the global financial crisis and fears of looming recession, misstated the total debt amassed by the British public during the consumer spending boom of recent years. It is $2.49 trillion, not billion.
Barack Obama will fly to his ailing grandmother’s bedside on Thursday, suspending his campaign for two days. She is the last survivor of the people who raised him.

That Brett Favre may have shared information about his former team with the rival Detroit Lions is the latest episode in an increasingly bitter split between the quarterback and the Green Bay Packers.
It is good to be Evan Longoria. Good to be 23 years old, good to be perhaps the best rookie in the American League and good to be playing in a World Series in your first season.
Curlin is not the biggest favorite at thoroughbred racing’s world championships — the undefeated filly Zenyatta is.
Congress ratified President Evo Morales’s draft constitution on Tuesday and authorized a nationwide referendum on the proposal on Jan. 25.

VAN SYCKLE--Colonel Lloyd George , Lord of the Manor of Hamptonet, 83, retired Army engineer and intelligence officer at Picatinny Arsenal. He was born October 2, 1925 in Puerta Cortez, Honduras. Died October 19 at home, Sussex, NJ. Blair Academy class of 1942. Attended Princeton, Stevens Institute of Technology and the Army War College. Served in the US Navy during the occupation of China. Member Holland Society, St. Nicholas Society, Society of Colonial Wars, Sons of the Revolution, St. Andrews Society, Netherlands Society of Philadelphia, Order of Founders and Patriots, Colonial Order of the Acorn, Veteran Corps of Artillery, PDDGM the Most Puissant Grand Council of Royal & Select Masters of NJ, PDDGHP Grands Royal Arch Chapter of Royal Arch Masons of NJ, member Army Navy Club and Nassau Club. Survived by son, Lloyd George; daughters, Georgiana Van Syckle and Eloise Mulvihill; grandchildren: Dana, Tyler and Reid Mulvihill; and Benjamin and Andrew Snavely. Visiting hours 2-4, 7-9 Wednesday, October 22, Pinkel, 31 Bank St., Sussex, NJ. Funeral will be held at 11am, Thursday October 23, First Presbyterian Church of Sussex, 21 Unionville Ave. Interment following the ceremony at Beemerville Cemetery.

JIRA--James John , a native New Yorker died at 49 on September 26, 2008. A true New Yorker, ''Jim'' was born on First St. & First Ave. and moved ''uptown'' to Second St. which he used to say was ''a very long trip.'' He left home at an early age, and lived with various alternative communities and friends in the village in the 1970s. School did not agree with him, but early on he showed huge talent in both building things, and creating beautiful drawings and paintings. He was one of the original NYC homesteaders, fixing up an uninhabitable building and acquiring it from the city along with his neighbors, making it into a ''sweat equity'' coop. He renovated numerous apartments in Manhattan, and worked as a studio assistant in recent years. This summer he traveled to the California desert to work on a special installation with old friend Randy Polumbo. Jim's loyalty, dependability, and humor will be missed by friends and family alike. His wonderful paintings will be exhibited in California later this year at Art Queen in Joshua Tree. There will be a service at Middle Collegiate Church at 50 East 7th Street on October 25 at 1pm with a reception after. Please make donations in lieu of flowers to: The Catholic Worker, Maryhouse, 55 E Third St., NY, NY 10003. Phone: 212-777-9617

An airstrike by the American-led coalition hit an Afghan Army checkpoint early Wednesday, killing eight soldiers and wounding four others, Afghan officials said. The checkpoint was in the Sayed Kheil area of Khost Province in eastern Afghanistan, said Arsallah Jamal, the province's governor.

He was a brilliant businessman, an involved and teaching father, an active community member, a leader of the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, and a man of enormous generosity. His family mourns his passing.
