WIESEN--Lawrence E. , died October 19th of complications stemming from progressive supranuclear palsy. Larry is survived by his beloved wife, Judy, his children Eric (Marika), David and Jeff and his brother Rob (Erica). He was predeceased by his father, Leo, and his mother, Irene. Larry was born on March 23, 1945 and grew up in Valley Stream, New York. He was a graduate of Cornell University, and received a Masters of Arts and Ph.D. in Psychology from Case Western Reserve. He also received an MBA from the Stern School of Business at New York University. He was a resident of Chappaqua, New York before moving to San Rafael, California in 1985. Larry was an executive of American Express Company and Fireman's Fund Insurance Company before striking out on his own, opening a restaurant and becoming a founding partner in a consulting firm. A memorial service will be held at his home, 60 Margarita Drive, San Rafael CA, 94901 on Tuesday October 21 at Noon. The family will be receiving visitors after the service, Tuesday evening from 5-9 and on Wednesday from 3-9. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to UCSF Memory and Aging center c/o Tamara Scott, Practice Manager, PO Box 1207 San Francisco, CA 94143-1207.

FOX--Berryl Caplan , beloved wife of Robert Friedman; adoring mother of Matthew, Lia, and Zack; sister of Philip and Steve; daughter of Jean, was taken from us on October 19, at age 50, after a long and courageous battle with ovarian cancer. A graduate of Yale, with a Ph.D. from City University, she had a successful private psychoanalytic practice in Manhattan and was a supervising and training analyst at the William A. White Institute. An admired colleague and gifted therapist and teacher, she was fiercely devoted to her family and her profession. Donations in her memory may be made to CancerCare. Memorial service 10am Thursday at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St.

So Far ... Perfect John Kasay made all three of his field-goal attempts in the Panthers' victory against the Saints, improving to 14 for 14 this season. Kasay is one of five regular kickers -- the Titans' Rob Bironas, the Texans' Kris Brown, the Lions' Jason Hanson and the Steelers' Jeff Reed -- who have not missed a kick this season. In fact, it has been a banner year for all kickers. No extra points have been missed, and field-goal accuracy (85.9 percent) has never been higher. JOHN WOODS

Had the Jets defeated the Raiders in overtime Sunday, Oakland Coach Tom Cable would have had some explaining to do. He called a timeout just before Jay Feely's field goal late in regulation. Feely missed, but Cable's move allowed him another attempt, which he made. Stefan Fatsis, author of ''A Few Seconds of Panic,'' an account of his George Plimpton-style tryout as a Denver Broncos kicker, said Tuesday that kickers had told him that ''icing'' them doesn't work. He said in an e-mail message: ''But they're happy to let opposing coaches think it does. Jason Elam, the Broncos' kicker when I spent training camp with the team, said the few extra moments afforded by a timeout gives kickers more time to prepare. They can better consider wind, distance and ball placement, and take a few more practice swings.''

HAGERTY--Harry C., Jr . The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Harry C. Hagerty Jr., a Life member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Brian M. Murphy, President Brian G. Andersson, Historian HAGERTY--Harry C., Jr., passed away peacefully on October 21, 2008, in Brunswick, Georgia at the age of 79 from complications related to melanoma. He was born April 10, 1929 in New York City to Eileen Foley Hagerty and Harry C. Hagerty Sr. He was graduated from Portsmouth Priory and the University of Notre Dame. He served in the United States Navy as an aide to Admiral Walter Ellery Moore in Korea. Upon his return, he commenced a career as a Member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was a partner in Adler, Coleman and Co. and Managing Partner of its successor, CMJ Partners. He retired in 1990 and moved to Sea Island, Georgia in 1994, where he enjoyed many happy years. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Mary Ann (Coleman); children Harry C. Hagerty III, Elizabeth H. Dessen and John C. Hagerty; and nine grandchildren. A wake will be held at Edo Miller & Sons Funeral Home, 3321 Glynn Avenue, Brunswick, GA, from 4pm to 6pm on Thursday, October 23. A Funeral Mass in celebration of Harry's life will be held at St. Williams Catholic Church, St. Simons Island, GA, on Friday, October 24 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Southeast Georgia Health System Foundation, 2415 Parkwood Drive, Brunswick, GA 31520.

The subject came up at a dinner Mr. Matthews attended last week that was held by Senator Barack Obama's biggest New York fund-raiser and attended by a phalanx of generous contributors to Democratic candidates.

REILLY--WIlliam F . The Trustees and staff of WNET.ORG, parent company of Thirteen and WLIW21, mourn the passing of William F. Reilly. A visionary businessman who made a lasting mark in the field of publishing, Bill also served his country as an officer in the 82nd Airborne Division of the U.S. Army and contributed to the betterment of society as a philanthropist. He joined Thirteen's Board of Trustees in 1995, serving on the Executive, Development, Marketing and Public Affairs Committees, and was named a Life Trustee in 2007. We are deeply grateful for his commitment to preparing the institution for the future through strengthening WNET.ORG's endowment and completing the critical conversion to digital broadcasting. We extend our condolences to his children Jane and Anthony, his sister Elizabeth, and his extended family. We grieve the loss of our good friend and remember his enduring contributions to our work. James S. Tisch Chairman Neal Shapiro President and CEO

LAUREN--Susan . To our beautiful, sweet, courageous friend. So many wonderful evenings imparting all our personal thoughts and feelings that only true friends would understand. Jerry, you are a beacon for those of us who witnessed your devotion during this trying time. With much love, Barbara and Arnold Cohen LAUREN--Susan. We are grieving over the loss of our dear friend Susan. She was the quintessential lady. A loving and cherished wife, adoring mother and grandmother and a treasure of a friend. We will miss her warmth, style and humor. Our most heart felt condolences to Jerry, Brad, Greg, Jenny and the entire Lauren family. Judy and Bruce Newman LAUREN--Susan. To the Lauren Family, we sincerely feel your pain and sorrow. To us, Susan was a bright shining star who we loved and admired. We were so proud to have called her our dear friend. We will truly miss her. Love, Linda and Stuart Schlesinger LAUREN--Susan, our dear and brave friend. We will keep your beautiful spirit alive in our hearts forever. Our love and devotion to Jerry, Brad, Amy, Greg, Elizabeth, and Jenny. Bette-Ann and Charles Gwathmey LAUREN--Susan. Our beautiful friend both inside and out, we will miss you. Love to Jerry and the family. Ninah and Michael. LAUREN--Susan. Wonderful friend and supporter of The Costume Institute. She illuminated our basement offices with her vivid presence. Her colleagues in the Museum will miss her vivacious and generous spirit, her lively contributions both scholarly and personal from her many years as a dearly valued docent, and her graceful beauty and effortless chic which she never relinquished. The Staff of The Costume Institute

WIGGS--Irving . The loving great-grandparent of six, grandparent of 11, and father of three. His wife, Gloria, joins us in mourning his loss. Irv was 94, he was a decorated hero of the second World War in the United States Navy. He spent his professional life in retailing to the age of 75, and when retired he continued in the business world. We will miss him, and hold him always in our hearts. ''For he who lives more lives than one, more deaths than one must die.'' WIGGS--Irving. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Irving Wiggs, beloved husband, father, grandfather, great - grand father, on October 20, 2008. He was 94 years old. He is the proud father of three sons, Dr. Robert Maslansky, Paul Maslansky, and Michael, who passed away. A proud grandfather of eight and a proud great-grandfather of seven. He also has one niece, Grace Wiggs, and one nephew, Dr. Richard Wiggs. He graduated valedictorian. Graduating from NYU he held a BA and a MA. He did his graduate work at the School of Education. He started on his Ph.D. at Columbia, Teacher's College. He was a Secondary School Teacher and a Guidance Counselor. After that, he was at Lewis County High Schools for just a year. He created New York's first guidance program for rural counties, and it is being used today. Family death necessitated leaving to take over family business, the Hudson View Hotel in Haverstraw, New York. He was Manager of the Hotel and Golf Club. There he met his late wife, Beatrice Plosky Wiggs. He joined the U.S. Navy in 1942 as an Apprentice Seaman; he came out as Lieutenant. He was Destroyer CIC officer, with five battle stars. In his final month, he was Acting Captain of the Navy's largest WWII destroyer. He was BuPers, where he initiated Navy's enlisted classification program. He was president of Bergen Mall New Jersey, and Peck's, Kansas City, Missouri, White Department Store Division. He was Vice President and General Manager at Gimbel's of the ninestore division in the New York Metro Area. His last three years were the best in New York division's history. He was a workaholic and a true gentleman. He was a golf pro and tennis champion and the recipient of many outstanding awards. Gloria Stevens Wiggs married him in 1984, and that marriage lasted nearly 25 years.

Ever since I was last in Shetland - the northernmost archipelago of that greater archipelago, the British Isles - I've had an Ordnance Survey map of the remotest of these islands pinned to the wall of the room where I write. Foula - which is pronounced "Foola" - to me, the very name sounds romantic; but then I love an island, and the smaller and remoter the better, within reason. For eleven years I've been promising I'll make it to this three-and-a-half by two-and-a-half mile niblet of a landmass that sits, like some Avalon, 15 miles off the west coast of Shetland, out in the tempestuous Atlantic.

Whenever I canvas the experts on where the jobs are in today's turbulent market, one answer I always get is that there are ample opportunities, if you're willing to leave the United States. That has started to become the refrain I sing to many job seekers who ask me for advice, especially those who are interested in travel and adventure (and who are often, though not exclusively, on the younger end of the spectrum and without family or financial commitments.) A few months ago, I started corresponding with Rachel Nolan, who graduated from Harvard in 2007 and moved to Berlin last September to see if she could break into journalism by living in a place with little competition and cheap rent. Today, we have a guest post from Ms. Nolan about how her experiment is going. -- Marci

The city's Department of Education, long criticized for basing all three of its citywide (and particularly prestigious) elementary school talented-and-gifted programs in Manhattan, says it is "in the process of identifying sites" for citywide elementary school gifted programs in Brooklyn and Queens, to open in September 2009. The department, in a news release, said it was also "tentatively planning to open citywide programs in the Bronx and Staten Island in September 2010."While gifted classes are available in all boroughs to children by their districts, the three selective elementary schools that cull the highest-performing children from throughout the city -- the Anderson School, NEST and TAG Young Scholars -- are all based in Manhattan.

For most of its history, the Sagrantino grape grew solely in Italy, in the Umbrian town of Montefalco. It made a sweet wine used for sacramental purposes. In the 1980s a dry style emerged. I adore its sandpaper-like tannins, sun-baked fruit and rusty iron acidity. Two favorites of mine are Filippo Antonelli, whose wine is shy and elegant, and Paolo Bea, which is chestnut, honeyed and seductive. So when my friend Kevin Hamel raised the possibility of making wine with Sagrantino grapes in California with Ridgely Evers of DaVero, the olive oil and wine producer in the Dry Creek Valley in Sonoma County, I was interested.

Updated, 7:30 p.m. | After a spirited, emotional and at times raucous debate, the New York City Council voted, 29 to 22, on Thursday afternoon to extend term limits, allowing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek re-election next year and undoing the result of two voter referendums that had imposed a limit of two four-year terms.The vote was a major victory for Mayor Bloomberg -- a billionaire and lifelong Democrat who was elected mayor as a Republican in 2001, won re-election in 2005, became an independent last year, and decided just weeks ago that he wished to seek a third term for himself in 2009 -- and for the Council's speaker, Christine C. Quinn. But the intense acrimony surrounding the decision left a sharply divided Council and could ultimately damage the mayor's popularity.

Indult is a tiny Parisian perfume house founded and run by Julien Maselli. It functions according to a clubby modus operandi whereby Maselli makes only 999 bottles of each perfume; when you buy a bottle, you get an Indult membership card -- the name comes from medieval Latin; an indultum was a privilege accorded by the church or a king -- and you can get it refilled until you die. (You can, of course, choose to make your card sufficiently plastic to cover friends, family, your trainer, his accountant and your entire entourage.) All the Indult scents are created by the perfumer Francis Kurkdjian, one of the three or four most talented and innovative artists working in the medium. Currently there are five Indult perfumes. Four are excellent.

Noha al-Ostaz, a 27-year-old Egyptian filmmaker, was standing on the side of a busy, traffic-choked Cairo street last June when a van driver reached out of his window and groped her. Then, pulling at her body, he looked into her face and laughed. Ms. Ostaz had seen women harassed on the crowded streets of the city before, and had seen them do nothing about it. Something inside her clicked.

The Labor Department released its weekly report on jobless benefits this morning, and it showed that layoffs continue to mount. Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics noted that the number of people filing a first-time claim for unemployment insurance reached a new high in the current downturn and said it was "consistent with a deep recession."
Designers Guild, a London company known for its brightly colored modern textiles, has just introduced the Royal Collection of fabrics and wallpapers.

For a 13-month stretch starting in March 2005, three environmentalists working for the Chesapeake Climate Action Network were listed in a Maryland State Police data base as being "suspected of involvement in terrorism." The description went on to note that the police had "no evidence whatsoever of any involvement in violent crime," and the listing, and possible tracking, did not continue. But the activists -- not surprisingly -- were not happy to hear about this when they received letters from the state police earlier this month informing them of the situation. [UPDATE: 3:30 p.m.: The climate group has been involved in civil disobedience, both before and since the law enforcement listing. But my guess is it would be hard to characterize such incidents as anything remotely resembling terrorism.] The American Civil Liberties Union is investigating the investigations.

A new study shows that the number of positive stories about Senator Barack Obama rose as his poll numbers rose, and negative stories about Senator John McCain rose as his numbers fell, Katharine Q. Seelye writes in her column.

Bloomberg to seek a third term next year and override two voter referendums that had imposed the current limit of two four-year terms. (The Council convened to debate the matter at 2:22 p.m. Updates here.)

Today's lead story concerns a brief letter written in 1906 by former President Grover Cleveland, deploring the resurgence of William Jennings Bryan in the Democratic Party. Cleveland, a Democrat, died June 24, and this letter was already reported in a front-page article (The TimesTraveler, Oct. 2, 1908), but with the name of the recipient withheld. Now it is published in full in the most prominent position in the paper, and the recipient, Col. Felix A. Reeve, Assistant Solicitor of the Treasury Department, verifies that it is genuine. Bryan Scored by Cleveland

Marathon runners know they’ll encounter both pain and — if they’re lucky — ecstacy during their races. But perhaps no event provides such stark mood swings as the New York City Marathon. In “A Race Like No Other: 26.2 Miles Through the Streets of New York” (Harper, $24.95), Liz Robbins, a reporter at The Times, follows the emotions of both elite and amateur runners through last year’s race. She writes that, after the silence and loneliness of crossing the Queensboro Bridge, runners pass the 16-mile marker and find themselves “running toward Nirvana” — the four-deep crowds lining First Avenue. “This,” Robbins writes, “is the moment when every New York City marathoner, first-timer or long-timer, amateur or professional, becomes a champion.” At least until they hit the infamous wall, that is.

The Sun Valley in central Idaho is challenging to reach, about a 12-hour drive from Seattle, San Francisco or Denver. The closest big airport is more than two hours away. All of which means that the quality mountain biking trails — some 450 miles of them — are practically free of other riders, no matter what time of year. Encounters with wildlife, however, are another matter. As The Times reports, “Seeing a mountain lion on the trail is rare, but a moose on Main Street, or a bear in the garbage, is not unknown. Deer, elk and fox are ubiquitous.”.

Even a casual glimpse of San Diego’s fabled Hotel del Coronado on Coronado Island calls to mind the Technicolor vibrancy and whimsy of the Wizard of Oz. Thus, it’s no small surprise to learn that 100 years ago, “The Del,” as locals call it, was Oz author L. Frank Baum’s favorite winter haunt. Since then, the red-and-white-splashed, multi-turreted hotel has welcomed everybody from U.S. Presidents to drag queens—Billy Wilder filmed “Some Like it Hot” here in 1958, with Jack Lemmon, Tony Curtis and Marilyn Monroe. Amid myriad incarnations, however, what’s remained unchanged is its beachside splendor and Victorian charm.

The Seattle Mariners hired the Milwaukee Brewers special assistant Jack Zduriencik as their new general manager. Zduriencik, 57, replaces Bill Bavasi, who was fired in June, and takes over for the interim Lee Pelekoudas. Zduriencik is known for his skill in drafting players. Since Zduriencik arrived in Milwaukee in 1999, the team drafted Prince Fielder and Rickie Weeks as well as the 2007 National League rookie of the year, Ryan Braun, J. J. Hardy, Corey Hart, Yovani Gallardo, Manny Parra and Tony Gwynn Jr.

Wilson Chandler is questionable for the Knicks’ final preseason game Friday against the Nets because of a sprained left knee. He is expected to be ready for the Oct. 29 season opener. Chandler was injured in Tuesday’s loss to the Celtics. A magnetic resonance imaging test Wednesday revealed a mild sprain, according to the Knicks. Chandler averaged 14 points and 8 rebounds in the first five preseason games. Coach Mike D’Antoni has used him as the first big man off the bench, primarily at power forward.

In a break with tradition, the notorious ascent of Mont Ventoux will be featured on the next-to-last day of the 2009 Tour de France. Ordinarily, the race has a time trial on the next-to-last day, deciding the overall results before what is largely a ceremonial ride into Paris on the last day. Next year, Mont Ventoux, a punishing climb on which the British rider Tom Simpson died in 1967, will be the 20th of the 21 stages.

The Weekend Explorer column on Oct. 3, about Brooklyn Heights, where the playwright Arthur Miller lived, misstated two aspects of his connection to the neighborhood. While he spent time there with Marilyn Monroe, his second wife, he did not live there with her. And while the name of the hotel where Willy Loman has an adulterous affair in “Death of a Salesman,” the Standish Arms, is the same as that of a former hotel in Brooklyn Heights, the setting for the hotel in the play is Boston, not Brooklyn Heights.

A music review on Wednesday about a concert by the soprano Isabel Bayrakdarian, at Zankel Hall, featuring music of the Armenian composer Gomidas misstated the date of his death. It was in 1935, two decades after the start of the massacre of Armenians in Turkey in 1915, not four years after.

An article on Friday about a new school in Wyoming that will teach students in Arapaho in hopes of preserving the language referred incorrectly to the school’s curriculum. The curriculum, which will be taught in the Arapaho language, is based on a curriculum used at the Wyoming Indian Elementary School, a public school that teaches its students in English and adheres to Wyoming state education standards. The state did not specifically approve an Arapaho curriculum for the new school.

An article on Tuesday about conservative criticism of the Supreme Court’s recent ruling on the application of the Second Amendment to gun control in the District of Columbia omitted two words from a passage in the decision concerning gun regulations that remained presumptively lawful. “Nothing in our opinion,” Justice Antonin Scalia wrote for the majority, “should be taken to cast doubt on longstanding prohibitions on the possession of firearms by felons and the mentally ill, or laws forbidding the carrying of firearms in sensitive places such as schools and government buildings, or laws imposing conditions and qualifications on the commercial sale of arms.” The words “felons and” were omitted.

An article on Oct. 14 about opposition to a proposal by Britain’s Labor government to toughen an anti-terrorism law misspelled the surname of a former leader of MI5, Britain’s domestic spy agency, who had criticized the proposal. She is Dame Stella Rimington, not Remington.

Last spring, Jeremy Sapienza, a 28-year-old Web editor, and his partner bought a two-story house on a rough block of Central Avenue in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Like most urban pioneers, they have been renovating as funds allow. They couldn't afford to redo the facade, though, which Mr. Sapienza described disdainfully as ''flat stucco painted Pepto-Bismol pink.'' So this summer they hired an artist named Erik Burke to cover it with a mural.

At least five suspects linked to regional Islamic terrorist groups were arrested in raids in and near Jakarta, the police said Wednesday. Weapons, bomb-making instructions and chemicals were found at one house that was raided, the police said. It is near a state-owned oil storage center, prompting the police to say the suspects may have planned to attack it. One was identified by the police as Rusli Mardani, a member of the local terrorist group Mujahedeen Kompak. ''He is a big fish, one of the people who has stirred up a lot of communal violence,'' said Sidney Jones of the International Crisis Group in Jakarta.

Peter Vansittart, the English writer who breathed new life into the historical novel by mingling myth with modernity and injecting 20th-century preoccupations into historical settings as various as Roman Britain, medieval France and 16th-century Germany, died on Oct. 4 in Ipswich, Suffolk. He was 88 and lived in Kersey, England. His death was confirmed by Jill Harbinson, a neighbor.

BLOMBACK--Birger, Ph.D . The New York Blood Center mourns the passing of Dr. Birger Blomback, a world-renowned senior scientist at our organization in the 1970s and 1980s, and professor at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm. A giant in his field, he was a rigorous scientist and innovative thinker who made many contributions to our understanding of thrombosis and haemostasis. Above all, he set the standard of excellence that has characterized NYBC's life-saving work ever since. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family in Stockholm, where he died on October 2nd. AT the Ford Ironman World Championship held in Kona, Hawaii, earlier this month, many of the triathletes looked a bit like cheerleaders or tourists with knee-high socks on. Instead, they were some of the growing number of triathletes and runners wearing compression socks, tight over-the-calf socks that are migrating from the medical therapy world to athletics. At Kona, 415 of the 1,677 competitors in the run portion of the race wore the socks, said Chris Bohannon of the triathlon gear manufacturer Zoot. They wore them to increase blood flow, supposedly supplying lower leg muscles with more oxygen and more evenly distributing muscle strain. Compression socks were originally used by diabetics, pregnant women and travelers seeking better circulation and preventing blood clots.

SIMMONS--Robert Z . A loving, dedicated father, grandfather and father-in-law, he will be deeply missed. His love, humor, wit, passion for songs, interest in politics, enthusiasm for golf, swimming, reading and movies and his entrepreneurial spirit lit up our lives. Steve, Eileen, Sara, Caroline, Julia, Nick and Cliff SIMMONS--Robert Z., 88 years old, died peacefully at Hospice of Palm Beach Medical Center in Florida on October 21. Robert was the beloved husband of Joan, father of Steve, Eve and Rifka, grandfather of Sara, Caroline, Julia, Nick and Cliff, father-inlaw of Eileen and Jeff, and brother of Sim. His career began as a cartoonist and his work appeared in publications such as the Saturday Evening Post. The company he founded in 1952, Robert Simmons, Inc., distributed artist materials for over 41 years. It became famous among American artists for its Roberts Simmons Brushes which were endorsed by Norman Rockwell and Andrew Wyeth and included innovations such as the White Sable Brush. Robert won the 2003 Lifetime Achievement Award from the artist materials industry. He became an accomplished painter himself. His impressionist oils with dazzling colors were sold at many galleries and shows including the National Art Club in New York and the Lighthouse Center for the Arts in Palm Beach Gardens. A wonderful husband, father and grandfather, and friend to so many, his love, caring, humor and zest for life will be missed by all.

Amnesty International has called for the immediate release of Jenni Williams, left, and Magodonga Mahlangu, leaders of Women of Zimbabwe Arise, who were arrested last Thursday for leading a peaceful protest in Bulawayo to demand food for the starving and the formation of a power-sharing government. Amnesty International called the women prisoners of conscience. The prosecutor said the women should be denied bail on the grounds that they were likely to commit similar offenses. A magistrate is expected to decide Friday whether to grant bail.

Bill Reilly, a publishing and media executive who was a founder and former chairman of Primedia Inc., which under his leadership amassed a varied portfolio of more than 200 magazines, including American Baby, Fly Fisherman, Soap Opera Digest, National Hog Farmer and Adhesives Age, as well as Seventeen, Modern Bride, Chicago and New York, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan and Quogue, N.Y. He died of bone cancer and prostate cancer at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he had been receiving hospice care, said David Adler, a friend and a former Primedia vice president of communications.

JIRA--James John , a native New Yorker died at 49 on September 26, 2008. A true New Yorker, ''Jim'' was born on First St. & First Ave. and moved ''uptown'' to Second St. which he used to say was ''a very long trip.'' He left home at an early age, and lived with various alternative communities and friends in the village in the 1970s. School did not agree with him, but early on he showed huge talent in both building things, and creating beautiful drawings and paintings. He was one of the original NYC homesteaders, fixing up an uninhabitable building and acquiring it from the city along with his neighbors, making it into a ''sweat equity'' coop. He renovated numerous apartments in Manhattan, and worked as a studio assistant in recent years. This summer he traveled to the California desert to work on a special installation with old friend Randy Polumbo. Jim's loyalty, dependability, and humor will be missed by friends and family alike. His wonderful paintings will be exhibited in California later this year at Art Queen in Joshua Tree. There will be a service at Middle Collegiate Church at 50 East 7th Street on October 25 at 1pm with a reception after. Please make donations in lieu of flowers to: The Catholic Worker, Maryhouse, 55 E Third St., NY, NY 10003. Phone: 212-777-9617

KANT--Harold Sanford , passed away peacefully on Sunday, October 19, 2008, after battling pancreatic cancer. Hal, a politically conservative entertainment lawyer, was a man of apparent contradictions. For over thirtyfive years, the registered Republican was the principal lawyer and general counsel for the seminal 60s rock band, the Grateful Dead. Hal created and oversaw the various corporations that managed the day-to-day business of the legendary band; his guiding hand is credited with preserving the band's enduring legacy and their valuable intellectual property, including ownership of their music masters and publishing rights (a rare feat in the early days of rock 'n roll music). So domineering was Hal's influence within the band, Jerry Garcia and the band emblazoned his Grateful Dead business cards with the simple title, ''Czar.'' Despite Hal's reputation as one of the most prominent and pioneering of music lawyers, the Grateful Dead were only a small part of Hal's diverse international business and legal practice. A devotee of classical opera, Hal was also an accomplished amateur poker player. In 1987, Hal won the World Series of Poker. In 1973, Hal coauthored the groundbreaking monograph, Pornography and Sexual Deviance, with Michael J. Goldstein and John J. Hartman; he continued to write numerous white papers throughout his career. Born in the Bronx, New York on July 29, 1931, Hal attended DeWitt Clinton High School before pursuing his undergraduate degree at CCNY and the University of Washington. Hal obtained his masters degree in psychology from Penn State University. In 1958, Hal graduated with honors from Harvard University Law School. After law school, Hal clerked for the esteemed Judge William Orr of the U.S. Ct of Appeals for the 9th Circuit. Hal had a passion for skiing, golf, painting, and was an avid art collector. Above all, he was a caring and generous man who had a strong influence on those who had the opportunity to know him. Hal is survived by his wife, Jesse Kant, his sons, Garth, Tony, and Jonas (Lucy); his sisters, Charlotte Silverman and Thelma Sameth; his stepchildren, Cameron Cassidy Sloane (Robin) and Sean Cassidy (Andrea); his grandchildren Ashlyn, Austin, Eva, Samantha, Trevor; and his many nieces and nephews. He will be sorely missed. Donations in his honor may be made to the Tower Cancer Research Foundation in Los Angeles (towercancerfoundation.org/ donations.html).

IVRY--E. Billi . The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of a beloved friend, the first woman to be elected as a member of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees, who also served on four other university boards, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law (CSL), Stern College for Women (SCW), Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies (BRGS) and Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration (AGS). A YU Benefactor, she was also the recipient of an honorary doctorate in 1987. In all these schools, as well as the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS), she established major scholarships and student free loan funds in her name. At Stern College, she established The Rebecca Ivry Department of Jewish Studies in her mother's honor, where she also established a chair in Jewish History in her own name. She also established the Rivka Ivry Student Center/Bet Knesset and The Israel Isaac Ivry Beit Midrash at the Jerome and Geraldine Schottenstein Residence Hall. She recently dedicated a special wall in the Lea and Leon Eisenberg Beit Midrash at SCW. At RIETS, a Kollel Fellowship was established both in her name and in the names of her parents, Rebecca and Israel Isaac Ivry. Highly regarded as one of the most beloved YU Trustees, she will be sorely missed by her fellow board members, administration, faculty and students, all of whom cherished her wise counsel and munificent support for close to 60 years. May her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grand nephews and cousins be comforted on their great loss. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Marjorie Diener Blenden, Chairman, SCW Board of Directors Moshael J. Straus, Chairman, AGS Board of Directors Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman, BRGS Board of Directors Kathryn O. Greenberg, Chair, CSL Board of Directors Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees

BORCK--Chester E. , a pioneer of frozen bread dough and a promoter and innovator of in-store bakeries, died on October 18, 2008 in Greenville, SC. He was 95 years old. Mr. Borck lived in Bridgeport Connecticut for over 60 years, followed by 30 years in North Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Borck began his career in the family business known as Borck and Stevens Bakery, and later became its president. He invented the first automated English muffin slicer and grill as well as equipment for automating Danish pastry production. In the late 1950s, he founded Country Home Bakers, a company based upon a new concept using fastfreeze technology that he developed. He was considered to be the father of the modern-day in-store baking industry which gave the consumer high quality, fresh bakery products baked-off in the store or supermarket on a daily basis. Country Home Bakers grew into one of the leading bakery and snack producers in the United States. Among its subsidiary businesses were Readi-Bake, Inc. Readi-Bake, Ltd., Jessie Lord, Inc. and Sanders. In 1998, Mr. Borck was the recipient of the Ernst and Young award as Master Entrepreneur of the Year and an honorary Doctorate degree from Babson University. His wife of 52 years, Jessie Lord Borck, his son Chester E. (''Jay'') Borck, Jr., and his son, James Lord Borck predeceased him. Survivors include his wife, Abbie, his daughter, Judith, his granddaughters, Kimberley Borck Pollard, Amity Borck Dey and, his grandson, James L. (''Jay'') Borck, Jr., nine great grandchildren, three stepchildren, and five step-grandchildren. Memorial Saturday, October 25th 1:30pm at St. Johns Episcopal Church, 769 Fairfield Avenue, Bridgeport, Connecticut. www.redgatehennessy.com

9 P.M. (13) BETRAYED In March 2007 George Packer wrote an article for The New Yorker about interpreters who jeopardized their lives on behalf of Americans in Iraq. He turned his reporting into a play about three young Iraqis, two men and a woman, motivated to risk everything by the promise of freedom. Writing in The New York Times, Charles Isherwood said that ''the clarity of the writing, the urgency of the story being told and the fine performances give the play a sharp dramatic impact and a plain-spoken beauty.'' Mr. Packer will introduce this presentation of his Off Broadway play, which was nominated for a Lucille Lortel Award. The cast includes, from left above, Waleed F. Zuaiter, Mike Doyle and Sevan Greene; Pippin Parker directs. 7 A.M. LAUREN--Susan. The epitome of style, elegance and grace. We will all miss your love and energy. Our sympathy to our dear friends Jerry, Brad, Amy, Ben, Greg, Elizabeth and Jenny. Deanna and Bob Adler and Family LAUREN--Susan. To the Lauren Family, we sincerely feel your pain and sorrow. To us, Susan was a bright shining star who we loved and admired. We were so proud to have called her our dear friend. We will truly miss her. Love, Linda and Stuart Schlesinger LAUREN--Susan. We will miss Susan's warmth and beautiful spirit, her generosity, her great style, her strength, and her grace. We will cherish these memories always, and she will be in our hearts forever. Love, Leonard and Rena Beth and Michael Susan and Phil Taylor and Brandon LAUREN--Susan. To our dear and cherished friend, you are in our hearts forever. Rest peacefully . Madeline and Daniel Patricia and Michael Bonnie and Robby Cathy and Chad LAUREN--Susan, 65, of New York, NY, died Monday, October 20, 2008 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. A native New Yorker and the daughter of the late Alexander and Mary Levine, Susan graduated from Monmouth College in New Jersey, furthering her studies at FIT in New York City. Her passion for the art and history of fashion was acknowledged in her role as a Docent for the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. On October 17, 2008, the Museum of American Folk Art honored Susan and her husband Jerry Lauren as passionate collectors and connoisseurs in the world of American Folk Art. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother, Susan is survived by her beloved husband of 44 years, Jerry Lauren, Executive Vice President of Men's Design, Polo Ralph Lauren, and their three children, Brad, Greg and Jenny Lauren. She is also survived by Brad's wife, Amy, their son Ben and Greg's wife Elizabeth Berkley Lauren. Memorials in her name may be contributed to the Ralph Lauren Center for Cancer Care and Prevention and to Stand Up to Cancer. A private memorial and inurnment will be held.

Among my husband's few faults is a mild Shakespeare aversion. He's not entirely to blame: he grew up in a small Midwestern town where the culture was always preceded by "agri," then spent his college years devoting himself to the study of chemistry and the pursuit of football. By the time I got him East, he'd more or less opted out of Bard appreciation, but was willing to sit through the occasional performance as a conciliatory gesture.

This week, thousands of young, zealous music fans descended upon New York City for the 28th annual CMJ Music Marathon to see roughly 1,200 bands playing at over 75 sites across the city. The assortment of microgenres at this year's confab -- including world music noise, minimal techno, avant-garde metal and dancehall grime -- was reflected in the multitude of well-designed band T-shirts. Take the experimental indie band Shearwater, for example, who hired the visual artists Nicholas Kahn and Richard Selesnick to create a conceptual artwork for a brilliant album photo and T-shirts. Others, like Bobby Freedom of the Sammies, followed a more D.I.Y. approach, making a face out of $80 worth of deli meats for its scoop-necks. "This generation likes to wear T-shirts at concerts," explained the Swedish indie chanteuse Lykke Li. "They want to make a statement about who they are." After you check out the slide show above, leave a comment telling us which band's statement is the most stylish.

Ridgely Evers, who is providing the Sagrantino grapes for my winemaking project, told me to arrive at 7 a.m. on Thursday for picking. But at 7, the sun had not yet risen. This is an absolute blockbuster Saturday. The kind where you can sit in front of the television all day long and bask in the warming glow of nonstop college football. I want you to briefly think about what is happening in America this Saturday solely for your entertainment. Let that marinate for a second. No. 1 Texas (7-0) is facing No. 6 Oklahoma State (7-0) in Austin at 3:30. Simultaneously, Georgia and L.S.U. meet for the first time since the 2005 SEC title game. (Keep the remotes handy). Then, in primetime, undefeated Penn state tries to win at the Horseshoe for the first time since 1978. Is it, or is it not great to be an American on an October college football Saturday of this magnitude? I think you know the answer to that. Start being nice to the wife now, because she's going to be angry when you tell her about your plans.

Reinhardt is a professor at Princeton.With the increasing likelihood of an Obama presidency and another Democratic Congress comes the increased likelihood that macroeconomic policy in the United States will shift from bolstering the supply side of the economy to bolstering the demand side of the economy through added government spending on our badly neglected infrastructure, on alternative energy production, on health care for the hitherto underserved, on unemployment compensation and so on. Before heading to the beach this summer, I decided to buy a plastic watch, so I ordered one from Swatch.com. What I didn't know was that Swatch sent information about my purchase to a company called Acerno, which runs an advertising network that reaches 80 of the top 100 Web sites. Since then, some of the ads I have seen on those sites could well have been placed by a company that specifically wanted to reach watch buyers. (There's no way to tell if that did happen.)

Starting "as soon after 6 A.M. as the light permits," the race will comprise eleven laps of the track, or 258.06 miles. "The estimates of speed for the race are very high. Every one seems to think the winner will do better than seventy miles an hour." Foxhall Keene's Mercedes, Robert Graves's Mercedes and Harry Payne Whitney's Brasier are among the favorites in the field of 11 American and 7 foreign automobiles. "For some reason W. K. Vanderbilt, Jr.'s car [also a Mercedes] is not nearly so well thought of." The drivers with the largest following are George Robertson, driving a Locomobile (he won the 24-hour race at Brighton Beach on Oct. 3 driving a Simplex: The TimesTraveler Sunday Slide Show, Oct. 4), and Lewis Strang, who will drive a Renault. An article on Tuesday about developments on the campaign trail, including Senator Barack Obama’s decision to visit his gravely ill grandmother in Hawaii, misidentified the city in which his running mate, Joseph R. Biden Jr., suggested that Mr. Obama would be tested in his first six months in office. It was Seattle, not San Francisco.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about a new Panasonic technology that allows compact cameras to take higher-quality pictures, misstated the weight of the company’s DMC-G1 camera, the first to use the new format. It weighs about 13.5 ounces, not 8 ounces.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Delta Queen undertaking what might be its final voyage referred incompletely to the status of legislation that would have allowed the boat to continue sailing. While Representative James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, refused to let the legislation come to a vote in his committee, a parliamentary maneuver allowed it to move to the House, where it lost by 13 votes.

An article on Tuesday about the effect of plummeting oil prices on Venezuela, Russia and Iran, which are heavily dependent on oil exports, referred imprecisely to the relative size of Iran’s oil reserves. While Iran ranks second to Saudi Arabia when measured by conventional reserves of crude oil, Canada ranks second when its vast oil sands resources are included. (Iran ranks third under those circumstances.).

FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES OF THE PUPPET PRINCESS' (Saturday and Sunday) Can a puppet show really mollify a witch? That's the issue in this new production from the Looking Glass Theater, which draws on Balinese puppetry, masks and folklore. Written and directed by Jennifer Goodlander, the show focuses on Putu, a tomboy, who is lost in the jungle with Nyoman, a boy training to be a puppeteer. (Through Nov. 23.) Saturdays at noon and 2 p.m.; Sundays at 2 and 4 p.m.; 422 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-9467, lookingglasstheatrenyc.com; $15; $12 for 12 and under.

SCHONHOLZ--Dr. David. It is with sadness that the Mount Sinai School of Medicine Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Science announces the passing of Dr. David Schonholz. After graduating with a Bachelor's of Arts from Syracuse University, he continued his studies there and received a Masters degree as well. Dr. Schonholz then earned his medical doctorate from Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia. He then served as an intern and Resident in Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Mount Sinai Medical Center before continuing specialized training as a fellow in Reproductive Endocrinology. Dr. Schonholz served on the faculty of Mount Sinai for 40 years and delivered thousands of babies during that time. He was recognized as a leader in his field with special expertise in gynecologic surgery, and is responsible for the training of two subsequent generations of gynecologic surgeons at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. His dedication to family, patients, residents and medical students is legendary. He participated in the Dean's office in a variety of positions related to applications, education and promotions. Dr. Schonholz published several research papers and textbook chapters dealing with obstetric and gynecologic surgery. He was the recipient of the Resident Education Award as an outstanding educator in OBGYN on five separate occasions, and received the award for outstanding contribution to the Department in 1997. He is survived by his wife, two children, who are both prominent physicians, and six grandchildren. We will all miss this outstanding educator, clinician and gentleman.

Presidential candidates are usually thrilled when they receive an endorsement, but of course that wasn't true when an Al Qaeda-linked site endorsed John McCain a few days ago and said his election would be just the right thing for Islamic militants. That's the topic of my Sunday column, and in particular I try to emphasize that the conservative fixation with "Islamo-fascism" doesn't suggest that conservatives have an upper hand in dealing with Islamic militants. On the contrary, the opposite is true: Fixations of all kinds tend to be blinding and lead to miscalculation. And that's why Al Qaeda presumably would welcome McCain's election.

A great cemetery feels like a world unto itself: a kind of theme park of the departed, where everyday life is left behind at the gate. A certain mood overtakes you when you visit. You are simultaneously overwhelmed by the sense of being surrounded by the dead, and seduced by the beauty of the place. This creates a special flavor of melancholy, the inevitable feels present and one's own life all the more fleeting -- as in Memento mori, "Remember that you are mortal."

Showing that his bag of tricks is far from exhausted, Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, uncorked a novelty in the eighth game of his title match with Vladimir Kramnik of Russia. It was the third time in the match that Anand had surprised Kramnik in the opening. Anand, who had Black, did not get an advantage from his novelty, but he got a good game and was able to hold on for a draw, preserving his overwhelming lead in the match. The score now stands at 5.5 to 2.5 with 6.5 points needed to clinch. More information about the match, which is being held in Bonn, Germany, is on the match Web site.

Arizona named Russ Pennell as the interim replacement for the retired coach Lute Olson. Pennell, 47, is a former assistant to Rob Evans at Arizona State and served last year as a Sun Devils radio analyst. Athletic Director Jim Livengood turned to Pennell, who has never been a college head coach, after Mike Dunlap, Olson’s top assistant, said he wanted to stay as an assistant.
David Beckham said he would be back with the Los Angeles Galaxy for the start of the 2009 M.L.S. season.

Amid growing speculation that he faced losing his starting job, Jamal Crawford scored 30 points in the Knicks’ 111-110 loss to the Nets at Madison Square Garden in the final preseason game for both teams. Crawford, who made 9 of 15 shots, missed a shot with 0.9 seconds remaining that would have won the game. Both teams finished the preseason 3-4.

Seve Ballesteros had a third operation for a cancerous brain tumor Friday, a six-and-a-half-hour procedure that went “better than expected.” Doctors removed the rest of the tumor and reduced brain swelling. Ballesteros, 51, was in stable condition in the intensive care unit at La Paz Hospital in Madrid. Doctors wanted to relieve pressure and remove remaining parts of the malignant tumor in a deep part of the brain. ¶Five months after his second heart transplant, Erik Compton shot a four-under-par 68 at Crandon Golf Club in Key Biscayne, Fla., advancing to the second stage of the PGA Tour’s qualifying tournament. Compton finished tied with six others for 23rd, taking the final qualifying spot. heart.

Venus Williams and Vera Zvonareva clinched the last two berths in the season-ending Sony Ericsson Championships. Williams joins her sister Serena in the tournament for the top eight women in singles and the top four doubles teams. ¶Top-seeded Andy Roddick fell to Robin Soderling, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (5), in the Lyon Grand Prix quarterfinals. Roddick was trying to qualify for the Masters Cup in Shanghai. roddick.

Five months after receiving his second heart transplant, Erik Compton shot a four-under-par 68 on Friday at Crandon Golf Club in Key Biscayne, Fla., and advanced to the second stage of the PGA Tour’s qualifying tournament. Compton overcame a seven-shot deficit and turned in the best score of the day. He finished tied with six others for 23rd, taking the final qualifying spot. Compton’s next test will be a qualifying tournament in Pine Mountain, Ga. The final qualifying tournament is in Palm Springs, Calif., where 25 golfers will receive tour cards. ¶Seve Ballesteros had a third operation for a cancerous brain tumor, a six-and-a-half-hour procedure that went “better than expected.” Doctors removed the rest of the tumor and reduced brain swelling. Ballesteros, 51, was in stable condition in the intensive care unit at La Paz Hospital in Madrid. seve.

Giants receiver Plaxico Burress was fined $45,000 by the N.F.L. for verbally abusing an official and tossing a ball into the stands during last weekend’s game against San Francisco. Burress was fined $20,000 for comments he made to the head linesman Phil McKinnely after he was called for an unsportsmanlike conduct penalty, and $20,000 for postgame comments critical of the officiating. Burress was assessed a $5,000 fine for throwing a ball into the stands after catching a touchdown pass in the third quarter.
On Wednesday night at John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, the second gala in the Wave Rising Series showcased the six companies that will perform through this weekend.
The editorial board’s choices for Congressional races in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The latest and least of the “Saw” films is just plain boring and even a little tame — albeit by the standards of a genre that helped bring the phrase “torture porn” into the lexicon.
Colonel Nett received the Medal of Honor for heroism in combat in the Philippines during World War II and later served in the Korean and Vietnam Wars.
Moscow’s displays of military might and newfound oil wealth convey a notion of an unstoppable Russian ascent. Population trends show a different picture.
The close race in Florida is a case study of the troubles of the McCain campaign.
New Jersey voters should re-elect Frank Lautenberg as United States Senator.
Food deliverymen have started to band together against employers who force them to work under brutal conditions. But consumers have a role to play too.

Re "Keeping Their Opinions to Themselves" (Oct. 19): Please, you do protest too much. My mother, a lifelong Democrat who is turning 100 years old, reads The New York Times every day, and she can't believe the obvious bias of the paper.First the paper was wildly anti-Hillary Rodham Clinton, while supporting her - in a blatant and laughable way. Then the Obama Nation rose, and your slant became acute.As a child of the Sixties, I thought we had all the answers and that the politicians and policies we supported were "golden," as my kids would say today. Instead, after reading a great deal of history, I have seen that the presidents who often get the best ratings are the ones who manage for events to fall apart just after they leave - a bit like the next year's teacher being saddled with curriculum not yet covered.My mother often remarks that The Times thought Ronald Reagan was an idiot, governing with the help of Nancy Reagan's astrologer, until he died and we discovered that The Times thought he saved the free world!Well, did he or did he not? It's the time lapse that settles your opinion page.The extreme bias of the paper's articles and opinion pages serves no purpose other than to rabble-rouse, and that the paper has done wonderfully well. Why not answer some questions we still discuss after dinner, for example, about the real relationship choices of Barack Obama, the myriad odd characters who have peopled his past?Does wanting to know these things mean we are biased against Mr. Obama - or does not covering them mean The Times is biased for Mr. Obama? HmmMarilyn ElkinMontreal, Oct. 19, 2008 ● The blurb for your column reads: "Everyone is biased. That means reporters and readers too."The challenge remains with the senior management of The Times to clearly define a separation between news reporting and offering opinions within a news article. This subject has previously been discussed in the public editor's column, yet The Times seems to have avoided taking decisive steps to resolve the controversy.I thought editors reviewed each news article. If so, why aren't the editors making changes when the reporter offers opinions rather than reporting news?Don TenerowiczEllington, Conn., Oct. 19, 2008 ● I believe I found the reason for the anger (on all sides) with the mainstream media in your column, and I do think that it lies where you placed it. You wrote: "But the paper's news coverage is another matter. It is supposed to be evenhanded."Evenhanded? I thought news was meant to be accurate, factual: what happened, who said what, whether what was said was truthful when checked against fact and public record.What on earth has "evenhanded" got to do with news? Can one be evenhanded about what causes H.I.V., about the age of the Earth, about the number of deaths in the Vietnam War? The goal should be accuracy, a clear presentation of the facts as best known and the limitations or gaps in what is known, not evenhandedness, as if the truth and its negation were equal contenders in some popularity contest.The reason "balance" is an issue on news pages is that front-page journalism has shifted toward opinion, using cute, snarky words that are loaded in meaning. Here is a testable hypothesis: if we turned a computational linguist to a semantic analysis of the front page and the opinion page of The Times over the past 50 years, we would see opinion and value-laden words (descriptors with positive or negative implications) steadily increasing.By the way, as a scientist, I take affront at the quote that journalism is harder than brain surgery. We might all be better off if journalists on the news pages were more about the facts and about trying to find the information than about cleverness, opinion and "palling around" with the power elite. Then journalism might really be "hard."Linda SmithBloomington, Ind., Oct. 19, 2008 ● ●Re "Urgent Issues, Buried in the Mud" (Oct. 12): I think you are being too hard on The Times's news and campaign editors when you argue that more of their coverage should be about policy and that too much of the coverage focuses on "the horse race, political tactics, polls and the like."You say that about 10 percent of coverage is on policy, while what's left is on that other stuff. But does "the like" include the series of compelling human interest articles about the candidates and their wives, for example, that help give readers insight into the candidates' character and how they might govern as president?This is, after all, a political campaign, which, like a military campaign, includes strategic and tactical dimensions that are as important as the policy issues driving the decisions of voters.I, for one, welcome the analyses of campaign advertisements, which may count in the "horse race" column but also provide clarification of policy issues as they fact-check each ad's assertions.Let's not forget that voters have many sources of information these days, including cable TV and the Internet. I'm not depending on The Times for all of my campaign coverage, and I value The Times for the kind of coverage it provides.Michael BroderBrooklyn, Oct. 13, 2008 ● I do believe that people told the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press that "they wanted more coverage of the candidates' stands on issues." But look at the articles and columns that show up on The Times's "Most Popular" lists on its Web site. What people actually read and send to each other is the horse race and commentary content of the paper, not the substantive content.I thank The Times for doing a better job than most at giving us excellent information and analysis of the things that matter, but, so far, doing so has not made the readership more responsible about actually consuming what matters. Meanwhile, I don't blame journalists as much as many do for printing and broadcasting what we're mostly getting. It's what we've asked for.J. Christy WarehamNewark, N.Y., Oct. 12, 2008 ● I was surprised to learn that even The Times is underreporting the content of issues in this year's campaign season. It is unfortunate when style is confused for substance. Members of the electorate need to make informed decisions when they vote.Would it be too much to ask that reporters follow a framework in their reporting? Campaign articles could report on four dimensions: (1) issues (proposals, including practical and political implications), (2) the race (polling and statements from the campaigns), (3) fact checking and (4) competence.Brian GaleBronx, Oct. 13, 2008 ● But it's even worse than that.The problem would seem to be that newspapers send most of their senior reporters around with the campaigns, ensuring that the reporting is about the race and the tactics, not the issues.Why waste senior reporters on collecting statements and reactions from campaigns and stitching together the usual he said-he said piece? Is it about journalism, or about the perks and proximity to power and its seductions?I've come to believe that the mainstream media like to get the coverage wrong so that they have something to write about in December and January. But I won't be reading it.Kevin McNamaraHouston, Oct. 12, 2008 ● We all recognize that television "news" has been transformed from information to entertainment, a 24/7 version of an infomercial.I read The Times and The Washington Post every day to actually obtain important aspects of the events of the world. You accurately reflect my frustration with the refocused election coverage: from defining and clarifying issues to a discussion of election-year tactics and the horse race.William CorinSarasota, Fla., Oct. 12, 2008 ● I agree with your assessment that The Times (and most of the news media) have not covered the substantial issues of the presidential race adequately.One suggestion: for a month before the primary and the presidential elections, The Times should devote an entire page to a daily question about an important national issue. Each of the candidates should be provided with equal space to provide detailed answers to the question of the day. The answers should be printed in their entirety. This suggestion could also be applied to state and local races and would provide readers who are interested in learning more about the candidates' stands on issues with the information they want. A side benefit: if TV stations and other daily papers followed this lead, there would be less expensive campaigns.Paul FeinerTown SupervisorGreenburgh, N.Y., Oct. 12, 2008 ● While I do wish that the news media in general and newspapers in particular would focus more on policy issues than some of the things out of left field, I do understand that sometimes that is all that the campaigns produce.For example, more people were talking recently about Gov. Sarah Palin's outrageous suggestion that Barack Obama is friendly with a domestic terrorist than either candidate's ideas on how to solve the economic crisis our country is facing.That is sad for the campaign's dialogue, and sad for the country.We need to speak about the economy and other issues important to Americans, and not something that happened when Mr. Obama was 8 years old!Steven M. ClaytonOcean, N.J., Oct. 12, 2008 ● ●Re "Political Scorekeeping" (Oct. 5): Scorekeeping indeed. Why are you giving in to the idea that "fair and balanced" reporting can be achieved by counting the number of articles or their placement in the paper?Balance is not the issue. Coverage of important issues, backed by competent investigative reporting, is.The Times should correct the facts if it got them wrong, state its opinions as opinions and not succumb to this right-wing whining. If there's a crime wave in Brooklyn, is it unfair not to mention the burglary in the Bronx? Not in my book. One is news, the other isn't.Give us your best shot at fair and factual. Leave balance to the scales of justice.Mary FellowsPortland, Ore., Oct. 5, 2008 ● Your rationale that the number of enterprise or investigative articles in The Times has been balanced is hard to swallow.Late August to the beginning of October:John McCain - 9Barack Obama - 4Front page, McCain - 4Front page, Obama - 1You say that "The Times has published more tough articles on Obama, 20, than on McCain, 13, since the beginning of last year." As though a reader remembers everything written last year?The comparison should be post-Labor Day articles, and they are quite imbalanced in Mr. Obama's favor.Glen SkovholtSt. Paul, Oct. 6, 2008 ● You present a good case that Times articles critical of Senator Barack Obama and Senator John McCain are fairly even. But most of those critical of Mr. Obama ended long past, while the news, editorial and Op-Ed articles and columns critical of Mr. McCain and Gov. Sarah Palin are quite current.We all know that what occurs in the month before the election has about as much weight with the electorate as all the prior information.Why not publish a summary of the policy statements of each presidential candidate, but also the negatives of each?Why do this? Many of us Republicans have an uneasy feeling about Mr. Obama's past and his money sources, many parts of which have not received much scrutiny by The Times or the press in general. A summary of his and Mr. McCain's positions and the pros and cons would give us all the "balance sheet" before the election. J. M. Van MetreAlexandria, Va., Oct. 8, 2008 ● A certain strain of irrationality has crept into this presidential campaign. The kinds of complaints that you must surely be tediously sifting through this election season I suspect come from people who wish newspapers did not even exist, let alone journalists who do their job well by uncovering even the most trivial of a politician's more glaring faults.Don StacyKunming City, China, Oct. 5, 2008 ● Your comparison of the number of investigative reports on Barack Obama versus John McCain started by using accurate data, then obfuscated that data with misleading statistics.To go back to early 2007 to begin a count of investigative articles demonstrates the tortuous road even you will take to stretch the truth. I'll go one up on you. I suspect that many of The Times's articles in 2007 about Mr. McCain were positive. Of course they were - The Times eventually endorsed him in the primary.What matters now is the information The Times gives readers to help them understand the current presidential race. Based on your own count, The Times's emphasis has been blatantly anti-McCain. To dilute that clear fact by referring to articles published last year was a deliberate and shameful tactic to mislead readers. I'm not sure whether to be angry or sad at your methods, but I am disappointed.Gene GambalePalm Desert, Calif., Oct. 6, 2008 ● Your column about coverage of the presidential campaign proudly touts how many more investigative articles were done on Senator Barack Obama than on Senator John McCain. But you distorted this by including in your total articles from the beginning of last year to the present.For most of this period, Mr. Obama was running against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination, not against John McCain.The Times's bias during that period of time was for Mrs. Clinton and against Mr. Obama, but the paper abruptly changed to focus its investigative articles on Mr. McCain once the nomination was decided.Nice try!Ken MartinVirginia Beach, Va., Oct. 6, 2008 ● It is of great concern and no surprise to me that as you mention, The Times has actually published more "tough" articles on Barack Obama and Joseph R. Biden Jr. than on John McCain or Sarah Palin.In just the last few days alone, there has been an overall tone - in articles on Ms. Palin's unsubstantiated accusations of guilt by association, for example - and photo captions containing unrelated and undermining innuendo that serve to cast doubt on Mr. Obama's trustworthiness, while burying the exonerating lead.By contrast, the language and images used to cover Ms. Palin's feisty delivery of whoppers seem admiring and unquestioning.In its attempt to remain impartial and not slant its reporting in favor of the candidate I presume the editorial page will endorse, The Times goes too far in the opposite direction and is instead undermining Mr. Obama's campaign.Susan LichtensteinBelmont, Mass., Oct. 6, 2008
“Roadside Romeo” is something new under the Bollywood sun: sophisticated computer-generated animation that uses stars to voice the characters.
To the Editor:.

The Boston College junior linebacker Mark Herzlich has been one of the breakthrough performers in college football this season. He's been the backbone of a Boston College defense that ranks No. 4 nationally in total defense, keying the Eagles' 5-1 start and No. 23 ranking. Herzlich leads the team with 54 tackles and also has two interceptions. He's been so disruptive that ESPN's Bob Davie labeled him as one of the country's best linebackers during B.C.'s victory over Virginia Tech on Saturday. Herzlich, who has a 3.04 G.P.A. in his dual major of marketing and finance, sat down with The Quad on Thursday for a wide-ranging interview. He covered everything from his love of math to his opportunity to play lacrosse at Johns Hopkins to his de-commitment from the University of Virginia to why he'll resist overtures from the N.F.L. and return to B.C. for his senior year.
The Fish and Wildlife Service is proposing a wolf management plan that could end federal protections for the animals in Montana and Idaho while leaving them in place in Wyoming.
Former Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta, who spent about two years in prison for tax evasion, has been released from a halfway house.
State regulators blame the pilot of a container ship for causing an oil spill in San Francisco Bay when the vessel rammed a bridge tower.

Today's paper features pictures of the Vanderbilt Cup race, France's would-be monarch, unemployment lines, strikebreakers, the Yale-Army football game, society women and more, as well as cartoons on the presidential race.Click here to view the slide show.
A listing of credits on Friday with a film review of “Synecdoche, New York,” misspelled the given name of the composer of the music. He is Jon Brion, not John.

A map in some editions on Friday with the continuation of a front-page article about the New York City Council’s vote to approve a change in the term limits law omitted a label for Council District 33 in Brooklyn, and an accompanying list of council members who voted for the measure misidentified the home borough of 11 members. Only the first six members listed under the Queens subheading are from Queens; the remaining 11, from David Yassky to Michael C. Nelson, are from Brooklyn. A chart showing how each council member voted is at nytimes.com/nyregion.

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about possible changes in the estate tax, misstated the amount that can be excluded from estate taxes in 2011 and later years if the current law is not changed. It is $1 million, not $675,000. The column also quoted incorrectly from a report by the Tax Policy Center about the possible consequences if action is not taken. The report said that would create “grotesque tax planning initiatives,” not “grotesque tax policy initiatives.”.
A report in the Sports Briefing column on Oct. 16 about World Cup soccer qualifying misstated England’s record after a victory at Belarus. It is 4-0, not 3-0.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a growing credit crisis in India referred incorrectly to the exposure of emerging markets to the subprime home lending that has weakened many Western financial institutions. Like India, many emerging markets have little such exposure — not the opposite.

An article on Friday about the verdict in a lawsuit contending that Unum, a disability insurer, had fraudulently required ineligible people to apply for Social Security disability benefits misstated part of the jury’s verdict. In a test sample of six insurance claims, jurors found that two were fraudulent and that three — not two — contained no evidence of fraud. The jury was also unable to reach a verdict on one other claim — not two.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Friday about lawsuits challenging the New York City Council’s vote to change the term limits law misidentified the home borough of Councilman Lewis A. Fidler, who was shown congratulating Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn after the vote. He is from Brooklyn, not Queens.

The Department of Defense has identified 4,181 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 613 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:.
To the Editor:.

A letter on Friday from Silverado, Calif., about the financial crisis misstated part of the name of the school where the writer is a professor. It is the Argyros School of Business and Economics (not Business and Ethics) at Chapman University.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

The cover article on Page 52 this weekend about Senator John McCain’s campaign misspells the given name of Mr. McCain’s fellow senator from Arizona and the surname of the governor of Florida, both McCain supporters. The other Arizona senator is Jon Kyl, not John, and the Florida governor is Charlie Crist, not Christ. The article also misstates the name of the Ohio city where some McCain campaign staff members first met with Mr. McCain’s running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska. It is Middletown, not Middleton. And the article overstates the duties of Tucker Eskew, a member of Ms. Palin’s team. He is officially her counselor, not her chief of staff, though campaign officials say that he performs many of the same duties.

The Advertising column on Friday, about brands that are stressing value and savings in their marketing, misidentified, at one point, an analgesic brand that is promoting a “Buy one, give one” offer. It is Aleve, not Advil.
The markets are in turmoil. The economy is hurting. And there are other serious problems as well. The poor are being clobbered by all of them.
A big, talented gray horse named Delightful Kiss, who is among the favorites at the Breeders’ Cup Marathon, gives Pete Anderson a reason to get out of bed in the morning.
A once prominent Jesuit priest was convicted in federal court in Chicago of engaging in sexual activity with a teenage boy who accompanied him on religious trips.
A national voter group filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State Mike Coffman alleging that as many as 30,000 voters had been purged from the rolls in Colorado.
A federal magistrate in Salt Lake City has entered a not guilty plea on behalf of the man accused in the 2002 abduction of Elizabeth Smart.
BUSINESS DAY.
A tribute to Tim Russert, the NBC newsman who died on June 13, was held on Tuesday at St. Peter’s Church at Citigroup Center, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.
If you are thinking that today’s deal looks familiar, do not be alarmed: it was used in last Saturday’s column.

A rapidly spreading cholera outbreak has sickened more than 12,000 people and is infecting 1,000 people per month, United Nations officials said.
