Matthew Long, a New York City firefighter and a former triathlete, prepares to run the city’s marathon after being critically injured when he was hit by a bus in 2005.
Georgian opposition figures are split over protests to mark the anniversary of a government crackdown.
The banking industry’s dirty little secret is that it has no intention of using the bailout money to make new loans.
A handful of foreign companies have been slapped with sanctions for sales of technologies that could help Iran, Syria and North Korea to develop nuclear weapons.
Two government officials have already resigned over the dealings, in which a wealthy monastery traded cheap tracts of property for prime public real estate.
Experts are finding that multitasking can put us under a great deal of stress and actually make us less efficient.
A council in London has ordered that a 23-foot Banksy mural must be removed from the wall of a building on Newman Street.
The New York City Center’s Encores! series revival of “On the Town” has announced its full cast.
Many on City Council believe that the body shed its image as a weakling during the debate on term limits.
Disappointing art auctions in London and Hong Kong this month cost Sotheby’s $15 million in losses on guarantees to sellers, Bloomberg News reported.
Two magazines with upscale appeal, Radar and 02138, folded on Friday.
CBS’s prime-time shows topped Fox’s coverage of the World Series on Thursday night.

Dr Pepper announced earlier this year that it would give a free soda to everyone in the United States if the Guns N’ Roses album “Chinese Democracy” came out. Now, the beverage company will have to drink its words.
A federal mediator will try to break the contract stalemate between Hollywood’s major film and television studios and the Screen Actors Guild.
The director Steven Soderbergh, whose body of work includes the films “Schizopolis,” “Kafka” and “Ocean’s Thirteen,” is planning to make a rock ’n’ roll musical about Cleopatra.
The parents of Doreen Noone’s late fiancée have challenged the Fire Department’s decision to award her a $36,000-a-year pension.
The conductor David Robertson, a regular guest of the New York Philharmonic, led the orchestra through works by Brahms, Mozart and Bartok on Thursday night.
Iceland is pitching itself as an island of bargains, especially to Americans who hold a suddenly valuable commodity: dollars.
Felix Rohatyn, mayor of New York during the 1970s fiscal crisis, weighs in on Michael Bloomberg and the term limits debate.
RoseAnne Spradlin’s newest work, “Blue Liz,” shown on Thursday night at the Kitchen, finds its spark in Warhol’s 1963 painting “Blue Liz as Cleopatra.”
Sales of the controversial blood test were halted after a warning from the Food and Drug Administration.
Asian and European leaders promised mutual cooperation at next month’s emergency financial meeting called by President Bush.
As many as eight N.F.L. players, including Saints running back Deuce McAllister, have tested positive for performance-enhancing substances and face suspensions.
The St. Lawrence String Quartet gave the premiere of David Bruce’s lively “Gumboots” for clarinet and string quartet on Thursday at Zankel Hall.
Michael J. Critelli, executive chairman of Pitney Bowes, discusses unsolicited mail and its affect on the environment.
It was not until last month that many economists began to think a recession was likely, and many believe it began in the third quarter of this year.
With people seeking cash in hard times, garage sales are flourishing so much that some cities are cracking down.
Gov. Sarah Palin’s faith is being scrutinized after YouTube videos show her practicing an assertive brand of Pentecostalism called “spiritual warfare.”
Investors may soon hear a lot about an annuity that promises risk-free growth. They should use caution.
European Union governments approved a potentially costly system capping greenhouse gases from any airline flying into or out of the trade bloc.
Financial advisers to the elite are paid to worry about a shifting list of priorities.
The deal, valued at more than $5 billion, marks the latest step in what is widely expected to be continuing consolidation among the nation’s regional banks.
Quarterback Todd Boeckman, who led the Big Ten in passing efficiency last year and opened this season poised to lead Ohio State to another conference title, has instead found himself on the sideline.
Daryll Clark is a big reason Penn State is ranked third in the Bowl Championship Series standings heading into Saturday’s meeting against No. 9 Ohio State.
Sometimes called the “living room of the Harlem Renaissance,” the Y.M.C.A. is planning a $39 million overhaul.
Home resales saw their highest monthly rise in five years in September, with the sales driven largely by bargain-basement prices on foreclosed homes.
The automaker, which is in merger talks with General Motors, said that it would offer buyout and early retirement packages in the next two weeks and that layoffs would follow.
The ultra-Orthodox Shas Party said it would not join a government that Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni is trying to assemble.
OPEC ordered a cut in production of at least 1.5 million barrels a day, but a benchmark price dropped further.
Barack Obama spent the day saying goodbye to his grandmother, Madelyn Dunham, who is gravely ill.
After the Phillies were quieted by the Tampa Bay Rays, they must have been wondering if they should even bother shipping the bats to Philadelphia.
Stock futures had indicated a precipitous drop before the opening bell, but the actual declines, while large, did not amount to an uncontrolled selling frenzy.

DELANEY--Peter, of White Plains, NY passed away on October 23, 2008. Peter had a long distinguished career for more than 20 years in Public Service for Westchester County and New York State and, more recently in private business consulting. Born on October 26, 1951 in the Bronx, New York to Thomas and Veronica Delaney, he was educated in Catholic Schools graduating from Power Memorial High School and Iona College. An avid golfer, connoisseur of fine wine, food and cigars, Peter was active in Westchester and New York State Republican Party activities. He ran for the Mount Vernon District Assembly seat 1972, served as the Campaign Manager for his father's three elections as Westchester County Sheriff and Andy O'Rourke's Westchester County Executive Office in 1989 and 1993. Peter also held several positions in government including Commissioner of General Services for Westchester County and New York State, Executive VP and CFO of the New York Power Authority as well as being a longtime advisor and friend to former NYS Governor George Pataki. Peter was predeceased by his wife of 22 years, Mary Lindstrom, and his father, Thomas Delaney, Sr., former Westchester County Sheriff. He is survived by his mother, Veronica (Harvey), and his four siblings: Tom Delaney of Crestwood, Veronica Kearney of Bronxville, John Delaney of Amawalk, Mary O'Reilly of Mount Vernon and many nieces and nephews. The Mass of Christian burial will be held at 10am on Saturday, October 25, 2008 at Saint Joseph's R.C. Church in Bronxville, NY. Friends may send memorial donations to: Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation at Westchester Medical Center, 19 Bradhurst Suite 3060, North Hawthorne, New York 10532.

BECKER--Amy Line, on October 23, passed away peacefully in her 90th year, in Knoxville, TN surrounded by her three surviving children, Amy, Chris and Stephen, husband, Dr. Felix G. Line, and dog, Harry. Amy was married to Ted E. Becker Sr., a New York psychoanalyst, for more than 50 years. She was a wonderful wife, mother, sister, friend and pediatric physician to many. She was a woman ahead of her time, graduating summa cum laude from Carson Newman College and one of two women to graduate from Vanderbilt University Medical School in 1945. After the death of her first husband, she reconnected with her college sweet heart Felix and was married in 2002 and they shared the last years of her life together. She was loved by her kids, inlaws and 12 grandchildren, Stephen and Larisa Becker, Kostyantyn, Sean, Jessie and Carlos and Christina, Amy and Jon Barovick, Jeremy, Sam and Carly and Chris Becker and Mark Umbach, Robin and Mary Line, Harriett Clark, Tim and Lisa Line, Molly and Tim Birchfeld, loving niece Steffi Mayes, sister and brother-in-law Jayne and Jack Dale, loving friends Roberta Meyers, Dr. Larry Davis and Thelma Philbrook. Words cannot express how special and unique she was to all who knew and loved her. A memorial service will be held in Knoxville, TN on Tuesday October 28th.

Senator Barack Obama's fund-raising juggernaut has slowed significantly from its record-shattering pace of September, bringing in $36 million in the first half of October, according to new filings with the Federal Election Commission. Mr. Obama's spending, meanwhile, has picked up rapidly. Partly as a result, Senator John McCain and the Republican National Committee held a cash-in-hand advantage of about $20 million over him and the Democratic National Committee as of Oct. 15 when the money of various affiliated committees is taken into account.

Jay, Robert, Andre, Pam, Julia and Ryan Kramberg SLATKIN--Meyer H., M.D., Died on October 21, 2008 at age 95 in Bal Harbour, FL. Born in Estonia, he received his medical degree from the University of Edinburgh Medical School. Dr. Slatkin was a Major in WWII and awarded the Bronze Star. He was a Professor at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Chief of Dermatology at Brookdale Medical Center. During his 50 year career he was recognized as a noted researcher, clinician and lecturer. Beloved husband of Shirley for 57 years, cherished father of Charles, his wife Marcia, daughter Carol, her husband Paul, and adored grandfather of David, Rebecca, Lilly and Alice.
WEEKEND PLANS

The publicist for the Oscar-winning actress Jennifer Hudson said that Ms. Hudson's mother and brother had been found shot dead at their South Side Chicago home and that the police were investigating. The publicist, Lisa Kasteler, said no further comment would be made about the deaths of Darnell Donerson and Jason Hudson. A police spokeswoman, Monique Bond, said investigators were also seeking a missing child who was Ms. Donerson's grandson. Ms. Bond said the deaths appeared to be the result of domestic abuse. Deputy Chief Joseph Patterson said there was no sign of forced entry at the house. The police said the boy, 7-year-old Julian King, was accompanied by a man who was ''considered armed and dangerous.'' (AP)

Plaxico Burress was fined $45,000 by the N.F.L. on Friday for verbally abusing an official and tossing a ball into the stands during Sunday's victory against the San Francisco 49ers, The Associated Press reported. Day after day, and sometimes several times a day, the candidates have pounded out their stump speeches. Now, as Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama head into the final week before the election, the speeches have become a back-and-forth on taxes, the economy and a man in the plumbing business named Joe. Both of the speeches analyzed here were given on Tuesday; Mr. Obama's was in Miami and Mr. McCain's in Bensalem, Pa. Mr. Obama's remarks were crafted by Jon Favreau, his chief speechwriter, and a team of other writers. Like Mr. McCain's recent addresses, Mr. Obama's are now delivered with the aid of a teleprompter -- largely so his message of the day, typically a fresh criticism of Mr. McCain, is delivered intact.

DAY--Emerson, M.D., died on October 21, 2008 in Wilmette, IL. He leaves his wife Gerry Scherman Day; five children by his first wife, Ruth Fairfield Day who predeceased him--Tad, Bob, Nancy, Bonnie and Shery; thirteen grandchildren; four great-grandchildren. He was born in Hanover, NH in 1913, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College 1934, from Harvard Medical School 1938. After internship, fellowship, and residency, he served as Flight Surgeon for the ATC USAAF 1942-45. He had a brilliant career as physician, having been a pioneer in preventive medicine in the 1950s as Director of the Strang Cancer Prevention Clinic 1950-63 and Chief of the Preventive Medicine Division at Sloan-Kettering Institute 1954-64 both in New York City. His most recent professional positions were as Professor of Medicine at Northwestern University and attending and visiting physician at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, IL. During his lifetime he received numerous professional awards and published a number of professional papers focusing on cancer detection and prevention. Contributions may be made to either the Dartmouth College Fund Attn: Kim Hoyt, 6066 Development, Hanover, NH 03755 or Harvard Medical School, Attn: Friends of Harvard Medicine, Office of Resource Development, 401 Park Dr., Suite 22W, Boston, MA 02215.

SHIVELY--George C., former Mayor of Bronxville, NY, died at his home there on October 23. Born March 2, 1923 in Fairmount, Indiana to the late George Jenks and Hilda Cleveland Shively of Bronxville. Grandson of the late Benjamin F. Shively of South Bend, Indiana, United States Senator from Indiana during the Taft and Wilson Administrations, and Emma L. Jenks of Brookville, PA, daughter of George Augustus Jenks, Solicitor General of the United States in the Cleveland Administration. Graduate of Roosevelt High School, Yale College 1944 and Harvard Law School 1948. Served in Eastern France with the 71st Infantry Regiment, 44th Division, Corps of Engineers during World War II. Partner in the law firm of Satterlee & Stephens from which he retired. Survived by his lifelong companion Cynthia Towell Shively whom he married in 1953; three daughters, Cynthia S. May of NYC, Lucy Shively of Bronxville and Sally T. (Enrico) Moretti of Starrucca, PA; son George S. (Jenny) Shively of Bronxville; and three grandsons, Benjamin, Zachary and Joseph Shively.

Senator Barack Obama jumped off the campaign trail to spend Friday in Hawaii visiting his grandmother, who is dying. But with 10 days left in the race for president, this is no time for courtesy, and Senator John McCain did not offer it. Mr. McCain again strongly attacked Mr. Obama's economic policy, making the argument that an Obama presidency would mean higher taxes. Mr. Obama might have been off the campaign grid, but his surrogates were not. Michelle Obama; his running mate, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.; and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton carried the Obama banner in battlefield states across the country.
Chris Harris is a writer for television. Stephanie Chen is a graphic designer.

COLES AND SMITH ARE PROBABLE Laveranues Coles and Eric Smith, who sustained concussions Sunday against the Oakland Raiders, participated fully in Friday's practice and were listed as probable against Kansas City. In the N.F.L., a probable listing means there is a virtual certainty the player will be available for normal duty. For Coles, his latest concussion is his third documented head injury in the last 22 months. For Smith, it was his second concussion in three weeks.

A Palestinian smuggler pushed a calf through a tunnel under the border of Egypt and Gaza on Friday. With the militant group Hamas controlling Gaza, Israel limits the goods allowed in. A trade zone of sorts has emerged in the network of illegal tunnels.

ROSENFIELD--Allan G., M.D. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, Allan G. Rosenfield, M.D., Professor of Population and Family Health and of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Dean Emeritus of the Mailman School of Public Health and DeLamar Professor Emeritus of Public Health Practice. Dr. Allan Rosenfield died on October 13, after a long and brave fight with ALS. He was a graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, a faculty member for more than 30 years, former acting chair of our department and Dean of Public Health for more than 20 years. Dr. Allen G. Rosenfield's contributions to our department, the institution and the field of public health are legendary. Contributions that he made to the field will have a multi-generational impact on maternal and child health. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and are extremely proud and honored to have worked with such an outstanding physician, teacher, researcher and person. Mary E. D'Alton, M.D. Rappleye Professor, Chair, Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology

A new e-mail message making the rounds among Jewish voters in Pennsylvania this week falsely alleged that Mr. Obama ''taught members of Acorn to commit voter registration fraud,'' and it equated a vote for Senator Barack Obama with the ''tragic mistake'' of their Jewish ancestors, who ''ignored the warning signs in the 1930s and 1940s.'' At first blush, it was typical of e-mail floating around with false, incendiary, and often anonymous claims this year. But this one had an unusually official provenance: It was sponsored by the Pennsylvania Republican Party's ''Victory 2008'' committee.

A New Food Scene In a Colombian Port The Colombian port town of Cartagena has become an unlikely food destination, attracting the kind of culinary travelers who typically vacation in Rome and Paris. What they find is a city far more exotic, but no less adroit at catering to sophisticated palates. At left, a horse-drawn carriage pulls up to La Vitrola, a popular restaurant in Cartagena's old city.

SCHONHOLZ--Dr. David. The Mount Sinai Alumni deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Dr. David Schonholz. Dr. Schonholz spent his entire career at Mount Sinai. After completing his internship and residency, he was an attending physician in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology until his retirement. He was a dedicated teacher who received the ''Outstanding Teacher of the Year'' award from the House Staff on multiple occasions. Dr. Schonholz was a member and then chairman of the Medical School Admissions Committee from 1970 to 1997. Our sincere sympathy is extended to his wife Gleniss, his son Dr. Steven Schonholz, MSSM 1982, and his daughter Dr. Lyris Schonholz, MSSM 1983. E. Rayfield, M.D., President M. Goldstein, M.D., Vice President M. Padilla, M.D., Secretary W. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

His memory will live in our hearts forever and will inspire us always. Donations can be made in George's honor to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065). ROSENBERG--George. We are heartbroken. You were a treasured friend for over 40 years. Your life was filled with love and appreciation. We will miss you forever. SAXE--Marie P. Beloved wife of 34 years of Bob Saxe, she died of Pneumonia and Ovarian Cancer on October 19, 2008. Born in Atlanta, GA. She built a career in NYC as a merchandising executive in the intimate apparel industry. She is also survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Emilie and Joe Haas, her other brother-in-law, Stephen O. Saxe, and her niece, Alyson Hannigan, and her husband Alexis Denisof, all of whom Marie loved dearly. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 26, from 2:30pm-4:30pm at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 82nd St.

AUBERT-GOERING-Corinne, died a serene, peaceful death at the youthful, beautiful age of 51 years old on Tuesday, October 22, 2008, leaving her husband Kevin and daughter Camille, 14 (writer of this obituary). Born in Boulogne, France to parents Colette and Claude Aubert, Corinne grew up moving around France with her two sisters Laurence and Nathalie. She began studying in Hippocagne but her powerful, charismatic character drove her towards bigger and better things. She proceeded to complete her bachelor's degrees in Art History and Literature. She met my father, Kevin Goering, in Bordeaux where he was studying the French language. Together, they packed up and ventured to America to begin a new life in the Promised Land. My mother proceeded to begin her work at Yves Saint Laurent, Rive Gauche. She ended her 20 year career in the fashion industry when I, demanding little toddler that I was, kept her home for myself. Mom was a beautiful, intelligent and energetic woman. She particularly enjoyed dragging me on long walks in the wilderness of the Catskills as well as teaching and helping others. This year, she was working with the old and dying to put a stop to suffering and pain. She was full of generosity and compassion for people in general because of how much she had been through herself; she was a tough cookie. This is the one thing she couldn't get through. I write this today with a hint of humor and uplifting thoughts because I do not wish for her to be remembered because she died, but because of the beautiful life that she led. She left a deep impact on all of those people that she encountered in her lifetime and I can only aspire to be like her; my mother, ma maman.

(HBO) ELIZABETH: THE GOLDEN AGE (2007) Cate Blanchett (left center, with Abbie Cornish and Clive Owen), retakes the throne as the Virgin Queen, now 52 and intent on bringing the Spanish Empire to its knees, in Shekhar Kapur's sequel to his more restrained 1998 period drama, ''Elizabeth.'' Ms. Cornish plays Bess Throckmorton, the queen's female pet, and Mr. Owen is Walter Raleigh, ''the queen's favorite smoldering slab of man meat,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, calling the film ''intentionally playful and an inadvertent giggle, an overripe melodrama that's by turns a bodice-ripper, a cloak-and-dagger thriller and a serious-minded historical drama with dubious contemporary overtones.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S TOUGHEST JOBS The remaining contestants must repeat three jobs -- logging, oil rigging and crab fishing -- with the fastest person to finish the course winning $250,000. Josh Temple hosts.

WINTER--Bernard, 86, died of heart failure on Friday, October 24, 2008, in Palm Beach, Florida. Survived by his loving wife of 62 years, Janice Okner Winter; his children, Alan Winter, Cheryl (and Glen) Lewy and Robin (and Nanette) Winter; his grandchildren, Scott (and Sari) Winter, Jordan (and Ingrid) Winter, Ryan Winter, Zachary (and Anja Langenbucher) Lewy, Marshall (and Heather Fowler) Lewy, Brooke Lewy, Ariel (and Beth) Winter, Alix Winter, Adrien Winter; his great-grandchildren, Elena Winter, Yannick Lewy, Sydney Winter, Sara Winter, Sophie Winter and Danielle Winter. Bernard was born in Irvington, NJ where he graduated from Irvington High School and attended Upsala College. Bernard was a life member of Temple Beth Shalom of Livingston, New Jersey, and a member of Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach, Florida. He served in the army during World War II, where he was stationed in the South Pacific. Upon his return, he founded American Lamp Company, Lamp Specialties and Robin Products. He was active in B'nai Brith of Newark and an avid gardener and plantsman with a green thumb who could grow anything. Following the sale of their business, the Winters retired to Palm Beach, Florida in 1978, where Bernard was one of the founders of the Falls Country Club. Bernard was a talented sculptor in stone and clay whose work was shown in various galleries. His sculpturesbrought pleasure to many. A loving and adoring husband, a traveler par excellence he set off to see the world with his life long companion Janice, traveling far and wide. He had a wonderful sense of humor, encouraged his family to expand their minds and to be independent thinkers. He will be missed by us all. Funeral services will be on Monday, October 27, at 11:30am at Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, NJ 07088. Contributions may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158 and the International Myeloma Foundation, 12650 Riverside Drive, Suite 206, North Hollywood, California 91607.

DAVIS--Evelyn, 85, passed on October 24, 2008. Adored and beloved wife of the late Bernard. Greatly loved by children Jeffrey and Jewel, daughter-in-law Marsha, and grandchildren Philip and Reid. She was a pillar of independence and devotion for her family. Unbelievable that she is gone, we will miss her so much. Services Sunday, 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

He is survived by his wife Joan and sons Robert and Mark and will be deeply missed. Services will be held Sunday, October 26th at 10am at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave. at South Broadway, White Plains. Lexicon | Whence "in the tank"? As in, "The press is in the tank for Obama"? In the 19th century, "go into the tank" meant dive into the pool. William Howard Taft and William Jennings Bryan both came to New York yesterday, "the real battleground in the struggle" for the presidency. Arriving here just after 8 in the morning and looking sleepy, "Mr. Bryan was asked if he had seen The Times forecast of the vote in the Electoral College, which gave Taft 286 votes. 'I have seen the headlines,' replied Mr. Bryan somewhat severely. Of newspaper forecasts in general he said: 'They don't agree with our reports.' " Bryan was shown a cablegram with the endorsement of American Rhodes scholars living in Oxford, England. Taft, who arrived last evening, praised New York Gov. Charles E. Hughes for leaving his own campaign in New York State to travel to the Midwest to campaign for Taft. "I am very deeply interested in his election for a second term," Taft said. Bryan Here Weary; Taft Is Confident

The cover article on Page 52 this weekend about Senator John McCain’s campaign misspells the given name of Mr. McCain’s fellow senator from Arizona and the surname of the governor of Florida, both McCain supporters. The other Arizona senator is Jon Kyl, not John, and the Florida governor is Charlie Crist, not Christ. The article also misstates the name of the Ohio city where some McCain campaign staff members first met Mr. McCain’s running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska. It is Middletown, not Middleton. And the article overstates the duties of Tucker Eskew, a member of Ms. Palin’s team. He is officially her counselor, not her chief of staff, though campaign officials say that he performs many of the same duties.

I definitely agree with Michael Pollan’s premise (Oct. 12) that we need a robust national dialogue on how we produce food and fiber in America. The Clinton administration was in the forefront of many of these ideas, including the implementation of the Organic Standards Act and facilitation of a rapidly growing organic-food movement; creation of a national farmers’-market initiative with thousands of farmers’ markets all over America; expanding the federal nutrition programs, including WIC (Women, Infants and Children), to include fresh fruits and vegetables; a dramatic increase in the land-conservation programs; and the first serious review in many years of federal statutes dealing with the structure of the livestock industry.

Wayne Smith has been a downtown barber for 46 years. His front windows drew me in. A collection of antique razors shares the space with a life-size cardboard cutout of John Wayne in gunslinger mode and a cow's skull of the Georgia O'Keefe variety. Smith likes cowboys and Westerns and raises champion quarter horses on his 105-acre ranch. Trophies he'd won, dozens of them, are stacked up on the shelves.

THE video game Midnight Club: Los Angeles was released last Tuesday. It is the fourth installment of a street-racing series produced by the makers of Grand Theft Auto, but it is the first Midnight Club made for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, which means it is technologically more sophisticated than its predecessors in every way. Game play is not very complicated. Players buy sports cars -- choosing from more than 40 models, ranging from exotics to sport compacts -- modify them in seemingly unlimited combinations, and then race them on the streets of a virtual Los Angeles.

GHOSTS and goblins may own the rights to Halloween, but the rest of the year belongs to the less restless residents of cemeteries throughout the region, where carefully planned and well-tended grounds have been attracting both the living and the dead for eons. By the mid-1800s, spectacular plantings, shade trees and wide carriageways had transformed burial grounds into virtual arboretums that became fashionable to visit. Entire families would dress up and take Sunday afternoon buggy rides out of the city to visit departed loved ones and tidy up their graves.

An article last Sunday about a fungal disease afflicting maple trees in Connecticut and Westchester County included an arborist's misidentification of a disease that affects oak trees. The oak-tree disease is Taphrina caerulescens, or oak leaf blister, not Taphrina deformans, or peach leaf curl.

WATCHING THE CHANGING OF THE GUARD AT BUCKINGHAM PALACE, LONDON, OCT. 10, 2008 Carly Fay, 25, right, with her friend Keiko Read, also 25, from Vancouver. ''This is the first time we've traveled together. We both were working other jobs, the jobs finished, and we ended up working as restaurant servers. We thought 'We might as well do some traveling while we can.' About two weeks later, we're in London; then we're going to Italy, Greece, Spain and France. While we've been here we went and saw the Tate Modern, London Tower, Westminster Abbey. London's been exactly what we expected it to be, exactly what you see on TV. But it's a lot nicer to see it for yourself. To actually be here and see a double-decker bus and everyone driving on the other side of the road. And just meeting people, they've been really friendly. People just automatically assume we're American. It's fine. We just tell them, 'Nope, we're Canadians.' '' As told to Seth Kugel

SENATOR MCCAIN has a record as a staunch advocate of free trade; he supported efforts to expand and strengthen the North American Free Trade Agreement. Even in politically hostile places like Michigan, he has urged voters to accept the reality of a global economy. Experts say he has deviated little from the Bush administration on specific trade deals, except by emphasizing ''trade adjustment assistance,'' a mechanism designed to cushion displaced workers. His advisers say Mr. McCain's focus on that issue stemmed from an emotional encounter during his 2000 presidential campaign with a man who was losing his job in a South Carolina textile mill. ''McCain told his advisers they needed to do more than strike a message of free trade,'' said his current economic adviser, Douglas Holtz-Eakin. ''It was his personal demand that this was important.''

SENATOR MCCAINargues for a confrontational response to Russia's retreat from democratic practices and its efforts to intimidate neighbors, even as he promises not to restart the cold war. ''I looked into Mr. Putin's eyes, and I saw three letters, a K, a G and a B,'' he said in the first presidential debate, mocking President Bush's initial expression of optimism about the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, in 2001. He also accused Senator Obama of ''a little bit of naïveté'' for initially urging that both sides show restraint as Russia overran much of Georgia last summer. Mr. McCain has threatened to kick Russia out of the Group of 8 industrial nations and isolate it in other ways. He also wants to speed up NATO membership for Ukraine, a step that would certainly infuriate the Kremlin even more than NATO expansion and Western support for democracy advocates already have.

DAY--Emerson, M.D., died on October 21, 2008 in Wilmette, IL. He leaves his wife Gerry Scherman Day; five children by his first wife, Ruth Fairfield Day who predeceased him--Tad, Bob, Nancy, Bonnie and Shery; thirteen grandchildren; four great-grandchildren. He was born in Hanover, NH in 1913, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College 1934, from Harvard Medical School 1938. After internship, fellowship, and residency, he served as Flight Surgeon for the ATC USAAF 1942-45. He had a brilliant career as physician, having been a pioneer in preventive medicine in the 1950s as Director of the Strang Cancer Prevention Clinic 1950-63 and Chief of the Preventive Medicine Division at Sloan-Kettering Institute 1954-64 both in New York City. His most recent professional positions were as Professor of Medicine at Northwestern University and attending and visiting physician at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, IL. During his lifetime he received numerous professional awards and published a number of professional papers focusing on cancer detection and prevention. Contributions may be made to either the Dartmouth College Fund Attn: Kim Hoyt, 6066 Development, Hanover, NH 03755 or Harvard Medical School, Attn: Friends of Harvard Medicine, Office of Resource Development, 401 Park Dr., Suite 22W, Boston, MA 02215.

AUBERT-GOERING-Corinne, died a serene, peaceful death at the youthful, beautiful age of 51 years old on Tuesday, October 22, 2008, leaving her husband Kevin and daughter Camille, 14 (writer of this obituary). Born in Boulogne, France to parents Colette and Claude Aubert, Corinne grew up moving around France with her two sisters Laurence and Nathalie. She began studying in Hippocagne but her powerful, charismatic character drove her towards bigger and better things. She proceeded to complete her bachelor's degrees in Art History and Literature. She met my father, Kevin Goering, in Bordeaux where he was studying the French language. Together, they packed up and ventured to America to begin a new life in the Promised Land. My mother proceeded to begin her work at Yves Saint Laurent, Rive Gauche. She ended her 20 year career in the fashion industry when I, demanding little toddler that I was, kept her home for myself. Mom was a beautiful, intelligent and energetic woman. She particularly enjoyed dragging me on long walks in the wilderness of the Catskills as well as teaching and helping others. This year, she was working with the old and dying to put a stop to suffering and pain. She was full of generosity and compassion for people in general because of how much she had been through herself; she was a tough cookie. This is the one thing she couldn't get through. I write this today with a hint of humor and uplifting thoughts because I do not wish for her to be remembered because she died, but because of the beautiful life that she led. She left a deep impact on all of those people that she encountered in her lifetime and I can only aspire to be like her; my mother, ma maman.

BECKER--Amy Line, on October 23, passed away peacefully in her 90th year, in Knoxville, TN surrounded by her three surviving children, Amy, Chris and Stephen, husband, Dr. Felix G. Line, and dog, Harry. Amy was married to Ted E. Becker Sr., a New York psychoanalyst, for more than 50 years. She was a wonderful wife, mother, sister, friend and pediatric physician to many. She was a woman ahead of her time, graduating summa cum laude from Carson Newman College and one of two women to graduate from Vanderbilt University Medical School in 1945. After the death of her first husband, she reconnected with her college sweet heart Felix and was married in 2002 and they shared the last years of her life together. She was loved by her kids, inlaws and 12 grandchildren, Stephen and Larisa Becker, Kostyantyn, Sean, Jessie and Carlos and Christina, Amy and Jon Barovick, Jeremy, Sam and Carly and Chris Becker and Mark Umbach, Robin and Mary Line, Harriett Clark, Tim and Lisa Line, Molly and Tim Birchfeld, loving niece Steffi Mayes, sister and brother-in-law Jayne and Jack Dale, loving friends Roberta Meyers, Dr. Larry Davis and Thelma Philbrook. Words cannot express how special and unique she was to all who knew and loved her. A memorial service will be held in Knoxville, TN on Tuesday October 28th.

Senator John McCain heads to Iowa, which underlines an eyebrow-raising question in political circles: What does his campaign see there that others do not? Most suggest that the red state is slipping away from him. But his aides insist that Iowa remains in play and that voters are responding to his argument that Senator Barack Obama will raise taxes. Mr. Obama is in Colorado, a reminder of how the parties' decisions on where to hold their conventions appear to have yielded different results. The Democrats picked red Colorado, where Mr. Obama appears to have Mr. McCain on the run. The Republicans were in blue Minnesota, which seems to have fallen off Mr. McCain's top targets.

Saturday was a red-state day for the presidential candidates: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama campaigned in places President Bush won in 2004: Nevada and New Mexico. Mr. Obama tried to undercut Mr. McCain's efforts to distance himself from the president. ''President Bush doesn't seem to be at all offended, because yesterday, he cast his vote -- early -- for guess who? John McCain,'' Mr. Obama said. Mr. McCain hit Mr. Obama on taxes. ''If I'm elected -- when I'm elected president -- I won't spend a trillion dollars more of your money,'' he said. The McCain campaign says no one should read anything into crowd sizes. Still, Mr. McCain drew a spare crowd in New Mexico. Crowd size doesn't necessarily translate into votes, but on a Saturday nine days out from Election Day, it does say something about voter enthusiasm.

SENATOR MCCAIN would upend the tax treatment of health benefits in order to give all consumers the same advantages, whether they purchase insurance through employers or not. He would eliminate the provision that allows workers to exclude their employer-sponsored benefits from taxable income, replacing it with tax credits worth $2,500 per individual and $5,000 per family. He also would let consumers purchase policies across state lines. The McCain campaign argues that the tax changes will stoke competition in the individual market, lower prices and make coverage more affordable for the uninsured. Those with pre-existing health conditions who cannot obtain private insurance would be covered through a ''guaranteed access plan.'' It would put federal dollars behind the kinds of high-risk pools that currently operate in many states, often with inadequate financing.

SENATOR MCCAIN draws a snappy chant from supporters at his rallies -- ''drill, baby, drill'' -- but his approach is broader and more nuanced. He does support increased and immediate oil exploration on public lands and off the coasts. But unlike his running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, and many other Republicans, he opposes oil exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Mr. McCain advocates adding as many as 45 nuclear power plants, which would reduce consumption of fossil fuels, chiefly coal and oil, and the greenhouse gases they release that are the main culprits in global warming. He says that the Navy's 50-year history with nuclear-powered ships proves that the technology is safe. Mr. McCain supports increased use of renewable energy sources like wind, solar, geothermal and hydroelectric, but opposes large government subsidies for them, saying the market, not the government, should decide which new technologies are most promising. SENATOR OBAMA said he believes oil companies should exploit existing leases on public lands and off the coasts before new areas are opened to drilling. He, too, opposes drilling in the Alaska refuge. Unlike Mr. McCain, he supports a windfall profits tax on oil companies. Mr. Obama does not oppose expansion of nuclear power in principle, but says it must be done safely and economically, considerations that for decades have halted construction of nuclear plants. Mr. Obama advocates spending $15 billion a year for the next 10 years to develop alternative-energy businesses, which he says will produce millions of new jobs. Mr. Obama, who is from Illinois, a big corn-producing state, supports federal subsidies for ethanol production. He also supports requiring utilities to produce about 20 percent of their electricity from renewable sources by 2020. And he backs higher fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks.

MOKARZEL--Mary M., passed away October 23, 2008. Beloved daughter of the late Salloum and Helen Mokarzel, she is survived by her sister Alice M. Jaoudi and a host of nieces, nephews and their children. Mary was publisher of the Arabic-language daily ''Al-Hoda'' from 1954 until 1971 and its English-language affiliate ''The Lebanese-American Journal.'' In addition to her career in journalism, Mary was an accomplished artist and respected figure in New York's Lebanese American community. A viewing will be held Monday October 27 at 9am at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue in Manhattan followed by a funeral mass and interment at St. John's Cemetery in Queens. Memorial donations may be sent to Catholic Near East Welfare Association, 1011 First Ave, NY, NY 10022.

WINTER--Bernard, 86, died of heart failure on Friday, October 24, 2008, in Palm Beach, Florida. Survived by his loving wife of 62 years, Janice Okner Winter; his children, Alan Winter, Cheryl (and Glen) Lewy and Robin (and Nanette) Winter; his grandchildren, Scott (and Sari) Winter, Jordan (and Ingrid) Winter, Ryan Winter, Zachary (and Anja Langenbucher) Lewy, Marshall (and Heather Fowler) Lewy, Brooke Lewy, Ariel (and Beth) Winter, Alix Winter, Adrien Winter; his great-grandchildren, Elena Winter, Yannick Lewy, Sydney Winter, Sara Winter, Sophie Winter and Danielle Winter. Bernard was born in Irvington, NJ where he graduated from Irvington High School and attended Upsala College. Bernard was a life member of Temple Beth Shalom of Livingston, New Jersey, and a member of Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach, Florida. He served in the army during World War II, where he was stationed in the South Pacific. Upon his return, he founded American Lamp Company, Lamp Specialties and Robin Products. He was active in B'nai Brith of Newark and an avid gardener and plantsman with a green thumb who could grow anything. Following the sale of their business, the Winters retired to Palm Beach, Florida in 1978, where Bernard was one of the founders of the Falls Country Club. Bernard was a talented sculptor in stone and clay whose work was shown in various galleries. His sculpturesbrought pleasure to many. A loving and adoring husband, a traveler par excellence he set off to see the world with his life long companion Janice, traveling far and wide. He had a wonderful sense of humor, encouraged his family to expand their minds and to be independent thinkers. He will be missed by us all. Funeral services will be on Monday, October 27, at 11:30am at Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, NJ 07088. Contributions may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158 and the International Myeloma Foundation, 12650 Riverside Drive, Suite 206, North Hollywood, California 91607.

Thanks to modern video game technology, dancing has become a solo activity you perform with your computer. Back in the unenlightened '60s, it wasn't so easy. You actually had to move around with another human called a "partner." How did you know the steps without a video monitor to watch? It turns out there were precanned variations with names like The Monkey or The Loco-motion. It all started with (17 Across) The Twist, the No. 1 hit from 1960 by Chubby Checker. The Jerk (48 Across) was famously a "hip-based" dance that was far too suggestive for television at the time, but "arm-based" replacements like The Swim were deemed less insidiously dangerous.

I understand, and share, the reluctance to scrutinize the attire of female political figures and potential first wives if it means that it produces a double standard or just plain silliness. It seems almost old-fashioned, like poking into the bread basket of sex affairs conducted by male chiefs of state. Oops! He has been thinking about the differences and similarities between the so-called financial tsunami and the real thing:

My friend and fellow financial columnist Don McNay, who has consistently opposed the bailout bill, wrote me an e-mail message this weekend that led with this question: "Your column strengthens my steadfast opposition to the bailout, but I am curious if you have changed your mind?"

Would John McCain be in a better position today had he not chosen Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska as his running mate? Adam Nagourney takes a look at that question in his column today.

Through seven games, Brett Favre has eight more touchdown passes than the man he replaced on the Jets, Chad Pennington, but only one more victory as a starting quarterback. And Pennington, who has started all seven games for the Dolphins, has a better completion percentage (69.3 to 68.5), more passing yards (1,710 to 1,611) and a higher passer rating (100.5 to 89.5) than Favre.

Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. said today that Senator Barack Obama was being subjected to the same sorts of ugly slurs and innuendo that have smeared America's greatest presidents. He spoke in North Carolina as Mr. Obama was delivering what he called his closing argument in Canton, Ohio.
The Gospel Music Channel is trying to disprove the conventional wisdom that most new television networks don’t have a prayer.

Dr. Gary Curhan is a nephrologist at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and an associate professor of medicine and epidemiology at Harvard Medical School and Harvard School of Public Health in Boston. Notable studies looking at the causes and treatment of stones.

"Recession proof." Those are the words Suzy Menkes uses in describing the two new Marc by Marc Jacobs stores in Paris. Marveling at the foot traffic, she asks Robert Duffy (Jacobs's business partner, of course) where the cool kids are coming from. It's the brand's "cult following" he explains. Or maybe it's the recession-friendly pricing. Rubber Marc by Marc Jacobs boots? 5 euros. A scarf? 15 euros. An excuse to keep shopping? Priceless.
Dr. James E. Lingeman on why kidney stones have become more common and how to treat them.
Minimally invasive techniques and new drugs aid a growing number of people, young and old, with kidney stones.

China's top leader, Hu Jintao, appears to be blowing a historic opportunity to resolve Tibet's problems. Because of Chinese intransigence, the Dalai Lama has said that he has pretty much given up on conciliation with China: "As far as I'm concerned, I've given up," he said.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg didn't end up running for president; he had other plans for his future, it turns out. But that doesn't mean he doesn't have a thing or two to say about presidential politics.

Already an insomniac, I find myself awake at 2 A.M. regularly lately, thoughts and fears spinning through my brain. How will we pay for college? What if the insurance companies fail, too? The thing about insomnia is it takes something that is worrisome but manageable during the day and transforms it into a looming beast in the dead of night. By morning my overactive brain has made me homeless and penniless. And tired.

Politics | A journal publishes for the first time a speech by Leonard Bernstein given 22 years ago to a small group at Harvard -- one that "feels eerily current." It's about cultures of fear: "This is the way the world lives, is practiced in living-existing in terms of an enemy." [American Scholar]
So, anyone still complaining that the Phillies don't play small ball?
How long until there's a drug that makes it easy for anyone to be thin?

Three months ago, the Utility Player stumbled on a quandary at gas stations around New York City: With the price of a gallon of gas well above $4, station owners were running out of fours to put on the displays.
Tottenham's dismal start of the English Premier League season cost its Spanish coach, Juande Ramos, his job late last Saturday.
Campaigning in Iowa this weekend, Senator John McCain briefly invoked a word that has proved volatile for his campaign: ethanol.

Stephen Schiff isn't a trader or a banker, but he knows first-hand about the convulsions on Wall Street. He is the screenwriter who wrote was was supposed to be Gordon Gekko's long-awaited comeback vehicle -- only to have the landscape of Wall Street ripped up and rearranged in the months after his final draft was turned in.
The new-home sales figures out today are being heralded as a gain, showing that builders are finally cutting prices enough to move the inventory.

This recreation of a Cambodian dish may not be entirely authentic, but it is really good, a striking balance of mildly sweet and mouth-puckeringly sour. And if you start with peeled shrimp, it is also ridiculously fast.
After declining for four decades, rheumatoid arthritis is on the rise among women in the United States, according to new research.

Last fall in the Book Review, Joe Queenan inveighed against Henry Petroski's book "The Toothpick," the latest entrant of the neverending parade of histories of doodads, thingamajigs, and whatsis passing through stores in the past decade or so.

Many of you take exception to the notion, expressed here last week by Dr. Cheryl Woodson, that assisted living is a "myth" that promises more than it can deliver to the frail elderly and their families. Interestingly, Dr. Woodson's provocative observation is echoed in a study and an editorial in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Directors Association, both of which suggest that the medical needs of many current assisted-living residents exceed what these facilities can provide and that consumers are not adequately warned of these limitations.

Moncton, which is setting a torrid pace in the Canadian Hockey League (14-0, with two OT losses), tied a record for consecutive victories on the road with its 5-1 decision over Saint John on Sunday in Quebec Major Junior Hockey League action. This makes eight. Moncton's chance for a ninth-consecutive road victory comes on Nov. 8 at Halifax. As Patrick King of Sportsnet.ca writes, the Wildcats and the Windsor Spitfires are turning heads in junior hockey. The rest of the junior report begins after the jump.

With many of Wall Street's biggest profit centers shut down because of the credit crisis, making a buck has become a lot harder. The markets for initial public offerings and mergers are sickly, and the securitization market is in a coma.
Welcome, finally, to Wordplay, the newest blog at The New York Times.

After learning about delays in New York's voter registration process, Rock the Vote will hunt for people in New York, Virginia, Ohio and Florida who used its forms to register but haven't shown up yet on the official voting rolls.

Over the weekend, my TiVo finally ran out of space.
CenturyTel's deal to buy Embarq, valued at about $11.6 billion including debt, is one of the few big-ticket deals to be struck during the recent financial typhoon.
The weekend's results in motorsports...
In early 2008, Michael R. Bloomberg was at a loss for what to do next. Under New York City's term limits law, his job as mayor would soon expire.

Literature | A critic bemoans the vogue for quoteless dialogue in fiction from Coetzee to Gordimer to Vollman. The custom was popularized by Cormac McCarthy, and now it should stop, please. It "puts off what might otherwise comprise a larger audience." And we quote. [Wall Street Journal]
Nach Waxman, owner of Kitchen Arts and Letters bookstore in Manhattan, responds to a truly final batch of reader questions on food books.
Even in the rush to publish, writers and editors at The Times strive for polish and precision in our prose. Sometimes we succeed.
California is the bluest of states, but the early word on early voting there has some (Republican) observers seeing red.

Michael Mineo, a 24-year-old body piercer, said that on Oct. 15 he was wrestled to the ground by a group of New York police officers on a subway platform. One of the officers, he said, sodomized him with an object, possibly the antenna of a walkie-talkie. Mr. Mineo's allegations revived memories of the case of Abner Louima, a 30-year-old Haitian immigrant who was brutally assaulted with a broken broomstick by an officer 11 years ago.
Alan B. Krueger is an economist at Princeton.
David B. Armstrong was proud for a long time to be part of Merrill Lynch's thundering herd - the brokers in the storefronts and office buildings who are the face of Wall Street to many Americans.

As General Motors tries to salvage its future through a possible merger with Chrysler, the possibility of bankruptcy looms for G.M. and perhaps for Chrysler as well, The New York Times's Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley wrote in an article Sunday that looked at the effects of plunging S.U.V. sales on Detroit automakers.

Foundry Networks announced on Friday that it had adjourned its shareholder meeting from that day until Oct. 29 because of "recent developments related to" its proposed merger with Brocade Communications. This stunning and ominous disclosure, coupled with no clarifying statement, promptly resulted in a 25.7 percent drop in Foundry's stock price.

As of last week, David Geffen's phone line at DreamWorks SKG headquarters here was still live. But some people were already struggling to accept that he would no longer be part of the movie company he had helped build, The New York Times' Michael Cieply reported.
Downsized Wall Street executives are making a run for the hills.

KeyCorp, Capital One Financial and Huntington Bancshares each said they had been approved to receive capital infusions under the Treasury Department's program intended to open up the credit markets. Capital One said it would sell a $3.6 billion stake, KeyCorp a $2.5 billion stake and Huntingon Bankshares a $1.4 billion stake.
Several Democratic lawmakers lashed out Friday at hedge funds that have threatened to block attempts to renegotiate mortgages for struggling homeowners, The New York Times's Barry Meier reported.

Internet | An article predicts a struggle between sovereignty and efficiency as computing moves into a "cloud" of disembodied services and stored data that only look like they're on your computer. Yet geography still matters: huge data farms need a chilly climate, and Iceland fits the bill. [Economist]
The dirty little secret of the federal government's $700 billion bailout plan is that many recipients of Treasury's largess won't be using the money primarily to make new loans.

Silicon Valley has always been a land of big, bold dreams. In the first Internet boom its start-ups either grew fast or died trying, sometimes spectacularly. The casualties of the bust, like Pets.com and Webvan, became legendary. In this downturn, say investors and entrepreneurs, start-ups are adopting a strategy that they hope will let them hang on instead of flame out, The New York Times' Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller write.

The chase for a piece of the Treasury Department's $700 billion bailout program intensified Friday as the government considered extending it to include insurance companies as well as banks, and the auto industry stepped up efforts to secure a share of the money, The New York Times's Edmund Andrews and Eric Dash reported.
Citadel, the hedge fund in Chicago run by the wunderkind Kenneth C. Griffin, has found just how hard it is to calm investors during these troubled times, says Breakingviews.

In yet another example of the backchannel maneuvering that preceded the federal government's bailout of the financial sector, Goldman Sachs' chief Lloyd Blankfein reached out to Citigroup's Vikram Pandit last month to discuss a merger, The Financial Times reported.

The global financial crisis extended its reach into the Persian Gulf states on Sunday, as Kuwait suspended trading in shares of a major bank and the Saudi authorities announced a plan to help citizens receive credit, The New York Times' David Jolly writes.
Shares in blue-chip heavyweight HSBC plunged more than 10 percent to a six-year low on Monday, joining a global equities sell-off on fears of the impact of a global recession on corporate profits.

This morning feels in some ways like a replay of Black Monday in 1987. Now, as then, a mysterious professional investment strategy seems to be coming apart at the seams, and no one quite knows how far along the destruction is.

PBL Media, controlled by buyout firm CVC Asia Pacific, said James Packer had resigned from its board of directors after Mr. Packer's Consolidated Media Holdings said it would not provide more funding to PBL.
The disentangling of Lehman Brothers' European operations is taking longer than hoped thanks to slow cooperation from other banks, The Financial Times reported, citing lead administrator Tony Lomas.

I have to confess, I haven't paid much attention to Opera Software until recently. The Norwegian company has been an also-ran in the browser market for 13 years. On Friday, I had a chance to sit down with its co-founder and chief executive, Jon Stephenson von Tetzchner. I can't say that I'm convinced that Opera is now poised to take the Web by storm, but his take on the browser world makes good sense and paints a picture of a future with browsers everywhere.
John Devaney, whose $600 million hedge fund collapsed earlier this year, was heckled off the stage in Miami last week during an annual industry conference.
JSE has offered 173.2 million rand ($15.4 million) for the Bond Exchange of South Africa, seeking to join Africa's largest stock and bond markets, Bloomberg reported.
On fickle Wall Street, bank deposits are in and capital markets are out.

With a Sunday announcement of an increase in its Volkswagen stake, Porsche on Sunday became poised to seize full control of the company. Porsche said it had raised its direct stake in VW this month from 35.2 percent to 42.6 percent and had options on a further 31.5 percent.
An alternative source for video game news, Crispy Gamer, has raised $8.25 million in venture capital from J.P. Morgan's Constellation Ventures, VentureBeat reported.

Food | The Soup Nazi goes Japanese: a report on the phenomenon of the "sushi bully." Even with their surly attitudes, "these domineering sushi chefs can have lines of supplicants out the door." But in this foundering economy, how long can they fail to be your chum? [Wall Street Journal]
TuneCore has raised $7 million in a first institutional round of funding from Opus Capital, VentureBeat reported.

CenturyTel, a provider of local phone and Internet services, agreed to buy Embarq, its larger competitor and a spinoff from Sprint Nextel, for about $5.76 billion in stock, excluding debt. The deal was announced Monday morning, confirming a report in The New York Times.

Desjardins Group, Canada's largest financial cooperative, is shutting down lines of hedge fund-linked products as it joins insurers such as Manulife Financial and Sun Life Financial in dealing with problems in guaranteed investments that have been hammered by the current market crisis.
Aegon may tap into a 20 billion euro ($25.17 billion) fund set up by the Netherlands in order to shore up its financial institutions, The Wall Street Journal reported.

With the I.P.O. market facing its worst drought in decades, Reuters reports that history is providing little indication as to when the market will turn around.

In a move to avoid staff cuts, CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets, the regional brokerage unit of Credit Agricole, has asked 500 senior bankers and executives to accept pay cuts of as much as 25 percent next year.

Mike Singletary had an, um, eventful first game as an N.F.L. head coach. He benched quarterback J.T. O'Sullivan. He banished tight end Vernon Davis to the locker room after Davis picked up a ticky-tacky personal foul penalty. And, well, he lost to the Seahawks, 34-13. Afterward, he had an intense, riveting news conference in which he apologized to the fans.

Mark Kingwell, the author of "Nearest Thing to Heaven: The Empire State Building and American Dreams," answered selected readers' questions about the history, significance and architecture of the Empire State Building this week. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

Europe | A press roundup notes the European intelligentsia's sympathy for the Czech writer Milan Kundera, accused of being a Communist informant. Bernard-Henri Lévy comes to his defense. One journalist on how the K.G.B. blackmailed her: "It was child's play to crack my 'secrets.' " [Sign and Sight]

They're also "overpaid, oversexed and all over the place." [Times of London]

Tuesday, 3:30 p.m. Come wallow in nostalgia -- so pretty, so old -- as the Landmarks Preservation Commission considers protected status for the Lillian Goldman Fountain of Life and Tulip Tree Allée at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. They've been around for a long time, folks, but then again, so has the Blarney Stone on Ninth Avenue. Landmarks Preservation Commission, 1 Centre Street, ninth floor, Manhattan.

CenturyTel, a provider of local phone and Internet services, was near a deal Sunday night to buy Embarq, its larger competitor and a spinoff from Sprint Nextel.

In case you hadn't notice, the new James Bond film, "Quantum of Solace," is about to hit our cinema screens. The world premiere takes place in London on October 29, followed by the first public screening at the British Film Institute's 52nd London Film Festival.
Ms. Marokvia wrote two stirring memoirs describing her childhood in a French village and her wartime ordeals in Nazi Germany.
Amon Miyamoto designed his home on one of Okinawa island’s southeastern beaches to blend with the environment.
No show in Europe at the moment bids to be more spectacular, or ends up being more exasperating, than “Picasso and the Masters.”
Two people were reported shot to death and one other injured on Sunday night on the campus of the University of Central Arkansas, in Conway.
Though it stretches plausibility at times with coincidences and parallels, Kate McGovern’s “Blue Before Morning” is a quirky, personable little one-act with a warm heart.
The actor-playwright Josh Jonas’s one-man show “Capture Now,” at the Theaters at 45 Bleecker Street, takes cancer as its subject, and manages to avoid suds.
Police officers responding to a report of a missing 2-week-old at Kings County Hospital Center on Sunday found the child dead at its mother’s home in Brooklyn.
The Phillies pounded the Rays, 10-2, in Game 4 with a chain of home runs leaving them one game away from winning the World Series.

The Bengals fell to 0-8 on Sunday, and gave no indication that they were any closer to their first win. Their 29-point loss was their biggest of the season, and came a week after they lost to the Steelers by 28.
An ad from the Gospel Music Channel highlights the many acts it plans to feature this fall.
A project to build a wastewater treatment plant in Falluja has tripled in cost to $100 million and fallen about three years behind schedule.
Philadelphia now leads the World Series, three games to one, after Phillies’ Ryan Howard drove in five runs.

William Jennings Bryan, the Democratic Party's nominee for President, got a "tremendous" reception last night ("the ovation he received lasted 12 minutes") at Madison Square Garden, where he spoke for two hours to a crowd of 13,000. "His long talk, which did not end until after midnight, was listened to throughout with great attention, and every point he made was cheered again and again." Bryan criticized William Howard Taft and the Republicans for concealing their sources of campaign contributions and maintaining a "blind pool into which all those contributions will be poured which are too tainted to be made known even after the election." Bryan seemed to acknowledge that the odds were against him when he said, "And if there be any Republicans here let me say this to them, that they may defeat me if they will, but they cannot deny to me the credit that history will give me for helping to give an impulse to honest politics." 13,000 in Garden to Hear Bryan
Colt McCoy, Texas quarterback
We urge Congress to find time for a public lands bill that could add nearly two million acres to the nation’s store of permanently protected wilderness.
Trying to jack up oil prices is unacceptable. It could send the world economy into an even deeper slump from which it could take a long time to recover.
The former president is as forceful as ever in expressing himself. His statements, drawn from the historic record, are applied to contemporary questions.

The American Ted Ligety, the World Cup giant slalom champion, finished third in the season-opening race behind Daniel Albrecht and Didier Cuche on the icy Rettenbach course in Sölden, Austria. Albrecht finished in a two-run combined time of 2 minutes 15.78 seconds. Bode Miller, the defending overall champion, was fifth after the opening run, but was 21st on his second and finished 10th.

Roger Federer won his hometown tournament for the third straight year, beating second-seeded David Nalbandian, 6-3, 6-4, at the Swiss Indoors final in Basel. Federer hit eight aces and conceded only seven points on his serve.

Sergio García picked up his first European victory in more than three years on his home course and dedicated the three-shot victory at the Castello Masters to the hospitalized Seve Ballesteros. García had a four-under-par 67 for a total of 20-under 264 at the Club de Campo del Mediterraneo golf course in Castellon, Spain.
Top-seeded Andy Murray won the St. Petersburg Open in Russia for the second straight year, beating the qualifier Andrey Golubev, 6-1, 6-1.

Midfielder Xabi Alonso scored in the 10th minute and Liverpool ended Chelsea’s 86-match home winning streak Sunday, 1-0. It was the first goal Chelsea had allowed in seven league and cup matches. Chelsea last lost at home in February 2004 to Arsenal.

Kim Yu-Na of South Korea captured the Skate America women’s title in Everett, Wash., winning the free skate and short program. It was a disappointing debut for the former world champion Kimmie Meissner, the 2007 Skate America winner. Meissner, who switched coaches in February, was eighth over all.

Brad Evans scored the only goal and the host Columbus Crew denied D.C. United a Major League Soccer playoff berth Sunday with a win in their regular-season finale. The result gave the Red Bulls a wild-card spot.
With five teams from outside the major conferences ranked in the Bowl Championship Series standings, it has been a big year for the little guy in college football.
Kevin Faulk caught a 15-yard go-ahead touchdown pass with 3 minutes 13 seconds left and Deltha O’Neal pulled in a juggling interception leading the Patriots to victory.
Most bridge players follow traditional lines in their bidding and play. Their goal is to win by making fewer errors than their opponents. But a few players have a different insight on the game.
Sunday was Plaxico Burress’ first game in Pittsburgh since 2005 and Steelers fans disparagingly called him Dropsico and Plexiglass when he was there.
It’s a wonder that there are still two guys in the presidential race, pulling out all the stops to be chosen as the one to face this economic nightmare.
China is now in a position to pick up some of the slack in the economy: selling more of its own goods at home and buying more from the rest of the world.
The troubles in the banking system, hedge funds and emerging markets are mutually reinforcing. Bad news begets bad news, and the circle of pain just keeps getting wider.
The Republican center is giving way, and some on the political right are in retreat. Time for John McCain to finally make his case.
On Sunday, the Giants stuffed the Steelers when it mattered most, allowing Pittsburgh to convert on only 1 of 10 third-down attempts.

Pelham Memorial High School added 17 electives courses this year, allowing students to pursue specialized interests that once were relegated to after-school clubs.

Investigators have observed that L.I.R.R. retirees tend to use the same physicians to claim disability benefits.
Lottery numbers for New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
The fund-raising efforts of Nora S. Anderson, who is running uncontested for Manhattan’s Surrogate’s Court judge, have drawn the attention of the district attorney’s office.
For each concert of the Beethoven quartet cycle, the elegant Tokyo String Quartet has invited other instrumentalists to perform works that Beethoven composed around the same time as the quartets.
Even as “Madama Butterfly” grows familiar to Met regulars, Anthony Minghella’s staging retains its full capacity to beguile and move the viewer.
NATIONAL.
William Ayers, the former 1960s radical whose connection to Barack Obama has been decried by John McCain, appeared at a forum in New York on Sunday.
New albums from John Legend, Pink, Bloc Party and the Matthew Herbert Big Band.
The caretaker of the hotel Nello Summertimes in Southampton says he has seen and heard ghosts on the property.

The Phillies consider Carlos Ruiz’s hitting a bonus as long as he continues guiding their staff, which had the National League’s fourth-best earned run average, toward a World Series title.
A New Jersey appellate panel reversed a 2006 court decision that would have forced the author of a book about Donald J. Trump to reveal unnamed sources.
Two plainclothes police officers who said shots were fired outside a Brooklyn nightclub early Sunday morning shot and killed two men they believed were shooting at them.
The allegations of police violence from a Brooklyn man earlier this month are being investigated.
In the New York City Marathon, Zola Budd Pieterse hopes to find something that eluded her through two Olympics, two world cross-country titles and a handful of world records — contentment.
Just as financial analysts competed for attention on the way up, the pundit class seems compelled to out-gloom the next guy.
On Friday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom, the Killers played to a reverent crowd.
Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are spending time in states once solid for the Republican Party, a sign of Mr. McCain’s dire position in the final week.
Conservatives are working hard to pass Proposition 8, which would ban same-sex marriage in California.
To preserve cash during the current downturn, many tech start-ups are rushing to lay off employees and cut expenses.
Emerging markets that seemed to be thriving recently are finding themselves caught in the worldwide panic.
An exasperated Gov. Sarah Palin veered off script at a rally in Florida on Sunday to confront, as she called it, “the whole clothes thing.”
The F.D.A. regularly allows devices to market after only cursory review and without clear evidence they help.
As far as obscure numbers go, the Rays are now 1-2 in 2008 when they use the five-man infield. Surely that statistic will be useful some day.
A federal judge on Sunday dismissed one of the jurors in the trial of Senator Ted Stevens after losing contact with her after her father’s death.
Republicans contend that Barack Obama is trying to “steal” the election, and Democrats worry that such charges could add to confusion among voters.
Grand Guignol, the theater of the macabre, is alive and well at the Players Theater in Greenwich Village, where Zombie Joe’s Underground Theater Group performs the almost wordless “Urban Death.”
The Phillies have won only one Series in more than a century of baseball, and had not been in the Series since 1993. That qualifies as excruciating pain.
The Pyramid in Memphis, rising 321 feet from the banks of the Mississippi River, is a hollow, empty venue, which has had trouble finding a purpose for itself.
Iran’s President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad is suffering from exhaustion due to his job, a state news agency reported.
Food inspectors have found eggs imported from northeast China to be contaminated with high levels of melamine, the chemical at the heart of an adulteration scandal involving Chinese milk products.
Although they run competing Web sites, Tina Brown and Arianna Huffington are friends.
After Brett Favre called for a “next fly” in the huddle, Laveranues Coles sprinted down the sideline giving the Jets the final margin in their victory against the Chiefs.

A nine-person team at Microsoft Research India assesses whether quirky ideas can make technology useful to those who have heretofore lived without it.
A former Colombian lawmaker kidnapped more than eight years ago by FARC rebels escaped through the jungles with one of his rebel captors on Sunday.
The immortal hair bands of the 1980s finally receive their due in the brash jukebox musical “Rock of Ages” at New World Stages.

The Department of Defense has identified 4,183 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 615 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations.

Carlos Peña and Evan Longoria are almost out of swings and hope. With one more loss, the Rays will see a memorable season sputter to an end.

“Madonna of the Goldfinch,” a 500-year-old painting by the Renaissance master Raphael (1483-1520), will go on display next month after a decade-long restoration.

American Songbook, Lincoln Center’s annual celebration of American popular song, is returning for an 11th season, from Jan. 14 through March 9.

Men ABDERRAHIM GOUMRI, 32, Morocco, personal best of 2 hours 5 minutes 30 seconds. A decade ago, he was racing on the track in Norway, and he has gone on to run personal bests of: 3:39.80 for 1,500 meters; 12:50.25 for 5,000; and 27:02.62 for 10,000. In 2007, he made his marathon debut, and in two races finished second to Martin Lel of Kenya. In London, he was uncertain when to start his final sprint, and Lel beat him to the punch and won by three seconds. In New York, Goumri's first race in North America, Lel beat him by 13 seconds. Goumri shook that off, saying: ''That's sport: one winner and one loser. It's O.K.'' This year in London, he finished third in a personal best (Lel won again). Goumri began running at 17; a year later, he finished 25th in the world junior cross-country championship. After that, he told Runner's World magazine, ''I knew running was for me.''

BLUMBERG--George P. George began life on August 7th, 1945 and ended his journey on October 24, 2008. He truly loved and enjoyed life, his cat, his boat, his cars, his motorcycle, his writing, his friends and family. He loved and cherished his Mom, Lillian Blumberg, his daughter Tamara deLucia, his son-inlaw Rob deLucia, his sisters Nancy Garneau and Judy Blumberg, his brother-in-law Jay Spica and his wife Patricia Ihle. His humor was special and sometimes corny, but all who met him loved him for it. He was a wonderful writer about all thing automotive and truly loved his second career as a freelance journalist. He will be missed. A celebration of his life will be held for family and friends in November. If you wish to remember him please make a donation to the Yale New Haven Thoracic Oncology Program.

Traffic for the financial news and information category has been up and down with hourly developments in the markets and the price of oil. Most of the top financial Web sites declined in unique visitors from the week ended Sept. 21 to the week ended Oct. 19. But there has been notable week-to-week fluctuation for the top properties. In the eight-week period ended on Oct. 19, for example, traffic to Yahoo Finance was up 8.2 percent over all. But from its least busy week, ended Aug. 31, to its busiest, ended Oct. 12, the site had a 54.6 percent increase.

Sunday was the 41st anniversary of the day Senator John McCain was shot down over Vietnam, an event that might put into perspective these last nine days before the election in which he is trailing in the polls. He has been through worse. On ''Meet the Press'' on NBC, he undermined his attempt to separate from President Bush by saying, ''Do we share a common philosophy of the Republican Party? Of course.'' Senator Barack Obama immediately worked that into his speech, calling it ''a little straight talk,'' at last.

TULSA REMAINS UNDEFEATED David Johnson passed for 264 yards and a touchdown, ran for two scores and brought No. 19 Tulsa's high-powered offense to life in the second half to overpower visiting Central Florida, 49-19, on Sunday night. Damaris Johnson made up for a critical early fumble by returning the second-half kickoff 70 yards to set up a go-ahead touchdown. David Johnson ran in from 10 yards out to give Tulsa a 21-19 lead, and he kept the nation's top-ranked offense in gear from there on out. (AP)

LIPMAN--Melvin Daniel. We announce the passing of Melvin Daniel Lipman on October 25, 2008. Devoted husband of 45 years to Myra Rosenthal, adored father of Nathaniel, Asher, Rebecca, Benjamin, Jacob, Sarah, Rachel, and Deborah and beloved zeyde to Henry, Molly, Megan, Jessica, Charlotte and Jake. Born August 12, 1928, Mel grew up in New York City and, after graduating from Syracuse University and service in the US Army during the Korean War, became a successful real estate developer in Manhattan. His buildings include 200 Central Park South, 1050 Fifth Avenue and 1020 Park Avenue. Mel was a strong, gentle, quiet man who put his wife and children before all else. His life was full with family, love, and travel. The service will be held at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY, today at 10:30 am. The family requests donations be made in his memory to American Friends of Magen David Adom.

RIGER--Martin, retired lawyer and law professor. Died on October 25th, 2008. Born in New York in 1910, Martin won scholarships and worked his way through Cornell University, becoming editor of the yearbook, and through Columbia Law School, where he was editor-in-chief of the Law Review. Graduating from law school in the depths of the depression in 1934, he was recruited by Abe Fortas and William O. Douglas (both would become Supreme Court Justices) to join them at the new Securities and Exchange Commission, where he became director of the division governing the mergers and acquisitions of large corporations. An ensign in the Navy Air Force in World War II, he was on leave when his sister introduced him to her office manager, Anne Cohen. Immediately smitten, he proposed on his next leave. By war's end, he had a wife, two daughters, and the rank of lieutenant commander. After the war, he joined Federated Department Stores in Cincinnati and eventually became their general counsel. At age 59, he ''retired'' and became a law professor at Georgetown University Law School and ''of counsel'' to the law firm of Arnold & Porter. He cared deeply about legal ethics, writing articles decrying golden parachutes and other controversial practices. His wife Anne died at a hospice in Florida in 1994. At a memorial service for the relatives of those who had recently died at that hospice, he met his second wife, Elsie. He wore two wedding rings to commemorate two happy marriages. Martin was a painter and photographer, and loved music, art, ballet, and great literature, enjoying to his final days his beloved Mozart. In addition to his daughters and sons-in-law, Andrea (Andrew) and Stephanie (Dan), he is survived by his sister, Edith Berman, his grandchildren Adam, Scott, Matthew and Jake, and his dear friend, Hana Heller. He will be sorely missed. The funeral service will be at 11am on Monday, October 25th, at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. The family will be receiving on Monday and Tuesday evening, from 6:30 to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be made to The Riger/Potash Family Fund in Ethics and Public Life, Cornell University, Dept. of Alumni Affairs and Development, 130 E. Seneca, Ithaca, NY 14850.
