DAY--Emerson, M.D., died on October 21, 2008 in Wilmette, IL. He leaves his wife Gerry Scherman Day; five children by his first wife, Ruth Fairfield Day who predeceased him--Tad, Bob, Nancy, Bonnie and Shery; thirteen grandchildren; four great-grandchildren. He was born in Hanover, NH in 1913, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College 1934, from Harvard Medical School 1938. After internship, fellowship, and residency, he served as Flight Surgeon for the ATC USAAF 1942-45. He had a brilliant career as physician, having been a pioneer in preventive medicine in the 1950s as Director of the Strang Cancer Prevention Clinic 1950-63 and Chief of the Preventive Medicine Division at Sloan-Kettering Institute 1954-64 both in New York City. His most recent professional positions were as Professor of Medicine at Northwestern University and attending and visiting physician at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, IL. During his lifetime he received numerous professional awards and published a number of professional papers focusing on cancer detection and prevention. Contributions may be made to either the Dartmouth College Fund Attn: Kim Hoyt, 6066 Development, Hanover, NH 03755 or Harvard Medical School, Attn: Friends of Harvard Medicine, Office of Resource Development, 401 Park Dr., Suite 22W, Boston, MA 02215.

The McCain advertisement uses Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s words to raise questions about Barack Obama's ability to withstand ''an international crisis to test the mettle of this guy.'' ''It doesn't have to happen,'' an announcer says. ''Vote McCain.'' The Obama advertisement takes John McCain's words in the last debate -- ''Senator Obama, I am not President Bush'' -- and links him to Mr. Bush on taxes and Iraq. From an earlier interview, Mr. McCain says, ''I voted with the president over 90 percent of the time, higher than a lot of my even Republican colleagues.''

Kerry Collins's arm strength has never been in question -- he led the Giants to the Super Bowl -- but the calm he has brought to the undefeated Tennessee Titans may be a result of the calm he is feeling himself. Collins, who replaced the more mobile Vince Young, has been sacked only once this season. His statistics are not impressive -- he has three touchdown passes -- but with the running of Chris Johnson and LenDale White, they have not had to be. Colts quarterback Peyton Manning had two interceptions returned for touchdowns last week, so he must be wary of the Titans' Cortland Finnegan and Michael Griffin, who entered the weekend tied for the league lead with four interceptions each. ANDREW DAS

This is a debut puzzle for Steven L. Zisser, but he's winking at us with a little inside crossword humor. Great clues often rely on intentional misdirection. It's hard to read [South American flower] and not think of orchids. Well, unless you're an experienced solver, in which case you're on the lookout for that particular deception. Flower is "one that flows" as in the AMAZON. Once you've fallen for that a few times it's a nice feeling, I think it's called smugness, when you're finally immune to it. Mr. Zisser has built his whole theme around that ruse and it makes for a delightful puzzle.

Tracy Colburn started driving the overnight shift for New York City Transit more than three years ago, when her daughter became ill and needed medical care more than once a week. Instead of calling in sick on the days when her daughter received treatment, Ms. Colburn transferred to the night shift. Her daughter is now well, but Ms. Colburn says she will not leave this shift, which she considers a well-kept secret. The city's drivers, she says, call the shift "the Hawk," perhaps as in "nighthawk." Above, Ms. Colburn -- who calls herself a Ralph Kramdette after Jackie Gleason's bus driver character in "The Honeymooners" -- is maneuvering the Q54 through Brooklyn and Queens.

Astronomy | The discovery is Nobel-worthy: the universe is expanding faster and faster, driven by a mysterious force called "dark energy." But who deserves the credit? An amiable, polite, bespectacled man described as "Woody Allen with a Ph.D."? Maybe. [Alumni California, Berkeley]

Diets with "complex formulas that promised abundant eating with just the right combinations of fat, protein and carbohydrates,'' Kim Severson writes in this week's Dining section, "are starting to look like exotic mortgages and other risky financing instruments. And just like a reliable savings account, good old calorie counting is coming back into fashion.'' Of course calories are hard to ignore these days--they're plastered on menus all over town.

ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" led Monday in the ratings as 18.8 million viewers tuned in to the dancing competition from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. In a close, emotionally charged decision that some preservationists warned would set a precedent weakening protection for the city's historic structures, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted 6 to 4 on Tuesday to approve the so-called hardship application of St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan.The decision clears the way for the demolition of a 44-year-old landmark building central to a controversial $1.6 billion plan for a medical tower and condominium in Greenwich Village.

It's hard enough to make modern mathematics comprehensible in print, so I'm especially impressed to see anyone try to do it on television. Tonight, at 8 p.m. on PBS, Nova is presenting "Hunting the Hidden Dimension," an hour-long documentary on what it calls a "compelling mathematical detective story," the discovery of fractal geometry and its resulting applications. Of course, it doesn't hurt that there are lots of beautiful examples of fractals the natural world -- and the unnatural worlds of "Star Trek" and "Star Wars."

A grim worldwide economy has turned the software maker, SAP, awfully quiet. The company on Monday tried to erase an earlier fiscal-year revenue forecast from investors' minds, saying it would no longer release predictions to investors about its current year or 2009 because of widespread "uncertainties."

Homecomings can be rare in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a place where real estate and reinvention can stop people from returning to the streets of their youth. So imagine the sweet joy being savored by Frances Lucerna and Luis Garden Acosta, who managed to find a permanent home for their small public school - El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice - not far from where they started it 15 years ago.

Science | Dean Kamen, man behind the Segway, is betting that a 200-year-old Scottish engine that nobody else thinks can work will replace today's car engine. He's already showing off a prototype. which in theory can run on anything "from jet fuel to cow dung." [London Telegraph]

Ralph Vacchiano has seen the best and the worst of Giants quarterbacks. He started covering the Giants for The Daily News in 2001, right after Kerry Collins led them to Super Bowl XXXV. But he also covered the Giants for The North Jersey Herald & News from 1993 (Phil Simms's final season) through 1997, which for the most part covered the Dave Brown-Kent Graham years.

Since the late 1960s and early 1970s, when working women made child care benefits a key part of the feminist agenda, it has become routine for companies to provide maternity leaves, job sharing and pre-tax accounts to pay for child care. These days, the accommodations offered to those of us caring for elderly parents often are modeled on these kinds of child care benefits. But the so-called "mommy track" and "daughter track" are more dissimilar than similar, and the child care paradigm does not always work to benefit adult caregivers.

Marat Safin, a two-time Grand Slam champion, said he was considering retirement after a 6-0, 7-6 (4) loss to Juan Monaco in the first round of the Paris Masters. “I need to think everything through,” said Safin, 28. “I have no pressure and I have nothing to prove or show. I just want to be comfortable with my decision, whatever I will take.”.
The Trenton Thunder was named the best team at the Class AA level by Minor League Baseball, the governing body for affiliated professional baseball.

The billionaire T. Boone Pickens will give another $63 million to Oklahoma State to finish athletic projects that were supposed to be paid for with a $165 million donation that took a hit during the economic downturn. Pickens’s $165 million donation, announced in January 2006, was the largest gift to a college athletic program. He intended to increase it through his investments so it would pay for an estimated $420 million in renovations and new construction on the campus. That plan was going smoothly until Pickens’s BP Capital energy encountered financial trouble in recent months.

Eastman Kodak Co. is ending its 22-year sponsorship in Nascar and putting more sports marketing dollars into professional golf. Kodak said the realignment fit better with a new effort to highlight its brand digitally, like on PGA Tour scoreboards. Kodak also wants to engage more customers overseas because 60 percent of its sales are outside the United States. Kodak said it would also end a four-year sponsorship of Penske Racing.

Beginning Jan. 1, all junior and senior gymnasts who represent their countries at most international meets will need a license from the International Gymnastics Federation. The licenses will include gymnasts’ name, sex, country and date of birth, and be their proof of age for their entire career. The licensing system, approved by the federation’s executive committee at its Oct. 15-16 meeting and announced Monday, was in the works long before the Beijing Olympics. But it received new attention after questions were raised about the ages of China’s gold medal women’s team.

On the brink of retaining the world championship, Viswanathan Anand was unable to close the deal, losing Game 10 of the title match to Vladimir Kramnik of Russia. Anand still leads the match 6 to 4, with 6.5 points needed to win. More information about the match, which is being held in Bonn, Germany, is on the match Web site.

Major League Baseball decided not to resume Game 5 of the World Series on Tuesday, meaning the Phillies, who lead 3-1 in the Series, and Rays will remain tied 2-2 for one more day.

From the king of England to the Armenian Society of Philadelphia, well-wishers sent telegrams to the White House yesterday to congratulate President Theodore Roosevelt on the occasion of his 50th birthday. After the day's business, "Mr. Roosevelt, booted, spurred, and clad in his khaki riding suit, with the familiar Rough Rider hat," took his carriage to "the outskirts of the city" where he got on "his favorite saddle horse" and led a "little cavalcade a merry pace through Rock Creek Park and the rough country beyond." Returning, he changed clothes and had dinner with "members of the immediate family," and "before 11 o'clock the White House apparently had sunk into slumber." President Reaches Half-Century Post

An answer in the Q&A column on Oct. 14 about what became of the golf balls the astronaut Alan Shepard hit on the Moon, drawing on an interview Shepard gave in 1991, misstated the timing and details of another demonstration that showed an almost complete absence of air resistance on the Moon. It was the astronaut David Scott, not “other astronauts,” who did the demonstration, and he dropped a feather and a hammer that fell at the same speed, not a feather and a lead ball. That demonstration took place during the Apollo 15 mission in July 1971, which was after — not before — Shepard’s Apollo 14 mission, in February 1971.

An art review on Friday about “Mary Heilmann: To Be Someone,” at the New Museum, included an outdated reference to the organizer of the show, Elizabeth Armstrong. Since August, she has been assistant director of exhibitions and programs and curator of contemporary art at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts; she is no longer a curator at the Orange County Museum of Art in Newport Beach, Calif., where she originally organized the exhibition.
No one claimed responsibility for the blast, which occurred near the district courts in the southwestern city of Quetta.
Kidnappers killed five Chinese oil workers whom they had been holding hostage in central Sudan for more than a week, the Foreign Ministry said.

A picture caption on Saturday with a theater review of “The Doll Sisters” at the Annex Theater of La MaMa E.T.C., using information from a publicist, misidentified the actress shown. She is Mieko Yuki — not Kazuko Yoshiyuki, who is also in the play.
The police in Harare arrested 47 women who were protesting to demand a political settlement that would help stop the country’s steep economic decline.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about other contracts with New York City agencies held by a Long Island vendor indicted on charges of defrauding New York City Transit referred incorrectly at one point to the former owner of the company, Roselli Movers, who was convicted of paying kickbacks in 2002. The former owner is Robert Villano, not “Mr. Roselli.”.

An article on Saturday about the resignation of Charles J. O’Byrne, the top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson, following revelations that he had failed to pay his income taxes for five years misidentified, in some copies, the offices once held by Mr. Paterson’s father, Basil Paterson. The elder Mr. Paterson is a former state senator and New York secretary of state, not a former lieutenant governor. (He ran for that post in 1970 but was defeated.).
French investigators concluded that mercury found in the car of a prominent Russian human rights lawyer had been accidentally spilled from a broken thermometer.
The Japanese camera and printer maker Canon slashed its outlook for the fiscal year and said third-quarter profit plunged as weaker sales and a stronger yen hit its bottom line.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about Sarah Palin’s formative years misidentified a man shown standing with Ms. Palin, her husband, Todd, and his mother, Blanche Kallstrom. He is Jim Palin, Todd’s father — not Chuck Heath, Sarah’s father.
Shares of Volkswagen more than doubled a day after Porsche said it had raised its stake in Volkswagen and was close to acquiring control of the company.
The “Smart Choices Program” aims to reduce confusion in the grocery aisle over nutritional value by adopting common standards.
George Osborne, a senior Conservative Party official, said that he had made a mistake in his dealings with a Russian billionaire in Corfu, Greece, last summer.

An article on Oct. 20 about tensions between the Vatican and Israel over efforts to beatify Pope Pius XII, who some Jewish leaders have said did too little to stop the deportation of Jews during the Holocaust, attributed an erroneous distinction to Pope John Paul II. While John Paul was the first pope to make an official visit to Israel, in 2000, after diplomatic relations between the Vatican and Israel were established in 1994, he was not the first pope to travel to the country. Pope Paul VI visited Israel in 1964. (His visit was not considered official and he did not acknowledge the state’s existence during the trip.).
The Rangers captain Chris Drury scored his first two goals and Henrik Lundqvist made 28 saves in a 4-2 victory over the Islander.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about public libraries’ embrace of urban fiction, a genre populated mainly by black authors writing about black characters, misidentified the publishing house whose imprints publish two writers of urban fiction, the rapper 50 Cent and Zane. It is Simon & Schuster, not St. Martin’s Press.

An article on Monday about the attitudes of voters in mill cities in Western Pennsylvania toward voting for a black man for president referred incorrectly to the location of Ambridge, Pa. It lies on the Ohio River, not the Beaver River.

New York City Ballet will hold its opening-night benefit on Nov. 25, its first performance in the newly named David H. Koch Theater. Mr. Koch, who recently gave a $100 million gift for the performance space (formerly the New York State Theater), and his wife, Julia, will be the honorary chairman and chairwoman for the program. The benefit will open with “Chichester Psalms” by Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet. Set to the music of Leonard Bernstein, the work will feature the New York City Opera Chorus. Tickets can be purchased at nycballet.com or by calling (212) 721-6500. ... The Chinese martial-arts show “Soul of Shaolin” will make its Broadway debut on Jan. 15 at the Marquis Theater. This will be the first time a production from the People’s Republic of China has played the Great White Way, its producers say. The show, which begins previews on Jan. 13 and ends on Jan. 31, features 33 performers trained in Shaolin kung fu, the martial arts style associated with the Buddhist Shaolin Temple in Henan Province.

KAY--Pearl, passed peacefully at the age of 90 on October 25. Devoted wife of Samuel Kay and sister of Alfred Bernstein, both deceased, she is survived by her son Andrew Kay. A woman of ability and intelligence, she presided over many organizations and enjoyed a long career in the New York City Department of Education. The memory of her beauty, charm and generosity will be forever in our hearts. Services Tuesday 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

DORFSMAN--Lou. The Trustees, faculty, students and staff of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art note with deep sadness the passing of a beloved and talented alumnus, whose illustrious career at CBS redefined the role of design in corporate communications. A true pioneer, his influence extended beyond graphics to include marketing and advertising, a paradigm shift to what's now known as branding. His unwavering devotion to The Cooper Union and its students-as Trustee, lecturer and role model-exemplified his generosity and creative spirit. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his wife and Cooper Union classmate Ann Hysa, their three children and their entire family. Ronald W. Drucker, Chairman George Campbell Jr., President DORFSMAN--Lou. The Officers and Members of The Cooper Union Alumni Association mourn the death of Lou Dorfsman, an icon of twentieth century corporate design and a former Trustee of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. Lou was recognized by the Alumni Association with the Augustus Saint Gaudens Award, and was an Alumnus of the Year together with his dear friend, classmate and colleague, Herbert Lubalin. Lou was always proud of his Cooper Union education, and we were always equally proud that Lou was an alumnus. Our thoughts are with his wife, alumna Ann Hysa, and their family. Carmi Bee, President, The Cooper Union Alumni Association

On questions of economic policy, Senator John McCain tends to rely on a limited group of people with whom he feels comfortable, as perhaps should be expected of someone who acknowledges that the subject has never been his strong suit. So when Mr. McCain convened an ''economic roundtable'' in Cleveland on Monday, it was interesting to see who was present -- and who was not. Most of those invited were business or political leaders rather than economists. From the first group, there was Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay, and David Farr, her counterpart at Emerson Electric; from the second came Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota and Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who ran against Mr. McCain in the primaries on a platform that emphasized his business experience.

This is the part of the campaign where John McCain and Barack Obama should consider sharing a plane, considering how much time they are spending in the same states. Mr. McCain and Gov. Sarah Palin are together again on Tuesday, with two rallies in Pennsylvania before they go in separate directions. Pennsylvania is pretty much the only Democratic state from 2004 that Mr. McCain is still hoping to win, but by afternoon he is off to North Carolina and Florida.

Starwood Capital, the real estate investment company, said it was in talks to sell a group of its French hotels to a Saudi investor. Starwood is negotiating the sale of the Concorde Groupe, through which it owns 12 luxury hotels, to JJW Hotels & Resorts. JJW is a unit of MBI International, which is controlled by Sheik Mohamed Bin Issa al-Jaber, a Saudi businessman. JJW already owns about 60 hotels and tourist resorts in Europe. A sale would include celebrated properties including the Concorde La Fayette and Lutetia in Paris, the Hotel Martinez in Cannes and the Palais de la Mediterranee in Nice, said Caroline Nico, a spokeswoman for Starwood Capital. The Starwood properties for sale do not include two Paris landmarks, the Hôtel de Crillon and Hôtel du Louvre, she added.

SUSSBERG--Linda Aland, 58, passed away peacefully at home on October 25 after a courageous two-year battle with cancer. Linda was born and raised in Birmingham, AL. She attended the University of Wisconsin-Madison where she met her husband of 37 years, Milton. After their marriage, Linda finished her degree at NYU. Linda was a beloved preschool teacher for over 20 years. Survivors include husband Milton, sons Jordan, Matthew and his wife Melissa, parents Jack, Sr. and Ellen Aland, sister Karen Nussbaum and husband Mitchell, brothers Jack Aland, Jr. and wife Barbara and Robert Aland and wife Kelly, and six nieces and one nephew. The funeral service will be held today at 1:15pm at Temple Beth-El of Northern Westchester, 220 South Bedford Road in Chappaqua, NY. Contributions may be made to the National Head Start Association, the American Cancer Society, or the UJA/Federation.

His memory will forever be etched in our hearts, and our love for him carried with us forever in our souls. Seymour and Jeanette Spira, David and Shan Spira, Mark and Leslie Lopez, Fred and Ellen Fulkerson, and all of our children. GOSWAMI--Swapan K. We love you. Your mentoring, support, and dedication will truly be missed. Your will forever remain in our hearts. Kew Management Corporation GOSWAMI--Swapan K., age 66, of Saddle Brook, NJ passed away on Saturday, October 25, 2008. Born and raised in India, Mr. Goswami moved to the USA in 1970. Before settling in Saddle Brook in 1978, he lived in Maywood, NJ. Mr. Goswami had a special love for his family and friends. Mr. Goswami was the Chief Financial Officer for Kew Management, a commercial real estate firm located in New York City, with whom he had a 40 year affiliation. He was a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and a Chartered Accountant in India. Beloved husband of Anuradha (Lahiri) Goswami. Loving father of Sourav Goswami and his wife, Neelakshi Ray. Cherished grandfather of Mahika Ray Goswami. Dear brother of Ratan and Likhan Goswami. Devoted Brother in-law of Dr. Swapnadip Lahiri and his wife Ellora. Faithful uncle of Jay and Ann Lahiri. Dear and caring friend of Seymour and Jeanette Spira, and family. Final Funeral Services will be held in India. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation-Swapan Goswami Memorial. This is possible in the following manner: (1) By mail, with check payable to: Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation-Swapan Goswami Memorial 1332 North Halsted Street, Suite 201 Chicago, IL 60642-2642. (2) Online, at www.pulmonaryfibrosi s.org, in loving memory of Swapan Goswami, date of passing, October 25, 2008. Thank you very much for your kind thoughts and support in this difficult time.

In the last three presidential elections, the percentage of the electorate that is young or African-American has remained basically unchanged. Registration efforts have expanded the voter pool, but it remains uncertain whether newly registered voters will actually turn out.

An author of an e-mail message sent by the PennsylvaniaRepublican Party to Jewish voters has apologized for the message, which equated a vote for Senator Barack Obama with the ''tragic mistake'' of those Jews who ''ignored the warning signs in the 1930s and 1940s.'' Sandra Schultz Newman, a former State Supreme Court judge and a member of Senator John McCain's Election Day legal task force, stood by the letter on Friday, but said Monday that she had not read the final draft before it was released.

PORTNEY--Charles, 92, died peacefully at home October 26. Retired in 2004 after 55 year investment-brokerage career. WWII veteran, served with distinction in the Pacific as Chief in Underwater Demolitions Team 6, participating in seven invasions, winning the Bronze Star for valor at Saipan and Guam. Survived by his loving wife, Tama Starr. Services Thursday, 11:30am, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors or compassionandchoices.org
TierneyLab From John Tierney's blog, nytimes.com/tierneylab.

SAX--Alice (nee Fisher), passed away peacefully on October 26, 2008, surrounded by her immediate family and the thoughts and prayers of her many friends from around the world. Beloved wife of Karl, mother to Wendy and Rick, Alice embraced the world with a passion for life and devotion to her family and friends. Her journey began in Kerhonksen, NY on May 15, 1928 as the youngest of 10 siblings. She was educated at SUNY Albany and Teachers College, Columbia University. Shortly after marrying, she moved to Okinawa, then to Frankfurt, Germany, where she was a teacher and counselor in the DoDDS system for over 35 years. On retiring to her present home in King of Prussia, PA, Alice continued her love for travel, exercise, bridge, politics, and healthy food, and discovered e-mail as the way to remain in touch with her many farflung friends. Those whom she touched will always remember her for keen insight, compassion, and grace with dignity. She will be terribly missed, yet with a smile, for all the fond memories she created in living her life so fully and with such love. Alice is survived by her children, her sister Ethel ''Boots'' Fisher, and her grandchildren, Emily, Jonathan and Jamie. In lieu of flowers, donations in Alice's name can be made to ORT, 75 Maiden Lane, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10038 or the American Association for Cancer Research Foundation, 615 Chestnut Street, 17th Floor, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

COTEL--Rabbi Moshe (Morris), died suddenly but peacefully at age 65 on October 24, 2008, during morning prayer. Moshe was a graduate of the Juilliard School of Music and one of the youngest recipients of the Rome Prize in Music Composition. He retired as Chair of Composition at the Peabody Conservatory of Music and received rabbinical ordination from The Academy for Jewish Religion in 2003. At his death, Moshe was serving as the Rabbi at Temple Beth El, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. His acclaimed opera Dreyfus was performed internationally, and thousands of people around the country heard and were influenced by his Chronicles: A Jewish Life at the Classical Piano, a performance piece charting his spiritual journey in music and rabbinic text. His loss is irreparable to his wife, dancepartner, and friend, Aliya Cheskis-Cotel, his children Orli and Sivan, father-in-law Barzillai Cheskis, sisters-inlaw Varda Cheskis-Sauer and Rena Cheskis-Gold and families, and friends and colleagues around the world. Donations in Moshe's name may be made to kulanu.org.

EPSTEIN--Lillian, of Livingston, NJ, formerly of Riverdale, NY, passed away on Sunday October 26 at age 90. Wife of the late Herman Epstein. Loved by her children Phyllis and Dr. Michael Zornitzer, Lisa and Michael Epstein, her grandchildren Nicole and Dr. Matthew Zornitzer, Amy and Daniel Delson, Jesse, Emily and Eric Epstein and her great-grandchildren Jared and Larissa Zornitzer and Samson and Helix Delson. She was a member of Livingston Hadassah. She will be missed by all. Contributions may be made to NorthShore-LIJ Health System, the Jewish Board of Family and Children services, and Livingston Hadassah.

SHENG--Samuel Y. We mourn the loss of a dear and kind friend, Sam, a successful businessman whose generosity supported the Sheng Laser Center and vision research. He will be greatly missed. PLOTNIK--Eugene, 82. Brilliant, beloved husband, father, grandfather. Oh the places you took us!

KATZ--Sally Etta (nee Rosenthal), 92, died peacefully in Florida on October 26, 2008. She was born in New York, NY, to the late Harry and Natalie Rosenthal on August 19, 1916. Sally was a true New Yorker. Beloved wife of the late Arthur W. Katz; mother of Benjamin, Jack, and Nikki. Nana to seven grandchildren and Great-Nana to 10 wonderful great-grandchildren,; sister to Evelyn Goldberg and Abraham Rosenthal, aunt, and friend to many, she will be missed by all.

WEISBERG--Alma. Very sadly died of cancer at the age of 81. Loving mother of her deceased daughter Rupali, greatly beloved by her brother Leonard, his daughters (her nieces) Dr. Glenna Andersen, Orren Falk Esq., and Dr. Frances Brookner, and her cousins Dr. Charles Greenhouse, Rena Golub, and Dr. Naomi Adelman. Adored by many because of her remarkable, open and loving nature and the care she gave to many people including in her psychiatric care. Our tears flow for you. Memorial contributions may be sent to: Bank Street College of Education, 610 West 112th Street, New York, NY 10025, Attn. Ms. Scheele for Alma.

Senator Barack Obama unveiled his closing speech Monday, reprising the themes -- change, attacks on President Bush, a call for national unity -- that have marked his campaign for two years. ''We can choose hope over fear,'' Mr. Obama said in Canton, Ohio, ''and unity over division, the promise of change over the power of the status quo.'' When an audience member booed at the mention of Senator John McCain, he responded, ''No need to boo, just vote.''

WERBELL--Bent, beloved husband of Eva and adored father of Jonathan and Jenny, passed away on October 27. Born in Sweden on May 21, 1943, he lived in New York for the past 40 years. He founded Meta Health Technology, a computer software company, and served as its President for 15 years. He was the kindest of spirits, a wonderful man with a great sense of humor who will be dearly missed by his many friends and large extended family in the US, Sweden, Israel, and England. Services will be held on Wednesday at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street (at Amsterdam Avenue). In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association or the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale.

When I began reporting about baseball for The New York Times in the fall of 2005, I was a clerk who fetched coffee and photocopies, and had few contacts. My editor would tell me which people I should try to call for information, but I feared they would never call me back. Why would they? These people didn't know me. Without any returned calls, I worried, I wouldn't have a story. I thought my only hope was to take advantage of my name.

Senator Barack Obama broadcast a half-hour prime time infomercial on Wednesday on three of the major broadcast networks - Fox, NBC and CBS - as well as Univision, BET, TV One and MSNBC. It was the first program of its kind in 16 years.

A new set of studies, I note in my Thursday column, looks at implicit racial attitudes and how they affect perceptions of Barack Obama; most notably, people saw Obama as less American than Tony Blair. The findings speak to something that I firmly believe: Most Americans consciously believe in equal opportunity and are opposed to racism, but many people also have unconscious biases that undermine those egalitarian beliefs.

Democrats are wringing their hands in nervousness over the "Bradley Effect," in which black candidates poll well but win fewer votes than expected. That's usually attributed to voters lying about racism -- telling pollsters they're going to vote for a black when they actually plan to vote for a white -- but some scholars believe it has less to do with lying than with unconscious racism that leaves voters with growing doubts that lead to a last-minute mind change in the voting booth. In any case, though, the Bradley Effect has been diminishing in recent years, and in many races disappeared.

The Internal Revenue Service dangled career possibilities when it held an open house at the federal office building at 290 Broadway in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday. An hour before the fair was scheduled to begin, the crowd began lining up -- recently laid-off Wall Street types in charcoal-gray pinstripe suits and trench coats; less formally dressed people; a woman with a new accounting degree on her résumé and a 14-month-old baby in a stroller.

The Obama-Biden campaign has directly singled out Senator John McCain's choice of a running mate -- using footage of Gov. Sarah Palin as she winks -- in a new commercial that questions the Republican ticket's preparedness on economic issues.

Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and several other firms are close to settling litigation from investors who claim the banks rigged initial public offerings during the dot-com boom of the late 1990's, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the talks.

I made the mistake of going into a Halloween store today. One of those make-shift kinds that seem to spring up out of nowhere just for the month of October in a storefront you hadn't realized had been empty until there was suddenly a ghost out front handing out leaflets.

History | A book explains why in 1939 Kern County, Calif. -- overrun at the time by Dust Bowl migrants -- banned Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath" as "lewd, foul and obscene." An official thought publicity over banning the labor-rousing novel would attract federal aid. [American Heritage]

Lazard said on Wednesday that its third-quarter profit fell 34 percent, as the investment bank took charges on buying back the parts of its asset-management business it did not already own, as well as the market turmoil and the collapse of Lehman Brothers.
GMAC, the auto finance and mortgage company, is seeking to become a bank holding company in order to access the government's $700 billion financial rescue plan, The Wall Street Journal reported.
An impatient White House prodded banks and other financial companies Tuesday to quit hoarding billions of dollars flowing into their vaults from Washington and start making more loans.
As hedge funds continue to be hit with deepening losses and mass redemptions, many industry observers are wondering what the formerly high-flying industry will look like after the shake-out.

Shares of Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Group tumbled on Tuesday on speculation the banks might be caught on the wrong side of a trade involving German automaker Volkswagen, traders said. But they erased their losses in the last hour of trading, ending the day higher.
So many biotechnology companies talk about "extending the runway" these days, you might think they had entered the airline business, The New York Times's Andrew Pollack writes.
Is General Electric one of the few remaining nearly risk-free borrowers in the United States? Or is its standing near junk level?
The timing of the departure of South Financial Group's chairman and chief executive is "precarious as hell," an analyst told TheStreet.com.

As credit streams from troubled Western banks dry up in the financial crisis, Russian oil companies, The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer writes, are negotiating multibillion-dollar loans from a more reliable source: the cash-rich Chinese government.

In my column today, I laid out the cases for being bullish and bearish. I gave more space to the bearish case, because I think conventional wisdom has (too) quickly coalesced around the idea that stocks have become cheap.
Ripplewood Holdings was picked on Wednesday as the favored bidder to buy South Korea's Daewoo Electronics.

The U.S. Treasury Department faces huge borrowing needs this year to finance multiple programs the government is running to try to restore stability to severely strained markets, a top U.S. Treasury official said Tuesday.

Even as markets plunge amid a crisis of confidence, Wall Street officials argued on Tuesday that the world's financial institutions need a new and different kind of regulation, rather than more of it, Reuters reported.
As financial panic spreads across the globe, some investors are moving their money to an unlikely place: Lebanon.

The national "bank holiday" that ushered in the New Deal in 1933 locked up the public's cash for four days. The crisis that hit last month at the Reserve Fund, the nation's oldest money market fund, has frozen hundreds of thousands of customer accounts for more than six weeks - with no sure end in sight, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques writes.

Media | Is the "elite media" tide turning for Sarah Palin? Tina Brown's Daily Beast features two pro-Palin articles. One's called "Sarah Palin's a Brainiac," by a Democrat and former editor of Ms.; another's by Tina herself: "How Obama and Palin Redefined Sex Appeal." But at Slate, Christopher Hitchens isn't joining any bandwagon. [Daily Beast, here and here; Slate]

The Japanese government will ask the European Union to block BHP Billiton's bid to take over Rio Tinto, on concerns that the deal would have an adverse effect on the country's domestic steel market, Jiji Press reported.
The owner of Miami Dolphins, H. Wayne Huizenga, is hoping to seal a deal to sell as much as 45 percent of the team to Stephen Ross before a new administration is ushered in.
Location, location, location is the theme for the first investments made by a venture capital fund backed by BlackBerry maker Research in Motion.
Pulte Homes founder and Chairman William Pulte recently sold 760,000 shares of the company's stock to satisfy margin calls and could be forced to sell more, the company said on Tuesday.
A leading Republican lawmaker asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to "thoroughly investigate" antitrust and privacy issues in a search advertising partnership planned by Google and Yahoo.

Lufthansa is set to become majority owner of BMI British Midland, a move that give German carrier the second largest share of take-off and landing slots at London Heathrow airport, The Financial Times reported.

ServiceMagic, a company owned by Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp that matches homeowners with prescreened home improvement contractors, said Wednesday that it is expanding internationally with the purchase of a majority stake in Luxembourg-based The Koening Company.
Singapore's DBS Group said 103 million Singapore dollars ($68 million) of structured notes linked to bankrupt U.S. brokerage Lehman Brothers Holdings are now worthless.

Asian stock markets rose on Wednesday, rallying amid expectations that the Federal Reserve and other central banks will stage yet another cut in interest rates to bolster flagging growth, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.
A tug of war is in full swing on Wall Street and those pulling for stocks came out way ahead on Tuesday for the first time in a while, The New York Times's Vikas Bajaj reported.
Icelandic-owned budget carrier Sterling Airways said it will file for bankruptcy Wednesday because of the financial meltdown.
Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain called Tuesday for China and the Persian Gulf states to put up more money to help the International Monetary Fund deal with the fallout of the credit crisis.
The billionaire financier Kirk Kerkorian has sold more shares of the Ford Motor Company, reducing his stake in the automaker to less than 5 percent.
An election-day rebellion is under way in San Francisco against Pacific Gas & Electric, a big California utility.

Mideast | Online activism is sometimes called "slactivism" in the West, but it's not a trivial pursuit in places where the freedom of assembly is repressed, like Egypt. An article looks at a Facebook-centered youth movement -- said to be 70,000 strong -- standing up to the Mubarak government. [Wired]
This cloying show about the irrationality of love, finds John Patrick Shanley communing loudly with his madcap side, which hasn’t been very visible in recent years.

Iceland | Celebrity journalism heats up Iceland! Bjork writes that those who bungled her country's finances now want to ruin its landscape of "naturally hot pools": "Iceland could easily become one big lush spa," she says, so invest there "rather than serving Alcoa and Rio Tinto." [Times of London]
Works from the exhibition “NeoHooDoo: Art for a Forgotten Faith” at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens, in which artists bring a secular eye to religious imagery.
Beyond providing red meat for the tabloids, Madonna's impending divorce is big news in the property business.
The main problem with eating in Rome is that all the food's, well, so Italian.

Eric Musselman isn't an N.B.A. coach anymore, but he's still in the loop.
Does Google's settlement of a lawsuit with authors and book publishers signal a more conciliatory approach to copyrights on the part of the Internet giant?
A new documentary offers a salutary and touching reminder that the race, like nearly everything else great about New York City, was the creation of a stubborn visionary.

America’s Cup teams will cut their budgets by up to 80 percent under plans for sailing’s richest event in 2010 as financial turmoil makes it harder to find sponsors, the Alinghi team owner Ernesto Bertarelli said. Under plans to be discussed by about a dozen prospective teams, syndicates will be allowed a budget between $12.5 million to $25 million, Bertarelli said.

Diego Maradona was offered a chance to coach Argentina’s national team but declined to say whether he accepted. Maradona and Carlos Bilardo were asked to lead the national team by Julio Grondona, head of the country’s soccer association. Maradona would be the coach and Bilardo the general director. “There are some things to resolve,” Maradona said.

Without a sack or interception in the last nine quarters, the San Diego Chargers fired the defensive coordinator Ted Cottrell and replaced him with Ron Rivera, the inside linebackers coach. Cottrell had become a popular target of fan anger as the Chargers (3-5) lost three of their last four games, including a 37-32 loss to the Saints in London on Sunday. ¶Defensive end Bruce Smith, defensive back Rod Woodson and tight end Shannon Sharpe are among first-year candidates for induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. The list includes 110 players, 7 coaches and 16 contributors, including Paul Tagliabue, the former N.F.L. commissioner, and the longtime team owners Bud Adams, Jerry Jones, Art Modell and Ralph Wilson. Hall of Fame selectors will announce the 25 semifinalists later this month.

No October baseball for Derek Jeter, but he did have a victory to talk about. Jeter and Tiger Woods were working on a promotion for Gillette, and Jeter said he took Woods down in “FaceBreaker” video boxing. “We were just playing a game which I beat him in a few times,” Jeter said. “We’ve got video, photos, all the proof.”.

Erik Compton, who advanced through the first stage of PGA Tour qualifying just five months after his second heart transplant, was given an exemption to play the final tour event of the year. Compton, 28, received a sponsor exemption to the Children’s Miracle Network Classic at Disney World on Nov. 6-9.

Authorities said a 32-year-old man who died during the New York City Triathlon last summer was killed by a condition linked to high blood pressure. Esteban Neira died in the Hudson River during the swim portion of the triathlon July 20. The cause was initially a mystery. After further testing, the medical examiner ruled that the cause of death was hypertensive cardiovascular disease. John Korff, a triathlon organizer, said Neira, from Argentina, apparently was unaware he had the condition.

The doctor for Lute Olson, the former Arizona coach, said that Olson had a stroke within the last year and that he advised him to retire. Dr. Steven Knope said a magnetic resonance imaging test confirmed the stroke, which left Olson with severe depression and impaired judgment. ¶The police in Hamden, Conn., said they were investigating complaints of racism at Quinnipiac University, including slurs and harassing phone calls directed at black players on the basketball team. Police said slurs were discovered Friday and Saturday on poster and cork boards outside the dormitory rooms of three black players and that players in the same building reported receiving harassing phone calls Monday. racism.
Kanoyama, a favorite of sushi savants for a while now, and Sushi Azabu, which opened this year, present what might well qualify as sushi bargains.
Patients receiving transfusions of blood stored 29 days or longer are twice as likely to contract an infection as those receiving newer blood, according to researchers.

William Howard Taft, the Republican presidential candidate, and New York Gov. Charles E. Hughes, the incumbent Republican running for re-election, reached "the climax of the National and State campaign" last night at Madison Square garden. "Between 13,000 and 14,000 people, including many women, cheered the two candidates till they were exhausted." Hughes arrived first and was greeted by a 16-minute ovation, and then Taft by a demonstration lasting 19 minutes. "When he finally began to talk, Mr. Taft's voice was so husky that he could scarcely be heard. A murmur of comment swept over the audience, then every one became extremely quiet. The candidate went on, and, with an obvious effort, succeeded in making his voice carry." Taft spoke for eight minutes and "the brevity was a great disappointment to the crowd." He attacked his opponent, William Jennings Bryan, saying, "If you put in power a gentleman who is in favor of the free coinage of silver, the Government ownership of railways, the guarantee of bank deposits, and every other quack remedy that is done to accomplish reform overnight, then you will introduce disaster to your business future, and you will insure business depression for four years." Host Greets Taft, Hughes

Los Angeles city officials say they will increase staff levels at the Police Department’s crime lab to clear a backlog of 7,000 untested rape evidence kits. A city audit has said the backlog caused the police to miss the deadline for prosecuting more than 200 of the cases if suspects had been identified. A statement by Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa said an agreement had been reached to hire additional staff members and increase outsourcing to DNA labs.

Two counts of capital murder were filed against four men in a drive-by shooting that left two students dead and another person wounded on Monday at the University of Central Arkansas . “This is an incredibly heinous case,” said Marcus L. Vaden, the prosecuting attorney of Faulkner County. At least one of the four fired eight shots, striking the three men, who the authorities suggested were in the wrong place at the wrong time. Lt. Preston Grumbles of the university police department said investigators believed that four other people, none of them students at the university, had been the intended victims. He did not elaborate. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, however, reported that only minutes before the gunfire, one of the two people killed sent a fellow student a text message that hinted darkly of imminent violence. The message cautioned that armed men had arrived on campus because of an incident the previous night in “PB,” an apparent reference to Pine Bluff. Mr. Vaden identified the four men, all charged with two counts of capital murder, one count of attempted capital murder and four lesser charges, as Kawin Brockman, 19, of Clifton; Kelcey Perry, 19, of Morrilton; Mario Toney, 20, of Little Rock; and Brandon Wade, 20, of Bigelow.

Mayor Ron Dellums of Oakland said he had asked the state attorney general to investigate accusations about his police department’s handling of the August 2007 killing of Chauncey Bailey, a prominent local journalist. Mr. Dellums’s actions came after a series of articles by the Chauncey Bailey Project, a collective of investigative journalists, drew connections between an Oakland police detective and Yusef Bey IV, who is accused of running a criminal enterprise out of a Muslim bakery. One member of the bakery, Devaughndre Broussard, has been charged with murder in the death of Mr. Bailey, the editor of The Oakland Post. The paper, a weekly with an emphasis on black politics and culture, had been investigating the finances of the bakery.

Texas A&M University agreed to pay $2.1 million to settle a lawsuit over the collapse of a bonfire tower that killed 12 people and injured dozens nearly a decade ago. The families of four students who were killed and several who were injured sued the university and the contractors who were hired to help build the 59-foot-tall tower of logs that fell apart in November 1999. After the collapse, the university prohibited students from building the bonfire on its property, a tradition for the Texas A&M-Texas football game that dates to 1909. Since then, the fire has been held off campus by students and alumni. Under the settlement, the university also agreed to have engineering oversight if it decides to allow future bonfires on campus.
Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia posted a third-quarter loss Tuesday as advertising revenue in its publishing division fell 18 percent and ad results in the current quarter were down.

A state senator who lost the Democratic primary last month was arrested by the F.B.I. and charged with accepting $23,500 in bribes from undercover agents who she believed were local businessmen. The senator, Dianne Wilkerson, 53, was charged with attempted extortion as a public official and theft of honest services as a state senator. An affidavit filed in court by the Federal Bureau of Investigation includes a series of still photographs from video recordings that it said showed Ms. Wilkerson accepting cash. In one series, left, taken in June 2007, Ms. Wilkerson appears to take cash and stuff it under her sweater and inside her bra. Ms. Wilkerson did not enter a plea at an initial court appearance. She faces up to 20 years in prison and $250,000 in fines on each count. Ms. Wilkerson was ordered to have no contact with witnesses and to retain any documents related to the extortion case or her personal finances.
Senator John McCain’s tax and spending proposals would create larger annual budget deficits than those of Senator Barack Obama, analysts say.

A former Milwaukee alderman convicted of extorting and taking bribes from business owners has been sentenced to six and a half years in federal prison. The former alderman, Michael McGee Jr., 39, was also ordered to pay $107,433 in restitution. He was convicted in June of taking money and gifts from business owners in his district in exchange for helping them keep their liquor licenses. Mr. McGee apologized to the victims, his family, friends and the community before sentencing.

TROY--Joanne Joslin. With great sadness, we announce the passing of Joanne Joslin Troy on October 27, 2008. Adored wife of Bill for 60 years, loving mother of daughter Jill Werner, Nancy de Wit and Susan Troy and sons-in-law Wim de Wit and Larry Zipursky; cherished grandmother of Teddy and Karin, Carolyn and Matt, Daniel, Liza, Amanda, Elias and Rachel; and devoted greatgrandmother of lsabel and Andy. Born in Providence, Rhode lsland to Marion and Archie O. Joslin on July 14, 1925, Joanne received her B.A. from Vassar College in 1947. As a result of her distinguished service as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York, Joanne was honored with the title of Life Trustee in recognition of her exemplary commitment to the mission and work of the Home. She dedicated her time and support to many other philanthropic organizations including Temple Emanuel, UJA, and the AntiDefamation League. Known for her devotion to her husband, daughters and grandchildren Joanne was an avid student of opera, an accomplished golfer and an intrepid fly fisherwoman. She was and will be forever admired by her many friends and family for her tremendous energy and determination, her fine intellect personal modesty, loyalty and grace. Memorial service Friday, October 31, 11am at Temple Emanuel, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. Family will receive friends after 5pm on Friday at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st. TROY--Joanne Joslin. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Joanne Joslin Troy our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. Rabbi David M. Posner Dr. Ronald B. According to Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson, the chief proponent of the big bank bailout, flooding the banks with taxpayers' money was supposed to get them to start lending freely again. And that, in turn, was supposed to stabilize the markets and prevent the downturn from being worse than it otherwise would be. It was not entirely clear from the start exactly how Mr. Paulson would ensure that things would go that way. Indeed, earlier this month, shortly after the bailout was enacted, The Times's Mark Landler reported that Treasury officials also wanted to steer the bailout billions to banks that would use the money to buy up other banks.

Mr. Hamid denied having kicked him.

WERBELL--Bent. Meta Health Technology, a leading-edge software developer in the healthcare industry, is sad to note the passing of Bent Werbell, our esteemed former president and cofounder. Bent was known for his kind personality, his ability to communicate with clients and colleagues, and his talent for building partnerships with other companies. He will be sorely missed. WERBELL--Bent. We mourn the passing of our dear friend who in the mid 1970s created highly sophisticated, computerized addiction registries in New York City and Hong Kong, allowing for the first time the demonstration of the enormous benefits of methadone maintenance treatment to the health and social welfare of patients and community alike. The Hong Kong registry remains to this day the most comprehensive and timely system in the world for monitoring trends in use of illicit drugs. To his wife Eva, his children Jonathan and Jenny, and all of his loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Robert Newman, M.D., MPH Director The Baron Edmond de Rothschild Chemical Dependency Institute of Beth Israel Medical Center

REINER--Estelle. Jazz singer, painter, and wife of comedy legend, Carl Reiner for 64 years, died on Saturday, October 25 at the age of 94. A talented artist and singer, Estelle was most widely known for the famous line -''I'll have what she's having,'' in son, Rob Reiner's film, ''When Harry Met Sally''. As an artist she had four one-woman shows of her paintings in the 1970's and at the age of 65 embarked on a new career as a jazz singer. Undeterred by any of the usual constraints of age, anxiety and later, illness, she developed her innate musical gifts and continued performing in clubs in New York and Los Angeles until the remarkable age of 93. Early in her new found career, the noted jazz critic, Leonard Feather, said of her work, ''Her bittersweet timbre suggests honey laced with vinegar. She has qualities many a seasoned pro would envy.'' A. James Liska of the Daily News in New York, wrote, ''she has wise and knowing phrasing, and a dry, wry, sly wit...'', and talented singer/songwriter, Dave Frishberg wrote, ''I feel comfortable entrusting my songs to Estelle Reiner, whose musicality shines through every track.'' She was a true original, a jazz stylist, part of whose repertoire included quirky, little known old jazz and blues songs which reflected her personal humor and uniqueness. Although she sang sweet ballads and standards, she fell in love with the Blues as a teenager, frequenting the Apollo Theater in Harlem, and did not shy away from raunchy old blues tunes such as, ''Handy Man,'' ''You Can Have My Husband (But Please Don't Take My Man''). Her friend, Dom Deluise never stopped talking admiringly about her sexy rendition of ''Don't You Feel My Leg,'' when well into her 80's. Jazz afficionado, David Chasman, also the former production head at United Artists, wrote of Estelle, ''More than innate musicality, more than seductiveness of voice, it is Estelle's undisguised, unequivocal, unabashed, unmistakable love for the songs that she sings, which makes her irresistible to her audience''. Her courage and determination also resulted in seven CD's, including, ''Ukulele Mama'', and a charming collection of standards called ''Grown Up Songs For Kids''. After raising her three children, acclaimed actor/director, Rob, Annie, a gifted writer and psychoanalyst, and Lucas, a painter whose work shows in the U.S. and Europe, Reiner began a career as a performer, studying with Viola Spolin and Lee Strasberg, and was soon cast in ''Fatso'', the directorial debut of her old friend, Anne Bancroft. Subsequently, she had a small part in Mel Brooks' film, ''To Be Or Not To Be'', and went on to do other performances in TV and film, including the often repeated line in ''When Harry Met Sally''. Born in Bronx, New York in 1914, the former Estelle Lebost graduated the National Academy of Design in the late 1930's and during World War II she was the first woman isometric draftsman to work at Sperry Rand, making blueprints for assembly workers building submarines and airplanes. She and Carl Reiner married on Christmas Eve, 1943, when Reiner was on a weekend pass from the Army. Her friends and family will remember her as a free thinker who never stopped searching, a courageous woman of extraordinary spirit and curiosity who lived life to the end. In addition to her children and husband, she also leaves nephews George Shapiro and Donny Shapiro, and five grandchildren, Jake, Nick and Romy Reiner, Livia and Rose Reiner. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Save The Children.

RESSMEYER--Ruth Bretscher, 85, Greenport, NY on October 26, 2008 at Greenport's Peconic Landing. Her loving husband of 64 years Reverend Henry F. Ressmeyer predeceased her by three months. Beloved mother of Christa Ruth Klein, Ph.D. (Rev. Leonard), Georgia Jo Ressmeyer, J.D., the Rev. Canon Victoria Grace Sirota, D.M.A. (Dr. Robert) and the well-known photo journalist Roger Henry Ressmeyer. Loving grandmother of Maria Hollenbeck, Nicholas Strauss-Klein, Renate Klein, Jonah and Nadia Sirota, Ryan and Rachel Ressmeyer and great-grandmother of five, dear sister of the Rev. Dr. Paul G. Bretscher, the Rev. Carl W. Bretscher and Dr. Manuel M. Bretscher. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Washington University, St. Louis, she also studied at Concordia Teachers College, River Forest, IL. and Adelphi University, NY. An early deacon of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, from 1985 she ministered to the sick, assisted with worship and taught Bible classes, after years of service as a kindergarten and preschool teacher at Grace Lutheran Church, Malverne, LI and St. Paul's Lutheran Church, East Northport, LI and a guidance counselor at Lutheran High School, Brookville, LI. An accomplished author, she wrote ''Neither Male Nor Female'' and other Bible studies, poetry, a spiritual biography and a family history. As a musician she served as a soloist, choir member and church accompanist. She is remembered for her gentle spirit and generous heart. Services are being handled by Horton-Mathie Funeral Home of Greenport, NY. Liturgy of the Resurrection, Wednesday 11am at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Main Rd., Greenport, NY. Committal to follow at East Marion Cemetery. Donations in lieu of flowers to a church or charity of your choice.

No need for $75,062 shopping sprees at Neiman Marcus, $36,000 for makeup or $19,215 for hairstyling. Many people will be turning themselves into Sarah Palin this week, and they will do it just by rummaging through their closets. Ms. Palin, the governor of Alaska and Republican vice-presidential nominee, is turning out to be one of the most popular costume figures this Halloween season -- and not just for women. And while a $22.99 ''Miss Alaska'' kit, consisting of a pageant sash (Miss Alaska on one side, Miss Vice-President on the other) and eyeglasses, is a hot item at Ricky's Halloween Costume Superstore in Manhattan -- they say they have sold at least 600 in three weeks -- many people are saying they prefer to do it themselves.

Eggplant alla parmigiana has a lot in common with montepulciano d'Abruzzo. Both the dish and the wine are staples in low- to middle-tier Italian restaurants. They are rarely worth raves. Usually, there is more to recommend about the wine than the dish. Eggplant alla parmigiana (eggplant Parmesan, as most people know it) all too often amounts to punishing the handsome and versatile vegetable by submerging it beneath breading, tomato sauce and oozing cheese.

Around the League Joe Flacco's 43-yard reception for the Ravens on Sunday was the longest by a quarterback since Stats LLC started keeping track of the statistic in 1991. Kordell Stewart had two longer receptions, but he made them when the Steelers were still using him mostly at receiver. ... Randy Moss had seven catches for 102 yards against the Rams, his 58th 100-yard game. Only Marvin Harrison (59) and Jerry Rice (76) have more, but Harrison has not had one since 2006. ... DeMarcus Ware of the Cowboys failed to get a sack against the Buccaneers, ending his N.F.L.-record streak at 10 consecutive games but sparing Harvey Martin's team record of 11 in a row, which occurred before the sack was an official statistic. ... In a season of highs and lows, Ben Roethlisberger is 5-2 and on pace for 23 touchdown passes, but also for a career high in sacks and his second-lowest passer rating. ... Clinton Portis rushed for 126 yards Sunday, his fifth straight game with at least 120. He leads the race for the rushing title by 260 yards. (NYT)

Happy Birthday to us! We launched comments on articles one year ago today. So it's only fitting - and with much excitement - that we announce the launch of the New York Times Community API, which allows you to access comments in several ways.

You've probably noticed, or you may be discovering it for the first time: we have video, lots of it, and it just went under a facelift. Now our videos are easier to find and sharable, with sharper, high-quality images.
Collingswood, N.J. has been drawing a diverse population of new residents with its walkable downtown, accessible public transportation, and eclectic housing stock.

The Florida quarterback and Heisman winner Tim Tebow was nice enough to host The Quad for an afternoon of Georgia game film and conversation on Sunday. Tebow sat down with The Quad before last season for a Q&A that was quite popular. This time around, Tebow gave his typically wide-ranging interview, which began with an explanation for why he loved watching game film and expanded to his devotion to the hilarious YouTube series, Luke and Skip's Football Fundamentals. Along the way, Tebow discussed just how injured he was in last year's Georgia game, his relationship with the offensive coordinator Dan Mullen, which Florida coach gives the best pregame speeches and why Big Ten football can be a tad, well, boring.

Based on figures from an annual count of bicyclists conducted since 1984, the New York City Department of Transportation announced on Thursday that commuter cycling rose a remarkable 35 percent between 2007 and 2008.

The only first-round draft choice from 2003 (one of the best drafts of all time) who has never played an N.H.L. game is the Rangers' Hugh (Huge Specimen) Jessiman. He's now the Predators' Hugh (Huge Specimen) Jessiman, having been traded to Nashville today for futures.

No one can accuse City Councilman Tony Avella of not speaking his mind. Mr. Avella, a Democrat from Queens, released a statement on Thursday to inform the public about his conversation earlier in the day with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that centered on the contentious issue of term limits. The councilman said that Mr. Bloomberg had called him to discuss last week's vote by the City Council, which passed a bill sponsored by the mayor to extend the city's term limit laws. Mr. Avella, who had been an ardent opponent of the bill, said that the mayor had called him to offer his rationale for seeking a third term and asking the councilman to consider the matter from his perspective.
American International Group has found another place to borrow billions of dollars from the government: the Federal Reserve's commercial paper program.

Let me add an interesting tidbit to the coverage of Netflix's deal to put its Internet movies on TiVo video recorders, which is similar to Netflix's previous deals with Samsung, LG, Microsoft and others.

Alberto Gilardino of Fiorentina is serving a two-game ban for intentionally using his hand to score a goal against Palermo in a Serie A game last weekend, and Pierluigi Collina, the dean of international referees, said the banishment is justified.
Lawrence C. Levy, a former political columnist and senior editorial writer for Newsday, is the executive director of the National Center for Suburban Studies at Hofstra University in New York.

After the actor Heath Ledger died in January, the fate of a restaurant and bar he had planned to open in Brooklyn was thrown into question. Then in July, his family announced that it would release money from his estate to complete the business.On Sept. 17, the restaurant-bar, Five Leaves, opened at 18 Bedford Avenue, near the Greenpoint-Williamsburg boundary. In an interview, Mr. Ledger's business partner, Jud Mongell, and Scott Campbell, a tattoo artist who was also a friend of the actor's, traced the evolution of their friendship with Mr. Ledger, who they say relished his friendships with ordinary people.

It may not be a bailout, but every little bit helps. That was the message on Thursday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn and six other council members unveiled a package of 18 initiatives that they said would help New Yorkers absorb the impact of the global economic crisis. The initiatives are broken down into several categories, including job creation, support for small businesses and support for homeowners. They also will not cost the city much money; instead, the city will rely on more than $30 million in money from the federal and state governments, and private donations.

In the face of what could be a nasty recession, it may not be surprising that some companies are calling off their holiday parties this year. But next year's, too? Employees of American Express found that lump of coal in an internal memo on Thursday that outlined the company's plan to eliminate 7,000 jobs while cutting annual expenses by $1.8 billion. The memo, from Kenneth I. Chenault, the company's chairman and chief executive, explained that there would be no year-end parties for employees in 2008 -- or in 2009, said Joanna G. Lambert, a spokeswoman. But she said that decision should not be taken as a projection of how bad things will be at this time next year. "I hope we'll have something to celebrate next year," she said.
The latest generation of loft-dweller calls the lifestyle D.I.Y., but has no objection to a super.

A few months ago, Venkatesh Rao caught my attention with the whimsical drawings about work-life issues he posted to his blog, Ribbonfarm. I have never met Mr. Rao. But through his comments on Shifting Careers, his posts on Ribbon Farm and on Twitter, and a series of e-mail exchanges, I've gotten to know him a bit. Meeting Mr. Rao reminded me that in this globally connected, 24/7 world, it really can be simple and productive to engage with strangers whose ideas intrigue you.

Hours after officials with the city's public housing agency were questioned about the safety of their elevators at City Hall on Wednesday, a woman was injured in an elevator accident at a Manhattan complex. The elevator she was waiting for malfunctioned and she stepped into an empty shaft instead of an elevator cab, the Manhattan borough president said.The woman, Jolanda Joyce, 28, lives in the East River Houses in East Harlem. Shortly after midnight on Thursday, Ms. Joyce was on the first floor of the building at 404 East 105th Street waiting to take an elevator upstairs. The elevator is an old-fashioned model with an outside door with a handle that a tenant must open before stepping into the cab. `
Shares of Pilgrim's Pride fell below $1 on Thursday, a day after a research report said there was a high probability that the chicken producer would file for bankruptcy protection in December.

Alex Ovechkin, in Russia to visit his ailing grandfather, was on hand at the Luzhniki Arena in Moscow as road flares set off by celebrating Dinamo Moscow fans filled the rink with enough smoke on Thursday to force officials to suspend the game.

Two of the state's largest developers of wind power agreed Thursday to follow a new, stringent code of conduct created by the Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who has been investigating the companies over allegations that they bribed and intimidated local officials to approve wind projects.
The North Carolina Board of Elections today announced that it would extend early voting hours on Saturday, the last day people can cast ballots in the state before Nov. 4.

Assemblyman Hakeem S. Jeffries said Thursday that a number of his colleagues in Albany have announced their support for legislation he is sponsoring to require a public referendum before the change in New York City's term limit law becomes effective.

The Hartford Financial Services Group lost about half its stock market value on Thursday after the big property and life insurer posted a surprisingly large quarterly loss, raising concerns on Wall Street that it might need to raise more capital.

Updated, 4:53 p.m. | They heeded the call the day before Halloween and came in droves: driving up to four hours, arriving in Times Square when the sky was barely light. They wore tattered clothes, glitter gloves and rhinestone belts.They showed up at Madame Tussaud's wax museum for a stated purpose: to break the Guinness world record for the most people doing the "Thriller" dance at the same time (which they believed to be set at 62 in Toronto in 2006, but actually apparently is not that at all).

Carla Moquin is the founder of the Parenting in the Workplace Institute, based in Framingham, Mass., which helps companies design programs that allow workers to bring new babies to the office regularly. My questions are in bold.

The firestorm engulfing Wall Street has singed nearly every financial firm this year and put the government in rescue mode. That has made Laurence Fink, who runs BlackRock, the multibillion-dollar money management firm, a very popular guy.

By now most everyone has seen ads from the Corn Refiners Association, claiming that our fears about high-fructose corn syrup are misplaced. Since our kids will soon be loading up on Halloween treats laden with the substance, it's a good time to consider why so many people find corn sweeteners so scary.

Either by virtue of or in spite of the fear and loathing surrounding the Big Ten, Penn State can now claim something that no other team in the country can. Despite being ranked third - behind Texas and Alabama - the Nittany Lions are the only 9-0 team out there at the moment.

Art | An article says graffiti artists are annoyed with photographers using images of their work and selling them without credit. Photographers are "reaping the benefits of street art without assuming any of the risk of creating it." Is it sampling or stealing? [Metromix, Tomorrow Museum]

I saw Emily yesterday, with a nasty burn on her arm. Obviously she's becoming a kitchen veteran. --MBI was still soaring on last week's squash soup triumph -- it was even better reheated -- when I decided that this week, I'd roast a fish, a whole one, with head and tail. Legg Mason said Thursday that it would cut about one-third of the jobs at Legg Mason Capital Management, the first layoffs at its investment unit run by the fund manager Bill Miller, after its assets fell by 53 percent this year.

In 2005, The Journal of the American Medical Association cited "concerns about misleading reporting of industry-sponsored research" to justify its stricter standards for any such research to be considered for publication. The new policy, requiring researchers with no financial connections to the sponsor to vouch for the data and perform statistical work, was promptly criticized in an editorial in The British Medical Journal as "manifestly unfair" because it created a "a hierarchy of purity among authors."

The gross domestic product numbers released this morning were better than I expected, and depended in part on some optimistic guesses about statistics not yet measured. I expect the 0.3 percent rate of decline will be much worse by the time they finish revising the figure.

Senator Barack Obama campaigns in three states that Republicans won in 2004 - Florida, Virginia and Missouri - as he attempts to throw his rival, Senator John McCain, off his game in each battleground state.

The city's current economic mess has been prompting some scary memories about the 1970s, when Fun City gave way to Done City and its dirty streets, grimy subways, abandoned buildings and free-for-alls on the street.

As businesses have begun cutting jobs, New York leads all states in the number of first-time unemployment claims. Companies as varied as Yahoo, American Express, Time Inc. and Swissport Cargo Services at Kennedy International Airport say they are preparing to lay off employees, including online ad sales representatives, magazine editors and baggage handlers, in the coming weeks.

Wednesday was Match Day 3 for the I.I.H.F. Champions League, the halfway mark of the tournament's group stage. Let's start with the Group C game, in Bratislava, featuring a Slovan club in disarray after a poor start to the season and the resignation of coach Zdeno Ciger earlier in the week. India | The tech outsourcing capital of the world has a dark underside, an article says. Bangalore suffers from "systemic corruption, a Byzantine justice system, and a criminal underworld more than willing to maim and murder its way into control of the city's real estate market." [Wired]

Evercore, the boutique investment bank, on Thursday reported adjusted pro forma net income of $2.3 million in the third quarter, compared with $9.8 million in the comparable quarter a year ago. It also said it hired Les Fabuss, former vice chairman of global investment banking at Lehman Brothers, as a senior managing director in New York.
Private equity firm Bridgepoint has closed its fourth European buyout fund after exceeding its fund-raising target by more than 20 percent, peHUB reported.
Deutsche Bank said Thursday that its third-quarter profit slipped 74 percent as it reported write-downs of another 1.2 billion euros ($1.5 billion) on mortgage-backed securities.
ON Semiconductor is trying to persuade a private equity firm to pony up cash so that it won't have to go hat in hand to the debt markets to fund the purchase of some Atmel assets, Reuters reported.

A recently released iPhone and iPod Touch application named greenMeter ($5.99) aims to help drivers lower their car's impact on the environment by weighing parameters like the vehicle's tonnage and the price of gas against "driving style" - a fancy way of saying whether or not you're a lead foot.

Westpac Banking Corporation, which is aiming to become Australia's largest bank through the acquisition of a smaller rival, shrugged off the gloom of the global financial crisis and posted a healthy 12 percent rise in annual net profit.

Motorola said Thursday it would postpone the spinoff of its mobile-phone unit, which it had expected to occur in the third quarter of 2009, citing "stresses in the financial markets," among other reasons.

One weekly aspect of life at United Nations is the arrival of reports thick enough to stun an ox, all crammed with statistics. I am not always clear on how they gather so many numbers from the far-flung corners of the world, but they often prove interesting. This week, for example, U.N. Habitat, a Nairobi-based branch of the organization that is supposed to promote socially and environmentally sustainable cities, rolled out a report about the state of the world's urban areas.

Environment | In a "special report," New Scientist magazine marshals environmentalists, economists and thinkers to argue for zero economic growth (yes) to save the planet. (One writer imagines a society in which "scientists set the rules.") Separately, a skeptic looks at their acceptable consumption limits and suggests that "producing half a cheeseburger would exceed an individual's daily carbon dioxide quota." [New Scientist, Reason]

Readily available credit and high oil prices were a boon for clean energy businesses. Fortune smiled on technologies like wind and solar when money was cheap, and when the gap in price between traditional fuels and low-carbon alternatives was narrow enough to make the alternatives look profitable.
