PNC Financial Services Group could save billions of dollars in federal taxes from its purchase last week of National City, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing tax experts.
Just as the American financial crisis has gone global, so has the rescue effort, The New York Times's Mark Landler writes.

I was scheduled to leave Baghdad the next day, and the weather didn't look good. The light fog that was lingering at midday turned into a yellow overcast darkness in the afternoon. And there were still a couple of hours before sunset.

After the mortgage, child care is the biggest expense in most family budgets. And in the face of job losses, belt tightening and economic uncertainty, parents are looking for ways to reduce what they spend on the people who watch their children. It is a painful cut, because there is a person we know and trust on the other end of the decision  one who needs what we pay her (women still overwhelmingly outnumber men in these jobs) to support her own family. And because we hesitate to use the word "cheap" when talking about who is with our kids when we're at work.

For years, it was the ultimate brass ring on Wall Street. But now admission into Goldman Sachs's partnership may have lost its luster - or at least, its lucre, The New York Times's Michael J. de la Merced writes.
Shares of Apple rallied Wednesday after an analyst said the maker of iPhones and Mac computers is in excellent position to launch a "substantial" share buyback program.

The American International Group is rapidly running through $123 billion in emergency lending provided by the Federal Reserve, raising questions about how a company claiming to be solvent in September could have developed such a big hole by October, The New York Times's Mary Williams Walsh says.
Film production outfit Dolphin Entertainment has secured more than $100 million in financing from Citigroup affiliate Continental Entertainment Capital, to fund six movies targeted at adolescents.
Financial engineering may have fallen into ill repute in Washington and much of the country, but let no one imagine that Wall Street has given up, The New York Times's Stephanie Rosenbloom writes.

European officials are putting the finishing touches on a draft law that is intended to prevent conflicts between credit rating agencies and their clients, The New York Times's Stephen Castle reported.
It seems like an odd moment for Goldman Sachs to cut the number of bankers it admits to its coveted inner circle of partners, Breakingviews muses.

One of the first hedge-fund backed film funds created to invest in a slate of movies seems to be on shaky on ground, The Hollywood Reporter said, and even the banks that provided senior debt financing could take a bath.

General Motors said on Wednesday that its global sales fell 11.4 percent in the third quarter, the latest sign, The New York Times's Bill Vlasic writes, of the growing problems that have led it into merger talks with Chrysler.
From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

Shares in Volkswagen fell by nearly half Wednesday after its main shareholder, Porsche, took steps to ease a quadrupling in the stock price that had pushed some of the world's biggest hedge funds to the wall.

The Internal Revenue Service is considering a plan to curb a tactic commonly used by multinational corporations with American operations to lower their tax bills, a move that would help bring back some of the billions of dollars in taxable profits held overseas, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.
For a few moments, Wall Street seemed on track for its most encouraging two-day performance in a month.
The mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae said on Wednesday that it would probably write down "substantially all" of a tax-related asset that has been a major component of its capital.

Ukraine's Parliament put aside weeks of political infighting on Wednesday to give initial approval for legislation that would secure an emergency loan from the International Monetary Fund to help ease the country's ailing finances, The New York Times's Sabrina Tavernise reported.

A broad array of businesses across the New York region have begun eliminating jobs by the thousands as the pain of the financial crisis spreads well beyond Wall Street, The New York Times's Patrick McGeehan reported.

Hungarian stocks and the currency soared Wednesday after the country secured more than $25 billion in backing from global institutions led by the International Monetary Fund, The New York Times's David Jolly reported.
Delta Air Lines completed its $2.8 billion acquisition of Northwest Airlines on Wednesday, turning two of America's airlines into the world's biggest carrier.

Europe | You've seen one European social democracy, you've seen 'em all, right? Wrong. Now France and Germany disagree over the way to financial salvation: Sarkozy's government-run solution vs. the German approach. Those two at odds: what could possibly go wrong? [Spiegel]

Art | Christie's planned auction of punk memorabilia on Nov. 24 (Ramones, Clash etc.) drives yet "another nail into the coffin" of punk, says one blogger. But another says anyone who can "convince some snooty rich guy" that the junk is worth big bucks is "pretty punk rock." [Gothamist, About.com]

World | In the Obvious Dept., a blog says small islands have drawn history's short straw "precisely because they are so small." But it raises an interesting question: What about when global warming submerges them? Will they be compensated by the larger powers responsible? [Foreign Policy]

Ericsson 4 shattered the 24-hour distance record for a monohull sailing boat on the first leg of the Volvo Ocean Race, beating the mark set by ABN AMRO 2 in the last race. The skipper Torben Grael and his crew covered 590 nautical miles as a cold front hit the fleet Tuesday, bringing gale-force winds and accelerating the high-tech boats toward Cape Town. The record is subject to ratification, but topped ABN AMRO 2’s mark of 562.96 miles in the 2006-7 race. ¶Richard Branson, who attempted a record-breaking sail across the Atlantic last week with his 99-foot maxi yacht Virgin Money, was forced to abandon his attempt Friday after the yacht was hit with large waves. The game had a 10-minute, benches-clearing brawl. The fan was treated for a concussion at a hospital. Castillo was indicted on two counts of felonious assault.

Broughton Brandenburg, a magazine writer who is charged with larceny in the second degree for selling an article to The New York Times that he claimed was written by Grover Cleveland, "was brought back yesterday from Dayton, Ohio, where he had been arrested." Today's report includes the texts of affidavits from two stenographers "who say they did the typewriting of the disputed Cleveland article for Mr. Brandenburg on Aug. 10 last, three weeks before its publication in The Times, and, of course, several weeks after Mr. Cleveland's death." The affidavit of Miss L.M. Bacon, stenographer, says that when she "began typewriting the manuscript, which I afterward recognized as an article entitled 'Grover Cleveland on the Campaign and His Prophecy of Its Result,' published in The New York Times of Sunday, Aug. 30, 1908, Mr. Brandenburg had not finished writing it, but he completed the article at my rolltop desk while I was typewriting the first portion. Mr. Brandenburg came over to me several times, read passages of the article to me, and asked if I did not think they were in Mr. Cleveland's best style. He also asked me if I did not think the article would sell well to a magazine or newspaper." Critical of William Jennings Bryan and praising William Howard Taft, the article predicted Republican success in the election. The Times ran the 3,000-word article as the lead story in its Sunday Magazine Section, stating that it was published "by an arrangement made between a literary agent and the executor of Mr. Cleveland's estate." Brandenburg Faces Fresh Testimony

Brett Favre has always stood out among his peers. So we asked MacGregor, a veteran sportswriter, to give us a few of his thoughts about the quarterback he describes as “the gunslinging Huckleberry.”.

It helps to have friends in high places — or at least one highly placed, all-powerful friend. That’s what Andrew Meier discovered when he ventured to Russia to explore the burgeoning success of professional sports there, a success evident on soccer pitches, basketball courts and hockey rinks around the country, including Omsk, the Siberian city that attracted one of hockey’s most glamorous sports stars, Jaromir Jagr. Fueled by the riches of the oligarchs, the country’s ambitions have received an additional assist from having a jock in the Kremlin, sports-obsessed Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

Once a year, the terror-inducing Hahnenkamm downhill in Kitzbühel, Austria, tests the mettle of the world’s top skiers. In an interactive graphic coming tomorrow, Doug Lewis, a former member of the U.S. Ski Team, explains how to get to the bottom in one piece.

Renardo Sidney represents a different sot of young athlete, Tommy Craggs writes in “The Next Big Thing.” Sidney believes that the high-school system is not in his best interest. “Instead, to the dismay of many scowling traditionalists” Craggs writes, Sidney is almost wholly a product of summer-league basketball. And, depending on your perspective, Sidney’s independence is an example of precisely what’s wrong with amateur basketball -- or what’s right.

With an unorthodox mix of fun, empathy and unbridled silliness — not to mention traditional football smarts — U.S.C. Coach Pete Carroll has forged the team of the decade, writes Michael Sokolove. But in college football, a single loss can disqualify a top program from the ultimate goal — a national title. And despite the Trojans’ abundance of talent, upset losses in each of the past two seasons have derailed their chances. So is there a limit to the power of positive coaching?.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about a reading by John Ashbery at the 92nd Street Y on that night as part of a celebration of the publication of a collection of his poetry by the Library of America referred imprecisely to a distinction Mr. Ashbery earned with that book. While he is the first living poet to be honored with a volume in the Library of America series, he is not the first living poet to have a collection published by the Library of America. It previously published a collection of poems by Samuel Menashe in its American Poets Project series.

It would be easy to dismiss Celerie Kemble. First off, her name is Celerie. Then there’s her privileged childhood in Palm Beach, and the fact that she joined an interior design firm founded by her mother. But that would mean missing out on the talent that put her at the forefront of a new group of society designers and that is evident throughout “Celerie Kemble: To Your Taste” ($45; Clarkson Potter). A tiny nine-point font was used to fit all her advice into the 256-page volume, which shows, step by step, how to design rooms that are elegant and personal. It isn’t often a decorating book includes a tribute to artisans and an apologia, but these sections, along with what must be Ms. Kemble’s genetic predisposition toward humor (her mother named her Celerie, after all), are what make the book so engaging. JULIE SCELFO.

LEVY--Laura Redfield, died peacefully on October 27th. She was born on February 23, 1919 in New York City and is survived by her husband of 69 years, Bernard; her three children, Dean (Janice), Marcia (Geoffrey), and Jonathan (Carol); her seven grandchildren; her four great-grandchildren; a nephew and niece; and her beloved pet, Lollipup, one of the many dogs that she rescued during her lifetime. Laura loved people, animals, and plants, sharing a gentleness, a kindness, and a genuine care for others with all who knew her. She made us laugh and she gave us love. She touched many lives. We will all miss her and we will always remember her. A private family service will be held in Palm Beach, Florida. Donations may be made in her memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

HUNT--Michael. It is with deep sadness that the officers and employees of Tanenbaum-Harber Co., Inc. acknowledge the passing of our friend and co-worker, Michael Hunt. During the course of his career, Michael worked as an Underwriter at Liberty Mutual and was a principal at an insurance brokerage agency in Westchester. He has been an integral part of Tanenbaum - Harber since 1980, and was a driving force behind the development of the Construction Department at our firm. He continued playing an essential role in our company until his passing. Michael is survived by his wife Eleanor, his daughter Elizabeth, and his two granddaughters. Michael will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

USADI--Jacob M., 90, cherished husband and best friend for 55 years of thelate Janna, loving father of Eva and Jonathan, devoted grandfather of Zachary, died peacefully on October 29, 2008 after a brief illness which he met with characteristic patience and humor. Jack had a long and brilliant legal career and a lifetime of passionate commitment to progressive political causes. He had a rare gift for defusing conflict, providing comfort to those in trouble and solving problems with creativity, wit and compassion. He was the person to whom countless family members, friends and clients turned for help and advice which was always forthcoming. All of us who knew him have lost part of ourselves, but the impact he had on our lives and of the world will last forever. Contributions may be made in his name to Doctors Without Borders or Vietnam Veterans Against the War.

WHEN you live in goth country, black is always the new black. Certainly it was the color of choice among disciples of the dark side who ventured to the East Village last week for the opening of VampireFreaks, a brick-and-mortar extension of a popular Web site. Arriving in a steady trickle, they pored over bondage corsets, velvet chokers and spiked cuffs. Some visited a New York Blood Center van parked just beyond the door. (A vampire store, a blood drive -- get it?) Mike Lalumera (bottom right) deemed the cause worthy, though not quite as compelling as goth itself. ''These people do what they want and wear what they want,'' he said. ''You have to appreciate that.''

BAGHDAD -- The Iraqi government demanded changes on Wednesday to the long-delayed security pact with the United States. The amendments would ban American troops from using Iraqi territory to carry out attacks on other countries, further limit when the troops would have immunity from Iraqi laws and allow inspections of American arms shipments. The amendments come just days after the United States sent American commandos over the border into Syria in what was by far the boldest attack there by Special Operations forces in the five years since the United States invaded Iraq. There have been increasing signs of discontent among powerful Iraqi political parties with the agreement, including by some that had negotiated the draft pact.

The left-leaning community organizing group that has become a favorite punching bag of Republicans and the McCain campaign for its involvement in cases of voter registration fraud tried to shift the conversation on Wednesday to what it says are Republican efforts to disenfranchise voters. The group, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, or Acorn, unveiled a 30-second television advertisement meant to spotlight voter suppression that it says Republicans have been pursuing in several states.

Senator Barack Obama broadcast a half-hour prime time infomercial on Wednesday on three of the major broadcast networks -- Fox, NBC and CBS -- as well as Univision, BET, TV One and MSNBC. It was the first program of its kind in 16 years. THE PROGRAM The program gave a new meaning to the word ''infomercial'' and, for that matter, to all notions of political advertising. Executed with high standards of cinematography, with help from the director of ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' Davis Guggenheim, the infomercial was part slickly produced reality program; part Lifetime biography; and part wonkish policy lecture with music that could have come from ''The West Wing.''

If you are chilling bulbs in the refrigerator and forcing them in soil, use any pot that appeals to you, as long as it is at least two inches deeper than the bulbs and has drainage holes. Regular potting soil will do fine. Tovah Martin, an intrepid bulb forcer, plants the bulbs close together, nose up, and covers them with a bit of soil. You don't need to fertilize, she added. ''These are little packages of energy.''

With less than a week to go before the election, Ralph Nader, who is running for president as an independent, is taking to the radio airwaves in places like Florida, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia, appealing to voters who are not happy with the two major parties. ''How much more political garbage will you take from the Republicans and Democrats?'' an announcer asks and then attacks both Senators Barack Obama and John McCain for supporting the $700 billion financial bailout. (In the 60-second version of the spot, the narrator refers to them as ''the bailout boys.'')

THE concerned homeowner will know by now that there is dispute about how best to rid the home of spirits. Some tools that the uninitiated might feel would be effective are not. The Ouija board, for example, is considered by many to be a magnet for spirits, the equivalent of spreading a trail of crumbs if you are plagued by ants. Megan Hoolihan, 28, manager of Marie Laveau's House of Voodoo, has studied the occult for 18 years and seems to take her calling seriously. She says many people in the South believe sage has cleansing properties.

Florida, Florida, Florida. If the state's 25 electoral votes were the bane of Democrats' existence in 2000, they have emerged as a target of opportunity for Senator Barack Obama in 2008. He ended his day at a rally in Kissimmee with President Bill Clinton -- their first joint event. Senator John McCain campaigned in Florida, too, and unleashed a new attack on Mr. Obama -- and The Los Angeles Times. Mr. McCain denounced the newspaper's decision not to release a video of Mr. Obama at an event with a former leader of the P.L.O. The Times said it had promised the source of the video that it would not be released.

LEAFS ARE MOST VALUABLE For the third year in a row -- and despite not having won the Stanley Cup in 41 years -- the Toronto Maple Leafs are No. 1 in Forbes magazine's 2008 list of the most valuable N.H.L. franchises. Forbes released its annual list on Wednesday and valued the Maple Leafs at $448 million. The Rangers, at $411 million, were No. 2, also for the third consecutive year.

If he gets his way, Samuel J. Wurzelbacher, also known as Joe the Plumber, will enjoy a lot more than just 15 minutes of fame. Two weeks after emerging as the Republican Party's favorite proxy for the American working man, Mr. Wurzelbacher has signed a management deal meant to keep him in the public eye past next week's election and earn him some money at the same time, preferably as a show business personality. ''Joe the Plumber is fast becoming a brand,'' said Jim Della Croce, president of Pathfinder Management in Nashville and one of three music industry professionals who will be representing Mr. Wurzelbacher. ''He is a dynamic speaker and an everyman who has become an overnight celebrity. It's going to be our job to find Joe's strengths and give him some options.''

BROCKWAY--Robert E. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Robert E. Brockway, Class of 1946, trustee emeritus of the Hofstra University Board of Trustees. Mr. Brockway's business career includes serving as vice president of marketing for Sylvania Electric, vice president and general manager of Manhattan Cable Television, president of the CBS Video Recording Division, president of Polygram Corporation, and chairman and CEO of Olympus Corporation. He served on Hofstra's Board of Trustees from 1984 to 1995, taking on the roles of vice chair and chair of the University Relations Committee. At the University's Frank G. Zarb School of Business, Mr. Brockway was a professor of marketing, a senior executive in residence and a special assistant to the dean. In September 2007 his son, Peter, established a distinguished professorship in his father's name to recognize his outstanding record of teaching and scholarship in Hofstra's Department of Marketing and International Business. The Brockway family has had a long history with the University. Robert Brockway convinced his future wife, Hope (Morehouse) Brockway, Class of 1945, to forfeit a deposit at William & Mary to attend Hofstra College with him. More than sixty years later, Mr. and Mrs. Brockway were honored with the Marjorie and James M. Shuart Alumni Family Award for their many years of service and friendship to the University. Mr. Brockway is also a recipient of the Hofstra Alumnus of the Year Award. He is survived by his wife, his sons Peter, Donald and Richard, and four granddaughters. In tribute to the memory of Mr. Brockway, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half staff. Marilyn Monter Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

Turco has a 4.26 goals against average and gave up six goals in a loss to Washington on Saturday night.

High oil prices this summer left Iraq with windfall revenue, but it is unlikely that the money will be spent anytime soon, even as many Iraqis go without electricity, clean water and other basic services. A report being released Thursday by the Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction shows that Iraq fell far short of spending the money allocated for reconstruction projects in 2008. The reasons? Regional political conflicts, continuing violence, a lack of technical abilities -- each province has its own handicaps.

With great sadness, we announce the passing of Joanne Joslin Troy on October 27, 2008. Adored wife of Bill for 60 years, loving mother of daughter Jill Werner, Nancy de Wit and Susan Troy and sons-in-law Wim de Wit and Larry Zipursky; cherished grandmother of Teddy and Karin, Carolyn and Matt, Daniel, Liza, Amanda, Elias and Rachel; and devoted greatgrandmother of lsabel and Andy. Born in Providence, Rhode lsland to Marion and Archie O. Joslin on July 14, 1925, Joanne received her B.A. from Vassar College in 1947. As a result of her distinguished service as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York, Joanne was honored with the title of Life Trustee in recognition of her exemplary commitment to the mission and work of the Home. She dedicated her time and support to many other philanthropic organizations including Temple Emanuel, UJA, and the AntiDefamation League. Known for her devotion to her husband, daughters and grandchildren Joanne was an avid student of opera, an accomplished golfer and an intrepid fly fisherwoman. She was and will be forever admired by her many friends and family for her tremendous energy and determination, her fine intellect personal modesty, loyalty and grace. ABC News pulled back on Wednesday after first publicizing an interview in which it said Gov. Sarah Palin hinted at a 2012 run for president. News media types have been looking for hints of Ms. Palin's intentions, should the Republican ticket not prevail on Nov. 4, and some reporters and bloggers quickly seized on the release that ABC News put out late Wednesday, with the headline ''Sarah Palin Vows to Remain Player in 2012: 'Not Doing This for Naught.' ''

Obama Commerical: ''His Choice.'' No spoken words, just images, upbeat music and a dig at Gov. Sarah Palin. Three quotations on-screen from Senator John McCain, saying that his strength is not economics and that he ''might have to reply on a vice president that I select'' for help. Then: A winking Ms. Palin. ''His choice?'' McCain Commercial: ''TV Special.'' His dig at Senator Barack Obama's 30-minute infomercial mocks his ''fancy speeches, grand promises and TV special'' and concludes that he ''lacks the experience America needs.'' But note the script's last word: ''The fact is Barack Obama's not ready yet.''
Senator Barack Obama At a rally in Raleigh, N.C.

Fernando Alonso set the fastest time of the day today in the second practice. And it was great timing for more than one reason. It not only shows that the Renault is really definitely improving - how many times have we seen that anyway this year - but it also meant there were a large number of journalists surrounding him at his little press meeting this afternoon and that meant a message he sent out will probably be heard by a lot more people than otherwise.

LIMA, Ohio - Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., ordinarily the most voluble of men, has had nothing to say to the reporters traveling with him for weeks. But tonight, at a nearly deserted Kewpee hamburger joint in Lima, Mr. Biden, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, spoke to reporters for a little more than 12 minutes. He discussed Iraq, his superstitions about the presidential race and his relationship with Senator John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee.

In extending their winning streak to five games, the Calgary Flames defeated two teams who were on quite a roll themselves this week. On Tuesday, the Flames beat the Colorado Avalanche 3-0 and on Thursday stopped the Boston Bruins 3-2. Entering their game, the Avalanche had won five consecutive games while the Bruins were coming off back-to-back 1-0 shutouts out west before facing the Flames.

You are watching a lot more video on the Internet, and you may start to pay your Internet provider more for it. That was one of the conclusions I walked away with after spending Friday at the annual seminar of the Columbia Institute for Tele-Information at the business school of Columbia University. The theme was "The Dawning of the Ultra-Broadband Era," and it explored the implications of Internet service that is far faster than the current offerings over phone wires, cable and wireless connections.

Sports Illustrated recently released "The College Football Book," the fifth in a series of books by the magazine focusing on a specific sport. It's filled with photographs and writing from more than 50 years of coverage by Sports Illustrated. It also features the magazine's all-time college football team, a list of players that is sure to provoke conversation about who should and should not be on the team. One of the wrinkles involved in the selection of the all-time team was Sports Illustrated's decision to limit each school to only one player each. David Sabino, an associate editor at Sports Illustrated, explained in a phone interview how the book was put together, how the team was selected and what players received the most support without making the team. But before David's answers, take a look at the all-time college football team, according to Sports Illustrated, and let us know what you think.

Victor Harbison teaches civics and history at Gage Park High School in Chicago, where he also sponsors the school newspaper. In 2000, he became the first National Board-certified high school history teacher in Chicago and he has worked on several educational reform projects during his career. Gage Park faces the all-too-common challenges of an urban school: test scores are so low that only 8% of students meet state standards; only 47% of its students graduate; and 97.4% of them live in poverty. Victor will help this blog keep education on its radar after the departure of long-time teacher and contributor Will Okun.

The city's municipal elections -- for mayor and City Council -- do not occur until next year. But within the array of elections for legislative and Congressional seats on Tuesday, there is one lone City Council race. That race is in Queens, for the Council seat currently held by Anthony Como, a Republican who represents a district centered in Middle Village.

I'm alone on a cold October morning at Kennedy Airport. The flight will be pleasantly solitary. I anticipate my enforced freedom from conversation and the Internet with excitement bordering on euphoria. There's a Major Tom factor to air travel now: silent go the devices as up we rise, while the taut invisible Web wires snap one by one until finally we're floating in a placid immaculate zone where no one can Twitter or gchat or e-mail. If the airlines knew how precious that icy aloofness was to some passengers, they'd find a way to make us pay for it. The JetBlue ColdSpot.

It is not an exaggeration to say that Pierluigi Collina, 48, might be one of the most recognizable people in soccer - still. From his large, piercing eyes, his ready smile and his bald head (the result of a severe form of alopecia, which caused the permanent loss of all facial hair), the former referee from Italy emerged as perhaps the rarest of species during his 13-year career - an official respected, even revered, in nearly every corner of the soccer world.

The long-term warming of the climate may be threatening the celebrated Dutch tradition of skating frozen canals and rivers between towns in Friesland, according to a new analysis of climate and skating trends there. Colder conditions permitted the Elfstedentocht, an 11-city skating marathon, to be held, on average, about once every four years a half-century ago. But researchers from the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency said this month that the conditions appear favorable only once every 18 years and that "continuing global warming will lead to further diminishing chances of holding an Elfstedentocht."

Jarett Dillard is a senior receiver at Rice. He holds almost every Rice career receiving record and leads all active N.C.A.A. receivers in receptions, receiving yardage and touchdown receptions. He also graduated with a degree in political science. Jarett will be checking in with The Quad from time to time to give readers an inside look at his season. Here he writes about how the Owls were able beat Tulane in New Orleans, how he is preparing for his last regular-season road game at UTEP and what the success of this year's team will mean for Rice teams of the future.

Aired Thursday night on NBC: I've noticed a number of athletes are now endorsing candidates in this presidential election. Barack Obama has been endorsed by Patrick Ewing and Charles Barkley, and John McCain's been endorsed by Ty Cobb and Jim Thorpe.

Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: John McCain introduced Joe the plumber during a campaign appearance in Ohio today, but Joe was not there. In Joe's defense, like every plumber, he said he could only be there sometime between 7 a.m. and 5 p.m.

Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: John McCain's campaign thought Joe the plumber was going to be at a McCain appearance in Defiance, Ohio. They thought Joe the plumber was going to be there. Joe told the news that they asked him to come and then nobody followed up, so he didn't go. That's surprising. It's not like a plumber to keep you waiting.

The "Classic Americana" look has been a major trend for the past several seasons, but a posse of natty brothers is trying to get the fashion focus back to the UK. James, Sam and Liam Fayed, who have long been involved with the inner workings of Turnbull & Asser, partnered with family friend Carlos Gonçalves to create Bespoken. The collection of slim-cut velvet blazers, colorful knits and cashmere cardigans, hoodies and sweaters are all sourced from British textile mills and made in the UK. The line has been available for a year at Harrods in London, and is now available at select Bloomingdales. Time to discover your inner dandy.

In North America there isn't much high-level women's hockey beyond the U.S. collegiate ranks, but across the ocean the I.I.H.F. is helping to support the women's game by staging the annual European Women's Championship Cup. The Champions League-style competition brings together the top clubs of 20 nations from Britain to Kazakhstan, and this year's edition continues on Friday with matches in Italy, Latvia and Russia. (Six games have already been played in the Czech Republic, resulting in the early-round mismatches that currently mark women's tournaments, like Slavia Prague's 36-0 win over Turkey's Polis Akademisi Ankara.)

Is there a state or city department that oversees the actions of co-op boards to make sure they are not doing anything unethical or illegal?

I have a co-op unit on the market that has water damage from a shower leak in the apartment above me. I asked the management company to write a letter advising the resident of the unit that she is responsible for the damage. The management company wrote the letter to the shareholder of record: the deceased husband of the current resident. What should be done if a co-op stock certificate is not in the actual resident's name?

I live in a rent-stabilized apartment complex with 14 buildings in Westchester County. The landlord is replacing all the doors and locks to maintain only 14 master keys instead of different keys for each apartment. (While the master key will open all locks in a building, an individual key will still open only the owner's apartment.) The owner is asking tenants to sign a statement that they will not put any other locks on their doors. Numerous tenants have complained about illegal entry into their apartments by maintenance workers after the doors were replaced. I do not want to sign this document. Do I have to?

Nearly 180 organizations representing the interdependent arenas of science, academia and business are urging the next president to appoint a White House science adviser by Inauguration Day and give the position cabinet-level rank. In letters sent Thursday to Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama, the organizations said scientific and technical advice was needed now more than ever given the importance of the entwined issues of energy security and climate change, mounting issues and opportunities in medicine, and problems in science education and American innovation and competitiveness. The letters reflect broadening concern that the White House has not been sufficiently stressing science.

"Cukor is surely smiling somewhere, recognizing that the world's cast of women is still a complicated, fractious bunch." [More Intelligent Life]
On Sept. 25, as the world financial crisis escalated, two of New York's most powerful lawyers met for lunch in a restaurant near Wall Street with a name that recalled happier times: Bull Run.

The Reserve Primary Fund, the giant money market fund whose customers have been waiting more than six weeks for their cash, announced late Thursday night that it would begin mailing checks to shareholders on Friday - for half their original investment, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.
A deal to merge General Motors and Chrysler has hit an impasse after the Bush administration ruled out financing for it, Reuters reported, citing three people with direct knowledge of the talks.
Google and Yahoo could announce a decision to walk away from their search deal by the middle of next week, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter.

Troubled financial giants getting cash infusions from the U.S. Federal Reserve owe their executives more than $40 billion for past year's pay and pensions as of the end of 2007, according to The Wall Street Journal's calculations.

GMAC, the money-losing auto finance and mortgage provider majority-owned by private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, on Thursday confirmed it was seeking to become a bank holding company, and said it planned to overhaul and slash its debt load, barely four months after completing a $60 billion refinancing package.

With United States vehicle sales down nearly 13 percent this year, most car companies have been cutting production rather than increasing it.

Shares in Asia and Europe fell on Friday, heading for their worst month ever, while the low-yielding yen surged as Japan's interest rate cut failed to erase concerns about the deteriorating global economic outlook.

The American International Group's announcement Thursday that it could now borrow up to $20.9 billion under the Federal Reserve's new commercial paper program, raising its maximum available credit from the Fed to $144 billion under three different programs, underscores the company's bewilderingly rapid decline, The New York Times's Mary Williams Walsh writes.

Fall in Detroit has always felt a bit like spring elsewhere. It is traditionally the season of fresh starts for the hometown industry, a time when the auto companies get a jump on the calendar and begin shipping next year's models to dealers.

Japan announced a stimulus package on Thursday that includes $51 billion to help households and businesses, the boldest of several measures that officials took to try to stanch the global credit crisis, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener said.
Fidelity Investments' flagship Magellan fund sharply raised its holdings of Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase in September, as it moved into bigger U.S. banks amid the worsening credit crisis.

Barclays plans to raise 7.3 billion pounds, or $11.8 billion, by selling shares to Abu Dhabi and Qatar to meet Britain's new capital requirements for banks without the government's help, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier reports.

Germany | Revile Hitler? Check. But schoolkids in the old East Germany don't know that Erich Honecker was a dictator or that his Stasi secret service was a nasty bunch. You can blame their teachers. An article says, "Germany may be reunited, but its views of history are anything but." [Economist]

At the start of the global financial crisis, Russian authorities insisted they had ample cash reserves to weather any storm. But as sorrow has succeeded sorrow - plummeting oil prices, a 70 percent descent in stock markets here, a global credit crisis and a slow-motion bank run on this country's private banks - Russia has had to spend its reserves faster than anybody imagined, The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer writes.

Literature | Mary Shelley created a monster out of her "waking dream," but how much of the original "Frankenstein" was actually written by her husband, Percy? A new edition of the earliest recoverable manuscript of this much-altered novel shows his writing and editing were substantial. [TLS]

Fernando Tatis, the National League comeback player of the year, signed a one-year deal with the Mets on Thursday. Before sustaining a season-ending shoulder separation on Sept. 16, Tatis, who entered the season having played in only 28 major league games since 2004, hit .297 with 11 home runs and 47 runs batted in. He batted .392 (29 for 74) with runners in scoring position, the fourth-best mark among players with at least 70 at-bats, according to Stats LLC. Tatis, 33, who may split time in left field next season with Daniel Murphy, is playing for Estrellas in the Dominican winter league. “I feel fine now,” Tatis said in a statement. “I didn’t need surgery and I will be ready to go in the spring.”.

Concerned about possible demonstrations during the Beijing Games, the Chinese government produced a list of nine American athletes and one assistant coach it thought might cause problems. The State Department knew about China’s concerns and made “multiple representations” to the country’s government to reinforce the American belief in freedom of expression. USA Today reported Thursday that it had obtained an internal United States Olympic Committee e-mail message in which a Chinese official expressed concern that American team members might demonstrate.

Arlen Kantarian, who brought blue courts and the women’s prime-time final to the United States Open, resigned Thursday as chief executive for professional tennis at the United States Tennis Association. In his nine-year tenure, Open revenue grew by $70 million and attendance increased by 150,000, to 720,000.

ESPN said Barack Obama and John McCain planned to participate in one-on-one interviews via satellite that would air at halftime of “Monday Night Football,” the day before the election. ESPN’s Chris Berman will do the interviews earlier Monday, if the candidates’ schedules permit.

David Beckham will join A.C. Milan in January on a three-month loan from the Los Angeles Galaxy. Beckham, 33, is one appearance shy of matching the record 108 for a field player, held by Bobby Moore. Goalkeeper Peter Shilton holds the overall England record of 125.

Kent Jones recovered from a tee shot in the rough to birdie No. 18 for a seven-under-par 65, giving him a share of the lead with the rookie Michael Letzig in the first round of the Ginn sur Mer Classic at Palm Coast, Fla. They led by two shots over Ryan Palmer. (AP).

Ken Macha was hired as the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, taking over from Dale Sveum after the team’s first postseason appearance since 1982. Macha, 58, took the Oakland A’s to two American League West titles and lost his job after the 2005 season for a week, only to return in 2006. He spent the last two years as a television analyst. Sveum became interim manager when Ned Yost was fired with 12 games left in the regular season. Sveum is expected to return to the coaching staff.

Playing with a soft cast protecting his broken left forearm, the junior Tony Pike had one of his finest games, throwing two touchdown passes and steadying Cincinnati’s offense in a 24-10 victory over No. 24 South Florida in Cincinnati.

Midnight Madness is going back to its regularly scheduled date next season. The N.C.A.A.’s board passed legislation that prevents coaches from holding opening night festivities earlier than the normal start date.

Politics | Want to track voting problems on Election Day or report on your local precinct? Try MyFairElection.com, which plans a crowd-sourced map of electoral conditions across the country Tuesday. It was conceived by Harvard's Kennedy School with ABC News. [My Fair Election]
“Zack and Miri Make a Porno,” in spite of its lewdness, follows a gee-whiz romantic-comedy formula that would not be out of place on the Disney Channel.

As we do from time to time here on The Quad, we've invited a guest blogger to write about the experiences of a college athlete. Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 junior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. He averaged 6.3 points per game for Bucknell last season and will be blogging for The Quad this season. Under the first-year coach Dave Paulsen, Bucknell will try to unseat American, which won the Patriot League's automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament last season. Behan will be stopping by The Quad all season for insights on Bucknell, the Patriot League and college life.

The news of the death of Caroline Astor, 78, leads the paper today. She died yesterday at 7:30 in the evening, in the presence of her daughter Mrs. Marshall Orme Wilson and doctors and nurses. "Her son, Col. John Jacob Astor, and his wife, had been in the sick chamber almost unceasingly yesterday, and were with the sick woman during the early part of the evening. It chanced, however, that neither was present when the last sinking spell occurred." After the news report, an appreciation of her life begins: "There are many who believe that with Mrs. Astor has passed away the last leader of New York society. No one, they say, will ever be able to occupy the place she filled, for the conditions of New York's upper set, which justified the term leader, with all it implied, and rendered the position almost as well established as though it had been provided by the Constitution, have changed materially since this gifted woman ascended to it." Mrs. Astor Dies at Her City Home

In what New York City Marathon officials are calling the most significant logistical change to the race since 2001, wave starts will be used to ease congestion. Instead of starting the race for everyone at the same time, the field of about 39,000 will be separated into three waves, released at 20-minute intervals.

A former Atlanta police officer pleaded guilty to federal conspiracy charges for his role in a botched drug raid that ended in the shooting death of a 92-year-old woman. The former officer, Arthur Tesler, faces more than 10 years in prison on a charge of conspiracy to violate civil rights resulting in death. The police originally said officers had gone to the home of the woman, Kathryn Johnston, in northwest Atlanta, in 2006 after an informant said he had bought drugs there. But after finding none, officers tried to cover up the mistake by planting bags of marijuana, prosecutors said. In May, Mr. Tesler, 42, was sentenced to four and a half years in prison for lying to investigators, but federal prosecutors decided to pursue more charges after reviewing the case.

A federal judge refused to stop a traffic checkpoint program in Washington, requiring drivers to provide the police identification and a destination before entering a crime-ridden neighborhood. The District of Columbia police began stopping cars in June in the Trinidad neighborhood. The program was set up at random hours over six days after a spike in violence in the neighborhood. The Partnership for Civil Justice sued, calling the program unconstitutional. The group asked the judge, Richard Leon of Federal District Court, to stop the checkpoints until a trial could be held on whether the program was lawful, but Judge Leon refused, saying it was unlikely that a lawsuit to stop the program permanently would succeed.

The state said it planned to cut water deliveries to their second-lowest level ever next year, raising the prospect of rationing for cities and less planting by farmers. The Department of Water Resources projects that it will deliver just 15 percent of the amount that local water agencies throughout California request every year. Since the first State Water Project deliveries were made in 1962, the only time less water was promised was in 1993, but heavy precipitation that year ultimately allowed agencies to receive their full requests. The state’s reservoirs are low after two years of dry weather and court-ordered restrictions on water pumping out of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.

A state law intended to keep children away from sex offenders on Halloween night can be enforced in its entirety, a federal appeals court ruled. The order means that the state’s registered sex offenders must remain inside their homes from 5 to 10:30 p.m. Friday night unless they have “just cause” to leave, like a medical emergency. They must keep their outside lights off and post a sign saying they are not distributing candy. They may not have any Halloween-related contact with children. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit stayed a lower court’s ruling blocking parts of the law until it could consider the state’s appeal and rule on the merits — sometime before next Halloween. The stay had been sought by Gov. Matt Blunt, a Republican, and Attorney General Jay Nixon, above, a Democrat, after the lower-court ruling in the case brought by four sex offenders sued over the law. “This stay comes not a moment too soon, as hundreds of thousands of Missouri children prepare to go trick-or-treating,” Mr. Nixon said.

Look for Al Gore to return to the campaign trail Friday on behalf of Senator Barack Obama, back to the place where his own presidential dreams died. Mr. Gore will travel to Florida's Palm Beach and Broward Counties, which were at the center of the recount battle he lost to George W. Bush in 2000. Senator John McCain wraps up his two-day bus trip around Ohio, where he is fighting for his political life. Ohio has voted for the winner of the White House all but once since World War II, and no Republican has won the presidency without it. Keep a lookout for Mr. McCain's running mate, Joe the Plumber.

ROBBINS HAS SORE HAND Giants defensive tackle Fred Robbins is expected to play despite a hand injury when the Giants host the Cowboys despite Sunday. When asked whether the injury is to bone or muscle, Coach Tom Coughlin said: ''Just sore. Very sore.'' But Antonio Pierce, a middle linebacker, said, ''I have a D-tackle playing with two broken hands.'' Robbins said neither hand was broken. Robbins has five and a half sacks, second on the team behind defensive end Justin Tuck, who has six.

YOUNG--Beverly Anderson, 57, of San Francisco passed away on October 25th, with her loving family by her side. Born and raised among horses and good people in Sioux Falls, SD, Bev chased her dream by moving to California in 1978. There she met her soulmate, a legendary musician in his own mind named Paul Young, and married him in 1983. They just celebrated 25 whirlwind years together. Bev loved her job and rose to high success at both Bank of America and First Republic as the Director of External Reporting. She was also a devoted mom and beloved role model to her kids, Paul, Ingrid, and Maggie. Bev was a bright, graceful and selfless woman who lived a full life of love and adventure. Memorials can be given to the American Cancer Society and Habitat for Humanity

ROUSSAN--Matei S., M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is saddened by the death of its former chairman of rehabilitation medicine. Dr. Roussan was one of the founders of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at Einstein and Montefiore Medical Center in the 1960s. An expert in neurogenic bladder disorder, he was a mentor to generations of residents and attending physicians. A superb physician and brilliant teacher, Dr. Roussan had an infectious passion for life and personal warmth that brought joy to his colleagues, friends and loved ones. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Roussan family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

STERNLIEB--Irmin, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the death of Dr. Irmin Sternlieb, a longstanding member of the Einstein community, who died on October 27, 2008. A distinguished gastroenterologist, hepatologist and expert on Wilson's disease, he came to Einstein following two years at Jacobi Medical Center as a founding resident. He collaborated with Dr. I. Herbert Scheinberg on the cause and treatment of Wilson's disease, previously a disabling and ultimately fatal hereditary degenerative disease affecting the liver and brain. His accomplishments led to his promotion to professor in 1972, as well as numerous invitations to lecture at international medical meetings. In 1974, with Dr. Irwin Arias, he developed a center for the study of liver diseases at Einstein that was the first to be supported by the National Institutes of Health. The center continues to be a magnet for scientists and trainees. Dr. Sternlieb retired from the Einstein faculty in 1993. He later moved to California, where he lived until his death. His many friends, colleagues and former patients will deeply miss him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Anne. Ruth L. Gottesman, Ed.D. Chair, Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Victor L. Schuster, M.D. Chair, Dept of Medicine David A. Shafritz, M.D. Director, Marion Bessin Liver Research Center Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

POWER THARP--Lorraine. With great sadness, the New York State Bar Association mourns the passing of Lorraine Power Tharp, the Association's 105th President. Serving from 2002-03, Tharp was the Association's third female president. Compassionate, warm, and wise, Tharp exemplified the best of the legal profession and unfailing service to society. From working to increase diversity in the profession and State Bar leadership, to fostering gender equity, from serving as a role model for the profession, to raising awareness of the ethical treatment of animals, she worked tirelessly to give a voice to those who did not have one. Her memory lives on through her pioneering work on behalf of women, the indigent and animals. Through these and other efforts, Tharp will be missed but never forgotten.

THE NEW MILLENNIUM PAPER AIRPLANE CONTEST When planes take off from Queens, it isn't exactly newsworthy. But the dozens of aircraft that will fly in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park on Saturday won't be the typical Boeings and Airbuses. They won't have engines, passengers or pilots, and they may travel only a matter of feet. Still, they are designed to soar right into history.

CHESTER--Hawley T., Jr., 90, of Greenwich, CT, died Sunday September 28 at Greenwich Woods. Born in Hoboken, NJ on July 24, 1918 he was the son of the late Hawley T. Chester Sr. and Lillian Lowenhertz Chester and the husband of the late Helen Cronkite Chester. Mr. Chester attended St. Bernard's School in NYC, graduated St. Georges School in Newport, RI in 1937. He joined the US Navy in 1941 and was commissioned an officer serving on the USS Miller in the Pacific Theater during WWII. After the war he joined Chubb & Sons Insurance Company. He later joined Marsh and McLennan and later Johnson & Higgins Insurance Group where he was made a partner in 1963 until his retirement in 1980. Mr. Chester is survived by three children, Tracy Chester, Hawley T. Chester III, Peter Chester, six grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday November 6, 2008 at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Way, One Lafayette Court, Greenwich, CT 06830.

If it's Thursday, it must be Missouri. Three of the four major-party candidates -- Senator Barack Obama; his running mate, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.; and Gov. Sarah Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee -- raced to the state, where polls show the contest to be dead even. Senator John McCain opened a two-day bus tour of Ohio, but could not find his favorite resident, Samuel J. Wurzelbacher, a.k.a. Joe the Plumber. ''Where is Joe? Is Joe here with us today?'' Mr. McCain asked at a rally. No. The campaign sent a car to pick up him up for later stops.

Here is one reason the Obama campaign has been making such an effort to sign up supporters to receive text messages: In this concluding phase of the presidential contest, the campaign has been using those messages to recruit and deploy volunteers. AUSTRIAN--Sonia Grace, 75, died on October 28th after a heroic battle with cancer. She was loved by her daughters, Sarah and Susan, her son-in-law Bayard Clarkson, Jr., and her grandchildren Emily and Matthew Clarkson. Sonia was born in New York City, graduated from Wellesley College and received her masters and doctorate in social work from Columbia University. She began her career in social work at Payne Whitney Clinic and ultimately became an Associate Professor of Public Health in Psychiatry at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University and the director of the Employee Assistance Program Consortium of Weill Cornell University Medical College, New York Presbyterian HospitalCornell Campus, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Rockefeller University and the Hospital for Special Surgery. An inspirational teacher, she had been an Assistant Professor and later was an Adjunct Professor at the Columbia University School of Social Work. At the EAPC, she developed an innovative placement program where she supervised and mentored Columbia social work interns. She had a private practice and was a prolific writer, having authored books that are widely used in social work education. She was a Fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine. Sonia will be deeply missed by her family and many friends. A memorial service will be held on December 6th at 2pm at All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to Partners in Health, 800 Boylston Street, Boston, MA 02199.

The maker of an over-the-counter weight-loss pill has suspended shipments after accusations the product contains, but does not list, an ingredient banned by the N.F.L. ''We've received notice of the problem with the N.F.L.,'' the makers of StarCaps said Thursday in a statement released via e-mail. The statement added that the company was ''taking all necessary steps to ensure that our customers receive product that is safe and effective.''

CATALLO--George C., Jr. a former member of the Emigrant Bank Board of Directors, passed away on Friday, October 24th. Mr. Catallo served with distinction on the Board of Emigrant from the time of its merger with Prudential Savings Bank in March 1979, and on the Board of Emigrant Bancorp, Inc. from its formation in November 1994. He retired from the Boards of Emigrant Bank and Emigrant Bancorp, Inc. as of December 31, 2002. Before joining Emigrant's Board, he was a Trustee of Prudential Savings Bank. Mr. Catallo served as Chairman of the Bank's Audit and Examining Committee from March 1987, and as Chairman of the Audit and Examining Committee of Emigrant Bancorp, Inc. from November 1994. He also served on the Asset and Liability Management Committee, the Investment Policy Committee, and the Real Estate and Loan Committees of the Bank. Throughout his service to Emigrant, Mr. Catallo contributed greatly to the progress of the Bank and Emigrant Bancorp. His sage counsel and professional guidance as Chairman of the Audit and Examining Committees and service on other Bank Board committees were highly valued. We join in extending our heartfelt regrets to George's wife Sandy and the entire Catallo family. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman Emigrant Bank New York Private Bank &Trust
GREGORY AMENOFF Alexandre Gallery

REIS--Muriel Henle, beloved wife of Arthur Reis, Jr., for 55 years, devoted mother of Arthur Henle Reis, Diane Mary Reis and Pamela Robin Reis, and a trail blazer for women in the legal profession, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 29th, at her home in Manhattan. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. A legal expert on the First Amendment, libel law and the Federal Communications Commission, she worked on legal issues confronting the broadcast industry for more than 50 years. Upon her graduation from Columbia Law School in 1949, she joined the American Broadcasting Company's legal staff, and in 1958 she went to work for Metromedia, Inc., first serving as assistant general counsel and assistant secretary. In 1974, she became vice president of Metromedia's WNEW - TV and was named associate general counsel of Metromedia in 1985. In 1992, she became vice president for legal affairs and East Coast litigation, at Fox Television (which had acquired Metromedia) and held that position until her retirement in 2005. During her tenure at Fox, she provided legal counsel to the upstart television program, ''A Current Affair'' and helped create the Fox News Network. In addition to being a leading First Amendment lawyer, she also worked as an on-air legal commentator, providing legal analysis during the murder trial of OJ Simpson. She hosted a public affairs program, ''Sunday Night with Muriel Reis,'' was a guest host of the program ''Midday Live,'' and made numerous appearances on ''Good Day New York'' as a legal expert. She was honored in 1994 by the New York Chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences by being inducted into the Silver Circle, an elite group of media professionals who made significant contributions to their industry and their community over a career span of at least 25 years. A lifelong and devoted New Yorker and a graduate of the Brearley School and Vassar College, she felt compelled to contribute to her community and the city she loved. She served on the New York Lawyers' Association Task Force on Judicial Independence and co-chaired the Media Subcommittee. She was a member of the Bar Association of the City of New York and served on its Communication Law Committee. In addition to her pioneering work as a lawyer, she was a passionate advocate for disadvantaged children. Her desire to help those in need led to her to contribute her time and talents to the Children's Aid Society. She was also a valued member of the board of directors of CASA, an organization of court appointed special advocates working on behalf of children in foster care, as well as a tenacious CASA volunteer, who used her legal skills to help improve the lives of others. She had a brilliant mind, a loving heart and a spirit of generosity that extended to all who knew her. She was loved by her four grandchildren, Chloe Reis Hyman, Mara Claire McCartin, Elisa Reis McCartin, and Lucas Henle Reis Hyman, her daughter-in-law Marianne McGeary Reis and her sons-in-law, Joseph A. McCartin and Kevin Hyman. She will be deeply missed by her family, friends and professional colleagues. Contributions in her memory may be made to CASA, Court Appointed Special Advocates for Children, 50 Broadway, 31 Floor, New York, NY 10004.

''At a time when the U.S. government has just nationalized a good part of the banking sector, we need to rethink a lot of the Reaganite verities of the past generation regarding taxes and regulation. Important as they were back in the 1980s and '90s, they just won't cut it for the period we are now entering. Obama is much better positioned to reinvent the American model and will certainly present a very different and more positive face of America to the rest of the world.'' Francis Fukuyama, author of ''The End of History,'' endorsing Senator Barack Obama in ''The American Conservative''

4:45 A.M. (TCM) 48 HOURS OF HORROR! Turner Classic Movies continues its two-day fright fest with ''Spirits of the Dead'' (1968), a triptych of supernatural tales based on works by Poe, directed by Federico Fellini, Louis Malle and Roger Vadim; Brigitte Bardot, Jane Fonda and Terence Stamp star. Other highlights include ''Cat People'' (1942), with Simone Simon, above, as a newlywed who fears that an ancient curse -- and a night of passion -- will turn her into a bloodthirsty beast, at 7:30; ''Freaks'' (1932), about a trapeze artist (Olga Baclanova) who plots to murder her dwarf husband (Harry Earles), at 9; a Bela Lugosi double bill of ''The Devil Bat'' (1940) at 1 p.m. and ''White Zombie'' (1932) at 2:15; three starring Boris Karloff: ''The Body Snatcher'' (1945) at 3:30, ''Bedlam'' (1946) at 5 and ''The Ghoul'' (1933) at 6:30; and a series of films based on the macabre writings of H. P. Lovecraft, starting with ''The Haunted Palace'' (1963), the Roger Corman-Vincent Price collaboration, at 8. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Mr. Philbin and Ms. Ripa unveil their Halloween attire in time for the annual costume contest. On ''Rachael Ray,'' at 10 on ABC, a mystery guest trick-or-treats and Jarod Miller brings creepy critters. Wanda Sykes is the guest on the Halloween episode of ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show,'' at 10 a.m. on Channel 55 and 3 p.m. on NBC. And Blake Lively whips up pumpkin confections on ''The Martha Stewart Show,'' at 11 on NBC.

DORFSMAN--Louis. The Trustees and Staff of the International Center of Photography mourn the passing of Lou Dorfsman, whose design genius helped shape this institution's award-winning annual reports from its earliest years. It was our great fortune to have benefitted from his inspired guidance. He remains a legend in the annals of ICP.
INTERNATIONAL SOUTH AFRICAN PARTY GIVES BIRTH

CUNNIFFE--Jane M., passed away at her home in Greenwich in the presence of her family. She was born May 4, 1934 in Nutley, NJ and graduated from Marymount Academy and then St, Elizabeth's College, NJ. She is survived by Maurice her husband of 51 years, Mark C. and David S. her sons and their wives Susan and Annette, and by her five grandchildren Mark, Daniel, Paul, Casey and Meaghan Cunniffe. Because of her dedication and love of art she was invited to join the Bryant Fellows of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Art Forum of the Smithsonian American Art Museum. She holds memberships in Greenwich at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and the Stanwich Club, in NYC at the New York Yacht Club and the University Club, and in Newport Beach, CA at the Balboa Yacht Club. Mass will be held Monday at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich at 10:00am. Friends are welcome at Gallagher's Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich Sunday from 4-8pm.

In my Sunday column, I argue that the paramount need for the new president is to end America's self-exile and rejoin the world. I start by looking at the unscientific survey of professional historians by History News Network that found that 61 percent rated George W. Bush the very worst president in our history. That fascinated me because I had always thought that James Buchanan, on the eve of the Civil War, was about as awful a leader as could emerge in a democracy; surely in a more educated age with better communications, an equally bad leader could never emerge. Well according to the historians, one did.

The Today Show will not air in the New York area tomorrow (it will be on in the rest of the country) because NBC will be covering the New York City Marathon. Since the women in the segment I gave you the heads up about yesterday (the one on Opting Back In) are all from New York, and I write from New York, and the jobs they will be looking for are in New York, it made sense that the segment actually be seen in New York. So it will be postponed until Sunday, November 9, when more viewers could actually watch.

Aired Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: John McCain is struggling to get crowds at some places. For a speech yesterday, he bused in 4,000 schoolkids to fill the stands, but the plan backfired when the kids wanted to know why Santa was so angry.

Politics | An article reflects on H.L. Mencken's "Notes on Democracy," which cast voters as a dopey, fear-driven "booboisie." You have to admit, that does ring something of a bell today, no? But another article finds some undecideds not dummies but deliberative skeptics. [Smart Set, L.A. Times]

Chile | An article reports on international investigations into a "utopia" in a remote part of Chile founded by an "evil" German evangelist, who turned it into "a torture and execution center for the disposal of enemies" of the Pinochet regime. Its name: Colonia Dignidad. [American Scholar]

World | A Danish former United Nations coordinator who testified to Congress on the Iraq oil-for-food scandal now reflects back: "I joined the U.N. as a youthful idealist," he says, but "for all its good intentions, the U.N. is broken and unfixable." It's time to try something new. [Prospect]

David Pollack, a former star defensive end for Georgia, is no stranger to the World's Largest Outdoor Cocktail Party. The Mets exercised their $12 million option on Carlos Delgado on Friday. Given that the Mets were already committed to giving him a $4 million buyout had they not picked up his option, paying Delgado an extra $8 million could be a bargain if he can come close to duplicating his second-half surge.

Alex Ovechkin will miss the Washington Capitals’ game at Buffalo on Saturday to visit his ailing grandfather in Russia. Ovechkin, who also sat out Tuesday, is expected back next week.

North Carolina was selected as the No. 1 team in The Associated Press’s preseason Top 25, the first unanimous No. 1 since the preseason poll began in 1981-82. North Carolina has the top six scorers — including the national player of the year Tyler Hansbrough — back from a team that had a team-record 36 wins and reached the Final Four. The Tar Heels are the preseason No. 1 for the second straight year, joining Nevada-Las Vegas in 1989-90 and 1990-91 as the only teams to do so. It also marks North Carolina’s record sixth time atop the preseason rankings, breaking a tie with Duke. Connecticut, which returns four starters, was No. 2, followed by Louisville, U.C.L.A. and Pittsburgh.

Alexei Cherepanov, the 19-year-old Rangers draft pick who died after collapsing in a game, was playing illegally for his Russian club, a top military officer said. Cherepanov’s death Oct. 13 prompted outrage among lawmakers and Russian sports officials, with many calling for an investigation into the cause of the heart problems that led to his death at a Continental Hockey League game. Col. Vladimir Karpenko, a spokesman for the commander of Russia’s Railway Troops, said on the state-run First Channel that Cherepanov should have been serving his mandatory military service. ¶Patrick Kane had a goal and an assist as the host Chicago Blackhawks beat the Dallas Stars, 5-2. blackhawks (AP).

Top-ranked Rafael Nadal retired with a knee injury after losing the first set, 6-1, against Nikolay Davydenko in the quarterfinals of the Paris Masters on Friday, just hours after Roger Federer pulled out because of a sore back. The second-ranked Federer pulled out shortly before his quarterfinal against James Blake because of a stiff back, but he said it was not serious. The 11th-seeded Blake will face No. 13 Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, who beat No. 7 Andy Roddick, 5-7, 6-4, 7-6 (5). The defending champion, David Nalbandian, advanced to the semifinals by defeating fourth-seeded Andy Murray, 7-6 (3), 6-3, and will next meet Davydenko.

An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing on Friday about Day of the Dead events misstated the day the National Museum of the American Indian, in Lower Manhattan, will offer a program of Aztec-style dance performances, storytelling and arts workshops from 1 to 5 p.m. It is today, not Sunday.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the opera “Arjuna’s Dilemma,” at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the date of a performance next week. It is Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., not Thursday. (The opera is also being performed Friday and next Saturday.).

The Favorites chart on Thursday with an article about the stock market’s performance on Wednesday was published in error. The chart, which lists stocks held by the largest number of accounts at Charles Schwab, gave results from Tuesday, not Wednesday.

An article on Thursday about the American International Group’s use of more than $120 billion in emergency lending from the Federal Reserve referred incorrectly to the 2007 restructuring of the bond insurance company ACA Capital Holdings, which some experts offer as a model for resolving A.I.G.’s difficulties. That transaction was done out of court; the company did not file for bankruptcy.
The cover article this weekend about Lauren Zalaznick, a television executive, misstates part of the address for her Manhattan office. It is 30 Rockefeller Plaza, not Center.
Schedule information on Friday with a theater review of “Hunchback,” at the New Victory Theater, misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (212) 223-3010.

An article last Saturday about Gov. Sarah Palin’s policy proposals for special education misstated the proportion of a local school district’s budget that is commonly consumed by special education costs. According to a nationwide survey of school districts by the Center for Special Education Finance, special education accounts for 14 percent of local expenditures, not half of a school district’s budget.

BARON--Frederick Martin, devoted husband, loving father, trailblazing lawyer, and champion of the working man, died peacefully at his Dallas home on October 30, 2008 after a long battle with cancer. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 3, 2008 at 4:00pm at Sparkman-Hillcrest Funeral Home to celebrate Fred's memory. Fred was born in Cedar Rapids, Iowa in 1947. He moved with his mother to the central Texas town of Smithville at the age of 15, where he excelled in his studies and was a high school football star. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Texas and then attended the University of Texas School of Law, where he was an editor of the law review. While in law school, he spent a summer in Washington, DC working for consumer advocate Ralph Nader, and developed a commitment to improving the plight of working men and women in this country. Upon his graduation from law school in 1971 he took a job with the law firm of Mullinax, Wells, and Mauzy, one of the few firms in Texas that represented labor unions and union workers. Among his early clients were Karen Silkwood, who alerted the public to unsafe practices at a nuclear power plant in Oklahoma, and Herbert Yandle, who developed cancer after working with asbestos at a manufacturing plant outside Tyler, Texas. Fred quickly developed a nationwide reputation for his expertise and skill in representing workers who had developed occupational illnesses. He formed his own law firm, now known as Baron & Budd, in 1977, which specialized in representing victims of occupational disease and industrial pollution. Fred was a pioneer in uncovering the harm caused to the public by the use of asbestos-containing products, and successfully represented thousands of individuals who had become sick or who had lost loved ones as a result of asbestos exposure. Other landmark cases include his representation of 1,600 residents of Tucson, Arizona who became sick because of their exposure to groundwater contaminated by the chemical TCE; his advocacy on behalf of several hundred West Dallas children who lived under the shadow of a lead smelter that polluted their neighborhood; and residents of the towns of Apollo and Parks Township, Pennsylvania who were exposed to radioactive emissions in an area near a nuclear plant. Fred also has been credited for his efforts in challenging abusive class action settlements in which corporations attempted to settle their liability for a fraction of what individuals would otherwise be entitled to recover in the courts. Fred twice led successful battles in the United States Supreme Court to defeat such settlements, and as a result, future victims of toxic injuries can no longer have their rights compromised by class action settlements in which they have no voice. In addition to his representation of individual clients, Fred was a tireless public advocate for workers and consumers. Together with Ralph Nader and several other prominent lawyers, he founded Trial Lawyers for Public Justice in 1982, and served as that organizations president from 1997 through 1998. Fred was a devoted supporter of the consumer group Public Citizen and a founding board member of the American Constitution Society. In 2000, Fred was elected president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America (now known as the American Association for Justice), an organization with 60,000 members dedicated to safeguarding victims rights, strengthening the civil justice system, and improving public health and safety. The awards and honors Fred received during his legal career are too numerous to list in full. In 2006, the National Law Journal named Fred one of the 100 Most Influential Lawyers in the U.S. On November 3, 2005, he received the Outstanding Service Award given by the William Wayne Justice Center for Public Interest Law at the University of Texas School of Law. In June 2000, the legal publication ''Texas Lawyer'' named him as a lawyer who helped shape Texas law in its series ''Legal Legends: A Century of Texas Law and Lawyering.'' Fred was mentor and inspiration to scores of young lawyers who became effective advocates for the less fortunate in their own right. He was a loyal supporter of the University of Texas School of Law. In 2001, the law school honored Fred by endowing the Frederick M. Baron Chair in Law, which is held by a senior professor of the law school engaged in original research on lawyering and the civil justice system. Fred turned his full attention to his life-long love of politics in 2003. He served as advisor to John Edwards that year, and in 2004 he headed the general election finance team of the John Kerry-John Edwards presidential ticket. He served as national finance chair of Senator Edwards' campaign for the Democratic nomination for President in 2008. He was involved in local politics as well, founding the Texas Democratic Trust in 2005. The success of the Trust has led many to credit Fred with single-handedly reviving the Democratic Party in Dallas County. Fred was widely known and admired for his charitable work. With his wife Lisa, he founded the Baron and Blue Foundation in 2002 to help non-profit organizations fight the problems of homelessness and displacement and to promote the needs of the underserved. The foundation distributed more than $300,000 in grants in the year 2008 alone. Fred dedicated his time and energy as well as his money to help the less fortunate. In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, he spent many days at Reunion Arena consoling and counseling the victims, bringing them food and toiletries, and helping them out however he could. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Texas Democratic Trust, at texasdemocratictrust.com or the Lance Armstrong Foundation at www.livestrong.org. Survivors include his wife, Lisa Blue-Baron; son Andrew Baron of New York, daughter Courtney Baron, her husband, Brad Singer, Courtney's daughter Liza also of New York; daughters, Alessandra, Caroline, and Nathalie; brother Robert of Oklahoma City and sister Joan of Dallas; and countless colleagues, former employees, clients, courtroom adversaries, and others who admired Fred's accomplishments, dedication, spirit, and enormous heart.

Who will kick off the half-time entertainment on ''Monday Night Football'' on Election Day eve, Senator John McCain or Senator Barack Obama? ''We'll flip a coin,'' said Norby Williamson, an ESPN executive vice president. Mr. Williamson said he would not ask campaign officials to call heads or tails. ''We'll do it amongst ourselves,'' he said. The presidential candidates will get to make a last-minute pitch to voters during half time of the Pittsburgh Steelers and Washington Redskins game. Their interviews, which will be shown at about 10:15 p.m., Eastern time, will be taped earlier in the day, at locations still to be determined, with Chris Berman questioning them from an ESPN studio in Bristol, Conn.
