It's the week before Election Day. Do you know where your president is? Probably not, and that is by design. With Senator John McCain lagging behind in the polls and many other Republicans fighting for their political lives, the nation's top Republican -- President Bush -- is intentionally lying low this week, and is likely to do so until after Americans cast their ballots to pick his successor.

John McCain and his running mate, Sarah Palin, spend a good part of their final hours on the trail tilling political ground once thought safely Republican. But how do they recover from a day that saw a top Republican insider, Kenneth M. Duberstein, endorse the Democratic nominee, and one of Mr. McCain's most valued supporters, former Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, send out clear signals that he does not think Ms. Palin is qualified to be president?

VeraSun Energy, the nation's second largest ethanol producer by capacity, filed for bankruptcy after making bad hedging bets on corn, a raw material used to make the fuel. The petition for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, filed in federal court in Wilmington, Del., listed both assets and debt of more than $1 billion. VeraSun, formed in 2001 and based in Sioux Falls, S.D., has 16 production facilities in eight states, and an annual capacity of 1.64 billion gallons of ethanol, according to its Web site. Its shares have plunged 89 percent since Sept. 16, and closed Friday at 48 cents. Poet LLC is the largest ethanol producer.

A mystical woman, Kahlan Amnell (Ms. Regan), helps Richard try to stop the evil Darken Rahl (Craig Parker) from unleashing an ancient power and achieving dominion over the world. Bruce Spence plays Zeddicus Zu'l Zorander, a wise wizard masquerading as a crazy hermit whose job has been to make sure that Richard lives to realize his destiny while learning to wield the Sword of Truth. Jay Laga'aia plays Chase Brandstone, Richard's closest friend. The director Sam Raimi of ''Spider-Man'' fame, is an executive producer. 11:30 A.M. JETS' SAFETY SMITH OUT Jets safety Eric Smith will not play against the Bills in Buffalo. Smith sustained his first concussion of the season Sept. 28 against the Cardinals, and after the Jets' bye and his one-game suspension for a helmet-to-helmet hit with Anquan Boldin, Smith sustained a second concussion against the Raiders. The Jets were criticized for allowing Smith and receiver Laveranues Coles, who both have a history of concussions, to play last week against the Chiefs, after both sustained concussions against the Raiders. Coles was not limited in that game. But the Jets took out Smith after halftime. Tight end Bubba Franks (hip) and linebacker David Harris (groin) are doubtful.

Kenneth M. Duberstein, Ronald Reagan's final White House chief of staff and a former political confidant of Senator John McCain, is the latest high-profile Republican to say he will vote for Senator Barack Obama for president. Mr. Duberstein's decision, confirmed in a brief interview, was not a big surprise, given his close friendship with former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who recently announced on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' that he would vote for Mr. Obama, the Democratic nominee, because he was disappointed that both Mr. McCain and the Republican Party had become so socially conservative and negative. Several other Republican figures have since publicly defected.

P. Cameron DeVore, a First Amendment lawyer who was an early expert in the field, representing news companies in many significant disputes over the freedom of the press, died on Sunday at his home on Lopez Island, near Seattle. He was 76. Mr. DeVore's death was confirmed by Bruce Johnson, his partner at Davis Wright Tremaine, the Seattle firm where he worked for 40 years. Mr. Johnson said the cause had not been determined. Mr. DeVore represented news organizations in, among other cases, Auvil v. CBS 60 Minutes, in which apple growers accused CBS of exaggerating the risks of a pesticide; Cable News Network v. Berger, which set guidelines for news companies sending reporters to ride with the police; and Greater New Orleans Broadcasting Association v. United States, which defined the limits of government-news media regulation.

Mrs. Wormser was born April 6, 1935 in Logan, WV to the late Bill Palmer and the late Edna White Palmer. Clara had a 30 year career at NYU in the Treasurers office. She was adventurous and had a passion for the arts, enjoyed reading, and doing crossword puzzles. But most of all she loved her family. She is survived by her children, Diana Ciciollo and son-inlaw Dominic of Waxhaw, NC, Sandra Santiago and son-inlaw Eddie and David Wormser both of Staten Island, NY; grandchildren, Matthew, Mindy, Anthony, Michele, Stephannie, and Maritza; greatgrandchildren, Christopher and Kyleigh; and other relatives and friends. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. Heritage Funeral Home and Cremation Service is assisting the family. An online guestbook is available at www.heritagefuneral.net

KOENIG--Pauline Ladin. Much loved wife, mother and grandmother died Thursday October 30, 2008 at her residence at Brighton Gardens in Camarillo, California from complications related to a stroke. Her passing was gentle and painless. She was 88. Pauline was born April 9, 1920 in New York City to Russian immigrant parents. She graduated with honors from Hunter College in 1941 where she majored in French. In 1948 she married Dr. Leonard Koenig. They lived in Manhattan until moving to Dumont, New Jersey in 1958 to raise their young family. In 1986 she and Leonard moved to California to live closer to their daughters. Pauline is survived by her devoted husband of 60 years, her two daughters Carole June Koenig and Phyllis Ann Koenig Aaronson and her son-in-law Reuben Aaronson and her grandchildren Sophie and Zachary Aaronson. Pauline had a deep love of classical music and was an avid reader. She enjoyed discussing books and ideas with friends and family. A devoted wife and mother, Pauline possessed the rare ability to listen and council wisely the people close to her. Her attentive and selfless spirit will be remembered by everyone whom she touched. The funeral will take place at 11:30am Monday November 3, 2008 at Riverside Cemetery in Saddlebrook, New Jersey. 201-843-7600 A memorial service will follow Monday, November 3rd in Camarillo. 213280-0220.

To the Editor: The photograph of the Lorraine American Cemetery and Memorial near St.-Avold, France, below, (Why We Travel, Oct. 19) brought back the almost unbearable emotions felt by us veterans of the 95th Infantry Division who have visited St.-Avold since World War II. This most heavily fortified city in Europe was General Patton’s prize at the cost of thousands of lives of soldiers of the 5th and 95th Divisions. These men lie forever with tens of thousands of other American soldiers under the crosses and the Stars of David at St. -Avold. Edward O. Shakespeare.

A roundup of predictions on tomorrow's presidential election from the editors of 20 "leading newspapers" is the lead article in today's Times. Twelve of the respondents are from Republican papers; five, independent; and three, Democratic. Most of the Republican and Independent papers' editors forcefully assert that William Howard Taft will win. "Taft will sweep the country, breaking the solid South, and carry New York State by at least 100,000," writes Edw. H. Butler of The Buffalo News. Of the editors of Democratic papers, only one, Albert E. Hoyt of The Argus, in Albany, has strong confidence in a William Jennings Bryan victory. "The signs of the times," he writes, "point to a Democratic landslide too great and widespread to be overcome by money, intimidation, the power of patronage, or the persistent unfairness of some so-called independent papers." An article in some copies on Oct. 19 about Hollywood’s caution in making films that focus on African-American themes misspelled the name of a character in a series of films by the writer, director and actor Tyler Perry. The character is Madea, not Medea.

An article last Sunday about learning to be a political pundit on television referred incorrectly to the Fox program “Hannity & Colmes.” Its hosts present opposing conservative and liberal views on issues; it is not a conservative show.

A calendar listing last Sunday misstated dates and ticket prices for “It Ain’t Nothin’ but the Blues” at the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick. It runs Nov. 6 to 16, not until Nov. 23; ticket prices are $55 on opening night, $45 at other times, not $175 and $90.

An article last Sunday about the views of Connecticut residents on the presidential campaign misidentified the occupation of one voter, Jay Wood of Darien. He is a financial adviser for Merrill Lynch, not a financial analyst. The article also misstated Mr. Wood’s attitude toward his employment. He did not say he was worried about his job.

An article last Sunday about the discovery of wax cylinder recordings dating from 1890 to 1927 misstated the year that commercial recording began. It was roughly 1889; it was not 1899, the year that classical commercial recordings began.

While it was amusing to read about President Bush’s affinity for Khinkali (Questions for Mikheil Saakashvili, Oct.19), there were many other questions that one could ask the man who brought the U.S. and Russia the closest they’ve been to direct confrontation since the Cuban missile crisis. Perhaps Deborah Solomon could have asked some of the still-unanswered questions posed by the Georgian opposition: Why did Tbilisi not know that Russia was preparing to intervene militarily and thus take actions to protect the Georgian people? Why did Tbilisi ignore “numerous and direct warnings of Georgia’s friends not to yield to Russia’s provocations?” And why did Tbilisi launch Georgia’s military action in South Ossetia? These are questions only Saakashvili can answer.

Roger Lowenstein (Oct.19) concedes the reckless role of speculators in driving up gasoline prices to over $4 a gallon. But he does not condemn that drive. He, too, wants high gas prices: not for exploitative gains, of course, but to support the development of alternative fuels within the U.S. at higher costs than gasoline. His “contrarian” proposal is a floor-type tax, to kick in only if oil prices fall below a set level of support.

I believe William Safire is inaccurate in applying the designation “verbal tic” to certain word choices by the presidential candidates (On Language, Oct. 19). Safire correctly explains that verbal tics are typically unconscious — essentially mental hiccups manifested involuntarily in speech, typically arising from nervous tension. An example would be Obama’s occasional “you know,” hiccupped reflexively as “yo.” Obama’s “distraction” and McCain’s “my friends,” by contrast, are not nervous tics; they’re deliberate word choices reflecting conscious preference, whether used habitually or occasionally. Viewed this way, they’re fodder for a Safire column that instead of dismissing a candidate’s wording preferences as superficial spasms explores their underlying psychology, political objectives and ultimate effectiveness.

What troubles me about Governor Palin’s sexual politics is not so much her being pro-life but her closed-mindedness when it comes to providing the dissemination of knowledge that would reduce unwanted pregnancy in the first place.

JUST WHEN you thought no one else could possibly weigh in on baseball and steroids, syringes come to the stage. The playwright Itamar Moses’s “BACK BACK BACK” fictionalizes the friendship — and performance enhancement — of the so-called Bash Brothers, Mark McGwire and Jose Canseco (below) and their pal, the long-forgotten shortstop Walt Weiss. It opens Nov. 18 at New York’s Manhattan Theater Club. . . . $1,350 is pretty steep for a book, but if that book is one of 200 numbered copies of “GUTS AND GLORY: THE GOLDEN AGE OF AMERICAN FOOTBALL, 1958-1978” (Taschen), which culls the best of the legendary sports photographer Neil Leifer’s 10,000 rolls of football photos and comes swaddled in a custom slipcase, well. . . . When undefeated Harvard (the home of Al Gore) scored 16 points in the final minute to tie undefeated Yale (perhaps mourning the recent graduation of George W. Bush) in 1968, the next morning’s Harvard Crimson declared, “HARVARD BEATS YALE 29-29.” That’s the title of this quirky documentary by Bush’s cousin, Kevin Rafferty, about the most famous football game ever played between the two academic powerhouses. It opens in New York Nov. 19. . . . Last but not least, gather your man-friends and settle in for a triple feature of (mostly) teary sports triumphs — “HOOSIERS,” “ROCKY II” AND “BULL DURHAM” — to be released Nov. 4 in a single box by MGM ($25). To the Editor: Regarding “36 Hours: Paris” (Oct. 19): The Shoah Memorial (17, rue Geoffroy-l’Asnier; 33-1-4277-4472; www.memorialdelashoah.org; free) is the largest research, information and awareness-raising center in Europe on the genocide against Jews during World War II. “Shoah” is the Hebrew word for catastrophe. The museum, fosters an understanding of the past to illuminate the future.

To the Editor: Regarding “Belfast Regains Its Voice” (Oct. 19), as a veteran of many a traditional music session in Ireland, I assure you that there is no “jamming” allowed. The tunes are set with specific melodies with room only for slight embellishment. Second, a bodhran (bow-rhan) is anything but an “Irish tambourine.” It is a drum made from animal skin (usually goat) stretched over a round wooden frame. It is all thump, thump, thump with no jingle, jangle, jingle. Slainte!.

The couple were married Saturday at the main branch of the San Francisco Public Library.

Laura Beth Nissenbaum and Andrew Todd Slabin are to be married Sunday at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. The ceremony is to be led by Leor Sinai, a graduate of the Jewish Theological Seminary who has been authorized by the seminary to officiate at weddings.

Howard Marc Sendrovitz and David Clifford Sinclair celebrated their partnership with a commitment ceremony Saturday evening at the Pegasus Suite of the Rainbow Room in New York. The Rev. Robert Brashear, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Michael E. Feinberg led the ceremony.

Tara Suzanne Holm, the daughter of Suzanne S. Holm of Wyomissing, Pa., and Dr. Eric K. Holm of Reading, Pa., was married Saturday to Timothy Rupert Riley, a son of Margaret G. A. Riley and Martin R. Riley of Buckingham, England. The Rev. Douglas L. Shaffer, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Bausman Memorial Church in Wyomissing.
Damon Eric Romine and Charles Wayne Robbins are to be married Sunday at the Viceroy, a resort hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. The ceremony is to be part of a double wedding.

Jamie Lynn Bartholomew and Steven Benjamin Aller were married on Friday at the New York City Municipal Building in Manhattan. Blanca Martinez, a staff member in the City Clerk’s office, officiated. On Saturday they had a Quaker ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

Marcia Jeanne Carlson and Timothy Michael Smeeding were married Saturday at St. Philip’s Church in the Highlands in Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

Bridget Ellen Marnane, a travel executive, and Evan Marc Katz, a dating coach, were married Saturday evening aboard the yacht Regent Sea. Joel L. Eve, a minister of the Universal Life Church and the captain of the yacht, officiated in the Pacific near Marina del Rey, Calif.
Dr. Julia Rebecca Sivitz was married to Matthew Gary Bieber Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Philadelphia. Rabbi Eric Yanoff officiated.

Molly Mannion Soudant and Joe Alterio married Saturday at the Swedish American Hall, an event space in San Francisco. Matt Glaser, a Universal Life minister and the bridegroom’s best friend, officiated.
Dr. Rebecca Sybil Goodkin and Lee Howard Carlin were married Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan. Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated.

Katya Rayevsky Fisher, the daughter of Regine Rayevsky Fisher and Wesley A. Fisher of Philadelphia, was married Saturday evening to Roman Yoffe, the son of Tatyana Titov and Vladimir Yoffe of Stratford, Ontario. Cantor Richard Botton officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.

An article last Sunday about Henry Chang, an author of detective novels involving a Chinese-American police detective, attributed an erroneous distinction to his work. Mr. Chang’s detective series is not the first to feature Chinese police officers; there are at least two such series: the Zhong Fong mysteries, by David Rotenberg, and the Inspector Chen novels, by Qiu Xiaolong.

An article on Oct. 19 about the Belfast music scene misstated the role of Henry McCullough in a folk band called Sweeney’s Men. He joined the band in 1968, two years after it was founded; he did not start the band. The article also misstated the name of a drink served at the John Hewitt, a Belfast pub; it was Harp Lager, not an ale. And an accompanying map misspelled the river that runs through Belfast. It is the River Lagan, not Logan.

The 36 Hours column on Oct. 26 about Charlottesville, Va., misidentified the building used as the model for the Rotunda at the University of Virginia. It is the Pantheon in Rome not the Parthenon, in Athens.

Get articles, slide shows and insider tips, including ideas on how to spend 36 hours in Bologna, above, a first-person account of kayaking the canals of Venice and a look at the growing culinary scene of Palermo's at-home trattorias. Plus, reviews and reader suggestions on top hotels and attractions. Three hours before their game Saturday night against top-ranked Texas, a large group of Texas Tech players sat in the bar area of a Holiday Inn. The Red Raiders had stayed at the hotel Friday night, as they traditionally do for home games.

Address: 1414 18th Avenue, #2215 The Property: A 1,600-square-foot two-bedroom two-bathroom condominium in Xanadu, a four-year-old over-55 complex in the commercial center of a suburban Monmouth County town. There are hardwood floors throughout, an upgraded kitchen and bathroom fixtures, and large California Closets in the bedrooms. The unit, only two miles from the beach, comes with two indoor parking spaces and access to the complex's amenities, like a heated outdoor pool, a fitness center, a library, a catering kitchen and a billiard room. The common charge is $365 a month; taxes are $4,228 a year.

If you live in Pennsylvania or Ohio, you might want to stay away from the airports as the candidates buzz in and out these next two days. John McCain campaigns Sunday in Scranton, Pa., hometown of Joseph R. Biden Jr.Barack Obama makes three stops in Ohio.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Oct. 18, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

LARMOTH--Jeanine Lenore. A writer, winning an award for her first book: ''Murder on the Menu.'' Sister of Donald and Richard Larmouth. Service: Monday, November 3, 2pm at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., NYC.

The son of Nezamudin, a commander working in Afghan security, collapsed into the arms of an Afghan Army soldier on Saturday as he arrived near the village of Kamu for his father's funeral. Nezamudin was killed during a mortar attack by the Taliban at an American and Afghan military base, Combat Outpost Lowell, near Afghanistan's border with Pakistan.

LURKIS--Alexander, died peacefully at age 99 in his Queens home on June 16, followed by a funeral and burial in LA, CA. Beloved husband of Carin, father of Jeff, uncle, friend and civil servant, he is survived by grandchildren, Elisa, Louisa and Clif, Jeff's partner Ed, great-grandchildren, nieces, nephew, greatand great-great-nephews and -nieces. Born in Manhattan, he graduated from Cooper Union and rose to become Chief Engineer of the Bureau of Gas and Electricity for New York City. He led an adventurous and productive life and will long be remembered for his unfailing determination and great sense of humor. A memorial service is set for Sunday, November 9 at 11:00am at Israel Center of Conservative Judaism, 167-11 73rd Ave., Flushing, NY 11366.

GLUCKSMAN--John. Be loved of wife Paula, son Joel and wife Hope, granddaughter Lily, countless friends. Stuyvesant High, NYU, Chinese Studies UC Berkeley, Columbia Engineering, partner Paula Green Advertising, WWII Vet. Warm, witty, wise, unfettered in mind and spirit. We were blessed with his love. Service: Sunday, 11:30am the ''Riverside'' 76th and Amsterdam. Contributions to PAL.

To the Sports Editor: It's time to fold up the laptops, eliminate coaches, writers and broadcasters voting, and put all Football Bowl Subdivision teams that have a winning record at the end of the season in a lottery to determine who plays for the Bowl Championship Series title.

(ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION Sugar Ray Leonard, George Foreman and Oscar De La Hoya, right, lend their ring cred to the renovation of the Geneva, N.Y., home of Tim Hill, an aspiring boxer whose dreams were destroyed when his back was broken while he was working on a construction site. Now he trains pugilists ranging in age from 8 to 21 in how to roll with the punches, and he has even been awarded custody of an Olympic hopeful from a broken family. The ESPN announcers John Saunders and Brian Kenny call the demolition of the Hill family's 200-year-old farmhouse as if it were a boxing match. 4 P.M. SHANKMAN--Miriam Frankenstein, in her 100th year, at her home in New Rochelle, NY. Beloved and loving wife for nearly 55 years of the late Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman of Temple Israel of New Rochelle. A devoted Rebbitzen who became the model for others in the 20th century. Survivors include daughter Judith and the late Alvin Kosak of New Rochelle, son Michael and Phyllis Shankman of North Potomac, MD, predeceased by daughter Diane and ''Punchy'' and Larry Hutchens of San Jose, CA. Grandchildren Deborah (Jeffrey) Gussoff, Andrew (Jennifer) Kosak, Rabbi David (Laura) Kosak, Elizabeth Socha, Jonathan (Tracie) Panish, Sarah (Demedric) Cooks, Rabbi Susan (Rabbi Michael Namath) Shankman, Jennifer (Tevin) Adelman, Rebecca Shankman and 17 great-grandchildren. Services at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, Today 10:30am.

OVER the years, Tina Lutz and Marcia Patmos of the innovative knitwear label Lutz & Patmos have worked with an array of guest designers on their dream sweaters, Sofia Coppola, Jane Birkin and Richard Meier included. Now added to the list is the Amtrak train conductor Chris Waugh, whom Ms. Lutz met on her weekly commute from New York to her house in Rhode Island. ''He jokingly said that if we ever needed a guest designer, he knew the name of the sweater and the charity it would benefit,'' she said. ''We took him up on it.'' The Shoreline hoodie, named after the train Mr. Waugh works on, was inspired by his favorite Izod pullover and a sweatshirt of his daughter's, and is dedicated to his father, who has Parkinson's; $20 of each sweater's purchase price will benefit the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.
Dance Jack Anderson

PERKINS--Bradford Southworth, 53, died on October 28, 2008 after a valiant two year fight against brain cancer. He was the husband for 22 years of Sara and father of Marit. He is also survived by his parents Eleanor and John Perkins of New York, a brother John M. Perkins Jr., and a sister Eleanor P. Robinson, both of Connecticut, he was the son-in-law of Millie and Jack Rotchford of Spokane, Washington. Brad was a writer, producer and voice talent for KIRO News Radio for 28 years. He was also an active ice hockey player, serious mountain climber, bicycle rider, coach, scuba diver, musician and enjoyed the study of languages. He graduate from Brooks School, North Andover, MA and Lake Forest College, Lake Forest, IL. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 15 at 11am at Epiphany Episcopal Parrish, Seattle, WA. Donations in his memory may be made to: SMC Foundation, FBO Brain Cancer Research, 747 Broadway, Seattle, WA 98122-4307.

PHILADELPHIA -- Brown quarterback Michael Dougherty has been dangerous this season no matter where the Bears' drives have started, but the team's defense made it easier for him Saturday. Dougherty threw for 234 yards and 4 touchdowns in a 34-27 victory against Pennsylvania at Franklin Field. None of the Bears' five scoring drives covered more than 57 yards. One covered 11, another 28.

JANOVER--Andrew Gumpert. Born in New York City; died at age 63 in Damariscotta, ME on October 23, 2008. Raised in New York City, Andy was a graduate of the Riverdale Country School and Lake Forest College and attended the Sloan School of Business at M.I.T. He spent most of his career as an executive in the food services industry. Andy leaves his wife of more than forty years, the former Caroline Davis, two sons, Jamie and Michael, and his sister Nancy Victor. We will always recall his wry wit, warm friendship, and good cheer, even in the face of ill health. Farewell, dear friend. Kathy & Andy Berkman, Andrea & Andy Potash, Rosalind & Gerry Rosenberg, Susan & Bruce Schlechter, Ceci & Jim Tripp

What I will miss most about George W. Bush as president is his sincere concern for promoting human dignity. I was at his side when he met with defectors from North Korean forced-labor camps, listened to firsthand accounts of the unconscionable atrocities Saddam Hussein committed, shared the elation of women freed from the injustices of the Taliban, worked to dramatically increase government funding to combat AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria in Africa, and pressed other world leaders to stop genocide in Darfur. The compassion President Bush showed for the oppressed and suffering in these moments was inspiring.

Every marathoner knows and dreads ''the wall,'' running lingo for the almost hallucinatory exhaustion produced by glycogen depletion around Mile 19. The running industry has come up with helpful solutions, like special sports drinks or concentrated carbohydrate gels, to help runners overcome the wall's challenges. But in New York it is possible to run the whole marathon without high-tech aid. Throughout the 26.2 miles across all five boroughs, spectators eagerly hand out their own versions of running fuel. After five years of subjecting myself to this trial, I have discovered some patterns.
INTERNATIONAL ENCLAVE OF BRAZILIANS

GLASSELL--Alfred C., Jr., was born on the 31st of March, 1913 at Cuba Plantation in north Louisiana. He was the son of Alfred Curry Glassell and Frances Elvira Lane. He graduated from Bird High School in Shreveport, Louisiana and later Louisiana State University where he distinguished himself as President of the Student Body and Kappa Alpha fraternity, ROTC commander, and member in 13 honor societies. Upon graduation he became a pioneer in the energy business, discovering and extending oil and gas fields on the gulf coasts of Louisiana and Texas. He was a founder of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, the first gas transmission system from Texas to New York. He served on the boards of corporations including Transco, El Paso Natural Gas, and First City Bank. During the Second World War, he answered the call to duty and joined the armed forces where he achieved the rank of major. His distinguished war record included active service in the African and European theaters. Upon return to civilian life, he again put his business talents to work, joining efforts to return the United States to prosperity with plentiful, affordable energy. He had a life-long interest in marine biology and the preservation of sea life. He participated in seafaring expeditions throughout the world, leading the Yale Seychelles Expedition from the Atlantic to the Indian Oceans and the east coast of Africa. In 1971 he was awarded the International Oceanographic Foundation Marine Science Award for outstanding contributions. An enthusiastic supporter of Texas wildlife and conservation, with the help of friends the Alfred C. Glassell, Jr. Professorship in Quail Research was established at the Caesar Kleberg Wildlife Research Institute. Quail season at Buena Suerte near Falfurrias was legendary, famous for plentiful coveys and gentlemanly sportsmanship. An avid sportsman, Alfred C. Glassell, Jr. achieved fame as one of the foremost anglers in the world. In 1953, he set the world record for the largest marlin ever caught on a hand-held rod and reel. At 1,560 pounds, this record remains today, and the worlds largest game fish resides on view at the Smithsonian Institution. A tribute to his skills, he was pictured on the cover of Sports Illustrated in 1954 and inducted into the International Game Fish Associations Hall of Fame in 2001. In addition to business, military, scientific, and sports achievements, he distinguished himself as a civic leader and philanthropist. Over a lifetime, he dedicated his time and resources to the Houston Museum of Natural Science, Houston Symphony Society, Society for Performing Arts, Houston Ballet Foundation, Houston Chamber of Commerce, Texas Children's Hospital, American Museum of Natural History in New York City, Smithsonian Institution, and Archaeological Institute of America. He fulfilled a great role as a leader at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. This world famous collector of art was first elected to the museums Board of Trustees in 1970. Realizing peoples fundamental need for hands on experience in the arts and recognizing the lack of studio opportunities, he established the Glassell School of Art. Since its dedication in 1979, the Glassell School has provided diverse training in the fine arts to children, adults, emerging artists, hospital patients, and older Americans. He was elected Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston in 1990, a time when the need for physical expansion was evident. With characteristic optimism and belief in the generosity of Houston, he led a ten-year effort that resulted in the Audrey Jones Beck Building as home for the museums collection of Western Antiquities, European, and American art. As a life-long collector of Asian, Pre-Columbian, and African art, he donated his excellent and extensive collections to the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. These works, primarily of precious gold, are without parallel. Frances Marzio, his curator, described him as a great connoisseur who recognized the creative genius of diverse cultures before they were appreciated by many others. After a life spent in the pursuit of excellence Alfred C. Glassell, Jr., 95, died on Wednesday afternoon, the 29th of October 2008. He was predeceased by his sisters, the late Joanna Glassell Wood, Lillian Glassell Crichton, and Emily Glassell Comegys. He is survived by his wife, Clare Attwell Glassell; children, Curry Glassell, Alfred C. Glassell III and Marli Andrade, Lisa Ford, Alison Ford Duncan, Emily Ford Embrey and her husband Mark C. Embrey; and grandsons, Nathan J. Roberts, Alfred Samuel Jared Roberts, Robert S. Duncan, W. Hudson Duncan, Nicholas E. Embrey, and Joseph M. Embrey. He is also survived by his niece, Janie C. Lee Warren, as well as numerous other nieces, nephews, and great nieces and nephews. The family wishes to express their gratitude to his longtime office manager Pam Lindberg, assistant Bonnie Gonzales, and Samantha Duff. A memorial service will be conducted at one o'clock in the afternoon on Monday, the 3rd of November, at The Episcopal Church or St. John the Divine, 2450 River Oaks Boulevard in Houston. For those desiring, valet parking attendants will be available at the River Oaks Boulevard Entranceway of the church. Immediately following the service, all are in invited to join the family for a reception in the adjacent Summers Hall. Honored to serve as pallbearers are Merrill Athon, Stuart Campbell, Dr. Byron Hall, Dan Japhet, Dr. Mavis Kelsey, Rich Kinder, Robert McNair, Meredith Long, Peter Marzlo, Dr. Walter McReynolds, Dr. David Ott, Fayez Sarofim, Bill Wheless, Dr. Jim Willerson, Wallace Wilson, and Gene M. Woodfin. Services in Houston are entrusted to Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, The Funeral Directors Since 1938, 713 - 789 - 3005, www.geohlewis.com. In lieu of usual remembrances, contributions in memory of Mr. Glassell may be directed to The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, P.O. Box 6826, Houston, TX 77265-6826; Texas Children's Hospital, P.O. Box 300630, MC-4-4483, Houston, TX, 77230-0630; or to the charity of one's choice.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Experts Say Staph Is Common Problem for Athletes,'' Oct. 25: Reports of staph infections among football players often fail to make the distinction between those acquired in the locker room and those acquired in the operating room.

I'll miss President Bush's moral clarity. The president's critics hated his willingness to label things right or wrong, and the press used to bang me around for it, but history will show how right he was. Shortly after 9/11, the president gave a speech in which he talked about the fight between good and evil, and that good would win. Afterward, I told him I thought he was being simplistic: ''There are a lot of shades of gray in this war. I think it's more nuanced.''

Memorials to George and Carol Sopkin Scholarship, Kneisel Hall PO Box 648, Blue Hill, ME 04614.

HANRIOT--Robin, 61, died October 31, 2008 in Miami Beach after a brief illness. Beloved wife of John Hanriot. She was the daughter of Arthur and Dorothy Bettigole of East Williston. She was a distinguished equestrian on Long Island having competed in local events and in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. Music was the major force in her life, after graduation from the Oberlin Conservatory of Music, she pursued a career in opera both in Europe and in the United States. Mrs. Hanriot was a member of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus performing with the Opera company for over twenty years. A visitation will be held at the Weigland Bros. Funeral Home 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park, NY Thursday, 10am-11am. Interment will be at Pinelawn Memorial Park. The family requests that memorial donations be made to the Bideawee Shelter for animals.

IT all started with her red Ettore Sottsass Valentine typewriter. Jane Schub, an illustrator and beauty entrepreneur, realized one day its color would make a wonderful nail polish. As would the pink in a Warhol painting she saw at the Dia:Beacon museum. ''It had black in it,'' Ms. Schub explained. ''It was a little off. It turned the corner from being pink to something very beautiful to look at.'' Those colors, along with six other similarly vibrant and somewhat eccentric hues (a midcentury modern orange, an Art Nouveau teal, a blue inspired by the depths of a lake at night) make up the first collection of StrangeBeautiful, a line Ms. Schub started with her business partner, Susan Strange. (''I like to say she's the strange, and I'm the beautiful,'' Ms. Schub said, laughing.) Free of any labels and elegantly packaged as a whole color story, StrangeBeautiful is like a Josef Albers art piece for your hand.

The late-1950s westerns of Budd Boetticher are shoestring masterpieces that put the idea of flashy, big-budget, prestige filmmaking to shame. These are taut miniatures: none of the pictures in this five-disc set -- ''The Tall T,'' ''Decision at Sundown,'' ''Buchanan Rides Alone,'' ''Ride Lonesome'' and ''Comanche Station,'' all made from 1957 to 1960 -- top 80 minutes. They were shot on minimal budgets with shooting schedules of around 18 days, but the storytelling is so compact and vital that you're never left feeling hungry. Boetticher (pronounced BET-i-ker), a Midwestern rich kid who grew up to be fascinated with bullfighting (which he used as a backdrop for several films, among them the 1951 ''Bullfighter and the Lady''), knew how to film action. The shootouts in his movies tend to have a kinetic gracefulness, and the characters move with economic agility. As Martin Scorsese notes in a brief featurette included on one of the discs, ''Any time anyone moved, it meant something.''

An article last Sunday about the discovery of wax cylinder recordings dating from 1890 to 1927 misstated the year that commercial recording began. It was roughly 1889; it was not 1899, the year that classical commercial recordings began.

I was listening to George W. Bush speak at a rally in New Hampshire, in January 2000, when he came up with what remains my favorite of his miscues: ''I know how hard it is to put food on your family.'' This could be an amusing few months, I remember thinking. The only slow period for Bushisms was right after Sept. 11, when the president's inadequacies no longer seemed very funny. Then Mr. Bush declared that normality was returning: ''I am here to make an announcement that this Thursday, ticket counters and airplanes will fly out of Ronald Reagan Airport.''

SAX--Alice (nee Fisher), passed away peacefully on October 26, 2008, surrounded by her immediate family and the thoughts and prayers of her many friends from around the world. Beloved wife of Karl, mother to Wendy and Rick, Alice embraced the world with a passion for life and devotion to her family and friends. Her journey began in Kerhonksen, NY on May 15, 1928 as the youngest of 10 siblings. She was educated at SUNY Albany and Teachers College, Columbia University. Shortly after marrying, she moved to Okinawa, then to Frankfurt, Germany, where she was a teacher and counselor in the DoDDS system for over 35 years. On retiring to her present home in King of Prussia, PA, Alice continued her love for travel, exercise, bridge, politics, and healthy food, and discovered e-mail as the way to remain in touch with her many farflung friends. Those whom she touched will always remember her for keen insight, compassion, and grace with dignity. She will be terribly missed, yet with a smile, for all the fond memories she created in living her life so fully and with such love. Alice is survived by her children, her sister Ethel ''Boots'' Fisher, and her grandchildren, Emily, Jonathan and Jamie. In lieu of flowers, donations in Alice's name can be made to ORT, 75 Maiden Lane, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10038 or the American Association for Cancer Research Foundation, 615 Chestnut Street, 17th Floor, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

McCain spot: ''Freedom.'' Swelling music, flags galore and emotionally powerful footage of John McCain as a prisoner of war and returning home. His closing argument is the same as the one that brought his campaign back to life a year ago. ''I've served my country since I was 17 years old. And spent five years longing for her shores. I came home dedicated to a cause greater than my own.'' Obama spot: ''Rearview Mirror.'' Returning to the McCain-equals-Bush argument, hitting back at Mr. McCain on taxes. A driver sees President Bush in the rearview mirror, Mr. McCain in the side mirror and warnings about Mr. McCain's tax policies in road signs. It ends with Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain in the rearview mirror.

A favorite holiday film is Max Ophüls's ''Reckless Moment'' (1949), which was released just three years after Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life.'' In this film, Christmas comes to epitomize the smothering nature of family. Joan Bennett, below with Shepperd Strudwick, plays an overprotective mother trying to cover for her teenage daughter, who is involved in a man's death. Every time Ms. Bennett's character, Lucia Harper, tries to find a moment alone with her blackmailer-lover, Martin Donnelly (played by James Mason), some relative barges through the room lugging a Christmas tree or strumming a ukulele. Her only moment of quiet time occurs when she's alone, out in a boat, ditching the body.

PHOTOS This semester, Arkansas State and Indiana University East retired their old mascots in favor of a red wolf. In Missouri, East Central College replaced its rebel with a falcon. Ethnic and regional sensitivities and the pressure of branding make for a lot of mascot-morphing. But how to choose a symbol that is noble, fierce and unique -- not a bird of prey, a wolf, a bear or Pistol Pete?

KESSLER--Esther Rose, passed away peacefully at the age of 95 on October 30, 2008. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, mother - in - law, aunt and friend. Wife of the late Al Kessler. Esther had a great zest for living, her family was the center of her life and above all she loved being together with them. She will be greatly missed. Private family funeral.

ZIMMER--Michael, who died on October 12, 2008 at the age of 74, leaves a host of saddened friends and family behind. Diagnosed with lung cancer only a few weeks ago, he was taken home to his house in the West Village to die among his books, his friends, and with a view of his beloved garden. Michael was born in Heidelberg in 1934, the youngest son of Sanskrit scholar and Indologist Heinrich Zimmer and his wife Christiane, daughter of the Austrian poet and librettist Hugo von Hofmannsthal (''Der Rosenkavalier'', ''Elektra''). The family fled Nazi Germany in 1939, and New York's Columbia University offered a hospitable teaching environment. After her husband's premature death in 1943, Christiane settled in New York's West Village where her house became a gathering place for luminaries from both sides of the Atlantic, among them Hannah Arendt, Wyston Auden and Joseph Campbell, one of Zimmer's most illustrious disciples. Michael and his two brothers attended Horace Mann School and Michael went on to study at Harvard University, supported by the Mellon family who had earlyon recognized the importance of Heinrich Zimmer's work on Indian myths and philosophy. Always fascinated by the built environment, Michael chose to major in architecture, studying with masters such as Walter Gropius and Siegfried Giedion. A short-lived career as an architect in New York followed: Michael, by his own admission, wasn't cut out for the compromises it entailed. After his marriage to Emily Sophia Harding, a cousin by marriage and daughter of Alice Astor, the couple briefly occupied the glamour pages of Vogue and other glossies. In 1967 they had a son, Jacob and soon after left New York to live ''off the grid''. In 1969, assisted by the proceeds of the sale of a Hofmannsthal heirloom, Picassos self portrait ''Yo Picasso'', they purchased a piece of land on the island of St. Barts. After his divorce from Harding, Michael made the little paradise his home, sharing it with his companion, Vera Graaf and a group of like-minded friends. ''Le Camp'' was a compound of mini buildings with a solarpowered kitchen and a beautifully cultivated tropical garden, all of which Michael used as a playful laboratory for his ideas of the good life, guided by aesthetic principles. It was a visionary example of ''green'' lifestyle, as well as a meticulously choreographed piece of theatre which Michael directed, smoking, talking, always a glass of rum in hand, endlessly amusing and usually surrounded by a bevy of awe-struck friends. When St. Barts became a celebrity hangout, Michael was soon looking for a more hospitable shore. He found it in Canada, on the island of Grand Manan, where his second wife Veronique Sari took him whalewatching and he discovered a group of defunct smoke houses. He managed to buy and transform them into a museum whose most striking exhibition piece was he himself, living in the midst of it all and motoring around in an aluminum boat shaped like a sardine can. He became the island's keeper of memories, the man who guarded and exhibited what the islanders threw away. The ''Sardine Museum and Herring Hall of Fame'' became Michael's last great project -a poetic environment, part museum, part curiosity cabinet, part living memory. Michael Johannes der Baptist Karl Maximilian Heinrich Hugo Zimmer (his full name) enjoyed what was perceived by many as a charmed life. He lived by his own rules and conventions, counting among his lovers and companions men and women. Tragedy intervened only once, when his son Jacob was killed in a drowning accident in 1990. Michael and Jacob had many unfinished plans. May they now be reunited to carry them out. Michael is survived by his cousins Romana McEwen, Octavian von Hofmannsthal and Arabella Heathcote-Amory of London, England, as well as his nephew Christopher Zimmer and his niece, Adriana Zimmer, both of Washington, DC. A memorial date is yet to be announced.
Pop Nate Chinen

Independents are a prized bloc. But surveys suggest that more than a third of them are ornery or apathetic and probably won't bother to vote -- mostly because they didn't bother to register. That leaves candidates to fight over the rest of an independent-minded diaspora that had skewed toward Republicans for many years but has recently flipped. Now, independents are drawn more to Democrats. Independents outnumber Republicans in the electorate this year, according to polling by the Pew Research Center conducted last month: Among independents, just over half lean toward one of the major parties: About one in 10 are the most purely independent -- they refuse to identify with either party but still care very much about who is president. The rest, not so much. Herewith, a map of mindsets proclaimed by America's independents. How to Read This Chart Each '' i '' symbol represents 1 percent of Americans who call themselves independents. Percentages are each group's share of all independents. Independents paired with a donkey lean Democratic. Independents paired with an elephant lean Republican. The higher on the chart they appear, the more liberal they tend to be regarding economic issues. Those positioned lower are more conservative. The more leftward their position on the chart, the more liberal they tend to be on social issues. Those positioned toward the right are more conservative.
The puzzle answers on Page 59 of the magazine this weekend omit the location of the start of 1-across in the diagramless puzzle. It is the first square of the top row.

WISTREICH--Margo, of New Rochelle, NY died October 31, surrounded by her family. Born in Germany on January 3, 1932. Beloved wife of the late Reginald Wistreich. She is survived by her devoted sister Helen Glaser, her loving children, Stacy (Lyle), Nicole (Peter) and Carl (Amy), and her six cherished grandchildren, Lauren, Emily, Adin, Brooke, Rebecca and Stephanie, who affectionately called her ''OMA.'' Donations may be made to Diabetes Education at Cheshire Health Foundation, 580 Court Street, Keene, NH 03431.

STEINBOCK--Elmer Lincoln, died peacefully at age 94 on October 24th, 2008. Beloved husband of the late Natalie Steinbock. Darling father of Miriam (Dennis), Bonnie and Susan (Jim). Adored grandfather of Jessica, Nick, Sarah and Sam. Born in New York City in 1914, Elmer graduated from CCNY and Brooklyn Law School cum laude. He retired as the President of Security Mutual Insurance Company in New York after starting out as their General Counsel. A major in World War II and head of the CID in the 5th Army under General Mark Clark, he was awarded the Bronze Star medal. Elmer touched the lives of many people. He was known for his wit, generosity and compassion but, above all, for his integrity and ability to handle any situation.

I tend to take my Christmas films regionally. ''Miracle on 34th Street'' will forever be the Christmas movie when I'm in New York. ''A Christmas Story'' is the one when I'm back in my hometown, Princeton Junction, N.J. (While the film is set in Cleveland, Ralphie's yellow-eyed nemesis, Scut Farkus, and the real-life villain of my childhood share the same last name.) George Bailey and his building and loan provide a most versatile (and slightly obvious) Swiss Army knife for life on the road, turning wherever you may be into Bedford Falls. But these days I find myself living in Los Angeles, not far from Century City, in the shadow of Fox Plaza or, as I will always call it, Nakatomi Plaza -- setting of perhaps the greatest American caper film since ''The Taking of Pelham One Two Three'' (1974) and undoubtedly the finest action film of its era, ''Die Hard'' (1988). Not often remembered as a Christmas movie (along with its not-so-timeless cousin, ''Lethal Weapon''), ''Die Hard,'' starring Bruce Willis, below, was and still is the ultimate stocking stuffer: a great action film, a great crime film, a great comedy and perhaps the single best use of Beethoven's Ninth in the history of cinema.
Trent Edwards vs. the Jets' secondary

YUDELMAN--Sally Anne Watters, passed away peacefully in her home on October 24, accompanied by her husband of 40 years, Montague Yudelman. She is survived by her husband; her two sons, Christian and Ethan Miller; her two stepsons and stepdaughter, John, Paul and Jane Yudelman; and nine grandchildren. Sally will be remembered for her love of her family and friends as well as her passion, energy and concern for social justice and the poor around the world. Her long and distinguished career in the field of human rights and international development positively touched the lives of countless people. Her loss will be especially felt by the advocates of women's issues in the developing world as she was a leading researcher, advocate and practitioner for women's advancement in developing countries. Sally's distin guished career included positions at the Peace Corps and Inter-American Foundation as well as being a part of many official delegations and commissions for governmental and non-governmental agencies and a member of board of directors for numerous nonprofit groups. Sally wrote and spoke widely about women's issues, nongovernmental agencies and social change in the developing world. Sally will also be remembered for her sense of humor and her love of animals. A memorial service will be held in Washington, DC on November 24. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Washington Office on Latin America or the International Center for Research on Women in Washington, D.C.

Those of us who, as young readers, read William H. Armstrong's children's novel ''Sounder'' in the early 1970s were thrilled to see the story of black sharecroppers in '30s Louisiana visualized in Martin Ritt's 1972 film. Watching the movie as adults, viewers can see the closest that American commercial cinema has ever come to the humanist purity of Jean Renoir, Vittorio de Sica, Satyajit Ray and Claude Jutra. In pictures like ''Hud'' and ''Norma Rae,'' Ritt combined a good liberal's politics with a storyteller's instinct for satisfying melodrama. ''Sounder'' (the title refers to the family's hunting dog) has a quiet, organic quality unmatched in Ritt's work. It's the kind of subject -- how love and determination hold a family together when the father (Paul Winfield) is sent to a prison camp for stealing food to feed his hungry children -- that invites homilies, sentimentality and false nobility.

Why are these two 1964 sculptures by John Chamberlain, roughly the same size and made the same year, priced so differently? Christie's estimates that ''Spike,'' from the estate of the philanthropist Alice Lawrence, the widow of the Manhattan real estate developer Sylvan Lawrence, will bring $900,000 to $1.2 million. ''Ca-D'Oro,'' which is being sold by an unidentified Midwestern collector at Sotheby's, carries an estimate of $1.8 million to $2.2 million.

Senator Barack Obama received help and trouble from his family Saturday. The trouble: An aunt from Kenya was reported to be living in Boston public housing, even though she was ordered to leave the country in 2004. The help: Vice President Dick Cheney, a distant cousin of Mr. Obama, endorsed his opponent, Senator John McCain, providing much fodder for gleeful Democrats. Republicans went after Mr. Obama on patriotism. Seizing on Mr. Obama's remark that his caucus victory in Iowa ''vindicated'' his faith in America, Mr. McCain said, ''My country has never had to prove anything to me.''

Alison Pill enters cursing in ''Milk'' (Nov. 26), Gus Van Sant's dramatic feature about the triumphs and tribulations of the San Francisco activist Harvey Milk, who in 1978 took office as the country's first openly gay, high-profile elected official. Ms. Pill plays Anne Kronenberg, the leather-jacketed, biker-babe lesbian whom Milk hires as campaign manager to whip his fourth try for city supervisor into shape. This time he wins. Her opening obscenity is directed at a guy who has just tried to hit on her outside Milk's campaign headquarters. What was he thinking? you might well ask. Ms. Pill's appearance answers the question. The humor of the scene -- and of her role throughout the movie -- pivots on a sight gag, the contrast between her dry, four-letter-word delivery and her young, delicate face. She turns 23 this month. But with her wide eyes, chubby cheeks and cloud of strawberry-blond curls, she looks like the littlest angel in the school Christmas pageant. In fact, Ms. Pill, a Canadian, is an acclaimed stage actress. In February she will resume her co-starring role in Neil LaBute's ''Reasons to Be Pretty'' when it transfers to Broadway; two years ago her work in Martin McDonagh's ''Lieutenant of Inishmore'' earned her a Tony Award nomination.

MATTES--Lillian (nee Kreditor). Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, devoted mother of Fred (Barbara), Sandi Mattes - Schwartz (Joddy), and Walter Mattes, cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Jared and Gabe, dear brother of Larry and Alan Kreditor. Services Sunday 1pm ''Sinai Chapel'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

THE French-born Alexa Davalos has all she needs to be a major movie star: serious talent, camera chemistry and a blue-eyed, dark-haired beauty with lush yet chiseled features that recall the young Elizabeth Taylor. Yet at 26, she has five years of television roles on her résumé and three less-than-indelible films. Edward Zwick's ''Defiance'' (Dec. 31), a movie dominated by vivid male performances, may be the break she deserves. ''Defiance'' is based on the true story of the Bielski brothers, played by Daniel Craig, Liev Schreiber and Jamie Bell. After fleeing occupied Poland, they holed up in a forest in Belarus where they managed against horrific odds to create a coherent community, which continued to fight the Nazis and sustained itself with ingenuity. At war's end 1,200 Jews, including some very young and some very old, emerged from the forest.

WOOLLEY--K. Elisabeth Spring (98), of Morris Plains, NJ died peacefully on 24 October, 2008 at Arbor Glenn in Bridgewater, NJ. She was the daughter of John Christian and Estella Conaway Spring and was born in Morristown, OH. Betty was a graduate of the College of Wooster. She was the wife of Samuel Harry Woolley and mother of Thomas Welch Woolley, both deceased. She is survived by her brother John E. Woolley, her son Harold S. A. Woolley, grandchildren John S. Woolley, Susan P. Woolley, Sarah C. W. L. Abanor, Evan B. A. Woolley, and six great-grandchildren. Our family cherishes the memories of our lives together, her courage, steadfastness, wit, and love. We are better because of her and will miss her dearly. A service celebrating her life will be held at the Presbyterian Church of Morris Plains, NJ at 11am on the 15th of November, 2008. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Presbyterian Church of Morris Plains, 400 Speedwell Avenue, Morris Plains, NJ 07950.

In Douglas Sirk's ''Magnificent Obsession,'' Jane Wyman loses her husband, a beloved small-town doctor, because when his heart attack strikes, the one respirator is being used to resuscitate the village playboy, Rock Hudson, after a boating accident. But that's not all: Hudson (right with Wyman), after meeting the widow and realizing that his survival came at the cost of her husband's life, scrambles to make amends and inadvertently causes an accident that results in her blindness. In real life, those kinds of things don't happen every day; in the alternate universe known as Sirk World, they're business as usual. But even though Sirk's movies are frequently referred to as tear-jerkers, his approach to these crazy plots was quite dry and precise. And though ''Magnificent Obsession'' is not the greatest of Sirk's movies -- it doesn't have the enveloping dramatic sense of, say, ''Written on the Wind'' -- it is a sterling example of how he used visuals as ornate picture frames for outsize emotions.

BOSSAK--Myra, 90, beloved wife of the late Alvin, adored mom of Andrea and Richard Goldstein, Bill and Janet Bossak and Alicia. Loving grandmother of Jason, Kelly, Michael, Andrew, Jeremy and Jessica. Always in our hearts!

MONTANA--Dr. John B. AIDS specialist/Gay Activist, dies at 61. John Buscemi Montana, M.D., gay man, physician, generous humanitarian, New Yorker, world traveler and art aficionado, died at Mt. Sinai Hospital early Monday morning, September 29, 2008. The cause of death was acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), diagnosed less than one year ago. Dr. Montana was one of the first NYC physicians to identify and treat people with AIDS at the outset of the epidemic in 1981. He saw many cases among his friends and the gay men who comprised a large portion of his internal medicine practice on lower Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village. Dr. Montana, the son of Vanni Buscemi Montana and Helen Bortnovski Montana, was born in Huntington, Long Island, NY on March 13, 1947. His parents met in Europe during World War II. John's father was politically active in anti-fascist and socialist causes in his native Sicily; he died in 1991. John's own politics reflected his father's leftist leanings. His mother Helene perished in an apartment fire in February, 2003. A product of New York City public schools, Dr. Montana graduated from Harpur College (SUNY Binghamton) in 1969 where he majored in Science and Mathematics. He taught junior high school in Newark, New Jersey for two years before attending medical school. Dr. Montana graduated New York Medical College, Valhalla in 1975. After working at Cabrini-Stuyvesant Polyclinic, he opened his internal medicine practice in 1984. He was an attending physician at Cabrini Medical Center until it closed. Then he attended at St. Vincent's Hospital. Dr. Montana's illness caused him to close his medical practice in mid-December, 2007. The AIDS epidemic motivated him to focus his practice on treating AIDS-related opportunistic infections and cancers--which signaled fatality in less than two years at the beginning of the epidemic. His beloved partner, Jimmie Jackson, died from AIDS early on, and his death both devastated and deeply politicized John to continue the fight against AIDS. A firm proponent of safer-sex, Dr. Montana advised the Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC) on medical issues from its inception. He lectured on AIDS to community and professional groups throughout the city and was politically involved in ACT-UP and other AIDS-related organizations. John gave generously of his time and money to many gay community organizations including Senior Action in a Gay Environment (SAGE) and the Callen-Lorde Community Health Center. Until the end of his life, he maintained his conviction that the right-wing-dominated, federal government covertly propagated the epidemic, if not intentionally, then by intentional negligence--the ultimate goal being the elimination of the gay community. A gay-civil-rights activist and life-long Democrat, he was horrified at the response of the Reagan and Bush presidencies to AIDS and gay rights issues in general. He became inconsolable when his long-term partner, Daniel C., was deported from this country in 1999. Being bi-lingual, John was a benefactor to many in New York's Latino communities, and especially to Daniel's family. Dr. Montana often visited South America where he was a benefactor to small villages helping poor people at local medical clinics. Dr. Montana was a patron of the arts whether for museum-sponsored projects or for individual, fledgling, gay artists including E. J. Weiss, Ferron Bell and William Schwedler. He especially appreciated the works of Charles Demuth. John loved New York City, but enjoyed traveling throughout Europe and South America. John had many patients and friends in diplomatic positions who hosted him in Brazil, Italy, France, and Spain. Recently he traveled to Turkey, and only two weeks before his death, he returned from a cruise to Venice and Greece with two friends who made his trip as comfortable as possible. He fell critically ill upon his return. John Montana is survived by his brother Victor and his nephew John, both of New Hampshire. He is deeply mourned by his cousins Vicki De Bruin-Tarlow, Carol Daniels, Jesse Kamras, and also by his close friends John Helmuth, Ron Illardo, Philip Kayal, Jim D'Eramo, Patrick Hacker, Joe Nicholson and Angel, who with others, nursed him daily near the end. He is also mourned by his extended family in Finland and Israel, and by his friends throughout the world, but most particularly by the New York City gay community that he shepherded courageously through the AIDS epidemic--Dr. John Montana was an AIDS hero. Dr. Montana's Memorial Service will be Sunday, November 23 at 3:30pm in the Auditorium (10th Floor) of St. Vincents Hospital, 170 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Family and friends are welcome. Any questions should be directed to Philip Kayal: pkayal@comcast.net.

In Andover Borough, Josephine Zaleski, 66, cleared her driveway on Tuesday after a snowstorm left up to 14 inches in some parts of Sussex County and left tens of thousands of homes without electricity across the state.

I feel nostalgic about the person I knew as Gov. George W. Bush. I miss that guy. He was the best politician I ever saw. He really was ''a uniter, not a divider.'' He refused to kowtow to the far right. He worked with Democrats to strengthen public education, while Republicans were pushing vouchers. He had four vacancies on the Texas Supreme Court and he filled them all with centrist judges. The extreme right wing of the Republican Party was his enemy, not his ally. His administration was untainted by scandal. Karl Rove remained an outside consultant rather than a gubernatorial staffer. But when he reached the White House, Governor Bush vanished, to be replaced by President George W. Bush -- a person I didn't recognize. He was never to return.

HEALY--Joseph E. The Officers, Governors, members and staff of the General Society of Mechanics & Tradesmen of NYC extend our deepest condolences to the family of our beloved Past President and Brother, Joseph E. Healy. Brother Healy served with distinction as President of the GSMT in 1981 and was awarded the Founders Day Medal in 2000. From 1952-2008 he was an active member of the Society and served on the following commmittees: Library, Membership, Finance, Assistance, Executive, School, Past Presidents and as Inspector of Elections. Brother Healy's experience, guidance, warmth and smile greatly contributed to the betterment of the Society. He will be deeply missed and forever in our hearts. Gerard Drohan Jr. GSMT President

REIS--Muriel Henle, beloved wife of Arthur Reis, Jr., for 55 years, devoted mother of Arthur Henle Reis, Diane Mary Reis and Pamela Robin Reis, and a trail blazer for women in the legal profession, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 29th, at her home in Manhattan. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. A legal expert on the First Amendment, libel law and the Federal Communications Commission, she worked on legal issues confronting the broadcast industry for more than 50 years. Upon her graduation from Columbia Law School in 1949, she joined the American Broadcasting Company's legal staff, and in 1958 she went to work for Metromedia, Inc., first serving as assistant general counsel and assistant secretary. In 1974, she became vice president of Metromedia's WNEW - TV and was named associate general counsel of Metromedia in 1985. In 1992, she became vice president for legal affairs and East Coast litigation, at Fox Television (which had acquired Metromedia) and held that position until her retirement in 2005. During her tenure at Fox, she provided legal counsel to the upstart television program, ''A Current Affair'' and helped create the Fox News Network. In addition to being a leading First Amendment lawyer, she also worked as an on-air legal commentator, providing legal analysis during the murder trial of OJ Simpson. She hosted a public affairs program, ''Sunday Night with Muriel Reis,'' was a guest host of the program ''Midday Live,'' and made numerous appearances on ''Good Day New York'' as a legal expert. She was honored in 1994 by the New York Chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences by being inducted into the Silver Circle, an elite group of media professionals who made significant contributions to their industry and their community over a career span of at least 25 years. A lifelong and devoted New Yorker and a graduate of the Brearley School and Vassar College, she felt compelled to contribute to her community and the city she loved. She served on the New York Lawyers' Association Task Force on Judicial Independence and co-chaired the Media Subcommittee. She was a member of the Bar Association of the City of New York and served on its Communication Law Committee. In addition to her pioneering work as a lawyer, she was a passionate advocate for disadvantaged children. Her desire to help those in need led to her to contribute her time and talents to the Children's Aid Society. She was also a valued member of the board of directors of CASA, an organization of court appointed special advocates working on behalf of children in foster care, as well as a tenacious CASA volunteer, who used her legal skills to help improve the lives of others. She had a brilliant mind, a loving heart and a spirit of generosity that extended to all who knew her. She was loved by her four grandchildren, Chloe Reis Hyman, Mara Claire McCartin, Elisa Reis McCartin, and Lucas Henle Reis Hyman, her daughter-in-law Marianne McGeary Reis and her sons-in-law, Joseph A. McCartin and Kevin Hyman. She will be deeply missed by her family, friends and professional colleagues. Contributions in her memory may be made to CASA, Court Appointed Special Advocates for Children, 50 Broadway, 31 Floor, New York, NY 10004. REIS--Muriel. We mourn the death of a great friend of children and board member. Court Appointed Special Advocates

COMEDY BROOKVILLE Tilles Center for the Performing Arts ''An Evening with Colin Mochrie and Brad Sherwood,'' improvisation. Nov. 14 at 8 p.m. $27 to $65. Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, 720 Northern Boulevard, C.W. Post Campus, Long Island University. (516) 299-3100; www.tillescenter.org.

IT all started with her red Ettore Sottsass Valentine typewriter. Jane Schub, an illustrator and beauty entrepreneur, realized one day its color would make a wonderful nail polish. As would the pink in a Warhol painting she saw at the Dia:Beacon museum. ''It had black in it,'' Ms. Schub explained. ''It was a little off. It turned the corner from being pink to something very beautiful to look at.'' Those colors, along with six other similarly vibrant and somewhat eccentric hues (a midcentury modern orange, an Art Nouveau teal, a blue inspired by the depths of a lake at night) make up the first collection of StrangeBeautiful, a line Ms. Schub started with her business partner, Susan Strange. (''I like to say she's the strange, and I'm the beautiful,'' Ms. Schub said, laughing.) Free of any labels and elegantly packaged as a whole color story, StrangeBeautiful is like a Josef Albers art piece for your hand.

IN ''Nothing Like the Holidays'' (Dec. 12), Alfredo de Villa's tragicomedy of manners good and bad, the scattered members of a middle-class Puerto Rican family come together in Chicago for Christmas. Conflicted and voluble, they have their tensions -- the father (Alfred Molina) has a secret that is wrecking his marriage, the stockbroker son (John Leguizamo) and his hedge-fund manager wife (Debra Messing) are in no hurry to have a baby, and the actress daughter (Vanessa Ferlito) frets over her not-quite-Hollywood career. But these eruptions pale before the silence of the youngest, Freddy Rodriguez's Jesse, supposedly home for good after fighting in Iraq. The traumatized soldier turned specter at the family feast has been a dramatic staple at least since World War I. But Mr. Rodriguez keeps his performance fresh and surprising by rigorously reining in the drama. When he first sees the huge, homemade welcome banner draped across his parents' house, a flinch of revulsion registers in his eyes but nowhere else. Later, during the boisterous, often heated give and take among family members, Mr. Rodriguez does some of his best work, occasionally venturing a word or a joke but mostly keeping quiet as expressions of bemusement or disgust flicker across his face.

REINER--Estelle. Jazz singer, painter, and wife of comedy legend, Carl Reiner for 64 years, died on Saturday, October 25 at the age of 94. A talented artist and singer, Estelle was most widely known for the famous line -''I'll have what she's having,'' in son, Rob Reiner's film, ''When Harry Met Sally''. As an artist she had four one-woman shows of her paintings in the 1970's and at the age of 65 embarked on a new career as a jazz singer. Undeterred by any of the usual constraints of age, anxiety and later, illness, she developed her innate musical gifts and continued performing in clubs in New York and Los Angeles until the remarkable age of 93. Early in her new found career, the noted jazz critic, Leonard Feather, said of her work, ''Her bittersweet timbre suggests honey laced with vinegar. She has qualities many a seasoned pro would envy.'' A. James Liska of the Daily News in New York, wrote, ''she has wise and knowing phrasing, and a dry, wry, sly wit...'', and talented singer/songwriter, Dave Frishberg wrote, ''I feel comfortable entrusting my songs to Estelle Reiner, whose musicality shines through every track.'' She was a true original, a jazz stylist, part of whose repertoire included quirky, little known old jazz and blues songs which reflected her personal humor and uniqueness. Although she sang sweet ballads and standards, she fell in love with the Blues as a teenager, frequenting the Apollo Theater in Harlem, and did not shy away from raunchy old blues tunes such as, ''Handy Man,'' ''You Can Have My Husband (But Please Don't Take My Man''). Her friend, Dom Deluise never stopped talking admiringly about her sexy rendition of ''Don't You Feel My Leg,'' when well into her 80's. Jazz afficionado, David Chasman, also the former production head at United Artists, wrote of Estelle, ''More than innate musicality, more than seductiveness of voice, it is Estelle's undisguised, unequivocal, unabashed, unmistakable love for the songs that she sings, which makes her irresistible to her audience''. Her courage and determination also resulted in seven CD's, including, ''Ukulele Mama'', and a charming collection of standards called ''Grown Up Songs For Kids''. After raising her three children, acclaimed actor / director, Rob, Annie, a gifted writer and psychoanalyst, and Lucas, a painter whose work shows in the U.S. and Europe, Reiner began a career as a performer, studying with Viola Spolin and Lee Strasberg, and was soon cast in ''Fatso'', the directorial debut of her old friend, Anne Bancroft. Subsequently, she had a small part in Mel Brooks' film, ''To Be Or Not To Be'', and went on to do other performances in TV and film, including the often repeated line in ''When Harry Met Sally''. Born in Bronx, New York in 1914, the former Estelle Lebost graduated the National Academy of Design in the late 1930's and during World War II she was the first woman isometric draftsman to work at Sperry Rand, making blueprints for assembly workers building submarines and airplanes. She and Carl Reiner married on Christmas Eve, 1943, when Reiner was on a weekend pass from the Army. Her friends and family will remember her as a free thinker who never stopped searching, a courageous woman of extraordinary spirit and curiosity who lived life to the end. In addition to her children and husband, she also leaves nephews George Shapiro and Donny Shapiro, and five grandchildren, Jake, Nick and Romy Reiner, Livia and Rose Reiner. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Save The Children.
Film Stephen Holden

Three reasons that ''Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas!'' (1966) could be the most subversive American film ever: 1) The Grinch is a character in a Cormac McCarthy novel. Let's think for a minute. How come there's only one Grinch? No girlfriend, no cousins, no shrink. And what is he doing in Whoville? Why isn't there a Grinchville? If I were the only one of my kind, eking out a miserable existence in a post-apocalyptic cave with my dog without the benefit of any medication, I'd hang myself from the nearest tree, provided it had tinsel.

WITH her ethereal cobweb creations, the designer Raquel Allegra has taken the shredded-clothing trend to a philosophical new level. Each of her tops and dresses is cut, dyed, sewn and then deconstructed by hand; and when finished, each is a far cry from the Los Angeles County Jail T-shirt (size 8XL) it once was. ''I needed to start with really soft, well-worn white shirts, and they're a good source,'' explained Ms. Allegra, who at first wasn't comfortable using the prison garb, but unearthed the poetry while digging through a 1,000-pound bale of it. ''Taking something that has an ugly past and creating something beautiful out of it, it's a form of redemption,'' she said. Certainly fans like Erin Wasson (inset), Penélope Cruz and Heidi Klum are sold. Raquel Allegra pieces, $225 to $1,500 at Assembly New York, Maryam Nassir Zadeh and Curve; raquelallegra.com.

Young people have been finding their way to the Democratic fold, with the number identifying themselves as party members near a high not seen since Jimmy Carter was president. Historically, Americans over age 30 have been more inclined to identify themselves as Democrats than the younger set. Now there is only a three percent- age point difference between the generations. MARJORIE CONNELLY

The Russian avant-garde artist Kasimir Malevich painted this ''Suprematist Composition'' in 1916, the same year he wrote his Suprematist manifesto arguing for the pre-eminence of emotion in creating works of art. For years the painting, an abstract composition of bright blocks and rods of color, resided in the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam with 14 others by the artist.

''The ground is moving from underneath us.'' Diane Swonk, chief economist at the investment firm Mesirow Financial, on the state of the economy. ''A harsh storm seen only once in 100 years is raging.'' Prime Minister Taro Aso of Japan, as he unveiled the country's second stimulus package in about two months.

Admissions conventional wisdom: elite institutions want geographic diversity, so to improve your chances, move to an underrepresented state. Indeed, for Harvard's fall freshman class, the highest admittance rate was Wyoming's, at 18 percent: 11 applied, 2 got in. What does that tell you? Nothing really. In fact, New York, California and New Jersey are big feeder states to America's selective colleges and universities. They have high numbers of applicants but also respectable admittance rates, as the chart below indicates. All things being equal, says William Fitzsimmons, Harvard's dean of admissions, ''we do give a geographic tip to Boston and Cambridge and students from local communities.'' So if you must move, move to Massachusetts.

LOSSES Virginia had a lead with under a minute in regulation before losing in overtime to Miami. Florida State fumbled into Georgia Tech's end zone on its final drive, sealing a defeat.

EARLY last summer a New York collector negotiated a hefty guarantee from Christie's in consigning his 1964 ''Study for Self-Portrait'' by Francis Bacon for the fall auctions. In the months it took to hammer out details of the contract, economic turmoil grew so worrisome that Christie's got cold feet and withdrew the guarantee. The auction house persuaded the seller to offer the Bacon anyway, and it is one of the highlights of Christie's Nov. 12 sale. Experts say that the full-length portrait, in which the artist is shown sitting on a bed, his body twisted from head to toe, should sell for around $40 million.

AT the press walk-around of the Chevrolet Volt on Wednesday in Manhattan, Frank Weber, chief engineer on the project, mentioned something he called ''range anxiety.'' General Motors had occupied Terminal 5, a nightclub near the West Side Highway, for the occasion. And on a weathered plank floor under a large disco ball sat a prototype Volt, which does not go on sale until late 2010 (at the earliest).

THE sardonically titled ''Revolutionary Road'' (Dec. 26) is based on Richard Yates's acclaimed 1961 novel about the hollowness of the postwar American dream. Directed by Sam Mendes, the movie has the star power of Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet (Mr. Mendes's wife) reunited for the first time since ''Titanic.'' Now they are the miserably married Frank and April Wheeler, with Kathy Bates as the relentlessly chipper real-estate broker who sold them the house on the suburban street of the title. But it's the 34-year-old character actor Michael Shannon who provides some of the movie's most thrilling fireworks. Mr. Shannon plays the broker's son, John Givings, who has been hospitalized for paranoid schizophrenia and, by his own account, given 37 shock treatments. Looking ahead to a weekend furlough, his mother asks the couple if she and her husband might bring by their son for drinks. The Wheelers and his parents watch John apprehensively, as if he might do something dangerously, or just embarrassingly, abnormal. Mr. Shannon, acclaimed as another paranoid in William Friedkin's movie ''Bug,'' certainly doesn't look normal here. Neatly dressed in jacket and tie and standing very straight, he seems painfully self-conscious; at times a tense misery glitters in his eyes. But there's a hawkishness about him too and a touch of barely suppressed aggression. When Frank makes a glib reference to ''the hopeless emptiness'' of the country, John vigorously agrees, then pounces on the phrase and what it means to acknowledge its reality. He's taking Frank far more seriously than he deserves.
