RECYCLED At the Oregon College of Art and Craft in Portland, the art is in the making, and the materials. Amy Baker, a senior, made a purse as well as a dress and gloves from old sweaters. Some belonged to her grandmother and her aunt. ''They embroidered them, and now I have, too,'' she says. Zoe Umholtz, also a senior, used sweaters for a quilt. ''I don't know how much it has to do with the economy, or whether we're just more environmentally aware,'' she says, ''but reusing is becoming very popular.'' STITCHED Needlepoint belts are a preppy staple, especially in the South. At the University of Kentucky, well-dressed Wildcats wear them to fraternity formals as well as Keeneland, Lexington's thoroughbred track. ''I have the Kentucky logo, my initials and my fraternity on my belt,'' says Clay Willett, a junior and president of Phi Delta Theta. ''Your belt shows what you love, and what's unique to you.'' The belts are often gifts from girlfriends, but because they take so long to make, they can outlast a relationship. Stephen Carson's girlfriend worked naval flags (like his father's) and pirate flags into his belt. ''We broke up when she was in the middle of making it,'' he says, ''and then it took her six months to finish.'' The frat brothers now call them ''breakup belts.''

OVER the years, Tina Lutz and Marcia Patmos of the innovative knitwear label Lutz & Patmos have worked with an array of guest designers on their dream sweaters, Sofia Coppola, Jane Birkin and Richard Meier included. Now added to the list is the Amtrak train conductor Chris Waugh, whom Ms. Lutz met on her weekly commute from New York to her house in Rhode Island. ''He jokingly said that if we ever needed a guest designer, he knew the name of the sweater and the charity it would benefit,'' she said. ''We took him up on it.'' The Shoreline hoodie, named after the train Mr. Waugh works on, was inspired by his favorite Izod pullover and a sweatshirt of his daughter's, and is dedicated to his father, who has Parkinson's; $20 of each sweater's purchase price will benefit the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

JAY LENO Alaska's senator, Ted Stevens, has been found guilty on all seven felony counts of accepting over $250,000 worth of gifts and services from a contractor. But he says he will not step down and he will win re-election. Don't you love how these guys have no shame? In fact, have you heard his new slogan, ''Vote for Stevens, a man of convictions''?

WITH her ethereal cobweb creations, the designer Raquel Allegra has taken the shredded-clothing trend to a philosophical new level. Each of her tops and dresses is cut, dyed, sewn and then deconstructed by hand; and when finished, each is a far cry from the Los Angeles County Jail T-shirt (size 8XL) it once was. ''I needed to start with really soft, well-worn white shirts, and they're a good source,'' explained Ms. Allegra, who at first wasn't comfortable using the prison garb, but unearthed the poetry while digging through a 1,000-pound bale of it. ''Taking something that has an ugly past and creating something beautiful out of it, it's a form of redemption,'' she said. Certainly fans like Erin Wasson (inset), Penélope Cruz and Heidi Klum are sold. Raquel Allegra pieces, $225 to $1,500 at Assembly New York, Maryam Nassir Zadeh and Curve; raquelallegra.com.

One spring morning last year, I happened to be strolling through the Congressional cemetery east of Capitol Hill with the White House press secretary Dana Perino as she walked her dog. Ms. Perino was candidly describing the challenges of her job, which were only mounting as George W. Bush's approval rating continued to drop. Then she looked directly at me and said, ''But it's all worth it, because I so believe in the president.'' It would have been easy for me to dismiss Ms. Perino as a bright and likable but ultimately Kool-Aid-stricken peddler of talking points, were it not for two things. First, my interviews with current and former Bush staffers constantly veered off into similar testimonials. Their belief in Mr. Bush transcended ideology: as much as anything else, they just loved the guy. They loved how he treated the elevator man with the same courtesy as a foreign leader; how he often picked up the phone to congratulate the bride of a junior staffer; how he never pointed fingers, harbored grudges, snubbed, publicly belittled or boasted. Above all, they loved how they never had to worry which George W. Bush would show up to the Oval Office. It was fitting that he worked at a desk carved from a British warship, the H.M.S. Resolute -- clarity of purpose being the admirable flip side to his at times infuriating certitude.

My favorite holiday film experience was in the small Mexican town of Yelapa, south of Puerto Vallarta. I was in architecture school at the University of Texas at Austin, and my friend Suby and I had traveled south for Christmas break, taking a ''tourist'' boat across the Bay of Banderas. The funky old boat held only about 50 people, but there was a D.J. who thought he was on a Princess Cruise -- he loved coaxing the gringos into dancing. He shared his surefire secret to a good life: ''Move your bonbon and be happy.'' (It turns out he was right. If you say his line and actually move your bonbon, you pretty much have to smile.) After about an hour, we arrived at a remote fishing village without electricity or automobiles. Suby and I set up our tent on the beach under the coconut trees. We swam and hiked during the day, and at night the jungle roads were lighted with candelaria. We heard they were showing a movie near the church, so we hiked up the hill and sat on wooden benches in a tiny dirt plaza. We watched as two guys hung a sheet on the side of the building. A projector hooked up to a generator started playing the 1940 black-and-white ''Mark of Zorro,'' with Tyrone Power, above.

THE NEWS White House officials sought ways to provide emergency financial assistance to the deeply troubled auto industry that could help spur a proposed merger between Chrysler and General Motors. BEHIND THE NEWS Two options being discussed include making the carmakers' financing arms eligible to take part in the Treasury's $700 billion bailout program, originally intended mainly for banks and other financial institutions, or using a $25 billion loan program recently created by Congress to help them modernize plants. The failure of any of Detroit's big three would have far-reaching implications and could start a national pension-financing crisis.

A hint of schadenfreude might have been in the air when gossip-mongers delightedly spread the news that the Museum of Modern Art trustee Kathy Fuld and her husband, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, would be selling 16 postwar works on paper at Christie's on Nov. 12. Still, their offerings could well be among the biggest draws of the sale, potentially attracting old-time collectors who bowed out of the market when it became overheated. Far lower in price than paintings by these modern masters, they are seminal images of the highest quality that only occasionally come to market.

1. PAPER tale Sheets of paper were once handmade from discarded cloth. For the course ''Medieval and Renaissance Literature,'' at the University of Washington in Seattle, students envision the papermaking process, and how an apprentice might have swept up a cloud of dust, fly included, that then settled into an open vat of paper pulp. The paper -- and the fly -- ended up in the university's copy of ''La Civil Conversazione,'' a book of etiquette printed in Venice in 1579. 2. THE EVOLUTION OF KNOWLEDGE Because it was large, decorative and expensive, the Nuremberg Chronicle, a world history published in Germany in 1493, was treasured and preserved. About 700 copies remain from a print run of perhaps 2,100. How many of the 1,804 illustrations were colored by hand after printing depended on how much the owner could afford to pay an artist. The pictured drawing, based on a second-century map by Ptolemy, makes a teaching point for ''The History of Science'' at Smith College: though seafarers had long known otherwise, the belief that the world was limited to portions of Europe, Asia and Africa prevailed. Direct observation would soon replace the authority of classical learning, laying the basis for modern science.

A museum retrospective can often boost the value of an artist's work, particularly when the piece at issue is included in the show. That may explain why Jennifer Stockman, president of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, is parting with ''Pine House (Rooms for Rent),'' a 1994 painting by the Scottish-born artist Peter Doig.

There are many movies about the power and allure of movies, but there are few as dreamily, urgently poetic as the French director Olivier Assayas's 1996 ''Irma Vep.'' Maggie Cheung (above) plays herself, a Hong Kong movie star brought to Paris for a remake of Louis Feuillade's 1915 jewel-thief serial, ''Les Vampires,'' an enterprise with an impassioned but emotionally fragile director (Jean-Pierre Léaud) at the helm. ''Irma Vep'' is partly a comedy about the process of filmmaking, about making valiant recoveries from all the missteps along the way. But it's even more about watching movies, about the way glamour and art, dreams and obsession intersect and overlap before our very eyes.

The Next Stop column on Oct. 19 about Turin, Italy, as a center for food and design referred incorrectly to the Fiat factory in the Lingotto district that has been transformed into a mixed-use complex. The Lingotto Factory Conversion is a converted former Fiat plant; it is not a conversion of the original Fiat factory.

In the last two months, Senator Barack Obama has gained momentum in some states traditionally won by Republicans. A number of swing states are now either a tossup or leaning toward Mr. Obama in his race with Senator John McCain. The two maps below show estimates by The New York Times of how each state was leaning in the presidential election in August and now NEW MEXICO In 2004, President Bush won by a slim margin, making the state among the most competitive. Hispanics, who make up nearly 40 percent of the state's electorate, are a big factor. OHIO This is another state that Mr. Bush won narrowly. Campaign experts predict that Mr. Obama will benefit from the economic and mortgage crisis, which hit the state hard. NEW HAMPSHIRE Once reliably Republican, the state has become more Democratic. Mr. McCain is trying to bring it back into Republican territory, but polls show Mr. Obama ahead.

Can you make memorable entertainment with an amnesiac hero? The three films in ''The Bourne Trilogy'' (Tuesday), starring Matt Damon and Julia Stiles, make a good case. Also on Tuesday, the oddball Jean Shepherd holiday fave, ''A Christmas Story,'' receives a deluxe DVD release, while ''The Gregory Peck Film Collection'' arrives with, among others, ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' and Peck and Sophia Loren in the espionage shenanigans of Stanley Donen's ''Arabesque.'' Kino's ''Ultimate Edition'' of ''The General,'' Buster Keaton's flabbergasting and delightful Civil War comedy, comes out on Nov. 11. On that same day two studios release special editions: the Roman epic ''Quo Vadis'' from Warner Brothers and, from Paramount, Billy Wilder's ''Sunset Boulevard,'' the most acidic -- and baroque -- of all pictures about Hollywood.

OUTPOSTS If Americans are walking without a skip in their step, and maybe with a pitchfork in one hand, you can't fault them. Gallup found that one in five people say their finances have already been hurt ''a great deal.'' On Tuesday, consumer confidence fell to the lowest level since the Conference Board started tracking popular sentiment 41 years ago. A bare 11 percent say the country is headed in the right direction. We are not a nation of whiners, despite what Phil Gramm has said. But where does this jet stream of anxiety go after the election?

DORFSMAN--Lou, died on October 22, 2008 at the age of 90 of congestive heart failure. He is survived by his beloved wife of 68 years, Ann Hysa Dorfsman, cherished children, Elissa Dorfsman of Morrisville, PA, Mitchell Dorfman of North Ridge, CA, Neil Dorfsman of Yorktown Heights, NY and beloved granddaughter, Sophia Dorfsman. One of The Cooper Union's most successful graduates, Lou remained life-long supporter of his alma mater serving on its board of directors for many years. Upon being graduated from Cooper in 1939, he held a number of design jobs, until joining the United States Army where he contributed his considerable design skills during World War II. In 1946, Lou began a career at CBS that would span 41 years. He began in radio, then television, and was ultimately named Senior Vice President and Creative Director for Marketing Communications and Design. His talent was not limited to design; he was the ''idea man'' behind some of CBS's most successful advertising campaigns. Over the course of his career he was the recipient of numerous awards from the Art Directors Club, AIGA, as well as the Augustus St. Gaudens medal from The Cooper Union, the Master Series Award from the School of Visual Arts, and honorary degrees from the New School for Social Research and Long Island University. Among his most esteemed accomplishments was the ''Gastrotypographicalassemblage'' wall that graced the CBS cafeteria for more than two decades. He was actively involved in directing the restoration of this legendary masterpiece up until the time of his death. His commitment to excellence in design right down to the smallest detail was as strong at the end of his career as it was at the beginning. As a tribute to Lou, his family has requested that any donations made in his memory be sent towards the restoration of this iconic work of twentieth century design. Donations and comments may be made by logging on to the website www.karma411.com/ campaign/savelouswall. A memorial service will be held in early 2009, to be announced.

ROSENSTEIN--Sondra (Rubin), a longtime resident of Great Neck, NY, passed away on October 28, 2008. Sondra had an unparalleled zest for life. To her, family was most important. She was the beloved wife of the late Louis Rosenstein and the proud and loving mother of Paula Rosenstein Jonas of Scarsdale, NY, William Rosenstein of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and Myra Rosenstein Kleinman and son-in-law Bill of West Hartford, CT. She was the cherished grandmother of Daniel, Alison, Lauren, Rebecca, Jason, and Louis and step-grandmother of Seth, Aaron, and Gabe. Sondra is survived by her sister Bette Bronstein, sister-in-law Ellen Rubin, and brother-in-law Alexander Schure. She was the loving sister of the late Mollie Bier, Pearl Fass, Irving Rubin, and Dorothy Schure. She adored her many nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, and innumberable friends. Sondra assumed a position in Washington, DC, for what is now HUD, and she later served as an executive administrator in the formative years of the United Nations. It was there that she met Lou, her lifelong love who was Chief of Finance at the time. After raising their three children, Sondra joined Lou's accounting practice as office manager. Sondra had a life-long passion for bridge, which she shared with her late husband. She was a dedicated member of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck and was selfless in her commitment to its Sisterhood, serving as its treasurer for over two decades. Sondra was also Treasurer of the Women's Guild of the Great Neck Symphony. In addition, she was an active member of Hadassah and generously volunteered her time to several other community service organizations. Services were held on October 31, 2008 at Temple Emanuel. Contributions may be made to the Louis and Sondra Rosenstein Endowment Fund at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

AUSTRIAN--Sonia Grace., 75, died on October 28th after a heroic battle with cancer. She was loved by her daughters, Sarah and Susan, her son-inlaw Bayard Clarkson, Jr., and her grandchildren Emily and Matthew Clarkson. Sonia was born in New York City, graduated from Wellesley College and received her masters and doctorate in social work from Columbia University. She began her career in social work at Payne Whitney Clinic and ultimately became an Associate Professor of Public Health in Psychiatry at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University and the director of the Employee Assistance Program Consortium of Weill Cornell University Medical College, New York Presbyterian HospitalCornell Campus, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Rockefeller University and the Hospital for Special Surgery. An inspirational teacher, she had been an Assistant Professor and later was an Adjunct Professor at the Columbia University School of Social Work. At the EAPC, she developed an innovative placement program where she supervised and mentored Columbia social work interns. She had a private practice and was a prolific writer, having authored books that are widely used in social work education. She was a Fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine. Sonia will be deeply missed by her family and many friends. A memorial service will be held on December 6th at 2pm at All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to Partners in Health, 800 Boylston Street, Boston, MA 02199.

MOST of the gas stations in my neighborhood don't sell gas anymore. It happened gradually, but one by one they started roping off the pumps and putting up ''no gas'' signs. They do repairs and emissions testing, and some sell candy, but they don't pump gas.
MUSIC AS SANCTUARY To the Editor:

It's almost redundant to complain about the stupidity of pressure groups that attack movies over their pet issues. If you view movies solely as vehicles for the right or wrong message, you've already announced your inability to comprehend the ambiguities and complexities of art. Samuel Fuller's 1982 ''White Dog,'' which, in this Criterion DVD, is getting its first official release of any kind in its own country, has suffered particularly from pressure groups. In this adaptation of the Romain Gary story, Kristy McNichol, below, plays a young Los Angeles actress who takes in a pure white German shepherd stray only to discover that the dog has been trained to attack black people. The black actor Paul Winfield, in a tense performance, plays an animal trainer who is convinced that because racism is learned it can be unlearned, despite the skepticism of his colleague, played by Burl Ives.
Television Ginia Bellafante

During the last eight years, when I've mentioned to people that I'm completely fascinated by Laura Bush, most think I'm kidding. They see her as a traditional wife and mother, a gracious and well-mannered conservative. And while this might, depending upon whom you ask, be an admirable description, it doesn't tend to prompt fascination. Oh, I say, but there's so much more to her! Among my favorite facts: She spent her 20s working at ethnically diverse, low-income schools and was a Democrat until she married George Bush at the age of 31 -- after knowing him just 12 weeks. As first lady of Texas, she'd eat at hole-in-the-wall Mexican restaurants, shop at Wal-Mart and fly Southwest Airlines to visit friends. In the White House, in addition to organizing literary events that featured writers who have publicly disagreed with her husband's policies, she has been far more politically involved than people realize -- traveling to Africa and the Middle East to raise awareness for, respectively, AIDS and breast cancer, and advocating for the opposition leader of Myanmar, who has long been under house arrest.

Tuesday is indeed an "early November occasion in the U.S." If you happen to live elsewhere, Gail Collins explained the process concisely in her recent column:

When I rolled into Lamar, Colo., I knew for certain I'd reached the American West. I bought some groceries at a market, and the clerk's greeting almost knocked me off my feet. His voice boomed from a barrel chest, drawing its power from those wide open spaces. I'd seen my first cowboy hat in Kansas, but they were common now, and the men walked taller, talked louder and acted as cocky as ranch hands let loose on a Saturday night.

I had the good fortune recently to visit the exhibit about the Etruscans at the Palaexpo with a friend who teaches ancient civilizations at a university in Poland. There's obviously nothing like going to see an exhibit with an expert in the field and four hours whizzed by before I knew it. But beyond the convenience of having a walking encyclopedia to consult at my whim, what was truly pleasurable was pausing to really LOOK at the objects on display, and admire their exquisite craftsmanship.

PRESCOTT, Ariz. | 12:37 a.m. (Mountain Time) - Nov. 4, final stop! We're here at last on a cold November night in the old territorial capital of Arizona, the place where Mr. McCain has opened and ended almost all of his Senate campaigns. The Yavapai County Courthouse is awash with light. There's a big, noisy crowd gathered for the homecoming.

CHICAGO, June 2008 I was traveling with the Obama campaign in June and we ended the day early in Chicago. I wandered over to the legendary Billy Goat Tavern, immortalized by Mike Royko and John Belushi ("Cheezborger, cheezborger") for a burger and a beer and some chips (no fries). The dive is frequented by journalists and lawyers and other lowlifes, so I should have been on my guard. But I struck up a conversation with a gentleman at the next table, a rumpled but distinguished-looking older man who happened to have a copy of the neoconservative journal "Commentary" on the table next to his newspapers.

Ready to evaluate jokes in the name of science? I can't vouch for the funniness of all these offerings, but deciding whether they're funny can't be much less entertaining than pulling levers at the polls. These jokes, like the ones cited in my Findings column, were part of a study measuring the reactions of self-described liberals and self-described conservatives to humor. By now, many political junkies know the recent history of prediction markets. In 2004, the election-morning odds at Intrade, one of the best-known prediction markets, correctly forecast the presidential election in each of the 50 states. (In other words, President Bush won every state where traders gave him a greater than 50 percent chance of winning -- and the same was true of John Kerry.) In 2006, the Intrade odds correctly called each Senate race.

What would John McCain's victory map look like? Nate Silver, the electoral math wizard at FiveThirtyEight.com, used his computer to simulate the presidential election 10,000 times on Sunday. McCain won 624 times. In the most common result (occurring 169 times), "Obama wins everything that either Al Gore or John Kerry won," Silver writes. "McCain wins everything else."

After decades of decline, commercial shipping has returned to the Erie Canal, though it is a far cry from the canal's heyday. The number of shipments rose to 42 so far this year during the season the canal is open, from 15 during last year's season, which lasts from May 1 to Nov. 15. Once nearly forgotten, the relic of history has shown signs of life as higher fuel prices have made barges an attractive alternative to trucks.

And the right has no answer. [Philadelphia Inquirer]

Gambling on the outcome of the election spiked in the last day of the campaign, with large bets placed on the governor's race. The betting was done with a degree of discretion, out of sight of "Central Office men, who were looking for violators of the anti-betting law." In the presidential race, "the odds on Taft were too great to admit of much plunging for large sums." It is said that the odds were "7 and 8 to 1 on Taft, and that the men who were willing to back Bryan even at those odds were few." The anti-betting law "comes in" with regard to "layers," The Times report says. "Four years ago when a President was elected, three years ago when William R. Hearst ran against George B. McClellan [Jr.] for Mayor, two years ago when Hearst ran for Governor against Charles E. Hughes, Charley Maloney, champion election-bet stakeholder of the world, held forth behind a little desk in the lobby [of the Hoffman House] with roped-in lines of would-be bettors waiting to place their money, and big stacks of bills reposing gracefully at either elbow as an evidence of the interest the sports were taking in the election. There was nothing of that kind last night. Just before the hour when the usual crowd begins to assemble at the Hoffman House word went around that there would be Central Office men there to see to it that the anti-betting law was enforced. They were there all right. Even the newspaper men could not produce their pads to make a note without somebody looking over their shoulders to see if a bet was recorded." Below are the answers to this week's quiz, which challenged readers to spot problems of grammar, usage and style in recent passages from The Times. If you haven't tried the quiz yet, click here to see just the questions. Then you can return to this post to compare notes. 1. Since appearing gaunt and pale at a previous Apple introduction earlier this year, Mr. Jobs's health has been the subject of intense interest. The company and Mr. Jobs have responded by saying that he has not had a recurrence of pancreatic cancer, which he battled four years ago. Answer A classic dangler. Grammatically, this sentence suggests that ''Mr. Jobs's health'' appeared gaunt and pale. 2. When asked why Tynes thought he was going to play, Coughlin said: ''I have no idea. Did you read my statement? That's all I'm saying.'' Neither Tynes nor Carney were available for interviews after practice. Answer Make it, ''Neither Tynes nor Carney was available for an interview.'' In a neither-nor or either-or construction, the verb agrees with the closest part of the subject. (In this case, of course, both parts are singular.) 3. For 39 years as an educator, Robert Grandt has been promoting other people's books. So this year, when his daughter helped create a graphic novel of ''Macbeth,'' Mr. Grandt could not resist bragging a little in the newsletter he distributes as a librarian at Brooklyn Technical High School. He also placed a few copies of the book at a library display table, and posted a sign: ''Best Book Ever Written.'' If someone were interested, they got a book free. Answer Two problems in the short final sentence. First, there's no need for the subjunctive ''were.'' This is not a contrary-to-fact or hypothetical condition; it's just the past tense of ''If someone is interested ...'' Make it ''was.'' Also, ''someone'' is singular, so the plural ''they'' doesn't agree. One simple solution to both problems: ''Anyone who was interested got a free book.'' 4. Hopes that a security agreement between Iraq and the United States could be concluded swiftly receded Sunday as several of the leading Iraqi political parties, including some that had negotiated the agreement, appeared to back away from quick approval. Answer The placement of ''swiftly'' creates a trace of ambiguity. Does it modify ''concluded'' or ''receded''? 5. Mr. Allen seemed like he was trying to avoid doing much harm to Mr. Stevens. Asked by Joseph Bottini, a prosecutor, why he had engaged in a trade of automobiles that the government said was a sweetheart deal, Mr. Allen said, ''I liked Ted.'' Answer We avoid this colloquial use of ''like'' as a conjunction. We could simply say ''seemed to be trying.'' 6. Van Gogh discovered new colors everywhere, especially at night. Peripatetically, briefly yet fulsomely, this show explores his special relationship with darkness. It provides a view of the tenderness, urgency and brilliance at the core of his art, as well as the openness to nature that set it aflame. Answer While the sense of ''fulsome'' and ''fulsomely'' has shifted over time, the primary meaning suggests something offensively excessive. As The Times's stylebook says, we should avoid using the words to mean simply ''abundant'' or ''abundantly.'' 7. Judge Kearse, in the decision, cited the payments to the detectives as one factor that supported the prosecution's view that the conspiracy spanned the entire period of the indictment, from 1979 to 2005. She said that the jury had been told the principle purpose of the enterprise, as the indictment charged, was to generate money for the detectives, through legal and illegal activities. Answer Aaarrgh. Make it ''principal,'' not ''principle.'' (It would also be smoother to move the ''that'' in this sentence, so it reads, ''She said the jury had been told that the principal purpose '') 8. Mr. Kerry's hesitancy may have been related to his constitutional disposition for Marquess of Queensbury rules; the prep-school-bred, Yale-educated Brahmin was never comfortable with slashing attacks. But mostly his concern was strategic: Mr. Bush enjoyed approval ratings of 50 percent or more in the fall of 2004, and he was often ahead in the polls of a closely divided electorate. Answer It's ''Marquess of Queensberry.'' You could look it up, and for a phrase like this, we should have. (I'll leave aside the question of whether Kerry, a Catholic whose paternal grandparents were Jewish immigrants from Central Europe, is aptly described as a ''Brahmin.'') 9. The Mullers were studying small animals called tardigrades that exist in extreme environments, like the Sahara desert. Tardigrades can suspend their metabolism by dehydrating themselves and living in such a state for as long as 10 years. Answer As the stylebook notes, ''Sahara'' means ''desert,'' so ''Sahara desert'' is redundant. Nonetheless, we've used the phrase 10 times in the last year. 10. Mr. Villeneuve downloaded the messages, decrypted them and used machine translation software to convert the Chinese messages to English. He then used word frequency counts to identify the key words that were flagging the messages. The exact criteria used by the filtering software is still unclear, he said, because some messages on the servers contained no known key word. Answer The word ''criteria'' is plural, so make it ''are still unclear.''

All of the top videos in the news and politics category on YouTube.com for the 30-day period ended Sunday were about the presidential election. Most of the videos mirror the most negative election advertising and leaflets, with conspiracies, innuendo and derision aplenty, as in one questioning Barack Obama's citizenship or a report on Al Jazeera English portraying McCain-Palin supporters as racist. Some, like the presidential debate feed from C-Span, above, or the vice presidential debate, present a more even-handed look at the candidates. SHELLY FREIERMAN

PHILLIPS--Eleanor, died peacefully on November 1, 2008. She was 80 years old. Beloved and devoted wife to her late husband Robert with whom she shared 55 years of affection, travel, and joy. She is survived by her adored daughter Randi and her husband Robert Krieger. Also by her son Steven, his wife Wendy, and their daughters Rebecca and Elizabeth Phillips, the grandchildren who always had a most favored place in her thoughts. Her brother, Bernard Schwartz, survives and mourns her too. Born with a flair for beauty and kindness, she brought a special loveliness to the people and places she touched and that touched her. Generous, compassionate, loyal, funny and enthusiastic about all that is exquisite and happy in life, she had legions of friends who cared deeply for her and who were cherished in return. We will all miss her so. Services will be held Monday, 11:15am at Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Chemotherapy Foundation, 183 Madison Avenue, NY, NY.

As Mr. McCain's motorcade wound through golden-leaved valleys on Saturday in Bucks County, Pa., a pair of hunters watched from the side of the road, not so much clinging to their guns as keeping them tucked under their arms. Minutes later, when Mr. McCain arrived at a rally in Perkasie, several people held signs declaring ''Sportsmen for McCain'' and one man, in an homage to Ohio's best-known plumber, held one identifying himself as ''Joe the Hunter.''

Some runners used the New York City Marathon as an opportunity to proclaim their political preferences two days before the presidential election. Fred R. Conrad, photographing his 15th New York marathon, captured some of them after the race.

Crisis Counseling in Silicon Valley Entrepreneurs and investors in Silicon Valley are still shell-shocked from the dot-com collapse, and the latest economic crisis is bringing back memories of the wave of failed start-ups. This time, they have vowed to act quickly to avoid making the same mistakes again. At a ''crisis roundtable'' hosted by VentureBeat on Wednesday on how to manage start-ups during a recession, venture capitalists and start-up founders discussed how start-ups can survive and what they learned the last time around.
A girl in Ziarat, Pakistan, on Sunday, with a Koran found in the rubble of her house. An earthquake struck the region, near the Afghan border, on Wednesday, killing at least 215 people.

At a premiere on Saturday night for his film ''Two Lovers'' in Los Angeles, Joaquin Phoenix, above, confirmed that he had decided to give up acting to focus on his music career, The Associated Press reported. He even had the word ''goodbye'' written on his knuckles, to illustrate the point. ''I think it's just moving on,'' said Mr. Phoenix, the star of ''Walk the Line.'' ''It's rediscovering something else.'' He mentioned his plans last week at a fund-raiser in San Francisco, when he told Jerry Penacoli, a reporter for the television show ''Extra,'' that he was ''not doing film anymore.'' The reporter thought Mr. Phoenix was joking and laughed, prompting the actor to walk away. On Saturday, Mr. Phoenix, 34, said ''Two Lovers,'' a romantic drama directed by James Gray and also starring Gwyneth Paltrowand Vinessa Shaw, would be his last movie. It is due in theaters next year.

The actress Mackenzie Phillips, who starred in the television series ''One Day at a Time'' from 1975 to 1983, pleaded guilty to possession of cocaine and heroin on Friday, The Los Angeles Times reported. Ms. Phillips, 48, right, was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport in August when the drugs were found in her luggage. ''I want to thank the Los Angeles Police Department and the Airport Police for stopping me; they saved my life,'' Ms. Phillips said in a statement during the hearing at the Airport Courthouse. She was ordered to attend a court-monitored drug diversion program.

Plans to build Ireland's tallest building, a $250 million Dublin skyscraper that would include a recording studio for the band U2, have been put on hold, The Associated Press reported. The Dublin Docklands Development Authority said Friday that it was still committed to the U2 Tower by the River Liffey but that for now it had suspended negotiations with possible developers because of the grim economic environment. The building (above in a computer rendering), designed by the British architect Norman Foster, is to include luxury apartments and, at the top, a suspended pod that will house the recording studio.

PERKINS--Bradford Southworth, 53, died on October 28, 2008 after a valiant two year fight against brain cancer. He was the husband for 22 years of Sara and father of Marit. He is also survived by his parents Eleanor and John Perkins of New York, a brother John M. Perkins Jr., and a sister Eleanor P. Robinson, both of Connecticut, he was the son-in-law of Millie and Jack Rotchford of Spokane, Washington. Brad was a writer, producer and voice talent for KIRO News Radio for 28 years. He was also an active ice hockey player, serious mountain climber, bicycle rider, coach, scuba diver, musician and enjoyed the study of languages. He graduate from Brooks School, North Andover, MA and Lake Forest College, Lake Forest, IL. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 15 at 11am at Epiphany Episcopal Parrish, Seattle, WA. Donations in his memory may be made to: SMC Foundation, FBO Brain Cancer Research, 747 Broadway, Seattle, WA 98122-4307.

The Los Angeles Opera, which is scheduled to present its first cycle of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' in summer 2010, is expected to announce on Monday that more than 50 cultural and educational organizations in Los Angeles County will join it in a 10-week festival revolving around the opera performances. The events will include performances, lectures, films, museum exhibitions and a food festival. Among the participants will be the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Getty Center, the Los Angeles Public Library, the Center Theater Group and the American Jewish University. The festival and three performances of Wagner's four-opera cycle are scheduled for April 15 to June 30, 2010. Before that, the Los Angeles Opera will present separate performances of the first two parts of the opera cycle, ''Das Rheingold'' and ''Die Walküre,'' beginning this February. The third and fourth parts, ''Siegfried'' and ''Götterdämmerung,'' will be presented in the 2009-10 season, followed by the complete ''Ring'' cycle, with all four parts performed in order over several days.

9 P.M. (Bravo) FIRST CLASS ALL THE WAY Partridge hunting, anyone? Flying in the face of the economic meltdown, this new series is an exercise in excess. Sara Ryan Duffy, right, recently crowned an A-list travel agent by Travel & Leisure magazine, fulfills the outrageous demands of her well-heeled clients, starting by sending five wealthy, presumably real housewives (it's Bravo, after all) to Monaco for a private tour of that royal family's art collection and a meeting with Albert II, Prince of Monaco. Watch it and weep. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY A final election poll, and Darrell Hammond and Fred Armisen of ''Saturday Night Live'' do their thing.

Two war films, ''Resolution 819,'' about the Srebrenica massacre during the final months of the 1992-95 war in Bosnia, and ''Opium War,'' set in present-day Afghanistan, took the top awards at the Rome film festival on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. The jury prize went to ''Opium War,'' by the Afghan filmmaker Siddiq Barmak, about two American soldiers lost in the poppy fields of Afghanistan. ''Resolution 819'' won an award based on votes by the public. The film, a French-Polish-Italian production directed by the Italian director Giacomo Battiato, is based on the true story of a policeman sent by the United Nations' highest court to investigate the disappearance of 8,000 Muslim men and boys from Srebrenica, after the town fell to Bosnian Serb forces.

CHU--Charles Chi-Jung, died on October 30, 2008 in New London, CT. Born in China in 1918, Chu taught for many years at Yale and Connecticut College, where he retired as Prof. Emeritus in 1984. An accomplished painter and calligrapher, Chu is survived by his wife Bettie Chu, four children, eleven grandchildren. His art can be seen at www.littlefrog.com. When you speak thousands upon thousands of words in public each day, some of them are bound to come out a bit twisted from time to time -- especially during the grueling, sleepless, what-state-are-we-in final days of a presidential campaign. Most of the time they are not so much gaffes as odd verbal hiccups. So there was Senator John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee, on Sunday in Wallingford, Pa., offering up a novel description of supply-side economics with his observation that ''keeping taxes low creates jobs, keeps money in your pants and strengthens our economy.''

Memorial Service to be announced. Donations to Action to Cure Kidney Cancer (ackc. org) most appreciated.

John McCain, a proudly superstitious man, spent Sunday holding the final town hall of his campaign, a tribute to the forum he has become so identified with during his two runs for president. And Mr. McCain did it in New Hampshire, which delivered primary victories for him in 2000 and 2008. Though this state went Democratic in 2004, he is hoping that it will support him on Tuesday. ''My friends,'' he said, ''the Mac is back!'' Barack Obama is perhaps not as superstitious, appearing at a packed-to-the-rafters campaign rally in Cleveland with Bruce Springsteen. You would find nothing but respect here for Mr. Springsteen, but let it not be forgotten that he appeared at a similarly packed rally for John Kerry in 2004, who went on to lose, as the Republican National Committee quickly pointed out.

CHESNEY--Malcolm McCay Jr., 87, died October 30th at home of Alzheimer's Disease. He was a man of exceptional charm, warmth and joie de vivre. He had a consistent commitment to community and environmental issues, and a strong sense of professional integrity. Malcolm was born in Pittsfield, Massachusetts and educated at Exeter and Yale. He served in the army, during World War II. Soon thereafter he came to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company as an economic research assistant, and settled in Brooklyn Heights. He was instrumental in the successful effort to create the first historic district in Brooklyn. Malcolm remained with the gas company for almost 40 years, retiring as a Senior Vice President. He was always engaged with public utility industry organizations, and professional economic and planning associations. His civic activities included directorships in the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, the Brooklyn Red Cross, Flowers With Care and memberships in Community Board #

We are running out of decks. This is the last day before Election Day, and the daily countdown ends. For the candidates now it is all about turnout and getting out base voters; there aren't many people left to convince. Senator John McCain is doing a seven-state swing -- airport hangar rallies -- while Senator Barack Obama is in Florida, Virginia and North Carolina, an appropriately aggressive finale to his campaign.

It is Washington's last home game before a presidential election, a game that until 2004 was known for its predictive powers. If the Redskins won, the incumbent party stayed in power; if they lost, the incumbent party lost. There will be a tightly fought, grueling battle on the field, too. Clinton Portis takes his five-game streak of 120 or more rushing yards to a Pittsburgh defense that has not allowed a 100-yard rusher since Week 15 of last season. The Steelers' two losses have come against N.F.C. East teams, but this is the first time they have faced one that does not have a mortifying pass rush. Ben Roethlisberger has been sacked 23 times -- 13 times by N.F.C. East teams -- but Washington has only 10 sacks this season. This is the teams' first meeting in Washington in 20 years. Barack Obama will be the first African-American president of the United States, but his achievement is "even more remarkable" than that, writes David Boaz of the libertarian Cato Institute at the Cato-at-liberty blog.

Notes for the New Punditry: Orin Kerr, a George Washington University law professor who blogs at The Volokh Conspiracy, highlights some of "the new ground rules" for political commentary during an Obama administration. Kerr writes:

A magnificent victory for Barack Obama. And bear in mind that the campaign, in its final stages, was really about different philosophies of governing. This wasn't like the 2004 campaign, which was essentially fought over fake issues -- Bush running on national security and social issues, then claiming that he had a mandate to privatize Social Security. In this election, Obama proudly stood up for progressive values and the superiority of progressive policies; John McCain, in return, denounced him as a socialist, a redistributor. And the American people rendered their verdict.

With the Obama victory the big news and the Senate scramble the undercard, the House has been relegated to bit player in tonight's drama. However, there was a watershed development in the peoples' branch: Chris Shays of the Connecticut, the last Republican in the Northeast, has been defeated. And while Democrats may be pleased, not all conservatives are crying in their beer, including W.C. Varones at Polipundit:
History will record this as the night the souls of black folk, living and dead, wept - and laughed, screamed and danced - releasing 400 years of pent up emotion.

If Barack Obama wins the presidency tonight, as seems very likely, what should conservatives fear most about his administration? Reason's Nick Gillespie, no liberal Democrat, is having a hard time finding much to worry about. Gillespie writes at Hit and Run, Reason's staff blog:
Updated, 12:33 a.m., Nov. 5 | The bustling scene at Times Square on Tuesday night was a cross between a warm New Year's Eve and a Super Bowl party filled with enthusiastic Giants fans.

Updated, 12:50 a.m., Nov. 5 | Bolstered by a surge of new voters, Democrats won a majority in the New York State Senate on Tuesday night, putting the party in control of both houses of the Legislature and the governor's office for the first time since the New Deal.
Well, Ohio going to Obama may have taken most of the suspense out of the evening, but the Democrats' effort for a filibuster-proof 60-seat majority in the Senate remains in the balance. Or does it?

This is a victory not for one man or one party, but for opportunity itself. Right now I'm trying to get my 11-year-old daughter to bed, but she is celebrating and insists that she wants to wait up half the night. Several times this fall she and a friend spent their afternoons and weekends selling lemonade and cookies to raise money for Obama, and she's just thrilled at what appears to be the outcome. It's clear that she'll be telling her grandchildren about this night.

Polling place foul-ups are not uncommon. But advocates say they are too common among a certain set of voters: transgender people who have changed their first names to match their new sex. Voter registries often carry the transgendered voter's birth name, which doesn't match their newly adopted names. As a result, many of these voters are turned away at the polling place and often shy away from trying to correct the problem immediately and cast their votes, said Michael Silverman, executive director of the Transgender Legal Defense & Education Fund, in Manhattan. Mr. Silverman estimated that there are "tens of thousands" of transgender people in New York City and that many will have problems voting because of problems with mismatched names.

It's been widely suspected that applications to M.B.A. programs are inversely correlated to the state of the economy, with several schools expecting record numbers for the class of 2011. The theory goes like this: the opportunity costs of going back to school - the forgone salary, bonuses, promotions, etc. - are much lower during the bad times. Therefore, returning to school becomes a relative bargain, positioning students for greater success when the economy recovers (ideally before graduation).

For 10 years, Jennifer Ochoa has been a huge help to mothers of newborns. Here she is caring for twins, Cyrus and Julian Roley. Before they were born, their mother, Carla Roley of Park Slope, Brooklyn, who would be raising them on her own, spoke with a number of other mothers of twins, and their advice was unanimous: get help. Through the Park Slope Parents Web site, she found Ms. Ochoa, a live-in certified baby nurse who for three months helped to get Cyrus and Julian up for their feedings at night and put them back to sleep, and to soothe them when they were upset so that Ms. Roley could rest. Now, nearly eight months after the twins' birth (Julian is two minutes older) and five months after this picture was taken, during one of Ms. Ochoa's last days with them, Ms. Roley says of Ms. Ochoa's assistance, "With Jennifer at my side, I was able to enjoy the first days and weeks of my babies' lives without the delirium of sleepless nights."

This new article from the Economist describes another pillar of the nonproliferation regime that is at risk. It depicts a schism among members of the Nuclear Suppliers Group, which controls trade in nuclear materials, equipment, and technology. China's recent statement that it will sell two new nuclear reactors to Pakistan is one source of strain. Another issue is that some countries - notably Canada and Brazil - oppose criteria proposed this year for curbing trade in technologies for enriching uranium or producing plutonium. A third source of tension is the United States' nuclear deal with India, which allows trade in nuclear materials despite the fact that India never signed the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty.

Conservatives are utterly convinced that the mainstream news organizations have been deeply unfair to the Republican ticket, and they have some points they can cite as evidence. For example, the Project for Excellence in Journalism found that there were twice as many favorable Obama stories after the convention as favorable McCain ones. Conversely, twice as many McCain stories were negative. The Center for Media and Public Affairs found that network TV coverage of Obama was 65 percent positive, compared to 31 percent positive for McCain. As Politico.com put it: "in the closing weeks of this election, John McCain and Sarah Palin are getting hosed in the press." Indeed, one of the editors of Politico.com received a scolding note about bias from his own mother.

If you haven't read Bottom Billion, do so!

Eugene Robinson uses his column in The Washington Post to reflect on the prospect that, at the end of the day today, a black man will be president of the United States. "Whoever wins this election, I understand what Barack Obama meant when he said his faith in the American people had been 'vindicated' by his campaign's success," Robinson writes. "I understand what Michelle Obama meant, months ago, when she said she was 'proud of my country' for the first time in her adult life. Why should they be immune to the astonishment and vertigo that so many other African Americans are experiencing? Why shouldn't they have to pinch themselves to make sure they aren't dreaming, the way that I do?"

Tennessee Coach Phillip Fulmer has been forced out after 17 years that included a national championship. Fulmer, 58, his voice cracking and pausing to keep his composure, announced Monday at a news conference that he will step aside at the end of the season. He said he was “accepting the university’s decision.” Fulmer had a 150-51 record with the Volunteers and won the national championship in 1998.

Defensive end Auston English could miss the next two games for No. 6 Oklahoma after spraining his left knee. English has 4 ½ sacks and 27 tackles in nine games.

A second investigation into whether Gov. Sarah Palin abused the powers of her office to pursue a personal vendetta has found ''no probable cause'' to believe she violated an Alaska ethics law by trying to get her former brother-in-law, a state trooper, fired or by actually dismissing the state's public safety commission, who was the trooper's boss. The conclusion by an independent investigator for the state Personnel Board contradicts a determination last month of an inquiry by the Alaska Legislature that Ms. Palin had breached the ethics act by pressing to have the trooper, Michael Wooten, dismissed. That investigation found, however, that the governor was within her right to fire her public safety commissioner, Walt Monegan.

HOCHBERGER--Jane Weiss, died November 2nd in Bryn Mawr, PA at age 83. Loving and beloved wife for 58 years of Samuel of Newtown Square, PA, adored mother of Ruth (Martin Flumenbaum) of New York, NY, Larry, of Bryn Mawr, PA and Michael (Shelley Dropkin), of New York, NY, doting grandmother of Martha, David and Judy Flumenbaum, and Nathan, Rachel, Jacob and Eric Hochberger, sister-in-law of Laura Regenbogen and Beatie Minstein. Former board member of Main Line Reform Temple, Wynnewood PA. Contributions to the Hunter College Mother's Day Scholarship Fund, Attn: Diana J. Robertson, 695 Park Avenue, Room 1313B East Building, New York, NY 10065. Services private.

A British jury investigating the death of a special-effects technician on ''The Dark Knight'' was told that he was killed in an accident during the shooting of a stunt, The Guardian reported. Conway Wickliffe, 41, was killed on Sept. 25, 2007, during the filming of a chase sequence for ''The Dark Knight,'' the blockbuster Batman movie directed by Christopher Nolan. On Monday the jurors at a coroners' court in Surrey, England, were told that Mr. Wickliffe had been riding in the back seat of a Nissan four-wheel-drive pickup driving parallel to a stunt car; the vehicle carrying Mr. Wickliffe crashed into a tree when it missed a 90-degree turn. The jury will rule on an official cause of death. A stunt technician who had worked on ''Casino Royale,'' ''Children of Men,'' ''Batman Begins'' and other films, Mr. Wickliffe was honored in the closing credits of ''The Dark Knight,'' along with the actor Heath Ledger, who died before the film's release.

BURRILL--Claude W., passed away October 20, at home in Coralville, IA. Claude was born February 19, 1925 in Akron, IA. He earned his BA, MS, and Ph.D. in Math at the Univ of Iowa, and a Fulbright to Manchester University UK, where he met his first wife Kathleen, with whom he raised two daughters before divorcing. Claude settled in the NYC area (Bronx then Tenafly, NJ). He taught at NYU/Bell Labs, and IBM's Systems Research Institute, with visiting appointments at Columbia, Dartmouth, and National University of Singapore. He lectured/consulted globally and authored eight books on management, computer modelling, decision support, project management and quality, pure mathematics, probability and statistics. Claude served on the Board of Trustees and as Acting President at William Paterson College. In 1991, Claude and his wife Tina moved to Iowa City, where he co-authored two books on total quality management and statistical process control, and taught at the University of Iowa. Claude was a gifted mathematician, with expertise in real analysis, measures, integration and probability, which he skillfully applied to project management and process improvement. Although suffering from a neuro-degenerative disorder in his final years, Claude continued to enjoy travel and hiking, and company of family and friends. He is survived by his wife Tina, children Anne, Jane and Thomas, sons-inlaw, and four grandchildren. Claude's remains were buried in Akron Riverside cemetery, Iowa. Memorial donations: Preucil School of Music, 524 N. Johnson St, Iowa City, IA 52245.
STILLER--Fanny Licht, age 88. Wife of Richard, mother of Helen and Michael, grandmother of Jonathan and Tali. She was a rebel girl, devoted mother, beloved comrade.

LANE--Dr. Patrick Richard, died peacefully on Sunday, November 02, 2008. He was an extraordinary psychologist who was deeply dedicated to the well-being of his patients. Dr. Lane will be greatly missed by his family and friends, who he sustained with his incomparable sense of humor and enduring wisdom. His generosity of spirit enlivened our days. Dr. Lane's love for his dogs and his work with abused animals were hallmarks of his expansive nature. He was a pioneer and leader in providing psychological services to AIDS patients and their partners. It was an unparalleled gift to be cared for and loved by this great person. The loving glow that defined his presence will live on in the hearts of all he touched. Dr. Lane was a resident of New York City and East Hampton, New York, born on June 22, 1939 to Marjorie and Thomas Lane in Brooklyn. He was raised in Queens Village, New York and Manasquan, New Jersey. Dr. Lane was a graduate of Manasquan High School, Seton Hall, Monmouth University, Fordham and New York Universities. He was past Assistant Director of ChildAdolescent Service at Maimonides Mental Health Center, Brooklyn and Clinical Supervisor at Bellevue Medical Center. He was on the original Board of Directors of the New York State Psychologist Association Task Force on AIDS, and Director of its Referral Service which oversaw and connected hundreds of AIDS patients to low fee psychotherapy. Dr. Lane was also co-author of Hip Reader I and II, an innovative phonics approach for non-reading inner-city adolescents. He served as President and Vice President of The Psychoanalytic Society of New York City Post Doctoral Program in Psychoanalysis, as well as a member of its Senate. Dr. Lane is survived by his partner, Raphael Sullivan; his twin brother Dr. Peter B. Lane and his wife Patty, of Denton, Texas; his sister-inlaw Alice Lane; six nieces and nephews, six grandnieces and -nephews, many cousins, and dear friends. His older brother, Thomas J. Lane, of Rochester, New York predeceased him. Viewing will be on Thursday November 6th from 5-9pm, with services at 7:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Donations in his name may be made to any animal rescue organization.

Shakir Stewart, below, an executive vice president at the Island Def Jam Music Group who succeeded Jay-Z at the helm of the hip-hop label Def Jam Recordings in June, was found dead in his home in Marietta, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta, on Saturday. The Associated Press reported that the police said Mr. Stewart, 34, had died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Mr. Stewart had been involved in the music industry since his days as a party promoter at Morehouse College; he is credited with signing Beyoncé to Hitco Music Publishing, where he worked as an executive, and with signing Young Jeezy and Rick Ross to Def Jam. In a statement, Def Jam called Mr. Stewart a ''truly incredible friend and father who was an inspiration to not only our artists and employees, but to his family and the many people who had the privilege of counting him as a friend.''

The Afghan National Army, a training team from the United States Marines, and a United States Navy corpsman conducted a joint patrol on Monday in Kamu, near the Pakistan border, to blow up a cave used by Taliban fighters as a firing position.

HAEMMERLI--Alice Braverman who died on October 25, was a lawyer, scholar and teacher, who took great delight in both legal argument and in her writing on intellectual properties. In the job she held as Assistant Dean of International Programs and Graduate Legal Studies at the Columbia University School of Law (from which she retired in 2006), she was responsible for both the graduate and international programs. In that capacity, she guided many foreign post-graduate students through the rigors of the American system, and many of them from Jerusalem to Paris, Rome, and South Africa, will remember her with great admiration and affection. Her articles were published in numerous law reviews and she was cited by the Supreme Court on a variety of intellectual property issues. Before Columbia, Alice was a member of the Law Firm of Debevoise and Plimpton where she specialized in intellectual property. Prior to that she was the Director of Public Policy at Chase Manhattan Bank. Most recently, she worked in Pennsylvania for Barack Obama's election. Born in New York City, Alice attended Hunter College High School, and went on to graduate summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Vassar College. She was a brilliant student and won both a Woodrow Wilson Scholarship, and a Fulbright Fellowship which took her to the London School of Economics for her first MA. At Harvard, she earned a second MA in International Relations as well as her Ph.D. in International Law. Her Juris Doctor was granted by Columbia. It was in Cambridge that she met her late husband, Alfred Haemmerli, and they had a long and fruitful marriage until Freddy's death in 2001. Their daughter Justine, who was the most important thing in their lives, continues the family tradition as a dedicated teacher. Her work was important to Alice, but she also took huge pleasure in family, friends and her pastimes, especially riding her horse, French, as well as travel, reading, and music. She is survived by her beloved daughter, Justine, her sisters, Laura Shannon and Marta Bartolozzi, twin brother David, niece, Heather Shannon and dearest lifelong friend, Reggie Nadelson. She will be sorely missed by all those whose lives she touched.

Before Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, there was Gov. Tim Pettigrew of New York, the first black presidential nominee for the Democratic Party. But that happened in 1976, and in the pages of ''Treasure Chest,'' a comic book distributed to Catholic school students around the country. ''It's been on the edge of reality,'' Berry Reece, author of the series, said of the current election.

Winning the White House is never easy, even those who manage it rarely command the overwhelming support of the American people. No president has managed to garner more than 51 percent of the popular vote in the past 20 years. In fact, of 15 presidential elections since World War II, only six winners actually cracked 51 percent -- Dwight D. Eisenhower in both 1952 and 1956, Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, Richard M. Nixon in 1972, Ronald Reagan in 1984 and George Bush in 1988.

The diplomatic tangle between Venezuela, Argentina and the United States reached a new pitch on Monday when a jury in Miami convicted a wealthy Venezuelan businessman of acting as an ''unregistered agent'' of Venezuela on American soil. The matter, known in Latin America as ''Suitcasegate,'' started last year with the discovery of a mysterious suitcase filled with $800,000 in cash at an airport here. But it has erupted into a scandal that has aggravated tensions between the United States and its neighbors to the south.

TRADEMARK BATTLE Brewed in a Bottle

A judge in Atlanta ruled Friday that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King's daughter must continue to catalog the personal papers of her mother, Coretta Scott King, that are being sought by feuding factions of the King family, The Associated Press reported. The Rev. Bernice King and her brother Martin Luther King III were sued by their brother Dexter King, who wants them to turn over papers for a biography of their mother that the Penguin Group was planning to publish; the book deal, valued at $1.4 million, fell through in October when the King siblings missed a deadline to provide those papers to the book's author, Barbara Reynolds. Once the cataloging of Coretta Scott King's possessions is completed, a judge will rule whether her papers are the property of the Martin Luther King estate, which Dexter King controls.

EARLY FINISH Nadine McNeil, 42, who had a stroke when she was 8 and lost the use of her right arm and right leg, competed in the handcycle division of the marathon and finished in an unofficial time of 3 hours 54 minutes 59 seconds. Her 18-year-old son, Tyler, who is autistic, made his marathon debut, running a time of 5:07:48. But McNeil missed her son's finish. She said she thought his time would be about six hours, so she was nervously waiting in a finishers' tent at 72nd Street and Central Park West. As she was about to head back to the finish line, Tyler arrived with his guide.

2008 was the year that YouTube became a mainstream tool for political communication. Most-Watched Obama Video: Senator Barack Obama's sweeping exploration of race in America, delivered in March, in the midst of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. controversy. More than 5.1 million views, despite its length -- 37 minutes, 39 seconds -- marking YouTube's emergence as a vehicle for substantive discourse, not just silly clips.

Two of the 37,899 finishers of the New York City Marathon on Sunday died after crossing the finish line, according to the New York Road Runners, the organizer of the event. The Fire Department added that at least two others collapsed on the course with heart attacks before they were revived and taken to a hospital. ''For us at New York Road Runners, there is nothing harder than when two of our athletes don't return home,'' the race director, Mary Wittenberg, said Monday morning.

HAMBURGER--Martin, passed away on Friday, October 24 in Miami, FL. He was born in New York City in 1920, graduated from CCNY and received his doctorate in education from Columbia University. He was a long-time professor of counseling at New York University, consultant in career planning and counseling at the New School for Social Research, visiting professor at Hadassah University in Israel and, most recently, instructor at Florida International University. He served as a staff sergeant in the U.S. Army. He was a world traveler and a passionate theater patron, regularly attending productions in London, New York and at regional companies and festivals. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Beverlee Kagan and is survived by brother Samuel, sister Rose De Piola (Frank), stepson Steve Kagan (Ann Marie), stepdaughter Lori Kagan-Moore (Patrick), grandchildren Caroline Kagan, Hannah Kagan Moore and Emma KaganMoore, nieces Leonora De Piola Smook and Roberta Considine, nephews Frank and Joe De Piola and several grandnieces and nephews. A memorial will be held at 2pm November 16 at 3 Grove Isle Drive, Coconut Grove, FL. Donations in Dr. Hamburger's name may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

POSTRACE MEMORIES Kara Goucher's 30-year-old body hurt as never before Sunday, a memento of her first marathon. She finished third, in 2:25:53, making her the third-fastest American woman, behind only the Olympic medalists Deena Kastor (2:19:36) and Joan Benoit Samuelson (2:21:21). ''I wasn't able to get any liquids in after 10 miles,'' Goucher said Monday. ''I couldn't keep anything down. I knew it would cost me, and three miles from the end it was very hard.''

KELSEY--Anne Talcott. The Jay Heritage Center is deeply saddened by the passing of a dear friend and member, Anne Talcott Kelsey. We will remember her for her vitality, intelligence, humor and a life lived with grace, as well as her enduring commitment to protect the natural beauty and character of the Rye community she loved. It was a privilege to honor her in 2007 for her personal efforts in preservation and conservation. She will be greatly missed and we extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, children, family and friends. Suzanne Clary, President Jay Heritage Center KELSEY--Anne Talcott. After a long vibrant life and a brief illness, Anne Talcott Kelsey died on October 31, 2008. Anne, the youngest of four daughters, was born March 29, 1927 to James and Mary Talcott in New York City. The following year, the family moved to Bramble Hill in Rye, New York, where, surrounded by flower, herb and vegetable gardens, Anne developed her life-long love of gardening and nature. After attending Rye Country Day School, she graduated from the Shipley School and then from Finch Junior College. On September 7, 1947 Anne married Harvey Marion Kelsey Jr. in her childhood gardens, and two years later returned to Rye where they raised their five children. She took great joy in tennis, sailing, skiing and backpacking, and especially in sharing these interests with her family. She was an active member of her community, involved in the Rye Nature Center, TWIG and the Rye Garden Club. She was a trustee of United Hospital, St. Lukes - Roosevelt Hospital and the Miriam Osborn Memorial Home; a member of the Board of Managers at the Osborn; and active in the American Hospital Association. One of her pleasures was attending the Philharmonic regularly with her friends. After her five children moved on to their own lives, she continued to rejoice in the company of her growing family and fifteen grandchildren. Anne is survived by her husband Harvey M. Kelsey Jr., her children Harvey Kelsey, Jim Kelsey, Peter Kelsey, Karen Thomas, Peg Cornwell, and their spouses. She also is survived by 14 grandchildren and her sister, Joan Batchelor. She is predeceased by her parents, two of her sisters and her grandson Tanner Cornwell. Her memorial service will be held at Resurrection Church in Rye, New York at 11am on Wednesday, November 5, 2008. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Jay Heritage Center, 210 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York 10580.

One of the most memorable moments in the 1992 presidential campaign came on an MTV show when a young woman cheekily asked Bill Clinton: Boxers or briefs? It took until the last day of the 2008 campaign for the subject of undergarments to come up again, and it was an MTV interviewer who brought it up.

The once-soaring superhero drama ''Heroes'' continues to come crashing back to earth. Two of the show's co-executive producers, Jesse Alexander and Jeph Loeb, have been fired from the series, Variety reported. ''Heroes,'' the comic-book adventure created by Tim Kring, was a bright spot on NBC's schedule when it made its debut in 2006, but its second season was cut short by the writers' strike. This year the show promised a return to the streamlined storytelling that made its first season a hit, but it has been plagued by convoluted plotlines, and its ratings have declined. Mr. Loeb, a longtime comic-book writer and a producer of the television shows ''Smallville'' and ''Lost,'' and Mr. Alexander, a producer of ''Lost'' and ''Alias,'' had been with ''Heroes'' since its first season.

With profound sadness, our entire agency mourns the passing of Joseph Kaplan, a visionary leader of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services for more than 30 years. Former President and current Co-Chair of the Board, Joe inspired us to stay true to our mission: to serve all people in need. He was a constant voice for the clients we serve. Joe was a man of great wisdom and a mentor to many. As Chair of our Jewish Connections division, he led in the creation of some of the most innovative and compassionate program ming, dealing with a wide range of life challenges. His enormous contributions were recently acknowledged by naming The Joseph S. Kaplan Center for Family Life Education at JBFCS. Joe understood the value of partnership with other Human Service Agencies supported by the UJA-Federation of New York, of which he too was a supporter and champion. He made a crucial contribution in establishing Ashalim, a learning and service partnership between New York and Israeli organizations for children and families (sponsored by UJA-Federation). Joe, a man of enormous personal integrity, understood the importance of professional and programmatic integrity in the outcome of our work. Staff, Board and volunteers loved and appreciated Joe: he respected each of us for our effort to better the NYC community. We will be inspired by his memory in the work we do every day. His first love was his family, his beloved and devoted wife Lily, also an agency volunteer over many years, and his cherished children: Michele (Ira), Andrew (Chaviva) and David (Michelle), ten grandchildren and his sister, Molla Reisbaum. We extend our deepest condolences to them all. John A Herrmann, President Jean L. Troubh, Co-Chair of the Board Paul Levine, Executive Vice President and CEO KAPLAN--Joseph. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Joseph Kaplan, a beloved leader and cherished friend. He will be remembered for his longstanding philanthropy and esteemed leadership with UJA-Federation's Commission on the Jewish People and two of our beneficiary agencies, the Jewish Board of Family and Children Services, where he served as a past president and chair, and the Shorefront YM-YWHA of Brighton-Manhattan Beach, where he served as a past president. As a founding board member of Ashalim, representing UJA-Federation, and a past New York chair of the Ashalim board, Joseph's passion to rescue at-risk youth in Israel profoundly impacted the community and further strengthened our ability to serve those in need. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joseph's wife, Lily; to his daughter, Michele, and son-in-law, Ira; to his son Andrew and daughter-in-law Chaviva; to his son David and daughter-in-law Michelle; to his grandchildren; and to the entire Kaplan family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

On Election Day, much of the nation, including most of the battleground states, will see fair weather that will encourage voters to go to the polls. According to the National Weather Service, temperatures are expected be mild for this time of year in many large urban areas, and precipitation should be minimal. Weather, of course, can be a factor in voter turnout, especially for Democrats. Because Democrats tend to be less affluent than Republicans and to live in larger cities, the theory goes, they not only depend more on public transportation to get to the polls, but also vote in precincts that are prone to long lines, and thus are more vulnerable to bad weather.

Jose Canseco went to a Tijuana pharmacy looking for something to boost his testosterone level — low after years of admitted steroid use — and got in trouble again. Limping slightly and saying he was tired, depressed and nearly bankrupt, Canseco pleaded guilty in San Diego to a misdemeanor offense of trying to bring a fertility drug across from Mexico. He was sentenced to 12 months of unsupervised probation.

A stray bullet that injured a Nascar fan in her motor home at Texas Motor Speedway might have been from a rifle of a target shooter, the police said. A 49-year-old man contacted the police after being told of news reports that a woman was hit in the arm Sunday morning by a bullet piercing through the roof of her recreational vehicle camped at the speedway, according to the Fort Worth police. The man told detectives Tuesday that he fired five or six rounds from a single-shot rifle near a rifle range about five miles from the speedway from about 10 a.m. to 11 a.m., the police said. The 62-year-old woman’s condition was unavailable.

Top-ranked Jelena Jankovic defeated Ana Ivanovic, 6-3, 6-4, in round-robin play at the WTA’s season-ending Sony Ericsson Championships in Doha, Qatar. Venus Williams defeated No. 2 Dinara Safina, 7-5, 6-3, and No. 9 Vera Zvonareva defeated Svetlana Kuznetsova, 6-2, 6-3. Williams trailed by 2-5 in the first set but won five straight games. In round-robin play Wednesday, Ivanovic faces Zvonareva, Venus Williams plays Elena Dementieva, and Safina plays Serena Williams.

Bo Pelini, Nebraska’s first-year coach, acknowledged his volatile sideline demeanor was casting a negative light on himself and the program. Pelini has drawn unwanted attention for his tirades against officials, assistants and players. He said at his weekly news conference Tuesday that he knew his temper could hurt the university’s image and work against the Cornhuskers in recruiting, especially with videos of him seething and screaming readily available on YouTube, where a montage of Pelini blowups was posted Monday. “Perception is reality, so that’s something I’ve got to fix,” Pelini said.

"The reverses were principally in Ohio, Indiana, and Nebraska. From Iowa came the most surprising news of the day, in the defeat of 'Uncle Pete' Hepburn, the old war horse of the Eighth District, who has been in the House for eleven terms. Iowa is a strong Roosevelt state, and Col. Hepburn has been one of the stanchest Roosevelt men in Congress, having been the author of the Railroad Rate bill and the sponsor in the House for the bill amending the Sherman anti-trust law, which he introduced in the last session." Indiana gave the Democrats two more seats in the House, for a total of 11, retaining only 2 for Republicans. The Indiana results "will also cost the Republicans a Senator. The Legislature having been carried by the Democrats, the prospect is that John W. Kern, the defeated candidate for the Vice Presidency, will now be elected to the Senate in place of Senator Hemenway, whose term expires on March 4." Republican Lead in Congress Cut Down

COHEN--Eugene . With profound sadness, we extend our condolences to our friend and partner, Burton A. Cohen and to the family of Rabbi Eugene Cohen on the loss of their beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Rabbi Eugene Cohen was a paragon of probity, a learned scholar, a wise counselor, a sage analyst of the human condition who probed the emotional and intellectual bases of understanding, and a warm, loyal friend. SIMON--David Robert , 74, died peacefully at home in Denver on November 3, 2008, following a long, valiant struggle from complications of Parkinson's Disease, surrounded by his ever-loving wife of 49 years, Myrna, and devoted son Geoffrey. Also survived by his daughter, Marianne, and brother, Larry, both of Boston. He was a doting grandfather to Erik, Elise and Emily. Contributions to The Brain and Vision Research Fund, c/o Dr. Victoria Pelak, greatly appreciated. For information, call 303724-2184.

LEVY--Jessica , age 81, died November 3, 2008 at her home in New York City. Daughter of Dr. Robert L. Levy and Beatrice Straus Levy. She leaves her beloved brother Gerald D. Levy, sister-in-law Marion F. Levy and nieces Alison Ryan, Elizabeth Levy Ward and nephew Robert J. Levy. She graduated from the Brearley School in 1944 and from Bryn Mawr in 1948. She was an interviewer and writer for NBC radio. She was Assistant to John Gielgud for Broadway's ''Hamlet'' and assistant to Arthur Penn for ''Two for the Seesaw''. She directed ''Stormbound'' for Play wrights Horizon'' and produced the plays ''Eastern Standard'', ''Real Estate'' and ''Crossing the Bar''. She commissioned two as yet unproduced screenplays. She is the granddaughter of Jesse I. Straus who was president of R.H. Macy and was appointed Ambassador to France by Franklin D. Roosevelt. Her father, Dr. Robert Levy, was a leading professor of Cardiology at New York Presbyterian Hospital and President of the New York Academy of Medicine. Jessica was an enthusiastic alumna of Brearley serving on an alumnae council, and was active with the New York Philharmonic. Interment will be private and a Memorial Service in December will be announced.

VELCEK--Damir . The Lenox Hill Hospital Urology attending and resident staff very sadly note the untimely passing of our beloved colleague and friend, Dr. Damir Velcek, on October 31st, 2008. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Dr. Frances Velcek and his entire family. Damir, a staff member for 30 years, was a most dedicated surgeon and teacher whom we all adored. We will miss him greatly. Mike S. Brodherson, M.D., Acting Director, Urology Division Lenox Hill Hospital, NY, NY
