BRODY--Frances . The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Frances Brody of Los Angeles. A dynamic and spirited Technion supporter, Ms. Brody was a Technion Guardian, representing the highest level of support. Among her highest priorities were the Frances Brody Career Development Chair and the Frances Brody Fellowship Fund in the David and Janet Polak Center for Cancer Research and Vascular Biology. Ms. Brody also played a pioneering role in the establishment of the Stephen and Nancy Grand Water Research Institute. A 2002 Technion Honorary Doctorate recipient, Ms. Brody was an active member of the Technion International Board of Governors and the National and Southern California Chapter boards of directors. Ms. Brody, a native of Chicago, ran a family business and became the first female CEO of a US steel manufacturer. To her niece Janet Farber and her extended family, we express our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Steve Emerson, Southern California Chapter President Diane Siegel, Western Region Director

(49) MEDAL OF HONOR Dating from the Civil War, the Medal of Honor -- the highest United States award for valor in combat -- is presented to soldiers for service ''above and beyond the call of duty.'' Only 3,473 medals have been awarded, and since the Vietnam War just seven have been given, all posthumously. This program tells the stories of 13 recipients, including Sgt. Paul Smith, above, the first soldier to receive a Medal of Honor in the Iraq war; Sgt. Alvin York, portrayed by Gary Cooper in the 1941 film ''Sergeant York''; and Gen. Smedley D. Butler, one of only 17 to receive the medal twice. Butler, who served in every conflict from the Spanish-American War through World War I, eventually became an outspoken critic of the American military's interventionist policies. He tried to return his medal for service in Vera Cruz, Mexico, but his superiors ordered him to keep it. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is the guest.

Want to be in Washington for Inauguration Day? Try Virginia. Hotels in the capital often sell out for presidential inaugurations, but usually not before Election Day. This time, hotels near the White House or along the parade route, like the Willard InterContinental and JW Marriott, have been booked for weeks. Even hotels a few Metro stops away, like the Marriott Wardman Park, Washington's largest, and the Days Inn Connecticut Avenue, are full.

BEIJING -- Chinese and Taiwanese officials signed agreements on Tuesday expanding charter flights, maritime shipping and cooperation on food-safety issues, bringing their governments closer together as both struggle to overcome economic slowdowns. The agreements were finalized on the second day of a planned five-day visit to Taiwan by a mainland delegation led by Chen Yunlin, the head of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, the main negotiator for China in matters related to Taiwan.

HUGHES--Joseph M. , (19??-2008). America and New York lost an authentic, ''one of a kind'' hero on Monday. Big Joe, of Mineola and Port Washington, was also affectionately known as ''Bad News Hughes'' to his legions of friends at Plandome Country Club and the too-numerous-to-mention fine establishments he frequented in New York, around the U.S. and Ireland over the years. Joe passed away peacefully on November 3rd. He owned and ran a successful graphic arts business for many years before retiring. Joe, who was passionately loved by all generations who remember him as a proud veteran, was seriously wounded defending his beloved country at the Battle of the Bulge, the decisive but costly battle leading to the end of Hitler's last gasp efforts in WWII. An unabashed patriot, he was also the absolute best friend, mentor, ''father, grandfather and great-grandfather'' to the Schlaefer, Hill, and McAuley families while considered part of the family and ''Uncle Joe'' to so many others. Beloved brother of Richard (deceased) and his wife, Irene, and uncle to Rick, Joe, Jerry and Kathy, all of Atlanta, GA. Known as the consummate gentleman, for his incredible sense of humor and generosity to all who ever knew him. A Memorial Mass celebrating his inspiring life will be held on Saturday, November 15, 9:30am at St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church in Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to his favorite charity, The Physically Challenged Irish and American Youth Team. Joe loved the children and they all loved him back!! He will be greatly missed by all -his legend and spirit will live forever!!

Senator John McCain had always watched a movie during the political dead time of Election Day, but on Tuesday he dispensed with that tradition to end a presidential campaign that both sides waged at warp speed. Then, too, his aides said, he was too restless to hang around Phoenix all day. So Mr. McCain headed off for a nearly full day of campaigning, first to a rally in Grand Junction, Colo., in a solidly Republican county, then to a phone bank in Albuquerque. At both stops, he seemed to have a difficult time letting go.

As the campaign ended Tuesday, The Caucus indulged in a bit of nostalgia, checking in with some of the characters (and snowmen) who kept us engaged over the two-year contest: Obama Girl: Amber Lee Ettinger, below, whose ode to Senator Barack Obama has been viewed nearly 10.6 million times since it appeared on YouTube in June 2007, did not spend election night with her crush. Instead, Ms. Ettinger, who has a jewelry line and an album in the works, planned to hang out with Oksana Baiul, the Olympic figure skater, and several reality show stars at Haven in midtown Manhattan.

Time magazine gets Mark Salter, one of McCain's closest aides, to talk about what went wrong. Salter follows tradition and blames the media. He's right to. But he should have been more specific: where the campaign faltered was not in getting the mainstream media on its side but in making better use of YouTube  and not getting so burned by it. It's YouTube satire (and not TV or print) that thrives on taking casual asides and jokes out of context. ("Bomb Iran," anyone?) The editing tricksters of YouTube helped defeat McCain whenever they starved him of context. Surrounded by peers, contemporaries, buddies, colleagues, fellow veterans  men like himself  McCain might have made more sense.

Over all, voter turnout in New York City on Tuesday increased by about 3 percent over 2004, according to preliminary election results analyzed by the New Americans Exit Poll. The increase was driven by higher turnout rates in election districts where blacks and Latinos are a majority. But there was a slight decrease in white-majority election districts. And in election districts where Asian-Americans are a majority, there was a 6.6 percent decrease in turnout from 2004 levels.

The Browns turn the offense over to Brady Quinn, although Coach Romeo Crennel seems to have tempered expectations. "Knock wood, I hope the guy doesn't fall on his face," he said. Saddled with one of the league's worst defenses, Denver has combusted. After averaging 38 points a game in a 3-0 start, the Broncos have not scored more than 19 points since and are down to the rookie Ryan Torain as their starting running back. In this once-bitter rivalry, Denver has won the last seven meetings.

After 1.5 weeks of festering convection off the Nicaraguan coast, TD17 formed on Wednesday, and has quickly gotten better organized. It was upgraded to TS Paloma, the 16th named storm of the season, early Thursday. As of 15Z, Paloma's intensity was 40kts and 998mb, but is rapidly intensifying, and could be nearly a hurricane by the next advisory. It has persistent deep convection organized into an eyewall, and the eye is clearing out as I type this. It's located just off the corner of Honduras and Nicaragua, and crawling north toward western Cuba. However, it is expected to gradually turn more NE and cross central Cuba late this weekend as a powerful hurricane. This has unfortunately been a devastating year for Cuba... Fay, Gustav, Ike, and now Paloma.

While the Mets exercised their $12 million option on Carlos Delgado’s contact, the team declined to to extend it by another season.

Tony Parker scored a career-high 55 points, including a 20-footer at the buzzer to force a second overtime, in the San Antonio Spurs’ 129-125 victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves.
This is Season 3 of the Siege of the NFL Network, a standoff that probably will not change this year.
The legend of Störtebeker, the egalitarian pirate, has been rejuvenated in Germany, partly as a response to the growing sense of economic justice.
Tuesday’s victory celebration in Grant Park let Chicago strut its stuff to the world: lakefront parks, a dramatic skyline, throngs of joyful — and well-organized — citizens.
Jean Charest, the premier of Quebec, announced an early election for the province on Wednesday, less than a month after a federal election in Canada.
The nearly $5 billion American aid package known as Plan Colombia failed to meet its goal of halving illegal narcotics production, says an American report.
Hunters in Mexico have started adapting their operations as the government has taken on violent drug gangs near bountiful bird grounds.
The heads of Chrysler, Ford and G.M. and the president of the United Automobile Workers are set to meet House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.
Jay Feely has helped rescue the Jets’ season by filling in for the injured kicker Mike Nugent, making 12 of 16 field goals.
The company began to founder after 389 illegal immigrants, about half its work force, were arrested on May 12 in a raid at its plant in Postville, Iowa.
A day after the Devils learned that their longtime goalie will be sidelined for months, Kevin Weekes gave the team the goaltending it will need to get by without him.
David Tyree was placed on injured reserve after missing the first six weeks of the season while recovering from knee surgery.
As the world’s spotlight fell on Barack Obama, officials from Chicago’s bid to host the 2016 Olympics knew exactly what was at hand: the best free advertisement they could dream of.
Although newspapers printed extra copies in anticipation of higher sales, demand far exceeded supply.
As he returned to Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, Larry Brown had nothing but praise for his hometown team and its young core of players.

Ads tying into the end of the presidential race appeared surprisingly quickly.

The federal Department of Agriculture announced that it would provide financial assistance to Kentucky farmers whose crops had wilted under a drought that has expanded northward from the Deep South. Farmers will also be eligible for loans if they suffered crop losses from high winds when the remnants of Hurricane Ike blew through the state in September. Gov. Steve Beshear, above, said the drought, now in its second year, had brought financial hardships to Kentucky. “This disaster aid will help lessen the impact on our farm families and rural communities,” he said. The loans will be available to farmers in all 120 Kentucky counties. Southeastern Kentucky is under “extreme drought” conditions, according to the United States Drought Monitor. Other parts of the state were under mild-to-moderate drought conditions.

A Palm Beach County jury on Tuesday awarded $27 million to a girl who was molested four years ago by a male family friend who was baby-sitting for her. After 90 minutes of deliberation, the jury concluded that the man, Pratak Siriwat, 50, molested the girl, who is now 16. The girl said Mr. Siriwat fondled her at his home while teaching her how to play a guitar. Russell S. Adler, a lawyer who represented the girl’s family, said Mr. Siriwat admitted molestation to the police and was charged with lewd or lascivious behavior with a minor. The charges were later dropped by the Palm Beach County state attorney’s office, and in the civil trial Mr. Siriwat denied any molestation. Mr. Siriwat represented himself in the case. The verdict included nearly $150,000 for the girl’s past and future medical and counseling expenses, $7 million for mental anguish and $20 million in punitive damages. Mr. Adler said Mr. Siriwat had filed for bankruptcy. He said Mr. Siriwat was still liable, but it was not known whether the award would be collected.

A jogger was attacked by a rabid fox, ran a mile with the animal’s jaws clamped on her arm and then drove herself to a hospital, the authorities said. The Yavapai County sheriff’s office said the woman told deputies that she was on a trail near Prescott on Monday when the fox attacked and bit her foot. The woman said that she grabbed the fox by the neck when it went for her leg but that it bit her arm. The woman wanted the animal tested for rabies so she ran a mile to her car with the fox still biting her arm, then pried the animal off and tossed it in her trunk and drove to the Prescott hospital. The sheriff’s office said the fox later bit an animal-control officer. He and the woman are both receiving rabies vaccinations.
Covidien Ltd. is recalling 471,000 disposable insulin syringes because of mislabeling that could cause patients to receive as much as 2.5 times the intended dose, federal regulators said.

The Points of Light Institute, which works to encourage civic activism and volunteering, has nearly completed its efforts to reimburse people who were unwittingly part of a scandal involving the sale of bogus travel packages through its store on eBay. Points of Light, which recently merged with the Hands On Network, has issued almost $7 million in refunds in response to some 4,500 claims it received from customers of the store, Michelle Nunn, the group’s president and chief executive, wrote in an e-mail message Tuesday to donors, employees and others. Ms. Nunn wrote that it appeared that the contractor running the store for Points of Light, a former fund-raiser for the group named Maria Hermann, had used some of the money from the sale of the false travel packages “for personal expenses and other unauthorized purchases.” She said the organization had used a combination of loans and insurance proceeds to cover reimbursement, as well as some gifts designated for that purpose, not any donations made to support its mission. “While we strongly believe this was the right and ethical course of action, this did place additional, difficult burdens upon the newly merged organization at a critical juncture,” Ms. Nunn wrote.
The credit crisis is affecting the cost — and the ability — of importers to find trade finance.
Representatives dealing with primary-care products will feel the brunt of the cutbacks, as Glaxo, like many drug makers, is losing sales of older products to generic competitors.
Even as financial turmoil has cut into sales at many stores, it sent consumers into the arms of Wal-Mart.
Serena Williams and Venus Williams have said they will refuse to play at a tournament in Indian Wells, Calif., that will be mandatory for top-1o players.
The District 3 Autumn Leaf Regional in Danbury, Conn., held in the middle of last month, continues to enjoy great popularity.
In two galleries, steps apart on West 24th Street, you encounter large brushy grisaille paintings based on newspaper images or other photographs.
In Amitav Ghosh’s latest novel, set aboard a ship carrying opium, the wordplay is as intoxicating as the cargo.

“The vision of a tall-masted ship, at sail on the ocean, came to Deeti on an otherwise ordinary day, but she knew instantly that the apparition was a sign of destiny, for she had never seen such a vessel before, not even in a dream.”
Green Equity Investors V has bought 17 percent of the grocery chain for $425 million, sending shares up nearly 22 percent.
Taschen has created a facsimile edition of 265 issues of Arts & Architecture magazines.
Broadway’s “Tale of Two Cities” will close on Nov. 16, its producers announced, just under two months after it opened at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.
The Al Hirschfeld Theater will become home to the Public Theater’s revival of “Hair,” which played this summer at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.
If you use Gmail and get annoyed by its worried alert box about the lack of body text, there is a simple fix to save a mouse click.
Tiffany Threadgould is intent on updating traditional crafts like weaving by using modern, discarded materials.
Erica Rosenfeld makes glass time capsules that can be used in a variety of ways.
Moss and Moroso, high-end modern furniture stores, will hold a warehouse sale Nov. 15 and 16.

It seems only fair to fight back and reduce -- or even eliminate -- the ads that have spread like kudzu over our analog and digital lives.
Q. I have a houseplant that was ailing until I put it outside for the summer, and it came back to life. What should I do now that I’ve brought it back inside?
With energy prices fluctuating, homeowners are now more determined than ever to find ways to save on heating bills.
Among the many, many pleasures of “Funny as a Crutch,” a bill of nine short plays performed by five actors with disabilities, is watching Shannon DeVido steal every scene she’s in.
A number of decorative and functional pieces represent a burgeoning trend in home design: knitted furnishings and accessories.
Two newly completed gardens demonstrate how sustainable technologies can be incorporated into landscapes that are varied enough to fill many needs.
GoStudio from Belkin can record stereo audio directly to an iPod Classic, Nano or Video just as if the iPod were a memory card or thumb drive.
For economic and health reasons, a number of Americans are making the seemingly anachronistic choice to turn their basement into a root cellar.
Asus’s Eee PC S101 netbook includes 20 gigabytes of free online storage, a 16-gigabyte solid-state drive and an integrated flash card reader that accepts four kinds of formats.
The Rumble Blaster turns your entire Wii controller into a two-handed gun system with realistic rumble action.
The ECO Showerdrop from Product Creation uses a numerical display to show how many liters of water you’ve used and how much time you’ve spent in the shower.
A Hudson Valley couple renovated a Beaux-Arts sporting pavilion designed by Stanford White in 1902 for John Jacob Astor IV.
News Corporation’s first-quarter income dropped while Time Warner’s situation was brighter.
The company announced first-quarter net income of $2.2 billion, edging past Wall Street expectations.
No one was more disturbed by “Blasted” than its director, Sarah Benson, and the three cast members, yet they have found inventive ways to cope with the nightly torture sessions.
During intermissions at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, nervous New Yorkers huddled obsessively around cellphones, but the unremitting focus and resolve of the dancers were hard to ignore.
Online shopping services are quickly building applications for smartphones that bring a new dimension to your next trip to the mall.
Pete Rouse has an innate knowledge of the workings of Washington and Congress after spending three decades on Capitol Hill.
The author, who died on Tuesday, turned out novels that were intricately engineered entertainment systems.
John D. Podesta, with deep ties to the Clintons, brings a savvy, gloves-off approach to politics and a command of policy issues after running his own research organization.
Like Ronald Reagan 28 years ago, Barack Obama must make decisions that cause short-term pain in order to combat long-term economic problems.
Valerie Jarrett has a fierce, almost familial loyalty to Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle.
“Many of our citizens thought they would never live to see that day,” President Bush said of Barack Obama’s election.

Around midnight of election day, I called my father in Las Vegas and let him hear the sobs of joy in the Harlem night. I’d finally experienced my own, long-awaited Joe Louis moment.
Alabama’s offensive line is paramount to why the Crimson Tide takes a No. 1 ranking in the B.C.S. standings into its game with No. 16 Louisiana State this weekend in Baton Rouge.
Democrats are second-guessing Barack Obama’s decision to ask Representative Rahm Emanuel — “Rahmbo,” one of the capital’s most in-your-face partisan actors — to be his chief of staff.
Researchers have found a set of genetic mutations that may provide clues about the origins of cancer.
The nation’s biggest carrier said that it would charge some passengers to check their first bag, but that it was eliminating the fuel surcharges for tickets using frequent-flier miles.
The prevalence of video, the proliferation of advance scouts and the encyclopedic memories of coaches have dramatically reduced the actual surprise of what teams see from the other side.
Quarterback Brian Johnson has led No. 10 Utah to a 9-0 record, and if the Utes beat No. 11 Texas Christian University on Thursday they would be on the cusp of a berth in a B.C.S. bowl game.
Indicators point to signs of further contraction of the economy, at worse levels than economists’ expectations.
Officials tried to rein in speculation that swirled over the cause of a plane crash that killed 12 people, including two officials who once led the fight against the country’s violent drug cartels.
The move, which came after antitrust regulators raised objections, leaves Yahoo scrambling for a plan for growth.
An airstrike by United States-led forces killed 40 civilians and wounded 28 others, officials said.
Like its rivals in China, Japan and Russia, ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, is moving to reduce capacity as global demand wanes.
Forty people, 11 of them children, died after a ferry capsized in the central Philippines, the coast guard said, the latest in a long line of maritime tragedies.
GMAC, the finance company partly owned by General Motors, lost $2.52 billion in the quarter, hurt by the housing slump and vehicle lease write-downs, and said that its mortgage unit may not survive.
Profit was driven by phone and Internet subscriptions but the company nudged down its forecasts for the year.
The Tibetans received prison sentences for their actions in the March 14 ethnic riot that engulfed Lhasa, according to a senior Chinese official.
Iran’s military said U.S. helicopters had been seen near the Iraq border and warned that Iran would respond to any violation of its airspace, IRNA news agency reported.
Time Warner, the media conglomerate, posted a higher-than-expected third-quarter profit, helped by strong advertising sales and a summer blockbuster movie.
In a wide-ranging attack, Dmitri Medvedev talked of the need to counter a perceived U.S. threat.
5 November 2008.
For many outsiders, Barack Obama’s victory raised expectations of an end to the bitterness of the Bush years.
Hopes for a post-election Wall Street bounce were dashed as investors took profits and dealt with another round of bleak economic news.

As the economic crisis reshaped the presidential race in early October, Senator John McCain abandoned his campaign in Michigan, a state where he had spent $8 million on advertisements and had made repeated appearances. That decision might have affected Republican candidates farther down the ticket, as Democrats won close House contests against Republican incumbents, giving Democrats an 8-to-7 edge in the state's delegation. Representative Joe Knollenberg, an eight-term Republican, lost to Gary Peters, a Democrat and former state lottery commissioner, in the Detroit suburbs. Jack Kevorkian, the so-called suicide doctor, won more than 9,000 votes.

By one measure, Oklahoma is now the most Republican state in the nation. Senator John McCain carried it by a bigger margin, 65.6 percent, than any other. Republicans also won a majority in the State Senate, giving them control of both chambers of the State Legislature for the first time since Oklahoma became a state in 1907.

Nine days after he was convicted of seven felony counts, Senator Ted Stevens held a narrow lead on Wednesday in his bid for re-election. The race remained too close to call. Mr. Stevens, 84, led his Democratic challenger, Mayor Mark Begich of Anchorage, by fewer than 3,400 votes with more than 55,000 absentee, early and questioned ballots still to be counted.

DUNN--Thomas , died on October 26 in Bloomington, IN, age 82. Founder of the Festival Orchestra of New York, conductor laureate of the Handel and Haydn Society of Boston. Funeral services will be held in Baltimore, MD, on Saturday November 15, at 11:00am at the Church of the Redeemer, 5603 N. Charles St.

The state of the economy was a major concern with voters in Florida and that benefited Senator Barack Obama, who drew strong support from voters in Miami and Tampa, as well as from Latinos in a state where they have traditionally voted Republican. Several of the state's 25 seats in the House of Representatives switched hands. In the Eighth District, Alan Grayson, a Democratic challenger, beat the incumbent, Ric Keller, a four-term Republican congressman who won the district, in the center of the state, by seven percentage points in 2006.

Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Washington Democrat, was headed to a decisive victory in her closely fought bid for re-election against her Republican challenger, Dino Rossi. Her victory came four years after she survived her first matchup with Mr. Rossi, a former state senator, by only 133 votes. With more than half of all ballots counted, Ms. Gregoire held a clear lead, about 54 percent to 46 percent. Many ballots in heavily Democratic areas, including King County, had yet to be counted.
401 West 14th Street (near Ninth Avenue); (646) 336-8170.

The wave of Democratic zeal extended to a Southwestern battleground as Representative Tom Udall picked up a Senate seat and Democrats won all three seats in the House of Representatives. Mr. Udall, a cowboy boot-wearing son of a political family who appealed to voters with a push for renewable energy and conservation and with opposition to the Wall Street bailout legislation, enjoyed a comfortable victory over his Republican opponent, Representative Steve Pearce.

In the race to fill the seat being vacated by Senator Larry Craig, Lt. Gov. Jim Risch, a Republican, won nearly 58 percent of the vote to easily defeat Larry LaRocco, a Democrat and former two-term congressman. Mr. Craig, a Republican, drew national attention last year after he was arrested in a Minneapolis airport bathroom in a sex sting. The Senate race included an independent candidate who went by the name Pro-Life. The candidate, an organic strawberry farmer previously known as Marvin Richardson, had his name legally changed. He received 1.3 percent of the vote. In the First Congressional District, in the north and western part of the state, a Democrat, Walt Minnick, unseated the Republican incumbent, Bill Sali, who was running for a second term. Mr. Minnick, a former executive in the forest products industry, became only the second Democrat in the last four decades to win the district, which includes rural and metropolitan areas.

With a robust bank account and extensive name recognition, Mike Johanns, a former governor of Nebraska who served as secretary of agriculture under President Bush, entered the race to replace Senator Chuck Hagel. Mr. Johanns, a Republican, banked on his deep Nebraska roots and his experience in Washington to convince voters that he was the right candidate to fill Mr. Hagel's shoes. (Mr. Hagel chose not to run again.) Mr. Johanns labeled his Democratic opponent, Scott Kleeb, an inexperienced outsider, while Mr. Kleeb said that Mr. Johanns represented the status quo. Mr. Kleeb, a Yale graduate and former college professor, wore cowboy boots on the campaign trail and used horses and lassos in his ads. But in the end, he fell far short.

Minutes before show time, the $2 million high-tech backdrop for Al Arabiya's election day news coverage was not working. But the channel's executive editor, Nabil al-Khatib, was calm. He is a tall man, with an easy presence, decades of experience in Middle East news and a conviction that events on Tuesday would not surprise. Senator John McCain, he believed, was going to win. ''Would Americans choose someone who thinks outside the box?'' he asked rhetorically as an army of engineers and technicians scrambled to get the big screen working again. ''This is just too good to be true.''

HOROWITZ--Sidney . Our sincere condolences to Grace, Richie, Heidi, Joanne, Jill, Jeff and Lucas on the passing of their beloved Sidney. The Membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Florida announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member, Sidney Horowitz, November 5, 2008 and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Grace and their family. Robert M. Merson, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc. HOROWITZ--Sidney. Rhode Island is an overwhelmingly blue state, only slightly less Democratic than neighboring Massachusetts, and it demonstrated that again in this election. Senator Barack Obama easily won the state's four electoral votes.

Senator Barack Obama captured Wisconsin by a comfortable margin, winning with voters in every age group except people older than 65. Those voters split their support between Mr. Obama and Senator John McCain, according to exit polls. Republicans fought unsuccessfully to pick up a Congressional seat in the conservative-leaning Eighth District, the only competitive House race in the state. In a rematch of the race from two years ago, John Gard, a former State Assembly speaker, lost to Representative Steven Kagen, a Democrat.

Two hours before dawn on Wednesday morning, four college students were tucked into a cherry-red booth at the Starlite Diner here, waiting for election returns. All of them had class in a few hours, and they were struggling to stay awake. Ilya Glazunov, 18, rested his cheek on the cool tabletop; Vladislav Malashenko, 22, slipped down the vinyl seat and threatened to disappear entirely.

Barack Obama may owe his narrow win in Indiana to good old-fashioned get-out-the-vote work. Exit polls show that nearly a quarter of voters questioned said they had been contacted by the Obama campaign about coming out to vote, compared with 8 percent for the McCain campaign. Of those contacted as part of the Obama effort, almost three-quarters said they voted for him. The Libertarian candidate, Bob Barr, was another major factor. With all but a handful of election districts counted, Mr. Obama held a lead over Mr. McCain of just 26,163 votes, less than 1 percent of the votes cast. Mr. Barr received 29,186 votes.

The state where Senator Barack Obama was born and spent most of his youth easily went his way and two Democrats, Neil Abercrombie and Mazie K. Hirono, coasted to re-election to the House of Representatives. Democrats also claimed three seats in the State Legislature, expanding their control to all but 8 of the 76 seats.

Senator John McCain won his home state by nearly nine percentage points, but Democrats picked up a Congressional seat held by a retiring Republican, allowing them to assume a five-to-three majority in the eight-member delegation. Ann Kirkpatrick, a Democrat and a former state legislator, trounced Sydney Hay, a mining industry lobbyist, for the largely rural northern Arizona seat being vacated by Rick Renzi. He is a three-term Republican who is retiring and is under federal indictment.

STEINER--Jeffrey , one of the last grand signeur of our time who was loved, respected and admired by all his friends and people who knew him. We will miss him. You will be in my heart forever. Agnes Beaugendre

Call it redemption. This town, in the same area where Senator Barack Obama's father was from and where some of Mr. Obama's cousins, half-brothers and a very gregarious 86-year-old step-grandmother still live, exploded into cheers when the news broke that Mr. Obama had won the presidency.
STILLER--Fanny Licht , age 88. Wife of Richard, mother of Helen and Michael, grandmother of Jonathan and Tali. She was a rebel girl, devoted mother, beloved comrade.

SKIDMORE--Joel , passed on October 25th, 2008. Retired from Stone & Webster, Inc. in 1994. Joel was admired and loved by all those who knew his generous heart and friendly smile. His spirit will live forever. Dario

As Vermont continues its change from a historically conservative state to one of the most liberal, its voters showed once again their lack of concern with party labels. Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican moderate, won easy re-election over an independent, Anthony Pollina, and a Democrat, Gaye Symington, who finished virtually tied for a distant second place.

North Dakota re-elected its governor, John Hoeven, by a landslide. Mr. Hoeven, a two-term Republican, never seemed to break a sweat in beating Tim Mathern by 74 percent to 24 percent. In winning a third four-year term, Mr. Hoeven, 51, will be the first North Dakota governor to serve more than eight years. Mr. Mathern, 58, has been a state senator for more than two decades.

More than 60 million viewers watched prime-time, election-night coverage on ABC, NBC, CBS and the three main cable news networks, an increase of nearly 10 percent over 2004, according to early estimates provided Wednesday by Nielsen Media Research. When adding in the viewership of eight other channels -- including Black Entertainment Televison and the Spanish-language networks Univision and Telemundo -- Tuesday night's combined viewership ballooned to 71.5 million, more than in either 2004 or 2000.

Wyoming again proved it is among the most Republican of states, voting for Senator John McCain by a two-to-one ratio, electing Republicans to all three seats in its Congressional delegation and retaining Republican control of its Legislature. Senator Michael B. Enzi, a second-term Republican, easily defeated his Democratic challenger, Chris Rothfuss, a chemistry professor at the University of Wyoming.

It should come as no surprise that liberal Massachusetts would vote overwhelmingly for Barack Obama, or that the state returned Senator John Kerry, a Democrat, to Washington by a margin of more than two to one in a race against Jeff Beatty, a Republican security specialist whose campaign never seemed to gain traction. This will be Mr. Kerry's fifth term. While there was little suspense in the electoral contests, ballot measures drew strong interest. Voters overwhelmingly approved a proposal to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, 70 percent to 30 percent.

Some of the most heated conversations on the morning after election night centered on Michelle Obama's dress. The first lady-elect took to the stage at Grant Park in Chicago on Tuesday night wearing a red-and-black sheath by Narciso Rodriguez, sparking instant debate among viewers, with some calling it an eye-catching statement and others, an eyesore. The dress, black with a splash of red from the bust through the hips, has two corset-like bands of black intersecting at the waist. It is a departure for Mr. Rodriguez, a proponent of low-key looks who is remembered for Carolyn Bessette Kennedy's sleekly minimalist ivory wedding dress.

A HAPPY HOLIDAY The financial turmoil that has hurt discretionary spending at many retailers, causing them to cut staff and discount merchandise, has sent struggling consumers into the arms of Wal-Mart, leaving it poised to have a blockbuster Christmas. FALLING PAYCHECKS Wall Street bonuses are expected to plummet this year, but some are wondering why executives should get any bonus at all. [B1.]
Alabama Reporting: 99% Jeff Sessions, R* 1,302,316 63%

Senator Barack Obama made inroads in Florida, North Carolina and Virginia, but his momentum largely stalled in South Carolina. Senator John McCain won by nearly 10 percentage points, and his good friend and Republican colleague Senator Lindsey Graham won a second six-year term. Mr. Graham defeated Bob Conley, a Democrat who opposed abortion and supported gun rights but claimed that the ''Republican Party left me.''

Virginia, once reliably Republican, continues to evolve in a Democratic direction. Senator Barack Obama won the state, the first Democratic presidential candidate to carry the Old Dominion since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.

A season that began well for Denver has sunk under the weight of injuries. A season of high hopes for Cleveland has dissolved in the wake of inconsistent play. The Browns turn the offense over to Brady Quinn, although Coach Romeo Crennel seems to have tempered expectations. ''Knock wood, I hope the guy doesn't fall on his face,'' he said. Saddled with one of the league's worst defenses, Denver has combusted. After averaging 38 points a game in a 3-0 start, the Broncos have not scored more than 19 points since and are down to the rookie Ryan Torain as their starting running back. In this once-bitter rivalry, Denver has won the last seven meetings. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

LEVY--Jessica , age 81, died November 3, 2008 at her home in New York City. Daughter of Dr. Robert L. Levy and Beatrice Straus Levy. She leaves her beloved brother Gerald D. Levy, sister-in-law Marion F. Levy and nieces Alison Ryan, Elizabeth Levy Ward and nephew Robert J. Levy. She graduated from the Brearley School in 1944 and from Bryn Mawr in 1948. She was an interviewer and writer for NBC radio. She was Assistant to John Gielgud for Broadway's ''Hamlet'' and assistant to Arthur Penn for ''Two for the Seesaw''. She directed ''Stormbound'' for Play wrights Horizon'' and produced the plays ''Eastern Standard'', ''Real Estate'' and ''Crossing the Bar''. She commissioned two as yet unproduced screenplays. She is the granddaughter of Jesse I. Straus who was president of R.H. Macy and was appointed Ambassador to France by Franklin D. Roosevelt. Her father, Dr. Robert Levy, was a leading professor of Cardiology at New York Presbyterian Hospital and President of the New York Academy of Medicine. Jessica was an enthusiastic alumna of Brearley serving on an alumnae council, and was active with the New York Philharmonic. Interment will be private and a Memorial Service in December will be announced.

In 2002, Elizabeth Dole was handpicked by President Bush to run for the Senate seat vacated by Jesse Helms, a fellow Republican. She handily won the party's nomination and defeated a former Clinton administration aide to win the race. But as Mr. Bush's popularity slipped, Mrs. Dole became more vulnerable. Throughout her re-election campaign she had to fend off attacks from her Democratic challenger, Kay Hagan, over her voting record, her absences from the state and her ties to Mr. Bush.

Barack Obama's historic win, with at least 349 electoral votes to John McCain's 162, can be attributed to his victories in several high-population states, like Florida, Virginia and Ohio, that George W. Bush won handily in 2004. The struggling economy, especially in more industrial states, and high numbers of new voters helped flip key areas from red to blue. Even where Mr. McCain beat Mr. Obama, he won by slimmer margins, as much of the electorate -- across age, race and income lines -- swung toward the Democratic Party. Margins of Victory

No longer will New England have a Republican in the House of Representatives. Christopher Shays of Connecticut, the lone conservative in a region long dyed blue, suffered a startling defeat to a Democratic businessman from Greenwich, Jim Himes.

Black voters overwhelmingly supported the Democratic candidate, Robert D. Tuke, in the race to unseat Senator Lamar Alexander, a Republican, who carried the white vote. Mr. Tuke, a lawyer, was backed by voters who strongly disapproved of President Bush, while Mr. Alexander, a former Education Department secretary, was backed by those who gave the president high marks, according to exit polls. Mr. Alexander's victory was, however, commanding. He bested Mr. Tuke and five other challengers in every other voting category, including age, income and educational attainment.

Aided by disaffected Democrats, including supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton, John McCain easily won West Virginia. Gov. Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, reclaimed his seat for a second term after being heavily favored in a three-way race that included Russ Weeks, a Republican and former state senator, and Jesse Johnson of the Mountain Party. Mr. Manchin easily outspent his rivals, raising almost $3 million and spending more than a third of that in the race's closing weeks on broadcast advertising.

GOLDSTEIN--Harvey, MD age 63, on November 5 of lymphoma. His wife, Barbara Goldstein, his children, Stephanie, Paul and Kimberly, seven grandchildren and his sister, Helane Fein survive. He was an ENT for 37 years in Westchester and Brooklyn. He received his medical degree at the University of Bologna and received additional training at the NY Eye Ear Infirmary and St. Lukes. Shiva: Saturday evening through Tuesday at home. Funeral service: 10:30am, Friday, November 7 Bet Torah, 60 Smith Ave., Mt. Kisco. Donations may be made to NWHC Foundation, Attn: Gaby Greenwald, 400 East Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549. GOLDSTEIN-MALICK-Marilyn, passed away November 3, 2008 of pancreatic cancer. She was 65 years old. Loving wife for 29 years to Jack; beloved mother of Marissa and Laura. Devoted daughter of Sylvia and the late David Goldstein. Cherished sister of Myron and Jackie and proud aunt. Attorney for the Office of the General Counsel at New York Life for 35 years. Funeral services at Scarsdale Synagogue Tremont Temple, 2 Ogden Road, Scarsdale, New York at 10:30am today, November 6. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: MSKCC, Office of Development, 633 3rd Avenue, 28th Floor Attention: Clare Pugsley, New York, NY 10017. Please put in the memo of check In Memory of Marilyn Goldstein. All proceeds will go towards pancreatic cancer research.

Senator Barack Obama easily carried Iowa, the state where his presidential ambitions took flight with his success in the Democratic caucuses in January. He received more votes on Tuesday than any presidential candidate in the state's history. Senator John McCain had alienated some voters with his outspoken criticism of agricultural subsidies, especially those for ethanol.

In just a generation, Maryland has turned from a longtime swing state -- George Bush won there in 1988 -- to a solid blue swatch on the national map, and it is more Democratic than ever this year. Democrats appear to have taken a Republican-held House seat, giving them seven of Maryland's eight districts.

Senator John McCain's win in Arkansas ended the state's record of voting for the winners of the last nine presidential elections. And while nationally, young voters overwhelmingly preferred Mr. Obama, in Arkansas, they were evenly split, according to exit polls.
''Unfortunately, the next president's No. 1 priority is going to be preventing the biggest financial crisis in possibly the last century from turning into the next Great Depression.''

HOWE--Edwin A. (Brick) Jr. , of Ticonderoga, NY (formerly of Westport, CT and Garden City, NY) died on November 3rd at the age of sixtynine. Mr. Howe, a practicing lawyer for over 40 years, first in New York City and then in Ticonderoga, was also active in many civic and charitable affairs in all the communities where he lived. Mr. Howe was born in Cleveland, OH, on January 21, 1939, to Edwin A. Howe and the former Helen Dorothy Beck. He attended University School, graduated from Yale in 1961, and was awarded an honors degree in law by The University of Michigan Law School in 1964. He also conducted post-graduate studies in law at the London School of Economics. In law school, he was an editor of The University of Michigan Law Review and was awarded the Jason L. Honigman Prize for his accomplishments in that position. He was a member of the Bar of New York State and of the United States Supreme Court. After serving six years at Debevoise & Plimpton LLP, Mr. Howe co-founded the international law firm of Sann & Howe (subsequently Howe & Addington LLP) in New York City in 1970, serving it as a Partner through 1989 and then as Senior Partner for ten years until he became Senior Counsel. In 2004, Mr. Howe joined the Ticonderoga law firm Viscardi Howe & Rudgers LLP. Mr. Howe was also a member of The Counselors of Real Estate and the National Real Estate Forum, which he served as chair and then as Executive Director. A source of particular pride to him was his selection as a Fellow of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Margaret, his three children Christopher, Melissa, and Katie, his son-in-law, Chris Miller, and his two grandchildren, Julia and Beck. Mr. Howe expressed the hope that, if he should end up, spiritually speaking, ''somewhere'' after death, it would be in Ticonderoga and or a place where he could continue to enjoy his memories of Ticonderoga and perhaps even follow the continued activities and progress of its citizens. Anyone wishing to sustain his shade in that endeavor may do so via contribution to Ticonderoga Main Street Partnership, Inc., PO Box 379, Ticonderoga, NY 12883-0379.

Pennsylvania, long described as a swing state or a battleground state, helped Senator Barack Obama clinch his victory. Senator John McCain made an all-out push here, but Mr. Obama became the fifth Democrat in a row to carry the state in a presidential election. Mr. Obama received strong support in Philadelphia and ran well in parts of northeastern Pennsylvania that Mr. McCain had been counting on.

SMITH--Charles John, Jr. , died November 2, 2008, at his home in Jupiter, Florida, comforted by the love of his family and friends. He was 82. The cause of death was cancer. As patriarch to the Smith family, Chuck and his wife, Margaret Rose, were married for close to sixty years. Together, they were the parents of eight children, twenty - one grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Born in Elgin, Illinois, in 1926, he was a gifted athlete earning induction to the Elgin High School Hall of Fame in football, basketball, and wrestling. Chuck started his college football career at the University of Illinois as a left tackle. In 1945 he entered the United States Navy at the Great Lakes Naval Base in Illinois and competed for the Navy in both football and baseball. After serving his country, Chuck entered Marquette University to complete his undergraduate studies. While at Marquette, Chuck was named co-captain of the football team and was awarded Honorable Mention All American status. At Marquette Chuck met the love of his life, Margaret. Upon graduation, he was drafted by the NFL but instead took his first job with the Arrow Shirt Company, a division of Cluett, Peabody & Co. Widely known in the menswear industry as ''Mr. Shirt,'' Chuck began his career as a shirt salesman. He went on to become the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Van Heusen Company and then the President and Chief Executive Officer of the Men's Apparel Group, Crystal Brands Corporation, which included sportswear under the Izod & Lacoste labels, during his almost fifty year career in the industry. In lieu of flowers, please support the Jesuit Colleges and Universities, c/o Fr. Charles Currie, S.J., 1726 New Hampshire Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20009. SMITH--Robert Imbrie, 77, beloved husband of Tamara, brother of Sally Cross and Harold Smith, father of Elizabeth Curtiss Smith and Robert I. Smith Jr., stepfather of Caleb Wheeler, grandfather of Eliza and James NovickSmith, died November 1st. Former president of Glenmede Trust Company and Pew Charitable Trusts, he was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University, and Columbia Business School. Service November 29th, 11am, Christ Church, Philadelphia. Memorial contributions may be sent to F. Harold Smith Scholarship Fund, Yale University Office of Development, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06519.

Sometimes during his campaign, Gov. Jon Huntsman Jr., a Republican, sounded like a Democrat. He pushed for the expansion of renewable energy sources and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and he called for stricter measures to protect the environment. It was part political conviction and part political strategy, and it left Mr. Huntsman's challengers -- Bob Springmeyer, a Democrat, and Dell Schanze, a Libertarian -- fewer chances to criticize him. The approach alienated some in Mr. Huntsman's own party, but in the end it helped him cruise to re-election.

The sputtering bus inched its way up the streets of Petare, this city's largest slum, delivering its passengers in front of Vecinito, Enrique Cisneros's corner store. Salsa blared from loudspeakers perched nearby on the stoops of cinder-block hovels. ''Pull up a seat, we're celebrating tonight,'' said Mr. Cisneros, 37, opening a bottle of Blender's Pride whiskey. He poured the spirit into plastic cups, mixed in some orange juice, and declared to his guests: ''The United States is choosing a black man as its president. Maybe we can share a bit in this happiness.''

Senator Barack Obama won this swing state, which has seen rapid population growth, demographic shifts and a rapidly deflating real estate market. President Bush won the state in 2004. Dina Titus, a Democratic state senator and a political science professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, beat the incumbent three-term Republican, Jon Porter, in the Third Congressional District, where Democrats have come to outnumber Republicans since the last election.

COTTON--Sylvia , a champion of improved early childhood education and quality childcare and the founding President of Illinois Action for Children, died Friday, October 31, in New York. She was 95. A native New Yorker born in the City and educated in NYC public schools and Hunter College, she was the dear husband of Eugene, the beloved mother of two sons, Rick and Steve, and the doting grandmother of two grandchildren, Rachel and Jon. After working as a social worker in NYC and then moving with her husband to Washington, D.C. during the New Deal and World War II, she moved again with her family to Chicago in 1948. Cotton became a highly visible, passionate and outspoken advocate for children's causes in Chicago over a period of more than 50 years. In her early years in Chicago, she was a strong advocate of school desegregation and greater federal aid to education. She joined and became an officer (usually President) of every PTA in her area. Twice the Chicago Urban League recommended her as a candidate for the Chicago Board of Education. Then in 1970, she founded an organization, Illinois Action for Children, that has flourished and grown to become one of the leading voices on public policy decisions involving childrens issues in Illinois. Her leadership led to the creation of the Office of Child Care Services of the City of Chicago and to important City and State initiatives to upgrade the availability of quality childcare--accomplishments recognized by official proclamation of the Chicago City Council in 2003. Cotton acted following a 1968 study she did on childcare in Chicago that found an appalling lack of decent childcare alternatives for working parents. Years later Sylvia would say, ''I really was an angry woman. And I guess I put that anger to good use.'' She organized a wide variety of childcare advocates and institutions-Jewish and Catholic charities, settlement houses, PTA's-and wielded them into an effective political force. As she told one reporter, ''I stepped on people's toes because I was outspoken about what I thought were the weaknesses in various legislative programs. But I continued to press for things that needed to be done and programs that needed to be improved.'' Maria Whelan, current President of Illinois Action for Children, said, ''With a combination of moral outrage and hard work, Sylvia was able to create systems to support children and working families in Illinois. Her legacy reminds us of the challenges that lie ahead as we fight to give every child a strong start in life.'' Her achievements led Chicago Mayor Michael Bilandic to proclaim April 25, 1978 as Sylvia Cotton Day. In addition, her efforts were recognized by the Chicago YWCA (Community Leadership Award), by the Illinois Welfare Association (Public Service Citation) and by the Chicago City Council in 2003 which credited her activities with ''getting elected officials on the federal, state and local levels to understand the day care crisis... and update city ordinances and state statutes governing day care centers.'' On the occasion of Cotton's retirement from Illinois Action for Children, her husband of more than sixty-five years captured her spirit: ''She's one of the few people in the world who is constantly outraged by the outrageous. So many other people adjust to the evils in society. She is one of the few that, when she sees something that needs to be done, has the instantaneous desire to do something.'' She is survived by her husband Eugene, now retired, of New York City; two sons, Richard Cotton of New York City, and Stephen Cotton of Andover, Massachusetts and Anchorage, Alaska; daughter-in-law Rebecca Backman; former daughter-in-law Jamie Fellner; niece Judy Quittman; nephews Stuart Cotton, Richard and Robert Glickstein, and Daniel Steinbrocker; and the apples of her eye, two grandchildren, Rachel Cotton and Jon Cotton. A memorial service will be held in New York City on November 30 by family and friends who will treasure memories of a feisty, loving woman who always sought an ever more just and fair society for all.

For the second time in two years, Kentucky Republicans resisted the national wave of sentiment against their party, barely holding onto a Senate seat. This time, it was Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, who survived, narrowly winning a fifth term against Bruce Lunsford, a Democratic businessman. Two years ago, it was Senator Jim Bunning who edged out a Democratic challenger.

Few states rode Senator Barack Obama's coattails as much as Colorado. Hosts to the Democratic National Convention in August, Coloradoans continued their shift to the left thanks to the growing number of younger and Hispanic voters in the state. Senator Obama handily beat Senator John McCain to become the third Democratic presidential candidate to win the state since Harry S. Truman. Representative Mark Udall, a Democrat, won the Senate seat left vacant by the retirement of Wayne Allard, a Republican. Mr. Udall beat Bob Schaffer, a Republican, with 52 percent of the vote.

Though the outcome of the presidential race in Missouri teetered on a few thousand votes, voters decisively elected a Democrat to the governor's mansion. Jay Nixon, the state attorney general, who branded himself as an agent for change with calls to expand health care coverage and create high-tech jobs, won by double digits over Representative Kenny Hulshof, a Republican.

STAYING hydrated on the trail used to be straightforward: take a water bottle. But concern over bisphenol-A, or BPA, a chemical in hard-plastic bottles, has confused the issue. Although the Food and Drug Administration maintains that BPA poses no health threat, in April Canada banned its use in some bottles, pointing to growing evidence that the hormone mimicker leaches into food and drink and is linked to several medical conditions and diseases. Health-conscious athletes are choosing alternatives made from stainless steel, aluminum or BPA-free plastics. ''Last year at this time we couldn't pay anyone to take our stainless-steel bottles,'' said Sloan Russell, the president of Guyot Designs, in Deer Isle, Maine.

The presidential race may not have turned Montana, a state that strongly supported George W. Bush and gave Bill Clinton a lukewarm victory in 1992, into Democratic territory again. But even after the dust settled, Democrats could claim two significant victories. Brian Schweitzer was elected to a second term as governor over Roy Brown, a Republican state senator from Billings.

WEINSTEIN--I . Bernard. The Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health mourns the loss of our colleague, Bernard Weinstein, MD, DSci (Hon.), professor of Environmental Health Sciences. Dr. Weinstein is renowned for his work in cancer biology, prevention and treatment. He was head of the School's Division of Environmental Health Sciences from 1976-1991, and, under his leadership, the Division grew significantly in the area of environmental carcinogenesis and pioneered the field of molecular epidemiology. In addition to his outstanding research accomplishments, he was a mentor to many cancer researchers around the world. We extend our sincere sympathies to Dr. Weinstein's family. Linda P. Fried, MD, MPH, Dean Joseph H. Graziano, PhD, Professor and Interim Chair, Department of Environmental Health Sciences WEINSTEIN--I. Bernard. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Bernard Weinstein, whose commitment and generosity strengthened our ability to serve those in need in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO WEINSTEIN--I. Bernard. The Board of Directors and Staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the passing of our esteemed Trustee, I. Bernard Weinstein, a distinguished professor and cancer researcher who played a pivotal role as member of YIVO's National Board of Directors. His commitment to preserving and teaching the rich Yiddish culture and heritage of East European Jewry was exemplary. His creation in 1982, along with his late brother Laurence, of the Max and Frieda Weinstein Archive of Sound Recordings at YIVO, reflected his love of yidishkayt and a determination to share it with the world. He will be sorely missed. Deepest condolences to his wife Joan, and children Claudia,Tamara and Matthew. May his memory be for a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Exec Dir.

In the increasingly Republican Deep South, that party won the expected landslide victories in the races for president and Senate in Alabama, while Democrats found a rare bright spot by capturing a Republican-held House seat. Senator Jeff Sessions, a popular incumbent, was never seriously challenged in his bid for a third term. He won more than three-fifths of the vote against Vivian Figures, a Democratic state senator.

-- defeating a Democrat in a conservative-leaning Southern state -- looked to be harder than Senator Saxby Chambliss had anticipated. Mr. Chambliss, the Republican incumbent, appeared headed for a runoff in four weeks after he slipped to 49.8 percent -- just shy of the 50-percent margin required for victory under state law.

As chief of staff to Tom Daschle, a former Senate majority leader, Mr. Rouse was known as the 101st senator. Seldom in the spotlight, He maneuvers behind the scenes as a measured, discreet and skillful problem-solver with a knack for navigating bureaucracy.

Senator Susan Collins, a Republican, was elected to a third term, easily beating her Democratic challenger, Representative Tom Allen. Ms. Collins portrayed herself as a moderate with a long record of working on bipartisan legislation, an approach that made it difficult for Mr. Allen to link her to an unpopular President Bush.

The debate over a ballot measure to ban gay marriage overshadowed other contests, including the presidential race and battles for a handful of Congressional districts. The same-sex marriage ban passed with more than 52 percent of the vote.
MARTINE--Salvatore . The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Salvatore Martine, associated with The New York Times from October 8, 1977, 6 until retiring on December 1, 1992.

For a state that has always leaned Republican, South Dakota looked downright centrist this year, easily returning Democrats to the Senate and House, and giving John McCain less than half the winning margins George W. Bush had in 2000 and 2004. Senator Tim Johnson, a Democrat, barely won his seat in 2002, and four years later he suffered a stroke that took him out of action for months. He remains partly disabled, but he and his staff have labored hard to send the message to his constituents and the media that he is still mentally sharp and actively engaged in his job.

A six-year grudge match played out in the Granite State as Jeanne Shaheen, a former Democratic governor, defeated the Republican incumbent, John E. Sununu, in the race for the Senate. In general, New Hampshire's electoral results contained good news for Democrats.

Louisiana had backed the winner in every presidential election since 1972, but that string ended this year, with Senator John McCain carrying the state. Senator Mary L. Landrieu, the only Democratic senator who faced serious opposition this year, won a third term by defeating John Kennedy, a Republican who is the state treasurer.

LUBALIN--Irwin , 90 of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY on October 30, 2008. A man of great humor, joie de vivre and vitality. He was an executive with Avnet for over 50 years, an avid artist, sailor and golfer. He will be missed by his children James and Margaret, grandchildren Kendra Lubalin, and her wife Aimee, Max Cherpitel and his wife Alison, Scott Cherpitel, great-grandson Jesse Lubalin, his nieces, nephews and many friends. He was married for 50 loving years to the late Anne Bradley, and predeceased by his twin brother Herb and sister Bobby Arkin. Memorial Service Sunday November 16th 11am, Beth Abraham Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleeker St.

The bitterly contested Senate race between the Republican incumbent, Norm Coleman, and his Democratic challenger, Al Franken, the political humorist and former ''Saturday Night Live'' cast member, is not over yet. The number of votes separating them is so tiny -- Mr. Coleman leads by fewer than 500 out of nearly 2.9 million cast -- that the state rule for an automatic recount was set off. State officials say a recount will not begin until mid-November and could take weeks. Each ballot will be inspected manually.

His class in international relations was starting in 10 minutes, but Tang Tang was busy studying a map on a computer screen inside a cramped common room at the prestigious Tsinghua University. His major is international relations -- the Chinese equivalent of political science -- and his screen displayed the biggest political show in the world: the red-and-blue electoral jigsaw of the United States, with every state written in Chinese characters. Mr. Tang, 23, admitted that the American election had been a serious distraction during his Wednesday morning classes. Given the different time zones, the outcome was still uncertain. Yet now that he could assess the historic Obama victory, Mr. Tang's reaction seemed akin to that of a sports fan dissecting a box score and betrayed none of the hopeful idealism once conferred on Western-styled democracy by young Chinese intellectuals.

Democrats had hoped to win one of the two Senate seats up for grabs. Instead, Thad Cochran handily beat Erik Fleming to keep a Senate seat he took over after Trent Lott resigned. And Roger F. Wicker, an incumbent who led throughout the race, won by a smaller but still comfortable margin over Ronnie Musgrove, a former governor of the state. Mr. Wicker's defense of his seat helped deny the Democrats any chance of controlling the 60 seats in the Senate they would need to prevent a Republican filibuster. Every incumbent representative won re-election comfortably, including Bennie Thompson, a seven-term Democrat representing the Second District. Gregg Harper, a Republican, won the open seat in the Third District with 63 percent of the vote.

Senator Barack Obama may have been the toast of Europe since his visit this past summer, but a stop at the John F. Kennedy School here showed that he might not want to take that popularity for granted. Not if the students have anything to say. A YouTube clip of Mr. Obama's victory speech kicked off the postelection discussion at the public bilingual school on Wednesday, but the effort that Mr. Obama's American supporters found so inspired did not seem to sway the jaded teenagers, exposed to news of American wars in Afghanistan and Iraq and distrustful of his intense popularity here.

Senator Gordon H. Smith, a two-term Republican, was in a nip-and-tuck race with Jeff Merkley, a Democrat who is the speaker of Oregon's state house. With 79 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Smith had fallen behind Mr. Merkley by about 9,700 votes. Mr. Merkley has been counting on a statewide surge in voter registration among Democrats spurred by the campaign of Senator Barack Obama.

BERGER--Edwin , on November 3, 2008. Beloved brother of Horty Lippman. Loving uncle of Donna, Nita, Hugh, Robby and Susie. Founder and C.E.O. of Lambro Industries. Funeral Service at 1pm, Thursday at Gutterman's Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre.

One of the few bright spots for the national Republican Party was the Second District of Kansas, where the state's treasurer, Lynn Jenkins, ousted Representative Nancy Boyda, a freshman Democrat from Topeka. Ms. Jenkins said her credentials as a certified public accountant would help in the current economic crisis.

Senator Barack Obama sailed to victory in the nation's capital, where Democrats account for three-quarters of the registered voters. The city's delegate to Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat, easily won a 10th term. Mayor Adrian M. Fenty was an early supporter of Mr. Obama, endorsing him in July 2007. Mr. Fenty hopes Mr. Obama will follow through on his promise to help the city secure voting representation in Congress.

Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democratic, defeated his Republican challenger, Dick Zimmer, by more than a dozen percentage points to win a fifth term. Mr. Lautenberg raised twice as much money as Mr. Zimmer, a former congressman. Mr. Zimmer, 64, had hoped that voters might consider Mr. Lautenberg, 84, too old to be returned to the Senate for another six-year term.

As Senator Barack Obama took one state after another, there was the occasional cheer, the occasional grunt of disgust, but mostly the soldiers looked serious. Either candidate could change their lives; where they served; how long they lived away from home or in harm's way. ''What's going to happen to us?'' asked Specialist Katherine Roy, of the First Battalion, 22nd Infantry Regiment Forward Support Company, Fourth Infantry Division. ''We know we're not going to leave Iraq right away, but we don't want to go to Afghanistan. We just want to go home.''

Ann Nixon Cooper stayed up late to watch President-elect Barack Obama's victory speech from her home in Atlanta and went to bed smiling, friends said. On Wednesday, Ms. Cooper, who is 106, woke up famous. In what became the emotional climax of the speech, Mr. Obama linked Ms. Cooper's story to America's progress over the 20th century, saying that ''after 106 years in America, through the best of times and the darkest of hours, she knows how America can change.''

The Republican West Even strongly Republican states like Idaho and Utah took large steps toward the Democratic side. John McCain won Salt Lake County, Utah, but by just 2,000 votes. President Bush had carried it by 80,000 votes.

Being considered for: Co-chairwoman of the transition team, she may get a cabinet post, perhaps as secretary of housing or transportation, but more likely as a White House adviser. She has also been mentioned as a possible replacement for President-elect Barack Obama in the Senate. Would bring to the job: Experience in negotiation, persuasion and conflict resolution; a long record of outreach to African-Americans; fierce, almost familial loyalty to Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle.

Richard J. Durbin, the Democratic Party whip in the Senate, scored an easy victory over four challengers. Exit polls show that he excelled in pretty much every category: he carried the black and white votes, and he beat his closest challenger, Steve Sauerberg, a Republican, among voters of every age and income, except those who make more than $200,000 a year. Mr. Sauerberg, a physician from the western suburbs of Chicago, ran a largely self-financed campaign around classic Republican tenets of smaller government, lower taxes and a strong military. Mr. Durbin, meanwhile, embraced the government-as-safety-net approach, favoring, for example, subsidized health coverage for the uninsured.

Democrats picked up three seats in the House of Representatives that were previously held by Republicans, and for the first time in decades, they won a majority of the seats in the State Senate. In the 13th Congressional District, covering Staten Island and part of Brooklyn, City Councilman Michael McMahon defeated Robert Straniere, a former state assemblyman, for the seat currently held by Vito J. Fossella, a Republican. Mr. Fossella decided not to seek re-election after he was arrested this year and charged with drunken driving; he then acknowledged having an extramarital affair, which had produced a child.

Texas sent Senator John Cornyn, a Republican, back to Washington; his Democratic opponent, Rick Noriega, narrowed long-shot odds against Mr. Cornyn, a former state attorney general and first-term senator, but could not close the gap. Mr. Noriega, a two-term state representative from Houston who served a year in Afghanistan with the Texas Army National Guard and holds a master's degree from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, tried to portray Mr. Cornyn as a ''tax-and-borrow'' conservative out of touch with Texas families. Mr. Cornyn's careful campaign was heavy on iconic Texas imagery of horses in pastures.

Senator Barack Obama's sweeping get-out-the-vote effort in Ohio helped Democrats win two Congressional seats long held by Republicans, and seize control of the Ohio House for the first time since 1994. About twice as many Ohioans said, after voting, that they had been contacted by an Obama volunteer urging their vote as said they had been contacted by a McCain supporter. That advantage helped Mr. Obama win Ohio's electoral votes, which went to George W. Bush in 2000 and 2004.
Hedge funds’ sell-offs, it seems, are adding pressure to an already troubled stock market.
It can take up to 30 seconds to load a traditional muzzleloader, but some hunters appreciate the challenge of getting only one shot.
Charlie Haden’s Liberation Music Orchestra makes use of folk forms, marches and anthems, but it’s all rearranged, put through a prism, warped a little, forced into broader meanings.
“Whale Wars,” which has its premiere Friday on Animal Planet, follows a band of self-appointed warriors as they try to thwart Japanese whalers in the waters off Antarctica.

Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 junior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. He averaged 6.3 points per game for Bucknell last season and will be blogging for The Quad this season. Under the first-year coach Dave Paulsen, Bucknell will try to unseat American, which won the Patriot League's automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament last season. Behan will be stopping by The Quad all season for insights on Bucknell, the Patriot League and college life.

Myron Rolle, of Galloway, N.J., is a junior safety at Florida State and a semifinalist for the Bednarik Award, given to the top college defensive player. Along with starting for the Seminoles, Rolle graduated in two and a half years with a 3.75 grade-point average as a pre-med major. Last week, he found out that he was a finalist for a Rhodes Scholarship.
Forget about swapping party pictures on Facebook and other "gee-whiz stuff," says former Vice President Al Gore. "Web 2.0 has to have a purpose."

Byron Walden knows how to make a tough Saturday puzzle. I don't know how he does it, but it's not accomplished solely by relying on a database of known answer words. Today's crossword includes 22 answers never before seen in my database, and they're all solid. Well, DRUPE was new to me. Fleshy one-stone fruits like peaches, plums or cherries are drupes, apparently. Don't laugh, but DON'T LAUGH has been used before. I bet he thought that was original.

That's what I kept thinking as I watched Barack Obama's first post-election press conference as he confronted the economic crisis as president-elect rather than presidential candidate. There was certainly something calming about his crisp responses, his clear sense of competence, and his obvious confidence. He also had an easy banter with the press that went down easily. Franklin Roosevelt had all of those qualities. But Roosevelt was also a beacon of hope and inspiration during the dark days of the Depression, and that is what this country desperately needs now, as it tries to claw its way out of this awful recession and a financial crisis that is far from over.

There are 433 votes left to be counted in the Georgia Senate race. After complaints to the city Buildings Department, and concern from the Urkainian community in the East Village, Cooper Union removed a giant banner with a reproduction of a Picasso drawing of Joseph Stalin. That decision has outraged Lene Berg, the 43-year-old Norwegian artist who included the banner as part of her one-woman art installation, "Stalin by Picasso, or Portrait of Woman with Mustache," in the school's historic Foundation Building, on East Seventh Street."I didn't get any explanation of what happened," Ms. Berg, who is based in Berlin, said in a phone interview this week. She said Cooper Union officials removed the banner last Friday, five days after it went up, without consulting either her or Sara Reisman, associate dean of Cooper Union's School of Art and the curator of the exhibition.

A hanging light by the artist Jorge Pardo illuminates the cover of the new Design & Living issue of T, in more ways than one. The magazine examines the various ways in which art and design intersect, both in living with art and the art of living. We take a look at the tradition of artists hanging their work in restaurants; investigate the under-the-radar cool of Brussels; and visit an artist at home and at work in Beijing. The queen of all things sparkling, Nadja Swarovski, discusses her passions for fashion and design, while six artists, all women, offer a glimpse of how they live with art, their own and others'. An austere, light-filled house in upstate New York showcases a stellar collection of new Chinese paintings, and a portfolio of furniture designed by artists offers everything from a table with human legs to a fluorescent-tube chandelier.

This is one of those weekends that could turn the college football landscape on its head. What if Texas Tech AND Alabama were to lose? I know that's unlikely, but nothing's impossible in college football. Think about it for a second. Don't you kind of see this season as being one with a huge glut of one-loss teams combined with an undefeated Penn State waiting in the wings? And heaven help the Big Ten if an undefeated Penn State gets blown out by a one-loss Southeastern Conference or Big 12 team in the national title game. Can you imagine the outcry from the conference that was shut out of the game? Or from a one-loss U.S.C.? I know that I am getting ahead of myself here. There's lots of college football to be played, and we're all hoping that things are going to neatly play themselves out with two undefeated teams competing for the national title, but I'm getting the feeling that this season is going to be chaos, which is simultaneously frustrating as well as wildly entertaining. Of course, our president-elect seems to be in favor of a college football playoff, but I think he has some more pressing matters to attend to first. Anyway, settle in for a solid Saturday of college football and don't take it for granted. There aren't that many left this season.3:30 P.M., No. 1 Alabama at No. 16 L.S.U., CBSAnnouncers: Verne Lundquist, Gary Danielson, Tracy WolfsonAs long as Nick Saban is at Alabama, it is going to be a big story whenever he faces his former team. Saban won a national title with L.S.U. before bolting to the Dolphins. And if that weren't bad enough, Saban then jilted the Dolphins to take the job at Alabama, which is not only a conference rival of L.S.U.'s but also is in the same division. Last season, Saban's replacement, Les Miles, led the Tigers to a victory over Alabama on their way to a national title. This season, Saban takes the No. 1 team in the nation into what is sure to be a hostile environment in Baton Rouge against an L.S.U. team that could save its season with a victory over the Tide. Phew. This is going to be a good one. SEC football is like no other. What other conferences have these kinds of blood feuds?

Toward the end of the campaign, one of the challenges we set out to tackle was to somehow capture the mood of NYTimes.com users on Election Day. We knew that as soon as the polls closed, readers would be able to pore over interactive maps and graphics that provided real-time detailed results, but what they would do in the wee hours of the morning and late afternoon, before the results would be available? And what would they be thinking and feeling? Would they be anxious? Nervous? Hopeful? And how would those emotions change through the day, as the voting wound down and polls started closing?

William Eggleston's photographs are instantly familiar -- and will be even more so after today's opening of "William Eggleston: Democratic Camera, Photographs and Video, 1961-2008" at the Whitney Museum of American Art. But his videos are virtually unknown. These black-and-white shorts captured his nighttime ramblings in Memphis and New Orleans from 1973-74. Like his photographs, they are both mundane and devilishly transcendent -- well worth the crush. Best followed by a stiff bourbon and free potato chips at Bemelmans.

Who is responsible for water damage caused by a leaky P-trap on a bathtub? Under our proprietary lease, the shareholder is responsible only if the pipe is exposed. The pipe in question is enclosed between my floor and the ceiling of the apartment below. But my co-op board said that the language in the proprietary lease is clumsy and that the trap is not "exposed" only because of the way modern tubs are designed. Therefore, it says, the shareholder is responsible for this repair. The board also says it has consistently taken the stance that the vertical water and sewer riser pipes are the only plumbing it is responsible for and that the shareholder is responsible for everything else. Am I responsible for the leaky trap?

Citigroup is drawing up lists of employees in a division including investment banking who will be let go in another round of layoffs, Reuters reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.
