With the recent dismissals of Ty Willingham at Washington and Ron Prince at Kansas State, the number of African-American head coaches in the 119-school N.C.A.A. Football Bowl Subdivision was reduced to four, the lowest in 15 years, according to a study. In 1997, there were eight black head coaches, the most in history. In 1993, there were three. Fifty-five percent of all student athletes are minorities. The report by the Institute for Diversity and Ethics in Sport at the University of Central Florida polled every major college on the ethnicity of its coaches, athletic directors, presidents, faculty, student athletes and N.C.A.A. faculty representatives.

At first glance, it looked like any other major league tryout, but this one had a twist: the pitcher, Rinku Singh, had never picked up a baseball before May. And he is from India, better known for producing world-class cricketers than pitching aces. Singh and Dinesh Patel, both 19, pitched in front of some 30 major league scouts at a Tempe, Ariz., sports clinic. The tryout was among their rewards for winning an Indian reality TV show called “The Million Dollar Arm,” which drew more than 30,000 contestants.

Troy Matteson opened the Children’s Miracle Network Classic at Disney with an eagle on the Palm Course, ran off three straight birdies at the turn and wound up with a career-low round of nine-under 63 to take a one-shot lead Thursday in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Jimmy Walker, who needs a victory in the PGA Tour’s final tournament to avoid going back to Q-school, opened with a 64 and was one shot behind with Scott Verplank and Kevin Streelman, who are both well inside the top 125 on the money list, the cutoff for keeping a card. Erik Compton, who received his second heart transplant just six months ago, shot 70. ¶Henrik Stenson of Sweden made a 20-foot birdie putt on his final hole for a seven-under 65 and a one-stroke lead over the defending champion, Phil Mickelson; Sergio García; Anthony Kim; and Adam Scott in the HSBC Champions in Shanghai. Playing in rain, fog and smog, García could have carded a 65, too, but he missed a 4-foot eagle putt on the 18th. The putt came after his 235-yard, 5-wood shot landed just below the hole and rolled close. shanghai.

Venus Williams defeated her sister Serena by 5-7, 6-1, 6-0 to reach the semifinals of the WTA Tour’s season-ending Sony Ericsson Championships in Doha, Qatar, a match Serena Williams called her worst of the year. Venus Williams won on her fifth match point, and is 3-0 in round-robin play in a tournament that features the top eight players. Serena Williams dropped to 1-1 but can still advance to the semifinals if she defeats Elena Dementieva on Friday. The Williams sisters are 9-9 in career matchups.

In three short days, the Florida-based Offshore Sailing School can make even the queasiest landlubber seaworthy, more or less. The school, Mike Grudowski writes in the latest issue of Play, is “a highly caffeinated blend of alarm and exhilaration, humiliation and triumph, bewilderment and bliss, often delivered within the same minute.” It takes several hours of fairly intensive daily classroom time and plenty of training on the water to learn nautical jargon and the nuance of tacking and jibbing. But in the end, even the driest landlubbers become seaworthy.

But she didn’t know she’d be tapping into such a deep vein of fascination — for several days, even amid the crush of election coverage, her column from this month’s Play Magazine (“Stretching: The Truth”) remained No. 1 on the Times’s most e-mailed list. Here, Reynolds talks about the widespread interest in this topic:.

For the current issue of Play Andrew Meier traveled to Russia to report on that country’s rising sports ambitions, which he chronicled in his article “Score Another One for Putin.” Today in Slap Shot, The Times’s hockey blog, Meier elaborates on what he saw there. Check out his insights, though it may pay to heed his warning: “When it comes to Russia, trying to predict the future is a foolhardy pursuit. In that country, as Russians like to say, the past is unpredictable enough.”.

The State Supreme Court ruled that a state law requiring sex offenders to register with law enforcement agencies and appear on a public list violated the constitutional guarantee of equal protection because it treats juvenile offenders more harshly than adults. The decision dealt with a Butte County case in which a boy admitted that he committed two counts of first-degree rape when he was 15. A judge ordered that the boy be placed in custody and register as a sex offender. Adult offenders sometimes get a suspended imposition of sentence, meaning a conviction is in essence wiped out if the person completes probation and the offender may then be able to have his name removed from the sex-offender registry. The boy’s lawyers argued that the law is unconstitutional because juveniles cannot get a suspended imposition of sentence. The ruling means it is possible all juvenile sex offenders will have to be removed from the sex-offender registry, Attorney General Larry Long said.
The plans to drill for oil in Utah is the latest of President Bush’s last-minute assaults on the environment.

A federal judge said he did not have jurisdiction to decide whether an Egyptian-born Muslim scientist was wrongly denied a security clearance but is still considering whether the man’s due process rights were violated. The American Civil Liberties Union, which sued on behalf of the man, Abdel Moniem Ali el-Ganayni, contends that Dr. Ganayni was wrongly fired from his job in May at a nuclear warship parts plant because he spoke out against American foreign policy and the alleged mistreatment of Muslims by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In an opinion issued Oct. 31, the judge, Terrence McVerry of Federal District Court, agreed with the government that he did not have the jurisdiction to second-guess the Department of Energy’s decision to deny Dr. Ganayni his security clearance. But Judge McVerry left open the possibility that the Energy Department had violated its own procedures.

The Kentucky attorney general, Jack Conway, has proposed a settlement aimed at ending a squabble with an Ohio city over a rock. The historic rock bears numerous carvings of initials, names and a crude face and was once an attraction for locals. It had been submerged since about the 1920s until last September, when a local historian led a team to extract it. The boulder now sits in a city garage in Portsmouth, Ohio. Mr. Conway sent a letter to the city solicitor in Portsmouth proposing that the eight-ton boulder be returned to Kentucky and put on display. He wants the City of Portsmouth to pay a total of $90,000 for legal fees and the cost of building a display facility on the Kentucky side of the Ohio River. Portsmouth officials did not immediately return calls from The Associated Press.

A wintry blast of punishing wind and close to four feet of snow in places pummeled the Northern Plains, stranding unknown numbers of motorists for a day or more and knocking out power to thousands. “This is a dangerous storm,” Gov. Michael Rounds said. “Western South Dakota is basically under a no-travel advisory.” A long stretch of Interstate 90 was closed, and dozens of vehicles along the stretch have been stranded for more than 24 hours, Mr. Rounds said. He added that search teams could not get to them because of zero visibility. “We cannot see a thing in many areas where we’re out actually searching for people,” said Tom Dravland, state public safety secretary, who added that the top speed for some rescue crews was as low as a half-mile per hour. Mr. Dravland said he did not know how many people were stranded. The Highway Patrol has responded to more than 400 calls for assistance, including 10 crashes. No fatalities were reported. The storm also closed Interstate 80 in eastern Wyoming and western Nebraska.

A former agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, John Connolly, was convicted of second-degree murder for leaking information to Boston mobsters that led to the 1982 shooting death of a gambling executive who also had ties to gangsters. Jurors deliberated less than three days before delivering the verdict after a two-month trial. The jury acquitted Mr. Connolly of conspiracy, but he still faces life in prison when sentenced Dec. 4. Prosecutors said the victim, John Callahan, the former World Jai-Alai president, was killed after Mr. Connolly warned gangsters that Mr. Callahan might implicate them in other slayings. James Bulger, known as Whitey, and Stephen Flemmi, Boston mafia kingpins, were federal informants handled by Mr. Connolly. Mr. Connolly long denied involvement in the killing of Mr. Callahan, whose body was found at the Miami airport.
The Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. warned that the success of Barack Obama “shouldn’t lull us to sleep” in the effort to combat racism and poverty.

Dry pet food contaminated by salmonella sickened at least 79 people, including many children, and could still be dangerous, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. No one is known to have died in the outbreak of a rare strain of salmonella, known as Salmonella enterica serotype Schwarzengrund, the C.D.C. said. But people can become ill, with bloody diarrhea, if they handle the pet food, especially the very young and very old. No pets have been reported sickened. Even though the affected brands have been recalled and the factory in Pennsylvania closed, pet owners could still have the cat and dog kibble in their homes. The brands, made by Mars Petcare U.S., include Special Kitty, Pedigree and Member’s Mark, among others. The full list of brands affected is available on petcare.mars.com.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger called for a sharp increase in the state’s sales tax, as well as new taxes on oil drilling and alcoholic drinks to help pay for a budget shortfall of billions of dollars. The governor, speaking during a special session to deal with the unraveling of the state budget, which was passed just last month, also said to expect deep cuts to education and other services to address what he said would be a shortfall of more than $24 billion by the middle of 2010. Central to his plan would be a sales tax increase of 1 1/2 cents from its current rate of 7.25 percent on the dollar to raise $10.8 billion. Republicans in the state have firmly opposed any tax increases.

An 8-year-old Indiana boy was left at an Omaha hospital, bringing to 28 the number of children left under Nebraska’s unique safe-haven law. Todd Landry with the Department of Health and Human Services Division of Children and Family Services said the boy from Wabash County was left by his mother late in the morning at Bergan Mercy Medical Center. It is believed the boy’s mother drove him to Omaha from Indiana, a spokeswoman for the department said. The boy is the fourth from out of state. They have since have been returned to their home states. Nebraska’s law says anyone can leave a child at a hospital without fear of prosecution for the abandonment. The law uses the word “child” and does not include any age limit. Gov. Dave Heineman has called a special legislative session to fix the law. It begins Nov. 14.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column last Friday about the return of a Fernand Léger painting from the Minneapolis Institute of Arts to the heirs of a French collector after the institute concluded that it had been stolen by the Nazis referred imprecisely to the timing of the theft. The Nazis, who invaded France in 1940, seized the inventory of the collector, Alphonse Kann, after he fled to London in 1938, not when he fled to London.

The Havens column last Friday about Ashfield, Mass., misstated the origins of the name of the Norton Anthology series. The anthologies are named for the series’ publishing house, W. W. Norton — not for the Harvard professor Charles Eliot Norton, who was a part-time resident of Ashfield in the 19th century. The column also misidentified Professor Norton’s specialized field of study. Although he was a devoted scholar of both literature and art, he was a professor of art history, not of literature.

WEINSTEIN--I. Bernard, M.D. , D.Sci (Hon.) We are deeply saddened by the passing of our colleague and friend Dr. I. Bernard Weinstein. The director emeritus of the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center at Columbia University Medical Center and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and the Frode Jensen Professor of Medicine, professor of genetics and development at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and professor of environmental health sciences at Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health, Dr. Weinstein was a world authority on the prevention and treatment of cancer. A founder of the field of molecular epidemiology, he contributed important insights into how genetic, environmental and dietary factors cause cancer. He helped initiate the study of environmental science at Columbia. Under his leadership, the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center developed world-class programs in basic science research, clinical research and cancer prevention. A brilliant scientist, mentor, and deeply caring human being, Dr. Weinstein will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the entire Weinstein family. Lee Goldman, M.D., Executive Vice President, Health & Biomedical Sciences, Columbia University Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

KAFKA-KOHLHAGEN--Joi Meredith . Beloved wife of Robert Joel, daughter of Malcolm Edmond Kafka and Suzanne Leah Ullman Kafka. Passed in her sleep in the arms of the Lord November 2, 2008, North Babylon, LI. Born June 16, 1970 The Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Sister of Scott Laurance Kafka, niece of Stephen David Kafka, granddaughter of the late M. Martyn Kafka M.D., former flight surgeon U.S. Army Air Corps WWII, Irma May Levy Kafka, Jerome Ullman and Hannah Ullman. Joi Meredith was educated at the New York City Public School System, Fresh Meadows, Queens including Martin Van Buren High School and continued at New York University graduating with concentration in Literature and Journalism and continued for her Law Degree at Hofstra University. She avidly contributed her writings to newspapers committed to issues especially affecting Youth, school newspapers and received awards for her poetry. At the time of her passing, her husband was compiling her writings for potential publication. Services at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. were conducted on November 3 with exquisite sensitivity and compassion by Rabbi Dr. H. Norman Strickman, Marine Park Jewish Center, Brooklyn. Further services were coordinated with precision and utmost care by licensed Funeral Director Nicholas P. Rudowicz, Park Avenue Funeral Home, Brooklyn whose professionalism contributed substantially to easing the family's burden. Among family, friends, colleagues in attendance was Suffolk County Assemblyman Andrew P. Raia and Staff. His thoughtful, articulate and appreciative sentiment not only extolled Joi Meredith's commitment to the motivated contributions of his office to the constituency of Suffolk County for several years, and as well expressed Joi Meredith's virtues as a caring and capable person. The music of her voice will continue to reverberate symphonically. Be at peace darling daughter. Your loving father forever.

MONTANA--Dr. John B . AIDS specialist/Gay Activist, dies at 61. John Buscemi Montana, M.D., gay man, physician, generous humanitarian, New Yorker, world traveler and art aficionado, died at Mt. Sinai Hospital early Monday morning, September 29, 2008. The cause of death was acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), diagnosed less than one year ago. Dr. Montana was one of the first NYC physicians to identify and treat people with AIDS at the outset of the epidemic in 1981. He saw many cases among his friends and the gay men who comprised a large portion of his internal medicine practice on lower Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village. Dr. Montana, the son of Vanni Buscemi Montana and Helen Bortnovski Montana, was born in Huntington, Long Island, NY on March 13, 1947. His parents met in Europe during World War II. John's father was politically active in anti-fascist and socialist causes in his native Sicily; he died in 1991. John's own politics reflected his father's leftist leanings. His mother Helene perished in an apartment fire in February, 2003. A product of New York City public schools, Dr. Montana graduated from Harpur College (SUNY Binghamton) in 1969 where he majored in Science and Mathematics. He taught junior high school in Newark, New Jersey for two years before attending medical school. Dr. Montana graduated New York Medical College, Valhalla in 1975. After working at Cabrini-Stuyvesant Polyclinic, he opened his internal medicine practice in 1984. He was an attending physician at Cabrini Medical Center until it closed. Then he attended at St. Vincent's Hospital. Dr. Montana's illness caused him to close his medical practice in mid-December, 2007. The AIDS epidemic motivated him to focus his practice on treating AIDS-related opportunistic infections and cancers--which signaled fatality in less than two years at the beginning of the epidemic. His beloved partner, Jimmie Jackson, died from AIDS early on, and his death both devastated and deeply politicized John to continue the fight against AIDS. A firm proponent of safer-sex, Dr. Montana advised the Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC) on medical issues from its inception. He lectured on AIDS to community and professional groups throughout the city and was politically involved in ACT-UP and other AIDS-related organizations. John gave generously of his time and money to many gay community organizations including Senior Action in a Gay Environment (SAGE) and the Callen-Lorde Community Health Center. Until the end of his life, he maintained his conviction that the right-wing-dominated, federal government covertly propagated the epidemic, if not intentionally, then by intentional negligence--the ultimate goal being the elimination of the gay community. A gay-civil-rights activist and life-long Democrat, he was horrified at the response of the Reagan and Bush presidencies to AIDS and gay rights issues in general. He became inconsolable when his long-term partner, Daniel C., was deported from this country in 1999. Being bi-lingual, John was a benefactor to many in New York's Latino communities, and especially to Daniel's family. Dr. Montana often visited South America where he was a benefactor to small villages helping poor people at local medical clinics. Dr. Montana was a patron of the arts whether for museum-sponsored projects or for individual, fledgling, gay artists including E. J. Weiss, Ferron Bell and William Schwedler. He especially appreciated the works of Charles Demuth. John loved New York City, but enjoyed traveling throughout Europe and South America. John had many patients and friends in diplomatic positions who hosted him in Brazil, Italy, France, and Spain. Recently he traveled to Turkey, and only two weeks before his death, he returned from a cruise to Venice and Greece with two friends who made his trip as comfortable as possible. He fell critically ill upon his return. John Montana is survived by his brother Victor and his nephew John, both of New Hampshire. He is deeply mourned by his cousins Vicki De Bruin-Tarlow, Carol Daniels, Jesse Kamras, and also by his close friends John Helmuth, Ron Illardo, Philip Kayal, Jim D'Eramo, Patrick Hacker, Joe Nicholson and Angel, who with others, nursed him daily near the end. He is also mourned by his extended family in Finland and Israel, and by his friends throughout the world, but most particularly by the New York City gay community that he shepherded courageously through the AIDS epidemic--Dr. John Montana was an AIDS hero. Dr. Montana's Memorial Service will be Sunday, November 23 at 3:30pm in the Auditorium (10th Floor) of St. Vincents Hospital, 170 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Family and friends are welcome. Any questions should be directed to Philip Kayal: pkayal@comcast.net.

CRYSTAL--Bernhardt , an accomplished artist, and gallery owner passed away on September 21, 2008 in New York City. Mr. Crystal was born on November 7, 1914 in Grand Rapids, Michigan. A self educated man, Bern, was blessed with a talent for turning his observations and opinions into imaginative sketches and drawings. While recuperating in a Scottish army hospital during World War II, he met Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, who asked Berns to sketch a portrait of him. ''Ike'' loved it, and encouraged Berns to use his talent in the war effort, which he did by creating powerful and humorous posters for war bonds. Eisenhower then sent him to D-Day at Omaha Beach as a combat artist, to interpret the war artistically. There were a handful of soldiers who came ashore that day with a rifle, a pistol, a pad and a pen. After the war, Bern opened the Washington Irving Gallery, in New York City, which collected and sold the work of fellow veteran combat artists, and an international body of artisans, representing such artists as Jack Levine, Alex Minewski, Marvin Cherney, George Luks, Jules Pascin, Ernest Fiene and a young artist named Zero Mostel. For over 50 years, the gallery was his home, and Sundays were spent holding court with many of the top artists, writers, and actors of the time, including James Cagney and Vincent Price. In 1996 he worked for Disney Animation, inventing unique animal characters for future projects, and a few years ago created a line of animated Greeting cards called ''The Fuzzees'' for the Target company. A most charismatic and funny man, who played Santa Claus in, ''When Harry Met Sally'', Berns made it his personal mission to make the Crystal family laugh with jokes, costumes, masks and songs. Billy Crystal, his nephew, recalls, ''He was a magical man to all of us, and always will be. He was a big reason I became a performer.'' Mr. Crystal was the subject of the HBO Documentary, ''My Uncle Berns'' which was inspired by the events of September 11th. It captured his life from boyhood to DDay to the tragedy of the World Trade Center. Berns and his wife Deborah had been living at The Hallmark, a senior residence, just one block away from the Towers. They were evacuated, inspiring his great niece, Lindsay Crystal to direct the award winning film, which was an official selection of the Tribeca Film Festival. Mr. Crystal is survived by his wife, Deborah, his daughter Dorothy Crystal Ross, nephews, Joel, Richard and Billy, loving nieces, Barbara, Fran and Janice, grandnieces, Jenny, Faithe, Lindsay, and Jackie, a grandnephew Jon, and greatgrandnieces, Holly, Ella, Laura, Dylan and a great-grandnephew, Shane.

Proud grandfather of Homer Parkes, Haley Parkes, Sophie Whitney, August Whitney, Eleanor Duke and William Angier Duke. A private family memorial will be held at a later date.

WITH the property market in turmoil, especially in the United States, real estate agents around the country are increasing their efforts to woo the Russian oligarchs, Korean industrialists and other international buyers who have been making news with splashy top-dollar purchases. ''They are the most aggressive buyers in the market right now,'' said Kevin McBride, an agent with Atlanta Fine Homes Sotheby's International in Atlanta. In international hubs like Atlanta, overseas clients now account for anywhere from 10 to 30 percent of sales, industry experts say.
